Corrective Action Plans that are submitted in a timely manner;
Coordinating with G.M. Safety, Quality & Standardization for ensuring that Follow-Up
Evaluations are performed to monitor Corrective Action Plans;
Responding to trends or Concerns identified in Internal Audits;
Responding to independent solutions developed during Special Evaluations;
Maintaining an active awareness of the (QAP) plans and results;
Ensuring Communication and supporting the company's commitment to safety, quality and
security to all employees through company bulletins, emails, newsletters and meetings;
Encouraging employees' participation by personally recognizing and commending the
outstanding performance;
Determining, providing and maintaining the physical infrastructure and work environment,
equipment and supporting services needed to achieve conformity with management system,
safety, security and operational requirements;
Ensuring that positions within the organization including management and non-
management that affect safety and security of operations are filled with competent personnel
having appropriate levels of knowledge, experience, qualifications, and skills to carry out
required duties and responsibilities (according to their job descriptions);
Ensuring that relevant training is established, maintained and effectively implemented for
operational personnel to promote operational competency within their respective areas in
compliance with the company policies, international standards and civil aviation regulations;
Ensuring that procedures are in place within the company to effectively identify and meet
training needs of operational staff including the internal auditors;
Ensuring that an effective system is in place within the company which maintains current
record of staff training, certification, and licensing;

The establishment and documentation of procedures that is applicable to the requirements of
their respective organization concerning the selection and dealing with the products suppliers
and services providers that is affecting the safety, quality and security of the operations. The
aim of these procedures is to ensure that the services and product purchased or contracted
conform to both, EGYPTAIR and regulatory requirements;
Ensure a contract or agreement is executed with external service providers that conduct
outsourced operations, maintenance or security functions for EGYPTAIR. Such contract or
agreement shall include or reference to measurable specifications (SLA) that can be
monitored by EGYPTAIR to ensure requirements that affect the safety, quality and security of
operations are being fulfilled. The procedures include operational routine audits as one mean
of achieving effective management of safety and quality of outsourced functions / contracted
services;
Ensuring that the management and other personnel who perform functions relevant to the
safety or security of aircraft who are required to maintain competency and /or technical
proficiency (such as pilots and cabin crew...etc.), are assigned with responsibilities and
activities that are reasonably accomplished;
Ensuring that all concerned operational personnel are in compliance with the organizational
procedures, corporate policies, regulations and laws of the states, regarding the operations
which are conducted;
Ensuring a delegation of authority and assignment of responsibility within the management
system for liaison with regulatory authorities, original equipment manufacturers and other
operationally relevant external entities and identify managers with authority for liaison with
external entities in all operational areas;
Delegating authority and assigning responsibility within the flight operations management
system for maintaining and ensuring compliance with the AOC, national, international
standards, regulations and company policies.
NOTE Whenever the CEO is unable to carry out his duties, they shall be transferred to his
assistant (or an assigned person using the formal delegation process) to ensure
managerial continuity.
1.3.2 Flight Operations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
1.3.2.1 Vice President Flight Operations Sector

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
He is directly responsible to the CEO for all phases of flight operations;
Flight operations are conducted in accordance with the conditions and restrictions of the Air
Operator Certificate (AOC) and in compliance with applicable regulations and EGYPTAIR
Standards;
He is accountable to the CEO for ensuring safety, quality and security in all flight operations
and operational control;
The V.P. Flight Operations is an active line Pilot with the status of a Commander. He is
appointed by and reports to the Accountable Manager;
He is responsible for the implementation of the EGYPTAIR Policy within flight operations;
ORGANIZATION AND RESPONSIBILITIES
1.3 Ops Mgmt. Accountabilities, Responsibilities, Authorities
OM A
1-3-4

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
He will have overall responsibility for the flight operations Safety and Quality Management
System, including the frequency, format and structure of the internal management evaluation
activities;
He is responsible for ensuring the functionality of the Safety and Quality Management System
within the Flight Operations Department;
He is responsible to attend to Emergency Management Center as an emergency Director
once he has received an alert notification from the duty manager declaring emergency,
otherwise he may assign his emergency duties to GM IOCC, his representative and/or ERP
manager in case he is unable to attend, then follow up the situation until his attendance.
Duties and Responsibilities of the Post

Supervises all departments within the Flight Operations Sector;
Ensures the keeping of records of the flight operations sector personnel in accordance with
what is prescribed by the law, as well as, by the organization’s regulations and manuals;
Ensures high levels of performance and efficiency with regards to the sector’s activities;
Coordinates with the Safety, Quality and Standardization Manager and with heads of the
other departments, for implementing the Safety Management System, economy and
efficiency;
Development of special policies for the flight operations sector aiming at the improvement of
staff efficiency and their training;
Taking final decisions concerning the staff of the flight operations sector;
Participation in the drawing up of the general policy of the organization;
Participation with the relevant sections of the organization for the presentation of technical
studies on the new types and models to be introduced to the organization’s fleet;
Participation in the High Committee for Training, at the organization;
Participation in laying down plans for the operation of the organization’s aircraft, and giving
opinions thereon on the basis and needs as well as of the abilities of the pilotage teams;
Develops procedures for take-off and landing so as to avoid unfavourable weather conditions;
Participation in the Specialized Committees of the Arab International Association for Air
Transport and of the IATA;
Authorizes all amendments to the Operations Manual so as to ensure the safety and security
of flight operations;
Follow-up on the implementation (by the G.M. Flight Operations) of the scheduling of flights
for the organization’s aircraft, and investigation of the most appropriate aviation routes, and

1.4 AUTHORITY, DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE COMMANDER

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The Commander exercises the final authority in relation to the operation of the aircraft. He is
responsible for its safety, as well as, that of the passengers, crew and cargo. Therefore, he must
take all measures required for safety during all phases of flight.

The Commander’s responsibility for the safety and security of the aircraft, its occupants and cargo
begins from the time he arrives at the aircraft and ends when he hands over the aircraft to the
authorized ground personnel or the next Flight Deck Crew taking charge or when the aircraft is
parked and locked.

In addition, the Commander is responsible for the operation of the aircraft from the moment the
aircraft is ready to move for the purpose of taking off until the moment it finally comes to rest at
the end of the flight and the engines are shut down.

The Commander shall:

Be responsible for the safety and security of the aircraft and all persons on board;
Have authority to give all operationally required commands, he deems necessary, for the
purpose of securing the safety of the aircraft and of persons or property carried therein. All
persons carried on the aircraft shall obey such commands;
Have authority to disembark any person, baggage or any part of the cargo, which in his
opinion, may represent a potential hazard to the safety of the aircraft or its occupants;
When he has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has committed, or is about to
commit, on board the aeroplane, an offence against penal law or an act jeopardizing the
safety of the aeroplane, persons or property on board, or any other act endangering good
order, impose upon such person reasonable measures, including restraints, which are
necessary to protect safety and maintain good order or to enable him to deliver such person
to competent authorities or to disembark him;
Not permit any person to be carried onboard the aircraft who appears to be under the
influence of alcohol or drugs to the extent that the safety of the aircraft or its occupants is
likely to be endangered;
Have the right to refuse transportation of inadmissible passengers, deportees or persons in
custody if their carriage poses any risk to the safety of the aircraft or its occupants;
Ensure that all operational procedures and checklists are carried out in accordance with the
OM Part B. In an emergency situation that requires immediate decision and action, he shall
take any action he considers necessary. In such cases, he may deviate from rules, operational
procedures and methods in the interest of safety;
Sets priorities; his decisions shall give absolute precedence to safety and due regard to
economy, passenger comfort and adherence to schedule;
Ensure that all passengers are briefed on the location of emergency exits and the location and
use of relevant safety and emergency equipment;
Not permit any Crew Member to perform any activity during take-off, initial climb, final
approach and landing except those duties required for the safe operation of the aircraft;
Ensure that, during a particular flight, the entire crew adheres to duty and rest time limitations
as given in Chapter 7 Flight Time Limitations ;
Not permit the flight data recorders (FDR, CVR, DLR) to be intentionally disabled, switched off,
or erased during flight nor permit recorded data to be erased after flight;
ORGANIZATION AND RESPONSIBILITIES
1.4 Authority, Duties and Responsibilities of the Commander
OM A
1-4-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Other than his overall responsibility, he is authorized to delegate tasks to his crew and to
other suitable personnel. It is his duty to co-ordinate, supervise and check the tasks of his
crew. He encourages teamwork and ensures that his Crew Members receive all information
essential for the performance of their tasks;
Coordinates the performance of flight deck related tasks and duties and decides on who acts
as Pilot Flying (PF);
In order to promote the aeronautical experience and knowledge of his First Officer, the
Commander shall give him the opportunity to plan and conduct the flight, or portions
thereof, under his supervision;
Commander shall not permit his First Officer to conduct a take-off and/or landing unless the
following conditions exist:
Runway braking action is RWYCC 5 or good;
Surface crosswind component does not exceed 15 kts;
Visibility/RVR is more than 1.000 m;
Airport category is A or B;
Any related operational restrictions require the Captain to be Pilot Flying; and
No VIP on-board.
NOTE The above limits do not apply when an instructor is the Commander and the First
Officer is a trainee conducting the flight under his supervision.
NOTE If a First Officer is permitted to conduct a take-off and/or landing and other adverse
weather or abnormal conditions are encountered, e.g. turbulence, equipment
serviceability, etc., the Commander should carefully consider whether or not to permit
the F/O to continue as PF.
At no time, permitting a First Officer to conduct a take-off and/or landing shall detract from the
overall responsibility of the Commander for the safe conduct of the flight. Thus, the Commander
shall perform take-offs, approaches, landings or other phases of flight he considers critical, himself.

1.4.2 Prior to Flight

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The Commander shall strictly observe and meet the requirements of Chapter 5 Qualification
Requirements in general and the provisions concerning route and aerodrome competence
qualifications in particular.

He shall obtain and check all available aeronautical and meteorological information pertinent to
his next flight including NOTAMs, SNOWTAMs, ASHTAMs, runway conditions, temperature/
pressure reports, upper wind and aerodrome meteorological forecasts.

This information will enable the Commander to:

Judge if the weather and the visibility/RVR at the aerodrome and the condition of the
runway intended to be used will allow for a safe take-off and departure (with regards to all
relevant performance aspects of the OM Part A and OM Part B);
Select destination alternate and take-off alternate aerodromes prior to flight, with regards
to the prescribed planning minima;
Crosscheck the operational flight plan, and calculate the planned amount of fuel and oil
being based on the expected operating conditions is sufficient for a safe completion of the
flight (whenever the flight plan is being calculated by third parties, it is his responsibility to
ensure that these requirements are met), and when departing from base has duly signed the
Dispatch Release Form;
If not already performed by ground personnel, submit the appropriate ATS unit with a flight
plan or sufficient information for the initiation of search and rescue (SAR) action, should the
flight become overdue;
Shall conduct a Cabin Crew briefing, latest upon reaching the aircraft with regards to the
information and particulars pertinent to the individual flight which will include the following:
Trip time, cruising altitude, weather en-route with possible turbulence encounters, weather
at destination with expected temperature and any defective items that affect cabin and
passengers. He also has to provide an agreed signal when he deems necessary for Cabin
Crew to discontinue service and have their seats due to the risk caused by heavy turbulence;
Shall ensure that the pre-flight inspection has been carried out, and decide whether or not
to accept the aircraft unserviceable items allowed by the CDL and MEL;
Ensures that one member of the Flight Deck Crew performs an exterior inspection of the
aeroplane prior to each flight. The inspections shall include:
Pitot static ports;
Locked or disabled flight controls;
Presence of frost, snow or ice on critical surfaces; and;
Aircraft structural integrity, e.g. damage.
When preparing for a flight, the Commander shall not release the aircraft unless he is satisfied that:

The aircraft is airworthy;
The aircraft configuration is in accordance with the CDL;

abnormal or emergency procedures and simulation of IMC by artificial means are not
simulated during flight, see Chapter 14.3.39 Simulated Abnormal Situations in-flight ;
Observation and evaluation of the development of the meteorological situation, specifically
forecasts for the route to be flown, for en-route alternates and for the destination
aerodrome and its alternate(s);
The flight is not continued to the destination, unless the latest information available
indicates that, at the expected time of arrival, the weather conditions at the destination, or
at least one destination aerodrome, are at or above the applicable aerodrome operating
minima;
In an emergency situation, immediate action is taken to keep the passengers and the aero-
plane from personal damage or danger. In such cases, it is permissible to deviate from rules
and procedures in the interest of safety;
Procedures and equipment limitations regarding flight in icing conditions are strictly
adhered to, as ice build-up, especially in a suddenly deteriorating situation, may have rapid
adverse effect on the aeroplane performance and controllability;
When the limit values for cosmic radiation are exceeded, descent is initiated as soon as
practicable;
The amount of usable fuel remaining suffices to proceed to an aerodrome, where a safe
landing can be made, with the final reserve fuel remaining;
Whenever the cabin altitude exceeds 10.000 ft for a period in excess of 30 minutes and
whenever the cabin altitude exceeds 13.000 ft all Flight Deck Crew Members use
supplemental oxygen;
The applicable provisions for re-planning the flight are met;
Timely corrective action(s), whenever system malfunctions or other variables impair the
aero-plane’s operation;
In case of such impairment, his crew and relevant ground personnel are kept informed
about the situation and his decisions;
By keeping close contact with his Cabin Crew, a polite and efficient passenger service is
being provided;
All requirements concerning cabin safety are being observed and, in particular, that all
provisions to be met "prior to taxiing" are also fulfilled prior to landing;
When leaving cruising level for descent, a landing distance assessment is carried out to
ensure that the landing distance requirements can be met, taking into account runway
condition and aircraft configuration, and the MSA has been identified;

1.5 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE FIRST OFFICER

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The First Officer is the Commander’s deputy. He shall assume the role of Pilot Flying when so
directed by the Commander. If the Commander becomes incapacitated the First Officer assumes
the Commander’s authority and the responsibility for the aeroplane and its crew, its passengers
and load, see Chapter 4.3 Succession of Command In Case of Commander Incapacitation.
Therefore, it is his duty to participate responsibly in the preparation of the flight and to attentively
monitor its progress in order to be able to assume this authority/ responsibility at any given
moment.

He cooperates, in a responsible manner, as a member of the aeroplane’s crew, and meticulously
performs the work routinely assigned to him or delegated to him by the Commander.

It is his duty to:

Report to the Commander any fault, failure, malfunction or defect, which he believes may
affect the airworthiness or safe operation of the aeroplane or aeroplane systems;
Report to the Commander any incident that has endangered, or may have endangered
safety;
Make use of the company’s incident reporting scheme in accordance with Chapter 11
Handling, Notifying and Reporting Occurrences.
1.5.1 Prior to Flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The First Officer shall meet the qualification requirements of Chapter 5.2.1 Flight Deck Crew
Qualification Requirements. If the conduct of the flight or part thereof is to be delegated to him
by the Commander, he must meet the requirements of Chapter 5.2.1.5 Route and Aerodrome
Competence Qualification.

He participates in the Commander’s crew briefing, and avails himself of all relevant aeronautical
(NOTAMs etc.) and meteorological information including forecasts and runway condition reports,
as well as relevant papers documenting the aeroplane’s technical status and its anticipated load.

By delegation from the Commander, the First Officer will usually:

Calculate the take-off data, the OFP and file the corresponding ATS flight plan (whenever
those tasks have been delegated to others, he shall crosscheck these documents before
handing them over to the Commander for signature);
Check that the prescribed manuals, maps, charts, documents and forms are on board and
cover the aeroplane’s intended operation until returning to home base;
Check the radio and navigation equipment for proper functioning;
Ascertain that fuel on board and fuels assumed for take-off data calculation are identical,
and equal to or higher than the minimum fuel specified on the OFP;
At stations without qualified personnel, he should check use of the correct fuel type, and
supervise the fuelling/defuelling of the aeroplane and ensure proper distribution of fuel.

1.5.2 In-flight

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The First Officer, as directed by the Commander, executes the tasks and functions of either the PF
or PM. He shall not perform any activities during critical phases of flight other than those required
for the safe operation of the aeroplane. He assists the Commander in the management of the
flight deck work by:

Ensuring that all appropriate type specific checklists are properly completed for the current
phase of flight;
Properly completing all other checklists, reports and/or documents before handing them
over to the Commander for signature;
Observing a well-balanced task distribution;
Systematic cooperation and exchange of information;
Monitoring the flight progress and the aeroplane’s systems;
Confirming the safe navigation of the aircraft and maintaining a continuous and
independent check upon both the geographical position of the aircraft and its safe terrain
clearance; and;
Monitoring the performance of other Flight Deck Crew Members.
Notwithstanding the overriding authority of the Commander, it is of utmost importance that the
First Officer draws the attention of the Commander to facts, circumstances or unfavorable variables
which may impair the safety of the flight and which may not yet have been noticed by the
Commander.

Such facts and circumstances may be:

Exceedance of limitations, abnormal indications, changes in meteorological conditions en-route or
at alternates/destination, ambiguous ATS clearances, deficiencies in navigation or the aeroplane’s
handling, abnormal response of the aeroplane to Pilot’s inputs, etc.

1.5.3 After Flight

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The First Officer assists the Commander in/by:

Closing the aeroplane’s documentation;
Putting into good order, for next Flight Deck Crew, all manuals, maps and charts which form
part of the flight deck library;
Handing over the aeroplane to its next crew, to the appropriate maintenance personnel, or
when not applicable, having the aeroplane secured; and;
Handing over the completed documentation to authorized personnel or forwarding such
documents by other means.

1.6.1 Safety Pilot

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Is a Pilot who is required to act as a Safety Pilot during base and/ or line-training.

He is intended to fulfill the following functions:

To take over command of the aircraft in an event of incapacitation of the Commander/
Instructor, see Chapter 4 Crew Composition ;
To monitor safe operation of the aircraft during periods of high workload (e.g. take-off,
landing, traffic congestion or approach);
To alert the Commander/ Instructor on:
Omission of any procedures by crew; and;
External threats.
A Safety Pilot may be any crew qualified to operate from at least one of the Pilot seats on the
relevant aircraft type.

A Safety Pilot is not intended to fulfill any training role. However, he is expected to assist the
instructor and trainee in any manner considered appropriate to the circumstances prevailing
during flight or ground operations.

The Safety Pilot must occupy a flight deck jump seat during all critical phases of flight, and when
specifically directed by the Instructor.

The Safety Pilot shall be briefed by the Instructor on all relevant requirements.

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Is an Observer Pilot, who has at least completed EGYPTAIR’s Airline Basic Course, assigned to the
flight for the purpose of the familiarization with type specific procedures, during his training on a
specific type.

1.7 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE DISPATCHER (FLIGHT

OPERATIONS OFFICER)
* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
In order to practically exercise operational control of flight operations, and for the interest of safety
and security of the aircraft and its occupants, EGYPTAIR delegates the Authority of the initiation,
continuation, diversion or termination of its flights to the Commander and the flight dispatcher.

Prior to Flight

The flight dispatcher is responsible for pre-flight planning, flight preparation, and the dispatch
release of flights, ensuring that the pilot-in-command is provided with the relevant information, all
in compliance with ECARs, operation specifications, including operational variations, the conditions
and limitations of the Air Operator Certificate (AOC), applicable regulations, and the standards of
EGYPTAIR. He shall strictly observe and meet the requirements of OM Part A and OM Part E.

He is responsible for the preparation of flight planning, routes and fuel calculation, according
to information indicated in the route manuals, approved company routes and fuel policy;
He analyzes the meteorological data and the appraisal of the prevailing and anticipated
weather conditions at the aerodromes, and throughout the air routes used, and thereof, briefs
Flight Deck Crew Members;
He shall prepare the operational and ATS flight plans, sign when applicable, file the ATS flight
plan with the appropriate ATS unit, and communicate any off-scheduled flights (delayed,
cancelled, or re-routed) to the ATS unit;
He coordinates with Eurocontrol Network Manager all aspects of the slot allocation process
including all Eurocontrol traffic messages;
He is responsible for the execution of the dispatch release and crew briefing system, ensuring
that it complies with ECARs;
He shall ensure that Flight Deck Crew Members are provided with, and totally aware of, all
relevant and updated information related to the flight e.g. weather reports, NOTAMs, aircraft
limitations, aeronautical information, flight documentations, maintenance status (provided by
the concerned department) with reference to MEL/CDL, en-route fuel availability and fuel
requirements etc;
He shall coordinate with other strategic quarters (commercial and flight maintenance control),
the completion of the trips, while preserving the security element;
He is authorized, in coordination with other IOCC departments, to delay, re-route, cancel and/
or re-dispatch a flight, if in his opinion or in the Commander’s opinion, the flight cannot
operate safely as planned or released. However, all other concerned parties within the IOCC,
shall be notified;
The Commander, and the flight dispatcher, shall not initiate a flight unless they both agree
that the flight will be conducted safely as planned under the existing forecast conditions;
He shall monitor the progress of EGYPTAIR’ flight operation schedule and shall execute the
system operating procedure for the flight following system properly, in order to achieve its
objectives;
He shall review and executes instructions of safety and/or security element such as safety risk
assessment and/or aviation security advises that can effect management of operational
control of flight operations;
ORGANIZATION AND RESPONSIBILITIES
1.7 Duties and Responsibilities of the Dispatcher (Flight Operations Officer)
OM A
1-7-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
He shall review and execute the instructions and policies of safety and security that can affect
the management of operational control of flights.
In-flight

He shall continue to analyze:
Weather information, both en-route and at the airport of intended landing, to identify
hazardous phenomena e.g. thunderstorms, turbulences, icing and restrictions to visibility;
Field conditions e.g. runway condition, availability and status of navigation aids;
En-route navigation systems and facilities, where possible failures that could affect the
safe continuation or completion of the flight, might occur;
Fuel supply, including actual en-route consumption compared to planned consumption,
as well as the impact of any changes of alternate airport or any additional en-route
delays;
Air traffic management issues e.g. re-routing, altitude, speed restrictions, facilities,
system failures or delays, and thereof, inform, and update, Crew Members with the
appropriate data change.
He monitors and maintains communication using the appropriate communication tools, to
maintain shared authority of the operation control system;
He gets the latest weather for the commercial and fuel alternates then relay it to the
concerned flight, through the appropriate communication system;
In case of diversion due to weather, it is his responsibility, in conjunction with other IOCC
divisions, and in coordination with the Commander, to decide which alternate to proceed to;
In case of diversion, he shall notify the PIC with the preferred commercial alternate, at least
one and half hour before ETA to destination airport;
He shall convey, by any appropriate means available, safety- and security-related information
to the Pilot-in-Command while in flight, including any necessary amendments to the flight
plan, and shall furnish any information necessary for the safe conduct of the flight;
He may not allow a flight to continue towards any airport to which it has been dispatched, if
in his opinion, the flight cannot be safely completed, unless in the Commander’s opinion,
there is no safer action. In this case, the flight is continued under the emergency authority of
the Commander;
He shall coordinate with the appropriate ATS unit, any operational instructions involving a
change in the ATS flight plan, before relaying it to the aeroplane;
He shall notify the appropriate ATS unit when the position of the aircraft cannot be
determined “4D/15 tracking” by an aircraft tracking capability and attempts to establish
communication are unsuccessful;
In the event of an emergency, the flight dispatcher shall initiate emergency procedures as
outlined in the operations manual while avoiding taking any actions that would conflict with
ATC procedures, notify the appropriate authorities without delay of the nature of the
situation, and request assistance if required.
After Flight

He shall keep monitoring the flight until the flight has landed;
In case any MEL/CDL has been reported, that one way or another affects the next sector or
next flight, he shall take the corrective action required;

Overall Responsibility

Both the PIC and the flight dispatcher are jointly responsible for maintaining a full shared
system that contains the flight monitoring. The flight dispatcher performs that by the Hermes
web messenger, Collins Flight Data Display, in-flight monitoring and/or the communication
system that contains:
VHF/HF after briefing and before take-off;
Hermes messenger via Data link, SATCOM or Stockholm Radio after take-off;
Hermes messenger via Data link, SITA or telephone after landing in case of outside
station.
Which enables both the Commander and the flight dispatcher to communicate with each other, at
all flight phases, in order to enhance the full shared responsibilities of the operation control.

He shall notify the concerned quarters with the progress changes of the flight that may occur
due to bad weather, NOTAMs, aircraft limitations, slot times and/or MEL/CDL;
He shall keep the statistical data for each flight (hard copy or electronic copy);
He shall carry out all instructions and duties contained in the Operations Manual;
Whenever an emergency situation (incident, occurrence, serious occurrence or accident)
emerges, that endangers the safety of the aircraft or persons, has been reported to the flight
dispatcher, he shall initiate an emergency, then inform the shift supervisor;
In case the regularity of flights is inadequate, he shall take immediate corrective measures in
coordination with the dispatcher shift supervisor, IOCC duty manager, G.M. IOCC, and the
concerned quarters;
In case any incident/accident occurs to any EGYPTAIR flight, he shall take the necessary
measures in coordination with the dispatcher shift supervisor, IOCC Duty Manager and G.M.
IOCC;
If any assistance is required, he shall contact the relevant authorities, including the
international operations authorities, if needed.

1.9 HEAD OF SECURITY (VICE PRESIDENT SECURITY)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The VP Security is the head of Security; he has a direct reporting line to the CEO.

He is respected by staff at all levels within the company.

Qualifications and Responsibilities

He has a professional background and is familiar with aircraft and company operations;
He ensures the availability of appropriate job descriptions, including required qualifications
and competencies for security staff;
He ensures proper recruitment, selection, training and certification (where applicable) for
aviation security staff, including instructors, managers and supervisors;
He ensures that only persons who have been properly trained and certified (where applicable)
are authorized to implement security controls;
He ensures that aviation security instructors remain occupationally competent and up to date
on both instructional techniques and subject matter;
He carries out his responsibilities as spelt out in the SeMS, Security Program & Supplementary
Station Procedures without hindrance and has direct access to the CEO, shall the need arise to
inform them of prevailing security situation(s);
Also, contacting the Senior Management and security bodies inside and outside Egypt;
He has sufficient experience in the field of security and aviation and has the qualifications,
knowledge and competence to be responsible for the development and implementation of
the Security Program / Supplementary Station Procedures & Manuals;
He has a clear list of responsibilities and tasks and surrounded himself with the appropriate
staff;
He shall be a person with direct access to the highest level of management;
He is accountable for ensuring the implementation of the AOSP/SSPs in the company
(ensuring operations are conducted in accordance with the AOSP/SSPs), interaction with other
business area managers/senior managers will be inevitable;
He has sufficient experience to build and promote an effective security culture;
Security issues/breaches are raised to him through CEO.
He is accountable and responsible for:

Formulation of an overall security policy for senior management acceptance;
Ensuring the management of security threats and risks within EGYPTAIR;
Ensuring the development and promulgation of security standards and practices to provide
line management with direction and control;
Establishing a clear order of command in the security structure and delegate duties to assure
managerial continuity when managers are absent from the workplace to maintain proper
management of operational security functions is always in place by issuing official,
administrative order and according to Delegation of Duties Table through security division;
Establishing the use of telecommuting technology and/or being on call and continually
contactable are acceptable means for operational managers to remain available and capable
of carrying out assigned work duties;

1.10.2 Cabin Crew Member

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
A Cabin Crew Member fulfills important functions:

They ensure, under the overall authority and responsibility of the Commander, cabin safety,
e.g., the safety of the passengers and the security of cabin load and galleys and shall report
to the PIC:
Any fault, failure, malfunction or defect, which they believe, may affect the airworthiness
or safe operation of the aeroplane or aeroplane systems;
Any incident that has endangered or may have endangered safety.
They shall make use of the company’s incident reporting scheme in accordance with
Chapter 11 Handling, Notifying and Reporting Occurrences. In such cases, a copy of the
report shall be communicated to the PIC concerned;
Form the link between the passengers and the Flight Deck Crew Members;
Provide optimum comfort and service for EGYPTAIR customers, and by their courtesy,
efficiency, thoughtfulness and ready assistance, directly shape EGYPTAIR image.
Whenever more than one Cabin Crew Member is required, the crew scheduling unit of EGYPTAIR
shall nominate a Purser/ SCC to:

Direct, coordinate and organize the functions and tasks of the Cabin Crew;
Be responsible to the Commander for the conduct and coordination of cabin safety and
emergency procedures specified in the Operations Manual, and for their observance by the
Cabin Crew and by all passengers;
Inform the Flight Deck Crew of all irregularities and malfunctions and, at the prescribed
times, reports ( CABIN SECURE ) or ( CABIN NOT SECURE ).
1.10.2.1 Prior to Flight

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Cabin Crew Members must meet the qualification and recency requirements of Chapter 5
Qualification Requirements prior to flight, all Cabin Crew Members must participate in the
Commander’s Cabin Crew briefing, receiving information and particulars pertinent to the individual
flight.

ORGANIZATION AND RESPONSIBILITIES
1.10 Duties and Responsibilities of Flight Purser / SCC and CC
OM A
1-10-4

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Whenever due to unforeseen circumstances EGYPTAIR’ designated purser is not available for duty
and cannot be replaced by the crew scheduling department, the PIC will nominate the Cabin Crew
Member holding the highest seniority to the duties and responsibilities of SCC. In such a case, a
full review of all relevant safety/emergency provisions shall be held during the crew briefing.

Cabin Crew Members shall check the emergency equipment, other equipment and the
catering equipment;
Check lavatories and galleys serviceability;
Check cabin cleanliness and tidiness;
Receive all catering items;
Take over flight sales;
Carry out all necessary work for cabin, lavatories and galleys;
Report deficiencies to Purser/ SCC for further action;
For boarding of passengers, they shall take up their prescribed positions.
1.10.2.2 In-flight

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
They conduct the prescribed passenger services apart from fulfilling the safety relevant
tasks. In the event of an emergency situation, they proceed to their emergency stations; the
Purser/ SCC immediately contacts the Flight Deck Crew for instructions;
They start all scheduled flight service duties and procedures;
At transit stations, the Cabin Crew Members ensure proper cleaning of the aeroplane’s
cabin and ensure re-catering for the next flight.
1.10.2.3 After Flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Cabin related documentation shall be filed;
Boxes/carts containing duty free items must be sealed, as prescribed;
Cabin Crew Members shall ensure the orderly hand-over of the cabin to the next Cabin
Crew or, where applicable, to the catering or cleaning personnel or to maintenance (shift
supervisor);
All Cabin Crew shall disembark as one unit.

1.11 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF GENERAL MANAGER SECURITY

AND IN-FLIGHT SECURITY OFFICER
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
1.11.1 Duties and Responsibilities of General Manager Security

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Implementing the policies, measures and security activities drawn up by V.P. Security and
submit security reports to the V.P. Security;
Supervising security procedures that include security inspection of the aircraft before
departure and the follow up on these procedures;
Supervising baggage reconciliation, either for transit or transfer passengers;
Supervising the implementation of security procedures on cargo, mail, express parcel,
catering supplies and checked baggage. In addition, securing persons traveling under
special status, carriage of weapons on board the aircraft or in holds and supervising aircraft
while parked and ensuring it is secured;
Participate in implementing a contingency plan, which contains measures and procedures in
case of hijacking, threats and when a suspect or a suspected item is found on board the
aircraft during the flight;
Insuring that aircraft is clear from any dangerous/ suspicious articles on ground and
participating in implementing a special security procedure during high threat periods;
Implementing the policy, measures and security activities;
Security General Department is responsible for the security and safety of passengers and
staff at the airport;
The general department is responsible for protecting the common fundamentals from theft,
fraud, intentional damage and other criminal acts;
Responsible for implementing corrective/ preventive actions resulting from quality activities;
Quickly resolving any deficiency in order to prevent re-occurrence and ensures that the
implemented corrective actions commensurate to the gaps or issues identified.
1.11.2 Duties and Responsibilities of In-flight Security Officer (IFSO)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
1.11.2.1 Before Flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Full commitment of wearing the company uniform and to report to the security office two
hours before flight;
IFSOs shall, at all times, comply with and follow Commander’s instructions;
Getting familiar with the latest instructions and updates;
To maintain good personal appearance.
First IFSO shall:

Passes through the departure gate with the last passenger;
ORGANIZATION AND RESPONSIBILITIES
1.11 Duties / Responsibilities of General Manager Security and In-flight
Security
OM A
1-11-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Performs random hand search for passengers or their belongings;
Receive deportees (if any) after assessing their state, inform the Commander of their
presence and be aware of the total number of passengers on board;
Upon arrival to the aircraft, he shall present and introduce himself to the Commander, who
shall brief him, if needed;
Notify second security officer of briefing details;
Notify the Commander of all incidents or violations, records all details in the flight security
report including the Commander’s instructions, he is obliged to notify him before any action
is taken;
If a passenger fails to board, his baggage must be off-loaded, station staff shall supervise
the offloading of the baggage, inform the PIC and sign the load sheet. After offloading, a
reconciliation shall be performed, with the coordination of the relevant authorities.
Second IFSO shall:

Before proceeding to the aircraft, he shall check and revise his passport with the
Immigration Police Authority in TB3 or through the IOCC;
Arrive at the aircraft one and a half hour before the expected time of departure, check staff
IDs and passenger’s boarding passes;
Supervise cargo hold baggage-loading process. Perform cabin search before passengers
boarding, in accordance with the pre-flight security checklist;
Assist in writing security incident reports;
Check the General Declaration and make sure all crew names are included.
NOTE IFSOs are responsible for handing over the Aircraft Security Checklist to the
Commander for completion and signature.
1.11.2.2 In-flight

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
All IFSOs should stay in their specified seats and their seats cannot be changed except by
the Commander’s approval, see Chapter IFSO Seat Allocation ;
NOTE The Commander has the authority to change the IFSO’s seats;
Supervise the Flight Deck door and prevent unauthorized access, see also Chapter 8.3.13.1
Flight Deck Door Principles ;
Shall handle security situation arising from various threat conditions (e.g. Level 3 and 4
Disruptive/unruly passenger). Refer to Chapter 10.2.10.3 Handling Disruptive/Unruly
Passenger ;
Supervise cabin and observe if any passenger changes his seat before take-off;
Notice any suspicious or unusual behavior;
Notify the Commander immediately of any incident or threat (serious or joke);
The IFSO shall inform the Commander about all the procedures that will take place during
the fight, the Commander has the authority to stop any procedure taken by IFSOs, if he
suspects that it may affect the safety of the aircraft and its passengers;
Do not interfere with the duties or work performance of the Cabin Crew;
Apply security measures and procedures for deportees and complete the deportee form;

Notify the Commander of unruly passengers on board, before any action is taken and then
after the situation is resolved;
Help Cabin Crew perform aircraft search during flight, in the case of any security threat;
In single aisle aeroplanes and during service, he shall proceed to the seat beside the galley
next to the Flight Deck door, until Cabin Crew finish passenger’s service;
IFSOs are responsible to carry out any other duties assigned by the Commander.
1.11.2.3 After Flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Check aircraft after passengers disembarkation, search for any items left behind, explosives
or firearms;
If a passenger valuable item is found, register the name of the person who found it, display
the item to passengers in the arrival hall, and hand over the item to the passenger, who
signs a collection receipt. If not taken by any of the passengers, the item shall be handed to
Lost and Found Security Department against a delivery receipt;
Remain for 1 hour after arrival to supervise catering off-loading and the cleaning process;
First IFSO shall hand over deportees to the relevant authorities in accordance with security
procedures;
First IFSO shall submit a flight security report and attachments, if any, immediately after
arrival, to the in-flight security office and inform security operation room of any in-flight
incidents.
At Transit Stops

Search the aircraft after passengers disembarkation, according to the aircraft security
checklist, search for any item left behind, explosives or arms;
If a passenger valuable item is found, register the name of the person who found it, the
item shall be delivered to its owner, when requested. If not, return the item on board the
return flight, to the Lost and Found Security Department at Cairo International Airport
against a delivery receipt;
Prevent unauthorized access to the aircraft;
Remain on board the aircraft and never wander away (make phone calls or shop at the duty
free shop);
Supervise cleaners while performing their duties on board the aircraft, search them and
their equipment before allowing access, in accordance with the relevant authorities;
Supervise and check flight catering duties, that are performed by Cabin Crew according to
their receiving procedures;
Check aircraft before passengers boarding, in accordance with the aircraft security checklist;
Manual search of carry-on items before boarding, in accordance with the requirements of
the relevant authorities;
Perform security measures/procedures required at the external stations.

1.11.2.4 In Case of Only One Security Officer on Board

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Before Flight

Attends the briefing and proceeds to the aircraft with the Cabin Crew before passengers
boarding, and check passenger’s boarding passes. Ramp security officer should check all
staff IDs before allowing access to the aircraft and supervise cargo and hold baggage-
loading process.
During Flight

Remains in the security assigned seat. When SEAT BELT sign is turned OFF, he shall proceed
to the area outside the Flight Deck door and remains there until the Cabin Crew finish
passenger service.
Thereafter, remains on the seat beside the galley, to apply security control on the Flight
Deck door and prevent access of unauthorized individuals. Ensures door is closed during the
whole flight and secures it when opened in coordination with the Cabin Crew;
In case any of the Flight Deck Crew exits the Flight Deck, the IFSO must ensure that the area
outside the Flight Deck door is clear and that no passengers are present.
After Flight

Search the aircraft after passengers disembarkation to ensure no passenger items are left
behind, explosives or arms (Cabin/ lavatories);
In case an item is found, it shall be handed to the Lost and Found Security Department
against a delivery receipt and should be written down in the flight security report;
He must remain on board for 1 hour after arrival in order to perform security control. In
case the aircraft is operating 1 hour after arrival, the IFSO will hand over the aircraft to the
IFSO of the next flight. If the interval exceeds 1 hour, it becomes the responsibility of the
ramp security department.

2.1 SUPERVISION OF THE OPERATION BY EGYPTAIR

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
2.1.1 General

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In accordance with the ECARs, EGYPTAIR must exercise operational control to establish and
maintain a method of supervision of flight operations. EGYPTAIR shall:

Ensure that operations are conducted in conformance with the requirements of the AOC
and all other applicable regulations;
Ensure that operations personnel are competent, skilled and qualified;
Establish a management structure which satisfies the ECAA requirements and matches the
scale of operations;
Provide and maintain the physical infrastructure necessary to produce a safe and secure
operations i.e. buildings, workspaces, associated utilities, required facilities and supporting
equipments and tools;
Produce, provide and maintain the Operations Manual for the use and guidance of
operations personnel; and;
Ensure that all operations personnel are properly instructed, have demonstrated their
abilities in performing their particular duties and are aware of their responsibilities and of
the relationship of such duties to the operations as a whole.
2.1.2 Means of Supervising Flight Operations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Defining in the Operations Manual the policies and the procedures to ensure that the
operations comply with the content of the granted AOC and its associated Operations
Specifications;
Ensuring that the aircraft is operated in compliance with the terms of its Certificates of
Airworthiness and within the approved limitations contained in its AFM;
Setting up operational procedures and instructions for all types of operations, that define
the duties and responsibilities of ground staff and Crew Members; and
Utilizing a checklist system to be used by the Crew Members under normal, abnormal and
emergency conditions.
The CEO, according to ECARS and/or EGYPTAIR’ qualification requirements, ensures that
management and nonmanagement positions within the flight operations organization are filled by
personnel on basis of knowledge, skills, training and experience appropriate for each position.

NOTE EGYPTAIR re-evaluates its qualification requirements and, when required, have them
updated.
2.1.3 License and Qualification Validity

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The exercise of the privileges granted by a license shall be dependent upon its validity and upon
the validity of the medical certificate.

OPERATIONAL CONTROL AND SUPERVISION
2.1 Supervision of the Operation by EGYPTAIR
OM A
2-1-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
No Crew Member shall perform a flying duty unless his license, rating, medical certificate, recency
and any other qualification that he might require for the particular flight are appropriate, current
and valid for the entire duration of the flight.

EGYPTAIR ensures that all Crew Members assigned to a flight meet the minimum qualification
requirements and are qualified as required for the area and type of operations.

License and training records are maintained for all Crew Members employed by EGYPTAIR. A track
of all the applicable expiries is kept in the rostering system. The systems in place monitor all
legalities and qualifications applicable to all duties.

While EGYPTAIR facilitates qualification and personal document renewal, each Crew Member is
personally responsible to ensure that he is in possession of the applicable documents,
qualifications and certifications required for any particular duty or series of duties.

NOTE The ultimate responsibility for the licence’s validity rests with the holder.
NOTE Training policies, requirements and training programs for Crew Members are
contained in OM Part D.
2.1.4 Competence of Operations Personnel

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The supervision of the competence of the operations personnel is achieved by:

Ensuring that the personnel assigned to or directly involved in, ground and flight operations
are properly instructed and have demonstrated their abilities in their particular duties.
Qualification requirements are defined in Chapter 5 Qualification Requirements ;
Ensuring that the personnel can communicate in a common language and that they are able
to understand those parts of the Operations Manual which pertain to their duties and
responsibilities.
The competence of operations personnel is monitored as follows:

2.1.4.1 Flight Deck and Cabin Crew Members

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew and Cabin Crew competence is maintained by:

The selection and recruitment of persons to defined suitability criteria;
The conduct of initial and conversion training and checking to the ECAA approved program;
The monitoring of Crew Members’ performance during training and checking and whilst on
operational duty, and the application of remedial training as required.
2.1.4.2 Ground Operations Personnel

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The competence of ground operations personnel is maintained in accordance with the
requirements of the Ground Handling Control Manual.

2.1.4.3 Maintenance Personnel

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The competence of maintenance personnel is maintained in accordance with the ECAA approvals
held by EGYPTAIR.

2.1.5 Control, Analysis and Storage of Records, Flight Documents and

Data
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Records, Flight Documents and Data used for the conduct of Flight Operations must be stored in
accordance with the storage period defined by the ECAA. The storage of Records, Flight
Documents and Data can be in any physical format.

When electronic storage is used, the concerned department shall ensure:

The integrity of system i.e. secure, safe and backed-up;
That measures are taken to prevent the loss of records due to hardware or software failures;
That an electronic system is programmed to create back-up files on a schedule; and
That hardware / software, when updated or replaced is retained to enable retrieval of old
records.
2.1.6 Documents Used for the Preparation and Execution of the Flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The list of documents to be carried for each flight are mentioned in Chapter 8.1.13 List of
Documents, Forms and Additional Information to be Carried Onboard. EGYPTAIR or it’s agent
shall retain on the ground, at the aerodrome of departure and for at least the duration of the
flight, a copy of each document relevant to the flight and appropriate for the type of operation as
listed below:

Copy of the Operational Flight Plan;
Copies of the relevant parts of the ATL;
Route specific NOTAM documentation;
Original of weight and balance documentation;
Original of notification(s) of special loads and/or special categories of passengers.
2.1.6.1 Reports

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
After each flight, the Commander shall ensure completion of the Aircraft Technical Log and Flight
Report. Other reports which may be completed as required are:

Captain Report;
Air Safety Report;
Voluntary Report;
Dangerous Goods Occurrences Report;
Commander Discretion Report;
Passenger Disturbance Report.

2.3 OPERATIONAL CONTROL

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Operational control is the conduct of operational planning, the exercise of authority over initiation,
continuation, diversion, termination or cancellation of a flight and the exercise of authority to carry
out the recovery from operational irregularities.

Operational control is exercised so as to ensure safety, regulatory compliance, passenger comfort
and economy of all flight operations. In order to achieve the above, the responsibilities are divided
as follows:

The V.P. Flight Operations bears the overall responsibility and has the overall directive
authority in:
Coordinating and supervising the flight operations department and appointing its
managers;
Setting up operational procedures and instructions for all types of operations, both on
ground and in flight, which define the duties of ground staff and Crew Members;
Drawing, in co-operation with other departments, appropriate conclusions and
addressing the noted deficiencies resulting from:
Regular meetings reports;
Occurrence and Air Safety Reports;
Hearings;
Check flights.
Co-operating in the audits conducted by the G.M Safety, Quality and Standardization, to
address all faults or deficiencies, particularly in respect to the standards of operational
personnel’s competence, their qualification/re-qualification process, their performance of
conducting the prescribed duties and their adherence to EGYPTAIR procedures;
Establishing the legally required procedures and instructions e.g. the Operations Manual;
Changes to the Operations Manual and related additional operational provisions and
regulations will be suggested to the V.P. Flight Operations by the designated department
and will be published, by that department, under the direction of the V.P. Flight
Operations, after prior co-ordination with the ECAA. This procedure provides the
necessary element of control, a standard of comparison, and the channeling of the
know-how.
The G.M. Flight Operations exercises operational control in:
Determining the usability of aerodromes, to be proposed to and approved by the G.M.
Flight Operations and thereafter published by the Technical Research Department;
The establishment of the aerodrome operating and planning minima, to be proposed to
and approved by the G.M. Flight Operations and thereafter published by the Technical
Research Department;
The approval of routes to be served and areas to be overflown and the establishment of
minimum flight altitudes and en-route operating minima, to be proposed to and
approved by the G.M. Flight Operations and thereafter published by the Technical
Research Department.
OPERATIONAL CONTROL AND SUPERVISION
2.3 Operational Control
OM A
2-3-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
The responsibility of an individual flight devolves on the IOCC two hours before departure.
The IOCC shall ensure that for each flight:
A Commander has been designated and that the required crew complement has been
allocated;
Flight time and rest time limitations for each Crew Member allocated to duty on the
flight have been met, and will continue to be met, see Chapter 7 Flight Time
Limitations ;
The aeroplane has undergone all maintenance actions that renders the aeroplane
capable, from a technical and legal point of view, of completing its tour of duty and
returning to home base before a major check is due;
An OFP has been prepared and all dispatch requirements have been met.
Commanders Responsibility:
Once the flight has commenced, the final authority to exercise control rests with the
Commander, who must coordinate his decisions with the IOCC and the Maintenance Control
Center, and who should base those decisions on the safety of the aeroplane, its passengers
and its Crew. The Commander must relay to the IOCC any deviations from the planned route,
diversion or any other operational irregularities through the available communication systems
e.g. VHF, HF, ACARS, SATCOM, etc.
Flight Dispatch Responsibility:
EGYPTAIR delegates the Authority of the initiation, continuation, diversion or termination of
its flights to the Commander and the flight dispatcher, see Chapter 1.7 Duties and
Responsibilities of the Dispatcher (Flight Operations Officer).
NOTE: Both the PIC and the flight dispatcher are jointly responsible for maintaining a full
shared system that contains the flight monitoring. The flight dispatcher performs that by the
Hermes web messenger, Collins Flight Data Display, in-flight monitoring and/or the
communication system that contains:
VHF/HF after briefing and before take-off;
Hermes messenger via Data link, SATCOM, ACARS or Stockholm Radio after take-off;
Hermes messenger via Data link, SITA, ACARS or telephone after landing in case of
outside station,
which enables both the Commander and the flight dispatcher to communicate with each
other, at all flight phases, in order to enhance the full shared responsibilities of the operation
control.
Editorial responsibility:
The editorial responsibility of the Operations Manual is as follows:

2.4 POWERS OF AUTHORITY

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
2.4.1 Access

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The Egyptian Civil Aviation Authority, or any Authority conducting ramp checks shall, for the
purpose of determining compliance with the relevant requirements be granted access at any time
to any Company facility, aircraft, document, records, data, procedures or any other material
relevant to the EGYPTAIR’s activity subject to certification, SPO authorisation or declaration,
whether it is contracted or not. Access to the aircraft shall include the possibility to enter and
remain in the aircraft, including the flight crew compartment, during flight operations unless
otherwise decided by the Commander in the interest of safety. The Commander shall ensure that:

Admission to the flight crew compartment does not cause distraction or interference with
the operation of the flight; and
All persons carried in the flight crew compartment are made familiar with the relevant safety
procedures.
The Commander shall make the final decision regarding the admission to the flight crew
compartment.

Worth noting is also that an inspection after landing shall not jeopardise the total resting time of
the crew.

2.4.2 Ramp Inspection

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The aeroplane and/or crew may be subject to a ramp inspection. If conducted in a state where the
EU Ramp Inspection Programme is in force (currently 48 states listed on the EASA webpage), the
ramp inspection will follow the SACA (Safety Assessment of Community Aircraft) instructions
checked against EU standards. If the ramp inspection is taking place elsewhere, the inspections will
instead follow the SAFA (Safety Assessment of Foreign Aircraft) instructions checked against ICAO
standards.

The ramp inspections are chiefly concerned with the aeroplane documents and manuals, crew
licenses, cargo carried, the apparent technical condition of the aeroplane and the presence and
condition of mandatory flight deck and cabin safety equipment. The applicable requirements for
these inspections are:

The ICAO international standards for aircraft used by third country operators;
The relevant EU requirements for aircraft used by operators under the regulatory oversight
of another Member State;
Manufacturers’ standards when checking the technical condition of the aircraft; and
Published national standards (e.g. Aeronautical Information Publications (AIPs)) that are
declared applicable to all operators flying to that State.
The outcome of the ramp inspection is then subject to reports which follow a common format. The
absolute number of inspection findings represents an important outcome of the inspecting
process which provides valuable information on the aeroplane or EGYPTAIR as its responsible
operator.

OPERATIONAL CONTROL AND SUPERVISION
2.4 Powers of Authority
OM A
2-4-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
On the other hand, this needs to be carefully taking into account in relation with the “severity” of
the findings.

To this end, three categories of findings have been defined. A “Category 1" finding is called a
minor finding; “Category 2" is a significant finding and “Category 3" a major finding. The terms
“minor”, “significant” and “major” relate to the level of influence on safety. The prime purpose of
categorising the findings is to classify the compliance with a standard and the severity of non-
compliance with this standard.

The inspections and the categories of findings are recorded in the centralised database.

Nevertheless, the final SAFA/SACA report will be sent to the Competent Authority as well as to
EGYPTAIR.

2.4.3 Crew Action

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The employees are expected to assist the inspections by providing requested information and by
responding to the questions of the inspectors in a knowledgeable and business-like manner
according to the best of their professional knowledge.

Before the inspection EGYPTAIR employees shall verify the identity of the inspectors and, if
needed, ask him to show his authorisation and identification card.

The Commander of the flight that has been the subject to a ramp inspection shall write an
occurrence report stating that an inspection has been performed, regardless of the result of the
inspection. If the ramp inspection has rendered in a finding/irregularity the occurrence report shall
include the number of findings received.

If the finding relates to a discovered defect on the aircraft, a corresponding entry must be made in
the Aircraft Technical Log (ATL) and the MCC notified.

To summarise:

An occurrence report shall always be filed after a ramp inspection;
If applicable, an entry in the ATL shall be made;
If the finding is a level 3 resulting in suspending the flight the NPFO has to be informed.

3.1.1.1 Safety Objectives

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
EGYPTAIR intends to provide a safe and healthy working environment for all personnel and
the highest possible safety standards for all customers, by continuously monitoring for
potential hazards and eliminating or reducing all recognized risks to a level as low as
reasonably practicable, to continuously improve the effectiveness of the SMS within
EGYPTAIR;
Safety objectives provide strategic direction to our activities and therefore be consistent with
EGYPTAIR Integrated policy that sets out EGYPTAIR high level safety commitment;
Safety objectives are brief, high-level statements of safety achievements or desired outcomes
to be accomplished;
Safety Objectives may be
a. Process-oriented: Stated in terms of safe behaviors expected from operational personnel
or the performance of implemented actions to manage safety risk; or
b. Outcome-oriented: Encompass actions and trends regarding containment of accidents or
operational losses.
Examples of safety objectives:

3.2.1 Introduction

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
This chapter sets out briefly the standards for the Safety Management System (SMS) of EGYPTAIR.
The SMS full Program has been documented and kept in a form of an integrated Safety & Quality
Management System Manual (SQMSM), which is an integrated management tool that is designed
to ensure control over the safety and quality of operations and is documented in accordance with
requirements, regulations and standards of various authorities including the Egyptian Civil Aviation
authority regulations (Including ECARs Parts “121” and “19”), relevant foreign aviation authorities,
IOSA, ISAGO, ISO standards, and applicable international regulatory bodies (such as the ICAO
Safety Management System Manual Doc. 9859 and ICAO SARPS Annex 6). In addition, it aims to
ensure full compliance with the company’s’ own internal requirements for the high standards of
safety and quality.

3.2.2 Safety and Safety Management Introduction

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
In order to understand safety management, it is necessary to consider what is meant by “Safety”.
Safety is increasingly viewed as the management of risk but depending on one’s perspective, the
concept of aviation safety may have different connotations, such as:

Zero accidents (or serious incidents), a view widely held by the traveling public;
The freedom from danger or risks, i.e., those factors which cause or are likely to cause harm;
The attitude towards unsafe acts and conditions by employees (reflecting a “safe” corporate
culture);
The degree to which the inherent risks in aviation are “acceptable”;
The process of hazard identification and risk management; and
The control of accidental loss (of persons and property, and damage to the environment).
While the elimination of accidents (and serious incidents) would be desirable, a one hundred
percent safety rate is an unachievable goal. Failures and errors will occur, in spite of the best
efforts to avoid them. No human activity or human-made system can be guaranteed to be
absolutely safe, i.e., free from risk. Safety is a relative notion whereby inherent risks are acceptable
in a “safe” system.

Ensure that remedial actions necessary to mitigate the risks / hazards are implemented; and

3.2.6 Hazard Identification Introduction

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
In aviation, a hazard can be considered as a dormant potential for harm which is present in
one form or another within the system or its environment. This potential for harm may appear
in different forms, for example as a natural condition (e.g., terrain) or technical status (e.g.,
runway markings). Hazards are an inevitable part of aviation activities; however, their
manifestation and possible adverse consequences can be addressed through mitigation
strategies which aim to contain the potential for the hazard to result in an unsafe condition.
Aviation can coexist with hazards so long as they are controlled;
Hazard identification is the first step in the Safety Risk Management Process, it precedes a
safety risk assessment and requires a clear understanding of hazards and their related
consequences. It is not uncommon for people to confuse hazards with their consequences. A
consequence is an outcome that can be triggered by a hazard, for example, a runway
excursion is a potential consequence related to the hazard of a contaminated runway. By
clearly defining the hazard first, one can more readily identify possible consequences;
The Hazard Identification Process is the reactive, proactive identification of existing and
potential hazards, whether they are internally or externally, even if they are outside the direct
control of the company such as extreme weather or volcanic ash. EGYPTAIR has developed
and maintains a formal process for collecting, recording, acting on and generating feedback
about hazards in operations, based on a combination of reactive, proactive and predictive
methods of safety data Collection;
Safety hazard identification program is applied to the full scope of: (Flight operations,
Dispatch operations, Cabin operations, Maintenance operations including line and base
maintenance, Ground Handling operations and Cargo handling operations).

3.2.7.1 Flight Data Analysis Program (FDA)

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
The Flight Data Analysis (FDA) program is a reactive, proactive and predictive tool for identification
of hazards. It works by capturing system performance as it happens in real-time normal operations
along with gathering and analyzing data recorded during routine flights to improve flight crew
performance, operating procedures, flight training, air traffic control procedures, air navigation
services, or aircraft maintenance and design.

The FDA program is a consistent complement to the hazard and incident reporting. It is a non-
punitive program and requires the cooperation of all personnel. Hence, prior to introducing such
program, a formal non-punitive policy has been signed from the CEO to be considered as an
agreement reached on the process.

NOTE Within the FDA program, “AirFASE” software program is being utilized, for further and
full details regarding the FDA & “AirFASE” refer to OM Part G, Appendix 4.
3.2.7.1.1 FDA Program Benefits

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
The FDA program is increasingly being used for the monitoring and analysis of flight operations
and engineering performance. It is a logical component in the safety management system. A
successful program encourages adherence to Standard Operating Procedures, discourages non-
standard behavior and so enhances flight safety. It can detect adverse trends in any part of the
flight regime and so facilitate the investigation of events other than those which have had serious
consequences. The Safety, Quality and Standardization General Department is targeting to cover
90% or more of its total flights with the FDA program.

Flight data analysis can be used to detect flight parameter exceedances and to identify non-
standard or deficient procedures, weaknesses in the ATC system, and anomalies in aircraft
performance. FDA allows the monitoring of various aspects of the flight profile, such as the
adherence to the prescribed take-off, climb, cruise, descent, approach and landing SOPs. Specific
aspects of flight operations can be examined, either reactively to identify problem areas, or
proactively prior to introducing operational change and subsequently, to confirm its effectiveness.

During incident analysis, flight recorder data for the incident flight can be compared with the fleet
profile data, there by facilitating analysis of the systemic aspects of an incident. It may be that the
parameters of the incident flight vary only slightly from many other flights, possibly indicating a
requirement for change in operating technique or training. For example, it would be possible to
determine whether a tail strike on landing was an isolated event, or symptomatic of a wider
mishandling problem, such as over flaring on touchdown or improper thrust management.

Engine monitoring programs may utilize the automated analysis of flight recorder data for reliable
trend analysis as manually coded engine data is limited in terms of accuracy, timeliness and
reliability. It is also possible to monitor other aspects of the airframe and systems. In summary, the
FDA program offers a wide spectrum of applications for safety management, as well as
improvements in operational efficiency and economy.

3.2.7.1.2 FDA Program Usage

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
Data collected from many flights may be useful to determine day-to-day operating standards,
identify unsafe trends, identify operational hazards in several extents (e.g., operating procedures,
airports, ATC procedures, etc.), monitor the effectiveness of specific safety actions taken, reduce
operating and maintenance costs, optimize training procedures and provide a performance
measurement tool for risk management programs.

The FDA data are typically used in five areas:

Exceedance detection;
Routine measurements;
Incident investigations;
Continuing airworthiness; and
a-Linked databases (or integrated safety analysis).
All the data gathered in the FDA program shall be kept in a central safety database. By linking the
FDA database to other safety databases (such as incident reporting systems and technical fault
reporting systems), a more complete understanding of events becomes possible through cross-
referencing the various sources of information. Care must be taken however, to safeguard the
confidentiality of FDA data when linking it to identified data.

The FDA Database is backed up on a monthly basis, a backup copy is securely saved at EGYPTAIR
Information Technology Division building while another copy is saved at the Safety, Quality and
Standardization General Department. Data is retained for 5 years.

3.2.7.2 Line Operations Assessment System (LOAS)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Line Operations Assessment System (LOAS) is one method for monitoring normal flight operations
for safety purposes. it provides another proactive and predictive safety management tool that can
aid in proactively managing the negative consequences of human behavior.

Like the Flight Data Analysis (FDA) program, LOAS facilitates hazard identification through the
analysis of actual in-flight performances. Whereas FDA provides accurate data on exceedances
from expected aircraft performance, LOAS provides information on joint system and human
performance, it facilitates understanding the context for the performance that may have
precipitated the exceedance.

LOAS is a tool for the understanding of human errors in flight operations. It is used to identify the
threats to aviation safety which lead to human errors, to minimize the risks that such threats may
generate and to implement measures to manage these errors within the operational context. LOAS
enables the company to assess their resistance to operational risks and errors by front-line
personnel. Using a data-driven approach, they can prioritize these risks and identify actions to
reduce the risk of accidents.

By observing normal day-to-day flight operations, data about flight crew performance and
situational factors are collected. Thus, LOAS facilitates understanding both successful performance
and failures. Hazards deriving from operational errors can be identified and effective
countermeasures developed.
