LOAS uses experienced and specially trained observers to collect data about flight crew
performance and situational factors on “normal” flights. During audited flights, observers record
error-inducing circumstances and the crew’s responses to them. The collected data might also be
integrated to the Flight Data Monitoring to get electronic assessment and trends through line
monitoring. The audits are conducted under strict non-punitive conditions, without fear of
disciplinary action for detected errors. Flight crews are not required to justify their actions.

Data from LOAS also provide a picture for the whole operational system that can guide strategies
in regard to safety management, training and operations. Like FDA programs, data collected
through LOAS can provide a rich source of information for the pro-active identification of systemic
safety hazards. A particular strength of LOAS is that it identifies examples of superior performance
that can be reinforced and used as models for training (Traditionally, the industry has collected
information on failed performance and revised training programs accordingly).

With LOAS, training interventions can be based on the most successful operational performance.
For example, CRM training can be modified to reflect best practices for coping with particular
types of unsafe conditions and for managing typical errors related to these conditions. LOAS
audits are conducted according to the “LOAS Implementation Process”. For further details
concerning the LOAS Code Lists, refer to OM Part G, Appendix 6.

Safety risk assessment and safety risk mitigation are two major tools required for the
establishment of the safety risk management process which is an integral key component in the
company’s safety management system. Safety risk management is a continuous activity because
the aviation system is constantly changing, new hazards can be introduced and some hazards and
associated safety risks may change over time, it facilitates the balancing act between assessed risks
and viable risk mitigation.

Assessed safety risks should be managed to an acceptable level by mitigating the safety risk
through the application of appropriate safety risk controls. This should be balanced against the
time, cost and difficulty of taking action to reduce or eliminate the safety risk. The level of safety
risk can be lowered by reducing the severity of the potential consequences, reducing the likelihood
of occurrence or by reducing exposure to that safety risk. It is easier and more common to reduce
the likelihood than it is to reduce the severity. The aim of risk management and control is to
improve the overall safety performance. Safety risks cannot be completely eliminated without
stopping all activity. However, they can be reduced and the objective of risk management is to
reduce them to an acceptable level as shown below.

3.2.10 Safety Performance Monitoring and Measurement

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
3.2.10.1 Safety Performance Management Introduction

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Managing safety performance will provide the feedback and means to determine whether activities
and processes are working effectively to achieve the safety objectives, while also being able to
compare the company’s performance with industry standards. This is accomplished through the
identification and measurement of safety performance indicators (SPIs), setting safety performance
targets (SPTs) if applicable, and monitoring safety triggers & alert levels in accordance with the
pre-set criteria to take the appropriate and effective necessary action(s) when an alert is triggered,
while examining where do we stand in-relation to regional benchmarking whenever possible.

Safety data collection is a wealth of safety data and safety information, including mandatory and
voluntary safety reporting systems; safety surveys; Line Operations Assessment System as well as
automated data captured from Flight Data Monitoring (FDM) program. Obtaining both safety data
and information combined with SPI identification will raise the senior management’s awareness of
the current situation and support decision-making, including determining whether actions are
required to further mitigate safety risks to ensure that safety goals are being achieved.

Safety performance management will give us the capability to answer assertively the four most
important questions regarding safety management:

What are our top safety risks? (derived from a review from our accident and incident data
as well as predictive analysis to identify and define emerging risks);
What do we want to achieve in terms of safety and what are the top safety risks that
need to be addressed? (our safety objectives);
How will we know if we are making progress towards our safety objectives? (through
SPIs and, if practicable SPTs & Safety triggers);
What safety data and safety information are needed to make informed safety
decisions? Including the allocation of our resources (i.e., using safety data collection and
safety data analysis).

3.2.12 Safety Audits

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Safety auditing is a reactive and proactive safety management activity, providing a means of
identifying potential problems before they have an impact on safety, it is one of the core safety
management activities. Safety audits provide a means for systematically assessing how well the
organization is meeting its safety objectives. Safety audits, together with other safety oversight
activities, provides feedback to managers of individual departments and senior management
concerning the company’s’ safety performance, this feedback provides evidence of the level of
safety performance being achieved. They are used to ensure that:

The structure of the SMS is sound in terms of appropriate levels of staff; compliance with
approved procedures and instructions; and a satisfactory level of competency and training
to operate equipment and facilities and to maintain their levels of performance;
Effective arrangements exist for promoting safety, monitoring safety performance and
processing safety issues;
Adequate arrangements exist to handle foreseeable emergencies.
Safety audits are conducted using the IATA Operational Safety Audit (IOSA) checklist, which is used
to ensure that all relevant topics are covered and each functional area is audited for evaluating the
overall safety performance. The IOSA checklist consists of comprehensive series of standards and
recommended practices (SARPS) grouped under topic headings, which are used to ensure that all
relevant topics are covered addressing all the operational areas including:

National safety regulatory requirements;
Safety policies and standards;
Structure of safety accountabilities;
Documentation, such as the SMSM and operational documentation including its
instructions;
Safety culture (reactive or proactive);
Hazard identification and risk management processes;
Safety oversight capabilities (monitoring, inspections, audits, etc.);

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Once the audit activities are completed, the audit team should review all audit observations and
compare them against the relevant regulations and procedures in order to confirm the correctness
of observations noted as nonconformities, deficiencies or safety shortcomings. Monitoring
mechanism(s) to verify the effectiveness of any necessary corrective actions may be implemented
using follow-up audits concentrating on:

Operational aspects of the operations where the need for corrective action was identified;
Eliminating root causes and enabling continuous improvement;
Completion a timely manner.

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Monitoring and assessing the Safety Management System (SMS) processes is a necessity to
maintain and continuously improve its overall effectiveness, this is achieved by conducting safety

processes. Though, it should be noted that maintaining and continuously improving the SMS is an
ongoing journey as the organization itself and the operational environment will be constantly
changing.

Continuous Improvement of the Safety System is one of the three elements in the safety assurance
component of the SMS. Assurance builds on the principle of the continuous improvement cycle,
facilitating continuous improvements in safety. Safety assurance ensures control of safety
performance, including regulatory compliance, through constant verification and improvement of

3.2.14.1 Implementation Methods

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The continuous improvement element can only occur through constant observance regarding the
effectiveness of the technical operations and the corrective actions. There is no way of telling
whether the SMS processes are achieving their objectives and no way of measuring the efficiency
of these processes without the ongoing monitoring of safety controls and mitigation actions.
Therefore, a variety of methods are implemented to determine the SMS effectiveness, measure
outputs as well as outcomes of the processes, and assess any gathered information. Using these
methods is a requirement in order to continually improve the SMS, they include:

Safety Audits (Internal audits and audits carried out by other organizations);
Assessments (Monitoring mechanisms including follow-up audits);
Monitoring Recurrence of Events (Using the safety reporting system and FDM);
Investigating Recurrence of Events (Conducting formal investigation processes);
Safety Surveys (Works as an indicator of the safety culture and provides useful feedback);
Quality Assurance Inspections (Quality Assurance Program to improve efficiency);
Management Reviews (i.e. Safety Review Board and Safety Action Group meetings);
Evaluation of SPIs and SPTs (Part of the Management Reviews);
Addressing Learnt Lessons (e.g. Bulletins, E-mails and Staff meetings);
Line Observation Flights (e.g. LOAS and FOQA).
3.2.15 Safety Culture, Training and Education

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
3.2.15.1 Safety Promotion Introduction

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Safety Promotion supplements the company’s policies, procedures and processes, providing a
value system that supports safety efforts. It also ensures that all staff fully understand and trust the
SMS policies, procedures, and structure. It creates and encourages a positive safety culture and
helps in achieving the safety objectives through training and education, effective communication
and information-sharing. Having a safety culture means that all employees are responsible for
safety, starting from the senior management, who should provide the leadership to promote such
culture.

3.2.15.2 Safety Culture

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Safety culture is the natural consequence of having humans in the aviation system, it has been
described as “how people behave in relation to safety and risk when no one is watching”. It is an
expression of how safety is perceived, valued and prioritized, and is reflected in the extent to which
individuals are:

Aware of the risks and known hazards faced by the company’s activities;
Continuously behaving to preserve and enhance safety;
Able to access the resources required for safe operations;
Willing and able to adapt when facing safety issues;

Willing to communicate safety issues; and
Consistently assessing the safety related behaviors throughout the organization.
Safety culture is the set of enduring values and attitudes regarding safety issues, shared by every
member and every group of every level within the company, it is arguably the single most
important influence on the management of safety, instituting all the safety management
requirements without having a positive safety culture will likely cause an underperformance in all
the safety managing activities. Understanding the context provided by culture is important to the
understanding of human performance, strengths and limitations, effective improvement in safety
requires applying a human factor approach in the SMS with a strong emphasis on safety culture.
This human factor approach considers aspects such as behaviors, attitudes, leadership and
accountability, for further details refer to the SQMSM Appendix 3.

3.2.15.2.1 Organizational Safety Culture Characteristics

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
As stated in the Safety Policy, achievement of highest levels of safety is always our concern, this
“Safety Comes First” value along with other values such as efficiency, effectiveness, teamwork and
continues learning, they reflect the organizational safety culture and form the basis for all the
company’s’ activities while simultaneously ensuring compliance with national and international
regulatory requirements. The organizational safety culture encompasses a range of different
characteristics to ensure that it is a positive safety culture such as:

Informed Culture : Those who manage and operate the system must have current knowledge
about the human, technical, organizational and environmental factors that determine the safety of
the system as a whole and they should actively disseminate any safety related concern or
information. This will eventually lead to applying appropriate risk management processes and
assessing new systems and procedures for any safety implications so that potentials hazards,
threats and risks can be identified and managed.

Reporting Culture : All staff are encouraged to raise safety concerns and take the initiative to
report hazards, threats and errors, enabling appropriate and timely safety actions to be taken. An
effective Reporting Culture depends on how the company handles blame and punishment.

Just Culture : A well-balanced “blame free” approach that enhances employee willingness to report
and seeks to establish a clearer line between what is an acceptable and unacceptable behavior
concerning safety. Hence, the application of the non-punitive policy that encourages staff to tell all
they know in an investigation and to report safety concerns without fear of inappropriate punitive
action. This kind of culture succeeds in creating trust and commitment resulting in good reporting
of incidents and anomalies using existing reporting systems.

Flexible Culture : Individuals should be capable of adapting effectively to changing demands.

Learning Culture : Management and staff must have the will and competence to learn from their
own mistakes as well as those made by others, at the same time be ready to implement
improvements.

3.2.15.3 Safety Management Training

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The organizational safety culture is tied to the success of the safety management training program.
The training program should ensure that the safety policy, procedures and principles are
understood and adhered to by all staff. Additionally, it should ensure that all staff understand their
roles and are aware of their positions’ safety responsibilities. Safety training should begin with a
personnel's initial employment phase and then continue throughout. Specific safety management
training should be provided for a staff who occupies positions with particular safety
responsibilities.

the Training Manager, should conduct a training needs analysis, to identify the training that will be
required for each position. The level of Safety Management training required will vary from general

3.2.16 Safety Communication

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
3.2.16.1 Introduction and Purpose

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Safety promotion activities are particularly important during the initial stages of the
implementation of an SMS, they play an important role in the maintenance of safety, as they are
the means by which safety issues are communicated within the company. These issues will be
addressed through individuals training programs supplemented by an ongoing two-way
communication process that helps ensure personnel benefit from safety lessons learned, see the
results of their actions, and continue to improve their understanding of the SMS. When safety
recommendations or new procedures are introduced, the associated underlying safety analysis
should also be communicated to the appropriate staff (flight crew, cabin crew and maintenance
personnel etc.) since safety communication is an essential foundation for the development and
maintenance of a positive safety culture.

Written safety communications such as the safety policies, procedures and bulletins, alone will not
necessarily bring about the development of a positive safety culture, it is also important for
employees to witness evidence of the commitment of top management to safety. The attitudes
and actions of management will therefore be a significant factor in the promotion of safe work
practices and the development of a positive safety culture.

3.3 QUALITY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (QMS)

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
3.3.1 Quality Management Concept

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Quality management is the means by which the company ensures that its products and/or services
meet internal, customer and regulatory requirements. It is a combination of resources,
responsibilities and actions that together ensure that specified requirements are met. It is also a
combination of systematic approaches to doing the work, together with specific checks to ensure
that the work has been undertaken correctly.

The Quality management system permits the company to monitor compliance with national/
international regulations and all other standards which are introduced by aviation authorities in
order to ensure the continuation of flight and ground safety operations and the continuing
airworthiness of the aircraft.

3.3.1.1 Quality Management Scope and Objective

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The scope of the Quality Management System (QMS) covers all aspects of safety and quality
management in operations, including but not limited to activities of the Flight Operations,
Maintenance and Engineering, Ground Services, Cargo and In-flight Services. Furthermore, all
process, products and services supplied by any external vendor or service provider shall be
monitored to ensure the safety and quality of operations.

The QMS focuses on compliance with regulations and requirements, consistency in the delivery of
products and services, meeting the specified performance standards and delivery of products and
services that are “fit for purpose” and free of defects or errors.

3.3.1.2 Quality Assurance Program (QAP) Overview

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The Quality Assurance Program has been established to provide senior management with an
accurate, real-time, planned evaluation of all aspects of EGYPTAIR functions as they relate to safety
and quality within the operational environment. For the QAP to operate effectively, there must be
an independent, direct communications link between the G.M Safety, Quality who is responsible
for the QAP process and the CEO.

3.3.1.3 Quality Policy

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Refer to Chapter 3.1.1 EGYPTAIR Integrated Policy.

3.3.1.4 SMS and QMS Integration

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Both the Safety and Quality management systems are complementary; the SMS focuses on
managing safety risks and safety performance while the QMS focuses on compliance with
prescriptive regulations and requirements to meet customer expectations and contractual
obligations. The objectives of an SMS are to identify hazards, assess the associated safety risk and
implement effective safety risk controls. In contrast, the QMS focuses on the consistent delivery of
products and services that meet relevant specifications. Nonetheless, both the SMS and the QMS:

Ensure compliance with all applicable regulations, standards and requirements;
Are planned and managed;
Involve all organizational functions related to the delivery of aviation products and services;
Identify ineffective processes and procedures;
Strive for continuous improvement; and
Have the same goal of providing safe and reliable products and services to customers.
Given the complementary aspects of the SMS and QMS, both systems are integrated without
compromising each other’s functions. This can be summarized as follows:

SMS is supported by the QMS processes such as auditing, inspection, investigation, root
cause analysis, process design, and preventive actions;
QMS identifies safety issues or weaknesses in safety risk controls;
QMS foresees safety issues that exist despite the organization’s compliance with standards
and specifications;
Quality principles, policies and practices are aligned with the objectives of the safety
management system; and
QMS activities considers identified hazards and safety risk controls for the planning and
performance of internal audits.
In conclusion, the integrated management system has been structured with unified goals and
decision-making that considers the wider impacts across all activities, quality management and
safety management processes are highly complementary and they support the achievement of the
overall safety goals.

3.4.4.6 Desktop and Self-Audits

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
In certain circumstances (outbreaks, audit postponed...), EGYPTAIR conducts desktop (remote)
audits, self-audits, and audit questionnaires instead of on-site planned audits. The team leader will
ensure that the audit has the adequate resources, internet connections, and software applications
to perform these audits. Audit notifications and checklists will be provided to the auditee, and all
desktop and self-audits will be properly recoded.

3.4.5 QAP Personnel Responsibilities

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
EGYPTAIR is committed to maintaining safety and quality, emphasizing each employee's
responsibility for evaluating policies, systems, Processes, and procedures, also to promptly and
openly communicate concerns to appropriate management personnel. The QAP is designed to
formalize EGYPTAIR dedication to safety and quality and to ensure that the CEO is actively involved
in safety and quality issues.

3.4.6 QAP Processes

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
3.4.6.1 Introduction

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
QAP is performed through data collection, inspections, site surveys, service providers
auditing, oversight, internal audits, desktop audits, self-assessment questionnaire
investigations, and corrective action, EGYPTAIR electronic database is the Aviation Quality
Database “AQD” system and/or CAR Log;
QAP is conducted to provide systematic and independent comparisons of how operations are
performed against established standards or procedures.
3.4.6.2 Audit Planning and Scheduling Process

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The G.M. Safety, Quality & Standardization and the Quality Assurance manager are responsible for:

Planning, preparing, and notifying concerned departments of planned audits under the QAP.
The audit report referenced below will serve to verify that the audit is:
a. Completed and detailed;
b. Directed;
c. Credible and recognized by Senior Management.
Planned audit focusing on all areas within EGYPTAIR will be performed at least once a year.
During the last two months of each calendar year, an audit Plan for the upcoming calendar
year will be prepared and documented in an audit plan that contains the area being audited
as well as the audit scope. The audit planning process is a major part of the Quality Assurance
Program that aids in fulfilling its objectives as stated in item 3.4.3 Program Policies.
After preparing the audit plan, it is sent to the CEO for approval.

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The G.M. Safety, Quality & Standardization and the Quality Assurance manager ensures QAP:

Conducted through systematic data collection, following these guidelines:

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
EGYPTAIR safety, quality, and standardization GD conducts audits on its internal activities,

3.4.6.5 Sampling Technique Procedure

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Auditors often use sampling as a technique to analyze evidence and information. Auditors
need to understand that sampling is just one tool in their evaluation process;
Samples provide approximations and should be used alongside common sense, good
judgment, and experience. When the results from sampling are combined with a checklist, any
deficiencies identified can be assessed as either isolated incidents or as indicators of
weaknesses in management controls. The audit team will randomly select samples for this
purpose.
3.4.6.6 Selection of Auditors Procedure

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The number of auditors at EGYPTAIR is adequate to ensure the timely completion of planned
audits;
A list of internal auditors will be prepared and approved by the General Manager of Safety,
Quality, and Standardization;
Selected auditors will be competent, objective, trustworthy, and impartial, in accordance with
Chapter 12 Rules of the Air ;
Selected Auditors will be operationally independent and will not audit their work areas.
3.4.6.6.1 Audit Team Selection

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
G.M. Safety, Quality & Standardization / Quality Assurance Manager will take into the
following considerations when selecting the audit team:
a. Audit scope and objectives;
b. Auditor conflict of interest.
i. A conflict of interest arises if the auditor:
1) Has worked at the company being audited within the previous two years; or
2) Is auditing a company with which a family member or close relative is affiliated
and could influence or benefit from the outcome of the audit.
ii. The auditor must inform the quality department of a conflict of interest;
iii. The auditor shall not disclose or use any confidential information including
documents and information that access may be given to before, during, or after an
audit or about the company without the explicit permission of the owner. All
auditors are subject to non-disclosure, ethics, and business conduct requirements.
c. Size of the department or station to be audited;
d. Previous audit history of the department or outstation to be audited, if known;
e. Cultural environment and language spoken;

3.4.6.7 Conducting an Audit Process

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
3.4.6.7.1 Audit Preparation

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The selected Audit team will accomplish the following items necessary to prepare the audit:

Collect and review the applicable Checklists Appendixes, ECARs, manuals/procedures, and
most current Internal Audit associated with the area to be audited; and build up the audit on
the AQD system;
Setup preliminary briefing to notify the audited department with:
a. Introduction of the internal audit process;
b. Planned audit scope;
c. Scheduled time frame to accomplish the audit;
d. Required procedural documents.
3.4.6.7.2 Utilizing the Checklist

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The purpose of a Checklist is to provide the team leader/ auditor with guidance to conduct an
audit for all departments/activities within EGYPTAIR that exist in checklists.
The QAP is structured to schedule audits of specific divisions departments within EGYPTAIR,
the items of the Checklist will contain a reference that should be reviewed by the team
leader/auditor and an EGYPTAIR Manual reference that specifies a process or procedure.
The auditor will proceed with the planned audit. Evidence and information are collected
through the use of updated checklists and interviews with key individuals in the audited area.
QAP evaluates the oversight of technical, safety and security related, and other areas. An
auditor may accomplish this through the use of a checklist. A checklist denotes points to be
checked and assists the auditor in determining the correct order in which to proceed during
an audit and is utilized during the collection of information and evidence.
The team leader attempts to analyze or evaluate the assigned topic. Thus, the team leader can
verify current compliance and is also able to evaluate the effectiveness of identified controls
that ensure long-term compliance.
The accomplishment of auditor actions is necessary to ensure internal auditors gather the
necessary evidence to determine whether (or not) a standard is documented and
implemented by the auditee.

3.4.6.7.3 Opening Meeting

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The team leader is responsible for conducting this meeting by using a presentation format, either
projected or opening/closing meeting Form, and shall address the following:

Introduction of members of the Audit Team and representatives of the Auditee including

Audit objective;
Scope of the Audit;

auditee; (paper /electronic report and/or using AQD system) refer to AQD system;

3.4.6.7.4 Finding Classifications

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Non-Conformities/ Non-compliance
a. Those are generated against a specific standard, regulation, company procedure, or SOP
according to the applicable checklist.
b. Based on objective evidence discovered during the audit.
c. Discussed with the Auditee during the Audit in an attempt to achieve agreement.
d. Discussed and agreed with the Audit Team members.
e. Documented along with supporting objective evidence.
Observations and / or Recommendation / Opportunity for Improvement (OFI)
a. Observations are isolated non-fulfillment of a specific requirement (e.g., typo, missing
word, etc.).
b. Recommendation / Opportunity for Improvement (OFI) are offered as potentially
beneficial feedback and an opportunity to improve performance and does require
corrective action from the auditee.
NOTE For Observations and Recommendations / Opportunities for Improvement (OFI), are
presented in the audit report.

b. Complete destruction of (aircraft/facility / equipment....);
c. Poses hazard to operational safety;
d. A revocation, or suspension of a certificate or an approval (provisions of the Civil

approval ECAA rules);
e. One or multiple fatalities resulting from injury.
f. Occupational illness spread;
g. Up to one-week shutdown of operations;
h. Aircraft grounded with flight cancellation or flight delay of greater than 2 days.
Non-Conformity / Non-Compliance CAT2 (Medium Risk), which leads to:
a. A deficiency (or deficiencies) in the organization's Management system;
b. Possibility of hazard to operational safety;
c. Potential effect on a certificate or an approval (provisions of the Civil Aviation Law, the
organization's certification requirements/conditions, terms of license/approval ECAA
rules) without restrictions to operations (issue a corrective action notice relating to
Regulatory noncompliance);
d. Affecting the capability of the management system to achieve its intended results;
e. Non-fatal injury that results in a person being unfit to perform his work.
f. Partial shutdown of operations;
g. Aircraft grounded with significant delay (Flight delay of 4 - 8 hours).
Non-Conformity CAT1 (Low Risk), which leads to:
A deficiency (or deficiencies) that requires attention.
Not affecting the capability of the management system to achieve its intended results;
Any near Miss not affecting work performance and not affecting daily life activities;
No disruption to operations;
No flight delays or less than 60 minutes’ flight delay.
NOTE The Quality Department will review the non-conformities/non- compliance listed in the
CAR Log annually. If there are more than three repeated non-conformities/non-
compliance classified as Category 2 (CAT 2) or more than five repeated non-
conformities classified as Category 1 (CAT 1) related to the same requirement or issue,
the non- conformity/non-compliance will be escalated to a higher category as per the
escalation policy. In this case, the "stop and fix" approach will not apply. The Quality
Department will decide on each case and will be presented in the Management Review
(MR) as significant issues.

3.4.6.7.6 Corrective Action Request (CAR)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
3.4.6.7.6.1 General

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The CAR shall be raised to initiate the corrective action for departments. The non-
conformities/non-compliance shall be reviewed with the Department Manager. All non-
conformity will be categorized based on risk level and shall be closed within the stipulated
days after the audit;
The appropriate completion date will be determined based on the deadlines outlined in the
CAP/FAT table and the escalation policy (refer to OM-G). If there is a need for corrective
action that is beyond the control of the department manager, a mutually agreed-upon
completion date will be established. In case of disagreements between the team leader or
auditor and the department manager, the issue will be referred to the General Manager of
Safety, Quality, and Standardization, who will make the final decision;
The Department Manager shall oversee and verify the implementation of the corrective action
to be taken within agreed timelines. Otherwise, an escalation policy will be applied;
Time extension requests are done through CAR /email to the Quality department. Extensions
are only granted on a case-to-case basis under the jurisdiction of G.M. Safety, Quality &
Standardization;
The following process shall be followed in regard to corrective action when weaknesses,
failures, and non-conformities are detected during monitoring activities:
The auditor/person responsible will issue a corrective action request for the auditee/
process owner in the following cases:
a. Non-conformities/non-compliance resulted from internal audits.
b. Customer complaints.
c. Process failure to achieve its target.
d. Increase opportunities/risk.
e. Legal or legislation requirements.
f. Repetitive defect resulting from an inspection.
g. An accident or incident.
h. Ineffectiveness of the existing/registered corrective action requests for the
nonconformity.
i. Any non-conformity/non-compliance that arises from QAP which is considered an
operational safety hazard will be identified & handled as a safety issue.
The auditee/ person responsible shall conduct Root Cause Analysis (RCA) for the non-
conformity to determine the main reason(s) of the issue (refer to next 3.4.6.7.6.2 Root
Cause Analysis (RCA) ).
The auditee/person responsible will determine the corrective actions regarding the
nonconformities noted through the corrective action plan (CAP) as follows:
a. Determination of Root Cause(s);
b. Description of the planned action/s to close the nonconformity;
c. The person responsible for implementing the corrective action;
d. The target date for closure for each action.

3.4.6.7.6.2 Root Cause Analysis (RCA)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Root Cause Analysis is a method that is used to get the main reason(s) of the non-conformity.
It is used so that we can correct or eliminate the cause, and prevent the non-conformity of
recurring. Also, it’s an in-depth process or technique to identify the most basic factor(s) that
cause a variation in the performance (non-conformity);
Root Cause Analysis (RCA) Objectives:
To innovate;
To improve processes;
To solve problems;
To standardize.
Implementing a uniform Root Cause Classification across all audit programs, aims to
standardize the classification system including guidance on accurate identification, allowing
better and more accurate identification and recording of root causes;
Categories have been identified (according to IATA Root Cause Classification); each IATA
Category has been divided into several Sub- categories, also each Sub-categories has been
reflected to the 6 M Module;
The Auditee identifies the relevant category of (17) IATA Categories or 6 M Module
Categories, and then selects the applicable Sub-category (Using the CAR Form that is
included Root Cause Classification through drop list).

A conflict of interest becomes evident.

3.4.6.8.2 Audit Reporting Procedures, follow up and Notifications:

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The auditee after receiving the Corrective action request will complete the Corrective action
plan including (root cause and corrective action plan) in the time period according to the
deadlines for CAP/FAT & escalation policy from the date of issuing audit report to issue the
corrective actions plan which forwarded to the team leader/ auditor;
The team leader/auditor will review the proposed corrective actions in 5 working days for
adequacy and appropriateness. and will forward the approved plan to the auditee to
complete the final action/s;
The auditee will complete the final action taken with supporting evidence for each action
according to the proposed action plan with supporting evidence according to approved due
dates for each action;
If the team leader/auditor accept, the final action taken and supporting evidence to ensure
the effectiveness of each action taken, it will be forwarded to the corrective action section to
evaluate the CAR;
Quality assurance department, analyze and double-check for the effectiveness of corrective
action and its root causes and reviews the data completed;
The quality assurance department will crosscheck and analyze regularly, as minimum to
identify:
a. Repetitive trends, weaknesses, and their root cause(s);
b. Monitoring auditors’ performance.
The result of such analysis needs to be regularly provided to all auditors, particularly;
Repetitive inconsistencies, which should also include correct examples and methods, to
prevent re-occurrences of the same inconsistencies;
The Auditor monitoring and evaluation procedure is focused on the proper completion of the
CAR. Any discrepancy raised during the evaluation procedure and all corrections performed
by the Team Leaders/Auditors will be recorded and tracked in the Evaluation Form and will be
completed after receiving the completed CAR and final audit report;
If the team leader/auditor refuses the proposed corrective action, the Response to Corrective
Actions Plan is reported to the G.M. Safety, Quality & Standardization;
The G.M. Safety and Quality will review and forward the Rejected Corrective Actions Plan to
Division / Department Management for further adjustment of corrective actions and send it
again to G.M. Safety, Quality & Standardization;
The Quality assurance department will send notifications in according to the deadlines for
CAP/FAT & Escalation policy;

3.4.7 IOSA Internal Evaluation Program (IEP)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
This program is implemented by the Holding Company (by a delegation from the CEO) in
accordance with the latest IAH (IOSA Audit Handbook) Instructions and while using the latest
effective ISM Edition (IOSA Standards Manual) to include auditing od all IOSA standards and
recommended practices (ISARP’s) once during 24 months (period of IOSA registration).
The Holding Company prepares and issues the Conformance Report (CR) which is then
certified by the CEO. The CR records all required information which includes the following:
a. Completed and signed Declaration of internal assessment completion;
b. Record of internal auditors who were assigned for this audit;
c. Operational profile of the company;
d. List of document references;
e. Information that is specific to the audit of each individual IOSA standard and
recommended practice to include:
i. The alpha-numeric identifier;
ii. Appropriate documentation reference(s);
iii. Auditors name(s) for each IOSA section;
iv. Audit date(s);
v. Auditor actions accomplished by auditor(s) to assess implementation;
vi. If applicable, a description of non-conformance(s); and:
- The root cause(s) of non-conformance(s);
- The corrective action(s) implemented to address nonconformance(s).

4.1 FLIGHT DECK CREW COMPOSITION

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
4.1.1 Minimum Flight Deck Crew

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
For all flights, the number and composition of the Flight Deck Crew at designated crew stations
shall not be less than the minimum specified in the specific type OM Part B.

For each flight, EGYPTAIR shall designate a suitably qualified Pilot as a Commander and at least
one other qualified Pilot as a second in command.

NOTE A Pilot qualified as a Commander may act as a First Officer, see Chapter 5
Qualification Requirements.
The Flight Deck Crew shall include additional Flight Deck Crew Members, when required by the
type of operation as specified in the Operations Manual.

All Flight Deck Crew must hold applicable and valid licenses, acceptable to the Authority and be
suitably qualified and competent to conduct the duties assigned to them.

A Flight Deck Crew Member that has attained 60 years of age, can maintain contract with
EGYPTAIR, after fulfilling all ECAA requirements for up to a maximum age of 65.

NOTE For procedures required for contracting over 60 years of age, refer to Human
Resources Department.
NOTE Only one of the Flight Deck Crew will be over 60 years of age.
NOTE Such Crew Member shall not be allowed to exceed a maximum of 75% of required
accumulative flying hours during any consecutive days as mentioned in Chapter
7.5.11 Accumulative Duty and Flying Hours.
EGYPTAIR shall establish procedures, acceptable to the ECAA, to prevent the crewing together of
inexperienced Flight Deck Crew Members.

A flight crew member who has attained the age of 60 years shall not act as a pilot of an aircraft
engaged in commercial air transport operations except as a member of a multi-pilot crew.

Only one flight Crew member over age 60 is allowed to act as PIC in single crew flight.

In Augmented/Double Crew flights, under all circumstances, only one flight crew member aged
over 60 is permitted to act as the operating PIC/SIC at any given time.

Flight crew with an operational medical limitation (OML) on their medical certificate shall only
operate aircraft in multi-pilot operations when the other pilot is fully qualified on the relevant type
of aircraft, is not subject to an operational medical limitation (OML) and has not attained the age
of 60 years.

A flight crew member who has attained the age of 65 years shall not act as a pilot of an aircraft
engaged in commercial air transport operation.

4.1.2 Relief of Flight Deck Crew Member In-flight

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
When, in accordance with company policy or the provisions of Chapter 7 Flight Time
Limitations , a member of the Flight Deck Crew requires in-flight relief from duty, the following
rules must be observed:

The Commander, the First Officer and the third Crew Member, will only occupy the seat to
which they are normally assigned and qualified;
The Commander may be relieved, only by another Pilot who is qualified to occupy the left
hand seat, or by a Pilot who is qualified in accordance with the provisions of the OM Part D
and nominated by the company to be a PIC;
A cruise relief First Officer may not be at the controls except with the Pilot qualified to be
Commander, or the nominated PIC;
A cruise relief First Officer may not, under normal circumstances be, or remain at the
controls below FL200.
NOTE The aeroplane Commander must be at the controls for take-off and landing.
NOTE The responsibility for the safety of the flight may not be transferred except in the event
of the Commander’s incapacitation.
4.1.3 Pairing of Inexperienced Flight Crew Members

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Flight operations have established the following procedures to prevent the crewing together of
inexperienced Flight Crew Members.

A Flight Crew Member is inexperienced, following completion of a type rating or command course,
and the associated line flying under supervision, until he has achieved on the type either:

100 flying hours and flown 10 sectors within a consolidation of 120 consecutive days; or
150 flying hours and flown 20 sectors (no time limit).
NOTE A lesser number of flying hours or sectors may be possible after acceptance, by the
Authority, if a Flight Crew Member has previously completed a type conversion course
with the operator.
4.1.3.1 Criteria for Flight Deck Crew Category

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
CAT C: Pilots with less than 100 flying hrs;
CAT B: After completion of 100 flying hrs;
CAT A: After completion of 300 flying hrs and after fleet review;
For long-range flights, Pilots are upgraded from CAT B to CAT A after passing all route
required flight checks;
Chief Pilots are responsible for issuing a monthly Crew Category List update, unless an earlier
update is required; only in case of Pilot category downgrade, the scheduling department has
to be immediately notified;

4.2 DESIGNATION OF THE COMMANDER

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
For all flights a Commander shall be designated by EGYPTAIR. The handling of an aeroplane or
conduct of flight may be delegated by the Commander to another suitable qualified Pilot.

The term "Commander" (replacing the term "Captain" and modifying the term "PIC/Pilot-in-
Command) denominates the Flight Deck Crew Member holding overall responsibility for the
aeroplane, its crew, its passengers and its load for the duration of flight.

EGYPTAIR will nominate a Flight Crew Member as Commander, only if he meets the minimum
qualification requirements laid down in Chapter 4.2.1 Route and Aerodrome Competence and
Chapter 5 Qualification Requirements.

One of the Flight Deck Crew Members shall be clearly designated by EGYPTAIR as the Commander
of the flight. This is of particular importance for determining the chain of command within the
Flight Crew.

If more than one Flight Crew Member holds the qualification of Commander (being so nominated
by EGYPTAIR), one shall be designated as the Commander of the flight.

NOTE The other active pilot with the qualification of a commander will be defined on the
roster with SIC as per chief pilot designation
Generally, the Flight Crew Member designated as Commander, shall occupy the left Pilot seat with
the following exceptions:

Flight Crew Members who have not carried out at least three take-offs and three landings as Pilot
flying in an aeroplane or an approved flight simulator, in the preceding 90 days, shall, prior to
being assigned as Commander, be given a refresher training course as specified in Chapter 5
Qualification Requirements and the OM Part D.

Whenever two Flight Crew Members with the qualification to act as Commander are scheduled as
active Pilots, Commanders with right hand seat qualification occupying the right Pilot seat, should
under normal conditions not act as PF during take-off and landing.

NOTE For augmented or double crew composition or If more than one Flight Crew Member
holds the qualification of Commander, fleet Chief Pilots designate the PIC of the flight.
NOTE (MS) on the Roster will define which crew is the Operating Crew while (*) defines all
other crew members assigned to the flight e.g. In-flight Cruise Relief, DHC, Positioning
etc.

4.3 SUCCESSION OF COMMAND IN CASE OF COMMANDER

INCAPACITATION
Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew Composed of 2 Pilots:

The Second Pilot takes the authority over all persons onboard the aircraft, until the normal chain of
command can be re-established, refer to Chapter 4.3.1 Chain of Command.

Flight Deck Crew Composed of More than 2 Pilots:

The Second Pilot takes the authority over all persons onboard the aircraft until a more qualified
Pilot (if any) takes the authority after having been informed by the Second Pilot and having
acknowledged the overall situation and this until the normal chain of command can be re-
established, refer to Chapter 4.3.1 Chain of Command.

NOTE The remaining crew may ask for assistance to perform the necessary duties on the
flight deck. This may include any other Crew Members, which the remaining crew
considers qualified or even deadhead Flight Deck Crew Member traveling as
passengers in the cabin.
4.3.1 Chain of Command

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
The chain of command will be in the following order:

Commander;
Safety Pilot, if carried;
F/O;
Third Pilot, if carried;
Purser/SCC;
Other Cabin Crew according to seniority.
NOTE Commanders (USV) have priority over F/Os, while Safety Pilots have priority over
Commanders in (IOE).
Cabin crew seniority is determined according to the sequence number stated In the flight's check-
in list which is printed from the flight operations system and is not related to work positions on-
board.

4.3.2 Incapacitation Reporting

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
An Air Safety Report shall be filled in case of Flight Deck Crew incapacitation.

4.3.5 Relief of Cabin Crew Members

4.3.6 Minimum Number of Cabin Crew to be Onboard an Aeroplane

During Operations
Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The minimum number of Cabin Crew that has to be present in the cabin during flight operations is
mentioned in Chapter 4.3.3.1 Minimum Cabin Crew.

During passengers embarkation, disembarkation, or when passengers remain on board during
transit stops, the number of Cabin Crew on board might be fewer than the number required for
dispatch, provided that:

The number of Cabin Crew on board is at least half the number required for dispatch,
rounded up to the next higher number in case of fractions;
Electrical power is available on the aircraft;
At least one exit remains open to provide for the deplaning of passengers and Cabin Crew
remain aware of the position of servicing and loading vehicles at and near the exits;
A mean of initiating an evacuation is available to the SCC and at least one Flight Deck Crew
Member is present in the flight deck; and
The pre-boarding cabin checks/briefing should have been completed.
4.3.7 Minimum Number of Female Cabin Crew

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
At least 30% with a minimum of two shall be a female. Waiver can be granted by a management
decision from the G.M. Flight Operations or the G.M. IOCC or their representatives to dispatch the
flight without fulfilling this requirement, e.g. (Duty manager).

4.4 OPERATION ON MORE THAN ONE TYPE / VARIANT

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
A Flight Deck Crew Member operating more than one type or variant must comply with all of the
requirements prescribed in Chapter 5 Qualification Requirements.

For Cabin Crew operation, aeroplane variants are considered to be different types, if they are not
similar in all the following aspects:

Emergency exit operation;
Location and type of safety equipment; and
Emergency procedures.
4.4.1 Flight Deck Crew Scheduling

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Crew Scheduling will ensure that in any one duty period, only aeroplanes within one type/variant
rating shall be flown by a Flight Deck Crew Member qualified to operate more than one type/
variant.

4.4.2 Cabin Crew Scheduling

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Each Cabin Crew Member is allowed to operate on more than one aeroplane types upon company
operational needs.

5.1 GENERAL

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
This chapter contains a description of the required licenses, ratings, qualifications, experience,
courses, training, checking and recency required for operational personnel to conduct their duties.

The minimum requirements for employment and promotion will be specified by the Flight Training
Department, according to the operations of EGYPTAIR and in accordance with ICAO and ECAA
regulations.

All training and checking programs are specified in EGYPTAIR ’ Training Manual (OM Part D) and/
or Safety Manual (OM Part F), and are approved by the ECAA.

5.1.1 Introduction

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
EGYPTAIR ensures candidates, prior to being employed as Flight Deck Crew Members, are
screened for the purpose of determining if they possess the requisite certifications, skills,
competencies or any other attributes required by EGYPTAIR/ECAA.

Such process, as a minimum, will include reviewing of and/or assessing:

Credentials and licenses and aviation experience; checking the aviation license, type rating,
flying hours, etc. age to be determined in accordance with company needs and ECARS
requirements;
Candidates must hold at least commercial pilot license issued by ECAA;
Common language fluency. ICAO English language at least level 4;
Medical fitness; must hold a valid class 1 medical issued by ECAA;
Security background; security screening according to state authorities;
Interpersonal skills; to be assessed through the interview;
Technical and Non-Technical competencies and skills; to be assessed during the ABC course
and type rating training.
5.1.2 English Language

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The English language is one of the common languages for all EGYPTAIR Crew Members.

All Crew Members must be able to demonstrate their ability to read and understand those parts of
the Operations Manual, which pertain to their duties and responsibilities. All communications
between Crew Members should be in the English language.

NOTE For more details, see Chapter 14.3.3 Common Language.
5.1.3 Crew Resource Management (CRM) / Threat and Error Management

(TEM) Training
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
CRM/TEM is the effective utilization of all available resources, (e.g. crew members, aircraft systems
and supporting facilities) to achieve safe and efficient operations.

CRM/TEM training will be provided as training for crew members and dispatchers, the training

5.1.4 Safety Management System (SMS)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In general terms, a Safety Management System (SMS) is a system focused on improving safety
performance by combining and integrating planning, implementation and review processes with
the management of organizational and consultative arrangements. Safety Management System
(SMS) training is required for all Crew Members.

5.2.1.1 First Officer

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
A First Officer is a Flight Deck Crew member acting in accordance with the duties and
responsibilities specified in Chapter 1.5 Duties and Responsibilities of the First Officer , or any
other piloting capacity other than a PIC or a Commander. The First Officer occupies the right hand
pilot seat.

According to EGYPTAIR needs, First Officer are nominated only after meeting the following
requirements and passing the selection process.

5.2.1.1.1 First Officer Minimum Qualification Requirements

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
Valid ECAA CPL, ATPL or Frozen ATPL;
Instrument rating;
A valid Class 1 medical certificate issued by the ECAA;
Crew must attain a Language proficiency ICAO level 4 or above.
5.2.1.2 Commander

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
According to EGYPTAIR needs, Pilots are nominated as Commanders in seniority order, after
meeting the minimum requirements and completing the pre-command simulator check, refer to
OM Part D, Chapter 6.

5.2.1.2.1 Minimum Qualification Requirements

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
Maximum of 55 years of age;
Minimum of 4.000 hours;
Satisfactory completion of 2 consecutive recurrent proficiency checks with no S1 to be
eligible for conducting command course and pre command Simulator check (LOFT);
Successful completion of the Command Course as specified in the OM Part D;
Successful completion Pre Command Simulator check as specified in the OM Part D;
An Airline Transport Pilot License;
A valid Class 1 medical certificate issued by the ECAA;
Crew must attain a Language proficiency ICAO level 4 or above.

5.2.1.3 English Language Proficiency

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Pilots who are required to use radio-telephony aboard an aircraft, shall be evaluated by the
AOC holder for their ability to speak and understand the English language as used for
radiotelephony communications:
This evaluation will be accomplished before initial assignment to duty and at the intervals
specified in item (2);
The evaluation results will be recorded.
Pilots assigned to Flight Deck Crew duties, will be evaluated to ensure that they can
communicate together, in English, at the Operational Level (Level 4);
Those persons demonstrating proficiency below the Expert Level (ICAO Language
Proficiency Level 6), shall be formally evaluated at least once every;
3 calendar years, for Operational Level (Level 4);
6 calendar years, for Extended Level (Level 5).
NOTE Formal evaluation is not required on recurring intervals for persons who demonstrate
expert language proficiency (Level 6), (e.g. native and very proficient non-native
speakers with a dialect or accent intelligible to the international aeronautical
community), during the initial evaluation.
5.2.1.4 Qualification to Operate in Either Pilot Seats

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
Commanders who are scheduled/rescheduled by EGYPTAIR to operate in the right-hand seat and
carry out the duties of a First Officer, or Commanders required to conduct training or examining
duties from the right-hand seat, shall complete additional training and checking from the right
hand seat specified in OM Part D, Chapter 6.

NOTE The checking must be re-validated during proficiency checks, additionally, the checks
required for operating in the left hand-pilot seat must be valid and current.
5.2.1.5 Route and Aerodrome Competence Qualification

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22

route to be flown and of the aerodromes, including alternates, facilities and procedures to be used
as specified in OM Part D, Chapter 1.

This route/area and aerodrome knowledge shall be maintained by operating at least once on the
route/area or to the aerodrome within a 12-month period.

Route/Area competence training will include knowledge of:

Terrain and minimum safe altitudes;

5.2.2.3 Flight Training

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight training is structured to be sufficiently comprehensive as to familiarize the Flight Deck Crew
thoroughly with all aspects of limitations and normal operation of the aircraft, including the use of
all flight deck equipment and all abnormal and emergency procedures.

Suitably qualified instructors, nominated by the training department, will carry out flight training.

For specialized operations such as EDTO, additional training will be provided.

Generally, the same training and practices given to Commanders will be given to the F/Os. The
flight handling sections of the syllabus for Commanders and F/O’s will include all the requirements
of the appropriate proficiency check.

During flight training, particular emphasis will be placed on the practice of Line Oriented Flight
Training (LOFT), Crew Resource Management (CRM) and the use of correct crew coordinated
procedures, including coping with Flight Deck Crew members incapacitation.

If the training program has been carried out in an appropriate flight simulator, and in a manner
approved for Zero Flight Time conversions, the training required may include an element of
proficiency training on an aircraft, including at least three take-off and landings.

5.2.2.4 Differences Training

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew must complete differences training:

Before operating another variant of an aircraft of the same type or another type of the same
class currently operated; or

5.2.2.5 Recurrent Training and Checking

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew must undergo recurrent training and checking for re-validation of the type rating
combined with the re-validation of the instrument rating. The training and checking must be
relevant to the type on which the Flight Deck Crew is certificated to operate.

The recurrent training and checking programs for Flight Deck Crew are established in the OM Part
Dand approved by the ECAA.

Recurrent training shall comprise:

Ground and refresher training;
Aircraft/Flight simulator training;
Emergency and safety equipment training; and
CRM/TEM training.
The following personnel conduct recurrent training:

Aircraft/Flight simulator training: Type Rating Check Airman /Examiner, refer OM Part D
Chapter 2;
Emergency and safety equipment training and checking: suitably qualified personnel; and
CRM/TEM training: suitably qualified personnel.
Recurrent checking shall comprise:

Proficiency checks;
Emergency and safety equipment checks; and
Line checks.
The following personnel conduct recurrent checking:

EGYPTAIR proficiency checks: Type Rating Examiner or Check Airman; and
Line checks: Type Rating Examiner or Check Airman.
According to the period of validity, Flight Deck Crew shall undergo the following recurrent training
and checking within Twelve months:

Simulator training, consisting of two sessions, every six months, day one for recurrent
training and day two for proficiency check;
Line check; and
Emergency and safety equipment training and checking.
Additional training conducted from the right hand seat shall include a minimum of three Touch
and Go, including the following items:

An engine failure during take-off;
One engine inoperative approach and go-around;
One engine inoperative landing.

5.2.2.6 Simulator Training

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Flight simulator training program shall be established, such that all major failures of aircraft
systems and associated procedures have been covered.

5.2.2.7 Route/Area and/or Aerodrome Competence Training

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Route/Area and/or Aerodrome competence training will include knowledge of:

Terrain and minimum safe altitudes;
Meteorological, communication and air traffic facilities, services and procedures;
Search and rescue procedures;
Navigational facilities associated with the area or route along which the flight is to take
place;
Obstructions, physical layout, lighting, approach aids, arrival, departure, holding, instrument
approach procedures, ground movement considerations and applicable operating minima;
Environmental knowledge related to the prevention of aeroplane upsets.
Depending on the complexity of the area or route/aerodrome, the following methods of
familiarisation is used:

For less complex areas or route/aerodromes, familiarisation through self-briefing with route
documentation, or through programmed instruction;
For more complex areas or routes/aerodromes, in addition to the items above:
In-flight familiarisation as a Commander or First Officer under supervision, observer; or
Familiarisation in a flight simulation training device (FSTD) using a database appropriate to
the route concerned.
Aerodrome competence qualification includes knowledge of obstructions, physical layout, lighting,
approach aids and arrival, departure, holding and instrument approach procedures, applicable
operating minima and.

For the more complex routes and/or aerodromes, in addition to the above, in-flight familiarization
as First Officer, observer or commander under supervision, or familiarization in an approved flight
simulator using a database appropriate to the route concerned.

Route and aerodrome competence qualifications are valid for a period of twelve calendar months
in addition to the reminder of:

The month of qualification; or
The month of the latest operation on the route or to the aerodrome.
Route competence may be re-validated by operating on the route within the previous period of
validity.

5.3.1.1 Cabin Crew Minimum Requirements

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A cabin crew member must:

Be at least 18 years old;
Have passed a medical examination or assessment and be medically fit to carry out cabin
crew duties;
Remain medically fit to discharge the duties specified in the OM Part A and Cabin Crew
Manual;
Have successfully completed initial training, including emergency and first aid training, and
the appropriate conversion course before operating as a cabin crew member;
Have completed recurrent training; and;
Be competent to perform his duties as specified in the OM Part A, OM Part F and Cabin
Crew Manual.
5.3.1.2 Senior Cabin Crew

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The Senior Cabin Crew must have at least one-year experience as an operating EGYPTAIR cabin
crew and have completed appropriate courses.

5.3.1.3 Cabin Crew During Familiarization Flights

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
After completion of transition training and prior to operating as one of the minimum required
cabin crew, a cabin crew shall undertake familiarization flights under the supervision of a cabin
crew instructor.

5.3.2 Cabin Crew Training

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Before undertaking assigned duties each cabin crew must have completed the appropriate training
as specified below and must have passed a check covering the training received in order to verify
proficiency in carrying out safety and emergency procedures.

5.3.2.1 Cabin Crew Initial Training (New Hire)

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
Initial training for Cabin Crew shall be successfully completed before starting transition training.

QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS
5.3 Cabin Crew Training and Qualification Requirements
OM A
5-3-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
It consists of:

Basic Indoctrination;
Emergency Training;
Aircraft Ground Training;
Aircraft Differences (if applicable);
Security;
CRM;
SMS.
The purpose of initial safety training for Cabin Crew is:

To familiarize them with dealing with emergencies, especially those involving fire and
smoke;
To ensure that they obtain the necessary skills and knowledge to deal with different types of
emergencies and survival situations, as well as to familiarize them with the emergency
equipment and its location;
To show the importance of effective communication between Flight Deck Crew and Cabin
Crew including techniques, common language and terminology;
To introduce cabin safety in general and in relation to their flying duties and the importance
of performing in accordance with the OM Part A;
To familiarize them with passenger management in general and to make them aware of
situations possibly arising on board.
During the course periodic written and aural tests monitors the trainee’s ground training progress.
The final test requires a pass mark of 70%.

Following completion of initial safety training, each cabin crew will undergo a check covering the
training received in order to verify their proficiency in carrying out safety and emergency duties.

5.3.2.2 A/C Transition Training

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Before undertaking assigned duties each cabin crew must have completed the appropriate
transition or differences training as specified in OM Part D.

Transition training must be completed before being assigned to operate another aircraft type.

The training includes the use of safety equipment and emergency procedures applicable to the
type or variant of an aircraft and involves training and practice on either a representative training
device or on the actual aircraft.

A review should be carried out, of previous initial safety training, in order to confirm that no item
has been omitted.

Following completion of training, each cabin crew will undergo a check covering the training
received in order to verify their competency in carrying out safety and emergency duties on the
aircraft type.

5.3.2.3 Differences Training

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A differences training must be completed before operating:

5.3.2.4 Recurrent Training

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Recurrent training is to ensure the competence of EGYPTAIR Cabin Crew and to comply with
the provisions of ECAA through the annual recurrent training on subjects related to efficient
and safe flight operations;
Recurrent Training will be performed on annual bases. The 12 calendar months recurrent
training program will be followed by the 24 calendar months recurrent training;
The 12 calendar months recurrent training program is to demonstrate their ability for
using the safety manual through an open book multiple choices exam;
The 24 calendar months recurrent training should include the emergency practical
training course which will be conducted for Cabin Crew every 24 calendar months. They
may practice the emergency drills jointly with Flight Deck Crew. They have to pass a ground
competency check following this training;
CRM, SMS and Joint Emergency training not exceeding 36 months;
Security recurrent course not exceeding 12 months.
5.3.2.5 Re-qualification Training

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
This training is for a Cabin Crew who has been trained and qualified by EGYPTAIR, but who has
become unqualified because of not receiving recurrent training and a competency check within
the appropriate eligibility period.

5.3.2.6 Types of Checks

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The Cabin Crew on board shall perform assigned duties under the supervision of a certified flight
Instructor / examiner Who personally observes the performance of these duties and carries out a
competency Check at the end of the training, as specified in the OM Part D.

The types of competency check lists are:
