6.1 Crew Health Precautions
OM A
6-1-1
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
6.1 CREW HEALTH PRECAUTIONS

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Crew Member’s sickness/illness, his feeling unwell/indisposed or the impairment of his senses and
reflexes by narcotics, drugs or pharmaceutical preparations/medicaments have quite often
contributed to incidents and accidents.

Therefore, crew health is of the highest importance and has a direct impact upon flight safety. This
is reflected in very stringent requirements for regular medical examinations and medical
certificates. It hardly needs to be mentioned that living a health-conscious life is in the self-interest
of every Crew Member.

A Crew Member shall not perform duties on an aeroplane if he knows or suspects that he is
suffering from fatigue or feels unfit to the extent that the flight may be endangered.

A Crew Member shall, without undue delay, seek the advice of an Aeromedical Examiner when
becoming involved in:

Hospital or clinic admission for more than 12 hours; or
Surgical operation or invasive procedure; or
Regular use of medication; or
Need for regular use of corrective lenses.
Crew Member whom are aware of:

Any significant personal injury involving incapacity to function as a member of Flight Deck
Crew; or
Any illness involving incapacity to function as a member of a Flight Deck Crew throughout a
period of 21 days or more; or
Being pregnant.
Shall inform the Authority in writing of such injury or pregnancy, and as soon as the period of 21
days has elapsed in the case of illness. The medical certificate shall be deemed suspended upon
the occurrence of such injury or the elapse of such period of illness or the confirmation of
pregnancy.

6.1.1 Alcohol and other Intoxicating Liquids

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A Crew Member shall not:

Consume alcohol less than 12 hours or within the same calendar day prior to the specified
reporting time for flight duty, or the commencement of stand-by duty period;
Commence a flight duty period with a blood alcohol level in excess of 0,2 permille which is
equivalent to 0,02 blood alcohol concentration (BAC);
Consume alcohol during the flight duty period or whilst on stand-by duty period.
NOTE Since the metabolism of alcohol in the blood is very slow, it is highly recommended
that Crew Members refrain from the consumption of alcohol 24 hours before the
expected commencement of flight or stand-by duty periods.
NOTE Alcohol combined with most types of medications is undesirable and dangerous.
CREW HEALTH PRECAUTIONS
6.1 Crew Health Precautions
OM A
6-1-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
It is EGYPTAIR’ policy that Crew Members, while in uniform, shall not consume alcoholic beverages
where they can be observed by third parties (e.g. the public).

6.1.2 Narcotics

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
For Crew Members, the consumption or use of narcotics is strictly prohibited, unless a medical
doctor has determined that such use is absolutely necessary in the interest of his patient’s health.
However, in such extremely rare cases, the concerned Crew Member shall commence flight duty
only if a duly appointed Aeromedical Examiner has certified that the physical and mental fitness for
such duty is not being impaired.

6.1.3 Use of Medication, Sleeping Tablets and other Treatments

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A Crew Member shall not perform any duties on an aeroplane while under the influence of any
medication, drug or any other treatment, which may affect his abilities in a manner contrary to
safety.

If you are taking any medicine you should ask yourself the following three questions:

Do I feel fit to fly?;
Do I really need to take medication at all?;
Have I given this particular medication a personal trial on the ground of at least 24 hours
before flight to ensure that it will not have any adverse effect on my ability to fly?.
Confirming the absence of adverse effects may need expert advice and the assistance of the AMS,
an AMC or an AME.

If you are ill and need treatment it is vitally important that the doctor whom you consult knows
that you are a member of an air crew and whether or not you have recently been abroad.

6.1.3.1 Drugs

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Crew Members shall not take any prescription or non-prescription medication or drug, or undergo
any other treatment, unless they are completely sure that the medication, drug or treatment will
not have any adverse effect on their ability to perform their duties safely. If there is any doubt,
advice shall be obtained from an Aeromedical Examiner.

6.1.3.2 Antibiotics

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Antibiotics may have short term or delayed side effects, which can affect Pilot’s performance. More
significantly, their use usually indicates that an infection is present and thus the effects of this
infection will normally mean that a Pilot is not fit to fly.

CREW HEALTH PRECAUTIONS
6.1 Crew Health Precautions
OM A
6-1-3
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
6.1.3.3 Tranquillizers Anti-depressants and Sedatives (Sleeping Tablets)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Inability to react due to the use of Tranquillizers, anti-depressants and sedatives has been a
contributory cause to fatal aircraft accidents. Again, as with antibiotics, the underlying condition
for which these medications have been prescribed will almost certainly mean that a Pilot’s mental
state is not compatible with the flying task.

6.1.3.4 Stimulants and Caffeine

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Stimulants such as caffeine, amphetamines, etc. used to maintain wakefulness or suppress appetite
are often habit forming. Susceptibility to different stimulants varies from one individual to another,
and all may cause dangerous over confidence. Overdosage causes headaches, dizziness and
mental disturbance.

Energy drinks or power booster etc. while flying is not permitted.

NOTE Excessive coffee drinking has harmful effects including disturbance of the heart’s
rhythm.
6.1.3.5 Anti-histamines

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Anti-histamines can cause drowsiness; they are widely used in ‘cold cures’ and in treatment of hay
fever, asthma and allergic rashes. They may be in tablet form or a component of nose drops or
sprays. In many cases the condition itself may preclude flying, so that, if treatment is necessary,
advice from the AMS, an AMC or an AME should be obtained so that modern drugs, which do not
degrade human performance, can be prescribed.

6.1.3.6 Anti-hypertensive

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Certain drugs used to treat high blood pressure can cause a change in the normal cardiovascular
reflexes and impair intellectual performance, both of which can seriously affect flight safety. If the
level of blood pressure is such that drug therapy is required the Pilot must be temporarily
grounded and monitored for any side effects. Any treatment instituted should be discussed with
the AMS, an AMC or an AME and a simulator assessment or line check may be appropriate before
flying.

6.1.3.7 Analgesics and Anesthetics (Pain Killers)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Following local, general, dental and other anesthetics, a period of time should elapse before flying.
The period will vary considerably from individual to individual, but a Pilot should not fly for at least
12 hours after a local anesthetic and for 48 hours after a general or spinal anesthetic.

The more potent analgesics may produce a significant decrement in human performance. If such
potent analgesics are required, the pain for which they are taken generally indicates a condition
which precludes flying.

CREW HEALTH PRECAUTIONS
6.1 Crew Health Precautions
OM A
6-1-4

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
6.1.3.8 Pharmaceutical Preparations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Many preparations are now marketed containing a combination of medicines. It is essential
therefore that if there is any new medication or dosage, however slight, the effect should be
observed by the Pilot on the ground prior to flying. Although the above are the commonest
medicines that adversely affect Pilot performance, it should be noted that many other forms of
medication, although not normally affecting Pilot performance, might do so in individuals who are
‘oversensitive’ to a particular preparation. Individuals are therefore advised not to take any
medicines before or during flight unless they are completely familiar with their effects on their own
bodies.

6.1.3.9 Psychoactive Substances

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Substances that can produce mood changes or distorted perceptions in humans, to include, but
not limited to, alcohol, opioids, cannabinoids, sedatives and hypnotics, cocaine, other psycho-
stimulants, hallucinogens and volatile solvents; coffee and tobacco are excluded.

Crew Members shall not exercise duties while under the influence of psychoactive substances.
Problematic use of psychoactive substances is prohibited. Any person who is identified as
engaging in any kind of problematic use of psychoactive substances will be removed from
operational functions.

6.1.3.10 Other Treatments

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Alternative or complementary medicine, such as acupuncture, homoeopathy, hypnotherapy and
several other disciplines, is developing and gaining greater credibility. Some such treatments are
more acceptable in some States than others. There is a need to ensure that "other treatments", as
well as the underlying condition, are declared and considered by the AMS, an AMC or an AME
when assessing fitness.

6.1.4 Testing for Psychoactive Substances

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Personnel employed by the Company will be tested for psychoactive substances in the following
cases:

Upon employment; and
With due cause in the following cases:
a. Following a reasonable suspicion, and following an assessment by appropriately
trained personnel; and
b. After a serious incident or accident.
After referral and assessment by the medical assessor of the licensing authority, the Company may
consider unannounced testing as part of a periodic medical follow-up for staff concerned after
rehabilitation and return to work.

6.1.4.1 Checks without Probable Cause for Alcohol, Drugs or Other

Psychoactive Substances for Flight Deck Crew Members
Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The Company is obligated to check, that no Flight Deck Crew member will fly a company aircraft
under the influence of alcohol, drugs or other psychoactive substances.

For this purpose, a certain quota of the pilots assigned for flight duty will be taken to a random
check related to alcohol, drugs or other psychoactive substances.

This check will be carried out under medical supervision.

Flight Deck Crew members who have been tested positive for alcohol or other psychoactive
substances or who refuse to be checked will be suspended from flight duty (shall be removed from
operational functions).

6.1.5 Immunization

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In accordance with the (WHO) International Health Regulations, many countries prescribe
vaccination of Crew Members and passengers against defined diseases, often specifying that such
immunization is only required upon entry "after leaving or transiting infected areas".

Each Crew Member scheduled for flight duty abroad must satisfy any requirement(s) for
vaccination(s), to have himself vaccinated in time, and to be able to produce, during his tour of
duty, the appropriate WHO-approved "Certificate of Vaccination or Revaccination".

Vaccination/revaccination shall take place not less than 24 hours before commencement of flight
duty; in case of strong reaction, medical advice shall be obtained in view of a possible impairment
of fitness for flight duty.

NOTE No alcoholic beverages shall be consumed for a period of at least 24 hours after
vaccination.
Vaccinations, which may be obligatory, and their validity:

Yellow fever (from 10 days after until 10 years after vaccination).
Vaccinations, which are recommended, and their validity:

Cholera (from 7 days until 6 months after vaccination);
Typhoid (from 7 days until 3 years after vaccination);
Poliomyelitis (after 3 vaccinations up to 10 years);
Tetanus (after 3 vaccinations up to 10 years);
Malaria prophylaxis, though not immunization in the strict sense of the word, should be
mentioned here: Crew Members scheduled for flight duty to malaria infected countries shall
obtain, on the advice of their aeromedical doctor, the appropriate medication and apply it
as prescribed.
CREW HEALTH PRECAUTIONS
6.1 Crew Health Precautions
OM A
6-1-6

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
NOTE Crew Members shall be aware of the fact that there are many extremely dangerous
diseases against which vaccination is not possible. Only general rules may be given
here for health-conscious behavior in foreign countries:
a) Observe strict hygiene in eating/drinking (amoebic dysentery, brucellosis);
b) Do not bathe in stagnant water (bilharziasis);
c) In infested (e.g. bush/jungle) areas, wear long-sleeved shirts and long trousers to
prevent or minimize bites by disease-carrying insects (filariasis, malaria,
encephalitis, sleeping sickness) or by outright poisonous insects or animals
(spiders, scorpions, snakes); use insect repellant.
6.1.6 Deep Sea Diving

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Crew Members whose sporting activities include deep sea diving to a depth exceeding 10 meters
shall not fly within 48 hours of completing such diving activity.

6.1.7 Blood / Bone Marrow Donation

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Crew members shouldn’t serve as a blood/bone marrow donors. If they have already done so for
any reason, they are required to promptly notify the company after the donation.

Furthermore, they shall refrain from performing any flight duties for at least 24 hours following the
donation. Prior to being assigned to flight duty, crew members must report an aeromedical doctor
for a hemoglobin check and blood count assessment.

Donation is strictly forbidden in the following cases:

When feeling unwell;
Presence of any infection (such as flu, sore throat, etc.);
Failure to meet the minimum hemoglobin level required for donation;
When under the influence of any medications (antibiotics);
When you have recently had a tattoo or body piercing you cannot donate for 6 months
from the date of the procedure;
When you have visited the dentist for a minor procedure you must wait 24 hours; for major
work wait a month.
NOTE Bone marrow donation by aspiration where a syringe is used to aspirate bone marrow
from the hip bone, may require longer recovery of up to 5 days. Crew members
should contact Aeromedical council for advice on fitness to fly after bone marrow
donation.

6.1.8 Meal Precautions Prior to and During Flight

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
To prevent the remote possibility of both pilots being incapacitated at the same time, it is
recommended that the PIC and other Flight Deck Crew do not eat the same meal and avoid certain
types of foods which are particularly liable to cause gastro-intestinal symptoms e.g. shellfish,
crustaceans, etc.

6.1.9 Sleep and Rest

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Flight safety requires that all Crew Members receive regular and sufficient sleep and are well rested
when commencing flight duty. Legal provisions, see Chapter 7 Flight Time Limitations , prescribe
maximum duty and minimum rest times. All Crew Members are expected to utilize their times of
rest to relax and to regain their fitness. Therefore, during rest times all activities shall be avoided
which run counter to those purposes.

6.1.10 Surgical Operations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A fitness certificate signed by an aeromedical doctor shall be produced prior to returning to flying
duties after any surgical procedure.

6.1.11 Pregnancy

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Every holder of a medical certificate shall inform the aero medical Center (AMC) of her pregnancy.

The medical certificate shall be deemed suspended upon confirmation of the pregnancy.

The Authority may lift the suspension of the medical certificate, subject to such conditions as it
Thinks fit, and shall cease upon the holder being medically examined under arrangements made
by The Authority upon approval of the AMC after the pregnancy has ended and being pronounced
fit to resume her function.

6.1.12 Corrective Lenses/Spectacles

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Each Flight Deck Crew Member assessed as fit to exercise the privileges of a license subject to the
use of suitable correcting lenses or spectacles shall use those lenses/spectacles or have them
immediately available when performing as a required Crew Member.

A spare set of the correcting spectacles shall be readily available when performing as a Crew
Member.

If near correction for distances other than those tested for the medical certificate are necessary for
visual flight deck tasks relevant to the types of aircraft in which the applicant is likely to function,
the Crew Member shall obtain and use such lenses in the medical evaluation.

6.1.13 Fatigue Precautions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Fatigue countermeasures can be divided into two categories:

Preventive Strategies (Used before work and during rest periods)
Preventive strategies are designed to minimize the sleep loss and circadian disruption
caused by work demands. They are aimed at the physiological causes of fatigue. Since the
effects of sleep loss are cumulative, it is important not to begin a work schedule or trip
pattern with an existing sleep debt. Therefore, try to get at least two nights of sufficient
sleep before a trip. On nights before or between duty days, try to get at least as much sleep
as you get on normal off-duty nights. Keep your regular home sleep schedule as much as
possible. If your duty schedule prevents you from getting that much sleep in a single sleep
period, try to sleep more than once (e.g. morning and evening) or to take naps.
Take advantage of times in the circadian cycle when it is easy to fall asleep (roughly
02:00-06:00 and 14:00-18:00, but this varies a bit depending on whether you are a
‘morning-type’ or an ‘evening-type’).
General Sleep Tips
If unable to sleep after 15 to 20 minutes in bed, get up and engage in a relaxing activity
(e.g. listening to music, reading). Return to bed when you feel sleepy; avoid watching the
clock;
Use relaxing imagery or thoughts to induce sleep.
Naps
Naps can acutely improve alertness and performance, and even short naps can provide
benefits. However, the duration of a nap is important because, if you enter deep NREM
(Non-Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, you may experience sleep inertia, a feeling of
grogginess, sleepiness and disorientation that can last for 20 to 30 minutes. To be on the
safe side, if you have a short nap opportunity just before work, or if you are likely to be
interrupted by a duty call, then limit the total time for napping to about 45 minutes or less.
At other times, longer naps can be beneficial, and two hours will normally allow for a
complete cycle through the different states and stages of sleep. A nap reduces the duration
of continuous wakefulness before a work period and can be particularly beneficial before a
period of night work when the challenge of working through the circadian low point is also
a factor. Getting some sleep is always better than none. Make sleep a priority over
sightseeing and recreational activities. Nap during circadian lows (02:00-06:00 and
14:00-18:00 body time).
Good Sleep Habits
Good sleep habits can help improve sleep quality on a regular basis at home and while on
trips. By practicing a regular pre-sleep routine, you can teach your body and mind that
certain activities mean that it is time to wind down and fall asleep. Once this pattern of cues
is established, it can be used anywhere and anytime. It may include such things as or
reading something relaxing and entertaining (not work-related). Also, various physical and
mental relaxation techniques can be learned and used in this way, such as meditation,
autogenic training, yoga and progressive muscle relaxation.
Sleep Environment
CREW HEALTH PRECAUTIONS
6.1 Crew Health Precautions
OM A
6-1-9
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Physical aspects of the environment can also affect sleep. A dark, quiet room is preferable.
Eye shades are a simple and portable solution to the problem of light. Earplugs can help by
reducing noise, but they must be used such that they do not interfere with a required
wake-up signal (such as an alarm clock or call for duty). Sudden sounds can disturb sleep,
and continuous background "white" noise can help mask such noises.
In general, sleep quality is better if the environment is cooler rather than warmer. A
comfortable sleep surface also can be important.
Effects of Food, Caffeine, Alcohol, Nicotine and Exercise
Food, caffeine, alcohol, nicotine and exercise shortly before sleep can affect the quantity
and quality of the sleep that you obtain.
The discomfort associated with being hungry or, conversely, with having eaten too much
may interfere with falling asleep. If you are hungry or thirsty at bedtime, have a light
snack or a small drink. In general, evidence that common foods significantly affect sleep
is not yet conclusive;
Both caffeine and alcohol have well documented disruptive effects on sleep. Caffeine
stimulates the nervous system, generally taking effect 15-30 minutes after ingestion and
remaining active for 3-4 hours. Caffeine can lead to lighter sleep with more awakenings
and reduced total sleep time;
Consider eliminating or minimizing caffeine intake at least three hours before bedtime.
Additionally, avoid caffeine when already alert;
Nicotine has much the same effects as caffeine on sleep and subsequent daytime
sleepiness and performance. As with caffeine, avoid nicotine for several hours before the
time you want to fall asleep. Nicotine is a stimulant and may inhibit sleep. Nicotine
withdrawal may cause sleep interruptions;
Alcohol can promote relaxation and thereby help a person fall asleep. However, with
moderate to excessive alcohol intake, sleep is easily disrupted. Alcohol suppresses REM
(Rapid Eye Movement) sleep in the first half of the night, leading to REM rebound and
withdrawal effects in the second half. Therefore, avoid drinking even moderate amounts
of alcohol 2-3 hours before sleeping;
There is evidence that regular exercise may enhance deep sleep and reduce the number
of brief awakenings during sleep, making it more restorative. However, strenuous exercise
results in physiological activation, which may interfere with sleep. Therefore, avoid
strenuous exercise at least three hours before going to bed; increased adrenaline and
body temperature make sleep more difficult.
Operational Strategies (Used during flight)
Operational strategies are designed to minimize the impact of sleep loss and circadian
disruption on alertness and on-the-job performance. They can temporarily relieve the
symptoms of fatigue to help get the job done as safely and efficiently as possible. Once on
the job, the range of available strategies to combat fatigue is more restricted. In most
commercial aviation operations, there is an additional constraint that Crew Members must
remain in their flight deck seats from take-off through landing, except for "physiological
need", which currently does not include sleep.
In general, operational countermeasures do not address the underlying physiological
causes of fatigue. Instead, they are meant to temporarily enhance alertness and
performance by masking fatigue so that operational safety and efficiency are maintained.

6.1 Crew Health Precautions

6-1-10

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Social Interaction Conversation and Environment
Interacting with others can be a useful operational strategy. To maintain alertness, it is
necessary to be actively involved in the conversation, not just listening and nodding. In fact,
a lack of conversation can be associated with declining physiological alertness. Keep the
flight deck temperature low and turn up the lights at night with due consideration given to
maintaining night vision.
Physical Activity
Physical activity is one of the most effective ways of combating sleepiness. Some stretching
and isometric exercises can be done in the flight deck seat. Almost any physical activity is
preferable to passivity.
Diet
Currently, there is no compelling evidence that specific types of food directly affect
alertness and performance. Candy or other "energy boosters" can produce a transient
increase in alertness (e.g. "sugar highs"), but this is frequently followed by a decrease in
alertness (sometimes suddenly) as blood glucose levels fall. Stomach upsets can be
disruptive to sleep, so maintaining a balanced diet is important. Also, drink plenty of water.
Dehydration causes fatigue.
NOTE Caffeine and Naps between multiple sectors are also operational strategies to
be used.
6.1.14 Fatigue Reporting Protocol

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
EGYPTAIR is committed to continually reduce the risk of fatigue.

To achieve this, a structured data collection process records when:

A flight crew is at risk of making a fatigue-related error (i.e., provided with insufficient sleep
opportunity within the schedule, actually obtained insufficient sleep, and/or exhibits fatigue
related symptoms);
Fatigue has been a contributing factor to a safety-related error and/or incident. Flight crew
are required to report all cases of fatigue-related risk, errors, and incidents to safety
department. The safety department will act accordingly, depending on the severity of the
case. This may include (but is not limited to) advising the employee to self-monitor
performance, allocating peer/ management supervision to the employee, task reassignment
or sending the employee home;
A confidential reporting database has been made available to all flight crew on the
company AQD system. The purpose of this database is to collect information on the
frequency that employees: are provided with insufficient sleep opportunity (due to overtime
or contingency situations); obtain insufficient sleep; exhibit fatigue-related symptoms; or
make a no consequence error that may have been fatigue-related. Although employees are
required to provide their name, the safety manager will only use this if more information is
required. The intent is purely data collection, and the information will not be used for
disciplinary purposes;
All reports of errors and incidents will be made using the existing SMS reporting framework
(refer to SMS policy document). During the error/incident investigation process, the
investigator may ask any flight crew involved to provide an accurate account of hours

6.1.15 BMI (Body Mass Index)

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
One of the main health risks for pilots is an unhealthy diet.

Obesity is linked to a number of chronic health conditions diabetes is one of the top 10 diseases
that causes longterm unfitness in professional pilots and is linked to diet and weight issues.

Healthy weight loss isn't about a diet or program, it is about lifestyle changes in daily eating and
exercise habits.

Overweight and obesity are defined as abnormal or
excessive fat accumulation that presents a risk to
health.
Below 18,5 BMI is considered Underweight, from 18,5
to 24,9 is considered Healthy Weight, from 25,0 to 29,9
is considered overweight and from 30 and above is
considered obese.
Maintaining a healthy weight is considered an essential
requirement for all EGYPTAIR crew members for safety
reasons, to stay in good shape and to maintain good
health.
CAUTION Pilots need to keep a healthy weight for safety reasons (escape in an emergency).
BMI = weight / height^2
(i.e) 95 KG / 1,86 m ×1.86 m= 95 / 3,46 = 27,4 BMI
If a Flight Deck crew member appears to be Obese (exceeding a BMI of 30) the Chief Pilot will
notify the Flight Deck crew member and schedule him for a follow up at EGYPTAIR Hospital with a
professional nutritionist to aid him in returning back to the specified BMI Limit.

NOTE For cabin crew members’ BMI limits and procedures refer to OM Part L.

6.3 DRUG, ALCOHOL AND PSYCHOACTIVE SUBSTANCES TESTING

PROGRAMS
Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Purpose

The purpose of this chapter is to establish programs designed to help prevent accidents and
injuries resulting from drugs, psychoactive substances and the misuse of alcohol by
employees who perform safety-sensitive functions in aviation;
This chapter has been issued in compliance with the ECAR part 121, sub-part O, Appendix I
and Appendix J to establish the following programs to be applied for all employees:
Drug, or Psychoactive Substances testing program;
Alcohol misuse prevention program.
Scope

Each employee who performs a safety-sensitive function directly within EGYPTAIR must be subject
to drug, alcohol and psychoactive testing in accordance with the Egyptian Law and ECAA approved
program.

The covered safety-sensitive functions are:

Flight Deck Crew Members;
Cabin Crew Members;
Aircraft Dispatchers;
Passenger/Baggage handling staff and Supervisors including but not limited to load control
and check-in, etc.;
Any other Personnel which may have direct relation with flight operations.
NOTE Drug and Alcohol program of affiliate (sister) companies or corporate sectors
performing safety sensitive functions for EGYPTAIR will be inspected during audits
performed on them.
Definitions

Annualized rate: for the purposes of unannounced testing of employees based on random
selection means the percentage of specimen collection and testing of employees
performing a safety-sensitive function during a calendar year. EGYPTAIR shall determine the
annualized rate by referring to the total number of employees performing a safety-sensitive
function at the beginning of the calendar year;
Positive rate: means the number of positive results for random drug, alcohol and
psychoactive tests conducted under this chapter plus the number of refusals to take
random tests, divided by the total number of random drug, alcohol and psychoactive tests
conducted under this chapter plus the number of refusals to take random tests;
Prohibited drug: means Marijuana, Cocaine, Opiates, Phencyclidine (PCP), amphetamines,
or any substance specified in the Egyptian laws, unless the drug is being used as authorized
by a legal prescription;
Alcohol use: means the consumption of any beverage, mixture, or preparation including
any medication containing alcohol;

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Performing a safety-sensitive function: an employee is considered to be performing a
safety-sensitive function during any period in which he/she is actually performing, ready to
perform, or immediately available to perform such functions;
Refusal to submit: means that an individual failed to provide a urine sample and/or
adequate breath for testing, without a genuine inability or a valid medical explanation to
provide a specimen (as determined by a medical evaluation), after he/she has received
notice of the requirement to be tested in accordance with this program, or engaged in
conduct that clearly obstructed the testing process;
Verified negative drug test result: means that the test result of a urine sample collected
and tested under this chapter has been verified by an approved medical examiner as
negative;
Verified positive drug test result: means that the test result of a urine sample collected
and tested under this chapter has been verified by an approved medical examiner as
positive.
Responsibilities

By delegation from the CEO, the G.M. Safety, Quality & Standardization is responsible for the
implementation and follow up of this program.

Substances for which Testing Must be Conducted

EGYPTAIR will test each employee for evidence of Marijuana, Cocaine, Opiates, Phencyclidine
(PCP), Amphetamines, or any other Psychoactive Substance specified in the Egyptian Laws.

Types of Drug, Alcohol, or Psychoactive Substances Testing Required

EGYPTAIR shall conduct the following types of testing:

Pre-employment testing:
EGYPTAIR requires a pre-employment testing for drug, alcohol and psychoactive
substances for any individual who will perform a safety-sensitive function for EGYPTAIR;
EGYPTAIR shall not allow an employee to perform a safety-sensitive function unless the
employee has been administrated an alcohol test with a result indicating alcohol
concentration of 0.02 or less and a verified negative drug test result.
Periodic testing:
Each employee who performs a safety-sensitive function for EGYPTAIR and who is
required to undergo a medical assessment that is required by ECAR shall submit to a
periodic drug, alcohol and psychoactive substances test.
The employee shall be tested for the presence of marijuana, cocaine, opiates,
phencyclidine (PCP), and amphetamines, or a metabolite of those drugs during the first
calendar year of implementation of the employer's anti-drug program.
The tests shall be conducted in conjunction with the first medical evaluation of the
employee or in accordance with an alternative method for collecting periodic test
specimens detailed in an approved anti-drug program;
EGYPTAIR may discontinue periodic testing of its employees after the first calendar year
of implementation of the anti-drug program when it has implemented an unannounced
testing program based on random selection of employees.

Random testing:
The minimum annual percentage rate for random drug, alcohol and psychoactive
substances testing shall be 50% of employees;
The annual rate may be reduced to 25% if the ECAA determines that the reported
Positive rate is less than 1% for 2 consecutive calendar years;
The annual rate will be increased back to 50% if the ECAA determines that the reported
Positive rate is equal to or greater than 1% for any calendar year;
The selection of employees for random drug, alcohol and psychoactive substances
testing shall be made by a randomized selection created by a customized software
program selecting the crew members from the General Declaration (G.D) or according to
a written report from the concerned management or up to the management discretion
through the CEO for a suspicious crew member or employee that might be under the
influence of Drugs, Alcohol or Psychoactive Substances;
EGYPTAIR shall ensure that random drug, alcohol and psychoactive substances tests are
unannounced and that the dates for administering random tests are spread reasonably
throughout the calendar year. Moreover EGYPTAIR shall provide access to the records of
random drug, alcohol and psychoactive substances testing, as determined to be
necessary by the approved medical examiner to ensure the compliance with the rule.
Post-accident testing:
EGYPTAIR shall test each employee who performs a safety-sensitive function for drug,
alcohol and psychoactive substances if that employee's performance either contributed
to an accident or cannot be completely as a contributing factor to the accident;
The employee shall be tested as soon as possible but not later than 8 hours after the
accident for drugs, alcohol and psychoactive substances;
An employee who is subject to post-accident testing shall remain readily available for
such testing or may be deemed to have refused to submit to testing;
The decision not to administer a test under this section must be based on a
determination, using the best information available at the time of the determination that
the employee's performance could not have contributed to the accident.
Testing based on reasonable cause:
EGYPTAIR shall test any employee who performs a safety-sensitive function and who is
reasonably suspected of using or under the influence of Drugs, Alcohol, or Psychoactive
Substances.
Administrative and other Matters

Collection and testing records:
EGYPTAIR shall maintain all records related to the collection process, including all
logbooks and certification statements, for 2 years;
EGYPTAIR shall maintain records of employee confirmed Positive drug test results for
indefinite period;
EGYPTAIR shall maintain records of negative test results (negative drug result and/or
alcohol result below 0.02) for 12 months;
EGYPTAIR shall permit the ECAA representative to examine those records.

Primary Sample:

Prior to conducting any test, the selected personnel shall fill and sign the form “ MSI-QMSF-
TM-01/TF-11/1 ” and declare the use of any substance he/she may be taking which could
affect the result of the test such as:
Prescription Medication;

Supplements.
The selected personnel shall provide an evidence for consumed medicine that might give a
false positive result. This may include, but not limited to:
A valid prescription;
Verification from the individual’s physician verifying a valid prescription.
A sample of urine is collected according to the following procedures that ensure the
samples are safe and not exposed to fraud or substitution. The examination needs sufficient
amount of freshly excreted urine in clean containers of glass or plastic.
Procedures (Primary Sample):

Verify the identity of the selected personnel through the Company identity card, National
identity card or Passport and keep until the sample is collected;
Ensure that the place where urine samples are collected does not contain any source of
water or any materials that can be mixed with the sample. If there is a source of water, it
should be colored water and the place should be clean, with good lighting, and intended
only for the sample collection;
Ensure that the work team responsible and supervisors for collecting samples are identified,
unified and present in the place where samples are collected;
The selected personnel whom the sample to be taken is required to take off the
unnecessary outer clothing such as coats and jackets, empty his pockets and leave his
personal belongings such as purse, handbags, etc. outside the sample taking area;
The selected personnel is given a clean container with his name written on it to give a urine
sample;
The selected personnel is allowed to enter the place designated for sampling, while
maintaining his privacy with the presence of one the work team near him;

7.1 INTRODUCTION

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
7.1.1 Purpose

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The purpose of this scheme is to interpret the requirements of the relevant articles of the ECAR
(Subpart Q), as they apply to the regulation of flight times and the avoidance of fatigue.

ICAO Standards recommend that States allow an operator to choose whether it will use the FRMS
to manage fatigue risk in all its operations, or only in designated specific types of operations (for
example, only a particular fleet, only long range operations, etc.). Operations that are not covered
by the FRMS must operate under the applicable prescriptive flight and duty time limits.

7.1.2 Aim

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The aim of this document is to express the intent behind the published relevant documents,
thereby taking all reasonable precautions to ensure that Crew Members are adequately rested at
the beginning of each flying duty period. To meet this aim, due note will be taken of the length of
duty cycles, periods of time-off and cumulative duty hours.

7.1.3 Applicability

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The scheme shall apply in relation to any duty carried out at the behest of the company by both
Flight and Cabin Crew. The scheme shall apply to all Cabin Crew carried as Crew Members.

7.1.4 Responsibilities

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
7.1.4.1 The Company

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The Company will publish rosters in advance so that operating crew can plan adequate pre-flight
rest.

7.1.4.2 Scheduling Department

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
In order to avoid fatigue, scheduling department shall follow the ECARS (Subpart Q) when
planning and executing rosters in addition to:

Flights with a maximum Flight Duty Period (FDP) minus 1 hour will be scheduled night stops
or double crew;
Chief Pilots in co-ordination with scheduling managers shall supervise the scheduling of
night flights. In order to mitigate fatigue, night flights shall be scheduled double or
augmented crew according to FDP after the approval of G.M. Flight Operations;
FLIGHT TIME LIMITATIONS
7.1 Introduction
OM A
7-1-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Maximum FDP and the start time of FDP, shall be considered by the Chief Pilot, in co-
ordination with scheduling manager, when scheduling CAT C airports, in order to schedule
flights that might impose fatigue by double crew or augmented crew after the approval of
G.M. Flight Operations.
The scheduling process will ensure Flight Deck Crew Members, prior to being assigned to duty, are
qualified and current in accordance with the applicable Flight Deck Crew qualification
requirements, and any other additional requirements of the ECAR.

In addition, the scheduling policy will ensure Flight Deck Crew Members, prior to being assigned to
duty, will not be affected by factors that could impair human performance, to include:

Pregnancy;
Illness, surgery or use of medication(s);
Blood donation;
Deep underwater diving;
Fatigue occurring in one flight, successive flights or accumulated over a period of time.
NOTE The scheduling processes addresses the requirement of Chapter 5.2.2.4 Differences
Training regarding flying two variants of the same type.
7.1.4.3 Crew Members

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Responsibility for the proper control of flight and duty time does not wholly rest with the
company. Crew Members have the responsibility to make optimum use of the opportunities and
facilities for rest provided. They are also responsible for planning and using their rest periods
properly in order to minimize incurring fatigue. The ECAR Subpart Q also places a further
responsibility on Crew Members. Simply, Crew Members shall not act as operating crew if they
know, or suspect, that their physical or mental condition renders them unfit to operate.
Furthermore, they must not fly if they know that they are, or are likely to be, in breach of this
scheme.

Crew Members are also reminded that: A holder of a license shall not be entitled to undertake his
duties if he knows or suspects that his physical or mental condition renders him temporarily unfit
to perform his required duties. The license is to be suspended if the holder therefore has:

An injury preventing him to undertake his duties;
Any illness preventing him to undertake his duties.
In such cases the holder of the license is required to inform the ECAA in written form for action to
be taken regarding the medical test required for the renewal of the license.

7.1.5 General Principles of Control of Flight Duty and Rest Time

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The prime objective of any scheme of flight time limitations is to ensure that Crew Members
are adequately rested at the beginning of each flying duty period. Operations will therefore
need to take account of inter-related planning constraints on individual duty and rest
periods, on the length of cycles of duty and the associated periods of time off and on
cumulative duty hours within specific periods;
FLIGHT TIME LIMITATIONS
7.1 Introduction
OM A
7-1-3
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Flight schedules must be realistic and the planning of duties must be designed to avoid any
overruns of flying duty limits;
The ECAA will conduct periodic spot checks of EGYPTAIR’ records and PIC reports to assess
whether EGYPTAIR’ planning of flight schedules and duty in general is producing results,
which are compatible with the limitations provided in EGYPTAIR’ scheme. The ECAA will
make the necessary amendments and will maintain direct contact with the Aeromedical
Council concerning any associated research or new developments in the areas of Crew
Member fatigue. The ECAA may volunteer its views and advice on particular problems
concerning the avoidance of excessive fatigue;
Time-off must be planned to ensure that crews are notified of their allocation well in
advance and also consecutive work patterns must be constructed to avoid undesirable
rostering practices as alternating day/night duties and the positioning of crews in a manner
likely to result in a serious disruption of established sleep/work patterns;
Standard provisions required for EGYPTAIR’ scheme of limitations:
a. The standard provisions the ECAA regards as the basis for an acceptable scheme of
flight and duty limitations;
b. Although EGYPTAIR plans its schemes in accordance with the requirements, it is
recognized that the standard provisions will not necessarily be completely adaptable
to every kind of operation. In exceptional circumstances, EGYPTAIR may request to
have deviations from the standard provisions approved for its schemes;
c. However, such variation should be kept to a minimum and approval will only be
granted where EGYPTAIR can demonstrate that the proposed provision will ensure an
equivalent level of protection against fatigue.

7.3 DEFINITIONS

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24 (A)
Standby Duty A period of time when the operations places restraints on a
crew member who would otherwise be off duty. However, it
shall not include any time during which operations require a
Crew Member to be available for the purpose of notifying him
of a duty, which is due to start 10 hours or more ahead.
Flying Duty Period Any duty period during which a crew member flies in an aircraft
as a member of its crew. The flying duty period starts at the
time the crew member is required by the operations to report
for duty (other than stand-by) and includes such, pre-flight and
immediate post-flight duties as are required by the operations.
Duty Period Any continuous period during which a crew member flies in any
aircraft, whether as a Crew Member or as a passenger, at the
behest of his employer, or otherwise carries out a required duty
in the course of his employment. It includes any duty period,
positioning at the behest of the operations, including all ground
training, ground duties and stand-by duty.
Local Night A period of 8 hours falling between 22:00 hours and 08:00
hours local time.
Rest Period A period of time before starting a flying duty period which is
intended to ensure that a crew member is adequately rested
before a flight.
Days Off Periods available for leisure and relaxation free from all duties. A
single day off shall include 2 local nights. Consecutive days off
shall include a further local night for each additional
consecutive day off. A rest period may be included as part of a
day off.
Eastward-Westward and
Westward-Eastward Transition
Means the transition at home base between a rotation crossing
6 or more time zones in one direction and a rotation crossing 4
or more time zones in the opposite direction.
Split Duty A flying duty period that consists of two or more duty periods
which are separated by less than a minimum rest period.
Positioning Means the transferring of a non-operating crew member from
one place to another, at the behest of EGYPTAIR, excluding:
The time of travel from a private place of rest to the
designated reporting place at home base and vice versa;
and
The time for local transfer from a place of rest to the
commencement of duty and vice versa.
FLIGHT TIME LIMITATIONS
7.3 Definitions
OM A
7-3-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Fatigue A physiological state of reduced mental or physical
performance capability resulting from sleep loss or extended
wakefulness, circadian phase, or workload (mental and/or
physical activity) that can impair a crew member’s alertness and
ability to safely operate an aircraft or perform safety related
duties.
Fatigue is a state that results from an imbalance between:
The physical and mental exertion of all waking activities
(not only duty demands); and;
Recovery from that exertion, which (except for recovery
from muscle fatigue) requires sleep.
Reducing the exertion of waking activities and/or improving
sleep reduce crew member’s fatigue.
Working Time Means any period during which the worker is working, at the
employer's disposal and carrying out his activity or duties, in
accordance with national laws and/or practice.

7.5.1 Extension of Flying Duty Period by In-flight Relief

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
When any additional Crew Member is carried to provide in-flight relief for the purpose of
extending an FDP he shall hold qualifications which will meet the requirements of the
operational duty for which he is required as a relief;
When in-flight relief is provided there must be available, for the Crew Member who is
resting, a comfortable reclining seat or bunk separated and screened from the flight deck
and passengers;
A total of in-flight rest of less than three hours will not count towards extension of an FDP,
but where the total of in-flight rest (which need not be consecutive) is three hours or more
the rostered FDP may be extended beyond that permitted in tables A and B by:
See table below.
Where a Crew Member undertakes a period of in-flight relief and after its completion he is
totally free of duty for the remainder of the flight, that part of the flight following
completion of duty may be classed as positioning and be subject to the provisions of
positioning detailed in Chapter 7.5.3 Positioning.
If rest is taken in a bunk If rest is taken in a seat
A period equal to one half of the total of rest taken,
provided that the maximum FDP permissible shall be
18 hours (or 19 hours in case of Cabin Crew)
A period equal to one third of the total of rest taken,
provided that the maximum FDP permissible shall be
15 hours (or 16 hours in case of Cabin Crew)
7.5.2 Extension of Flying Duty Period by Split Duty

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
When a FDP consists of two or more duties separated by less than a minimum rest period
the FDP may be extended beyond that permitted in the tables by the amounts indicated
below:
See table below.
The rest period shall not include the time required for immediate post-flight and pre-flight
duties. When the rest period is not more than 6 hours it will be sufficient if a quiet and
comfortable place is available, not open to the public, but if the rest period is more than 6
consecutive hours, then a bed must be provided.

7.5.3 Positioning

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
All time spent on positioning as required by EGYPTAIR shall be considered as duty, but positioning
shall not count as a sector when assessing the maximum permissible FDP. Positioning as required
by EGYPTAIR which immediately precedes a flying duty period, shall be included as part of the FDP
for purpose of Chapter 7.4, item 1.

7.5.4 Traveling Time

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Where traveling time between the airport and sleeping accommodation provided by
EGYPTAIR exceeds thirty minutes each way, the rest period provided must be increased by
the amount of the excess, or such lesser time as is consistent with a minimum of 10 hours at
the sleeping accommodation;
When Crew Members are required to travel from their home to an aerodrome other than
the one from which they normally operate, any travelling time over and above the journey
time from home to the usual operating aerodrome will count as positioning.
7.5.5 PICs Discretion to Extend a Flying Duty Period

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A PIC may, at his discretion, extend a FDP beyond the maximum normally permitted,
provided he is satisfied that the flight can safely be made. In these circumstances the
maximum normally permitted shall be 3 hours with the exception of emergencies;
Whenever a PIC so exercises his discretion he shall report it to his employer. If the maximum
normally permitted is exceeded by more than 2 hours both the PIC and EGYPTAIR shall
submit a written report to the ECAA within 30 days.
NOTE Discretion reports either concerning extension of a flying duty or reduction of a rest
period shall be submitted to the ECAA. Those reports will be used by the ECAA when
assessing the realism of particular schedules.
NOTE An emergency in respect of an extension of a flying duty is a situation which in the
judgment of the PIC presents a serious risk to health or safety.
7.5.6 Delayed Reporting Time

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Where Crew Members are informed of a delay before leaving their place of rest, the FDP shall start
at the new reporting time, or 4 hours after the original reporting time whichever is earlier. The
maximum FDP shall be based on the original reporting time. This paragraph shall not apply if Crew
Members are given 10 hours or more notice of a new reporting time.

7.5.7 Rest Periods

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
It is the responsibility of EGYPTAIR to schedule and operate so that adequate and, within
reason; uninterrupted rest can be obtained by the Crew Members. Away from base
EGYPTAIR must provide the opportunity and the facilities for the Crew Members to obtain
adequate rest. It is EGYPTAIR’ responsibility to ensure that rest accommodation is
satisfactory in respect of noise, temperature, light and ventilation. When operations are
carried out at such short notice that is impracticable for EGYPTAIR to ensure that rest
accommodation is satisfactory, it will be the PIC’s responsibility to obtain satisfactory
accommodations;
The minimum rest period which must be provided before undertaking a flying duty period
shall be:
a. At least as long as the preceding duty period, or a minimum of 12 hours whichever is
greater;
b. If rest is away from the company’s home base, then the minimum rest is 11 hours;
c. If the preceding duty period exceeded 18 hours, the minimum rest period must include
a local night.
7.5.8 PICs Discretion to Reduce Rest Period

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
A PIC may, at his discretion, reduce a rest period to below the minimum required by Chapter 7.5.7
Rest Periods item 2. The exercise of such discretion must be considered exceptional and should
not be used to reduce successive rest periods. A rest period must be long enough to allow Flight
Deck Crew Members at least 10 hours, and Cabin Crew at least 9 hours, at the accommodation
where the rest is taken.

When a rest period is reduced, the PIC shall submit a report to EGYPTAIR and if the reduction
exceeds two hours, then both EGYPTAIR and the PIC shall submit a written report to the ECAA
within 30 days.

7.5.9 Stand-by Duty

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The following limits shall apply:
See table below.
The length of the minimum rest period after stand-by duty combined with FDP is equal to
the preceding FDP and stand-by duty combined, but not less than a minimum of 20 hours.
Type of Duty Maximum Duration
Stand-by duty (all cases) 12 hours
Stand-by plus FDP 20 hours

7.5.10 Days Off

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
A single day off shall include two local nights. Consecutive days off shall include a further
local night for each additional consecutive day off;
Crew Members shall:
a. Not work more than 7 consecutive days between days off;
b. Have 2 consecutive days off in any consecutive 14 days; and
c. Have a minimum of 6 days off in any consecutive 4 weeks;
7.5.11 Accumulative Duty and Flying Hours

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
Maximum cumulative duty hours
The weekly total of duty hours shall not exceed 50 hours. All types of duty, flying duty,
ground duty, split duty, stand-by duty, office duty and positioning shall be counted in full
for this purpose.
Maximum monthly flying hours
The maximum number of flying hours which a Flight Deck Crew Member may be permitted
to undertake during any 30 consecutive days shall be 100.
Maximum annual flying hours
A person shall not act as a Flight Deck Crew Member if the aggregate of his flight times in
the period of 12 months expiring at the end of the previous month exceeds 900 hours.

7.6 CABIN CREW

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The requirements detailed in this section shall be applicable to all Cabin Crew required as
Crew Members;
The limitations, which shall be applied to Cabin Crew, are those contained in this section as
applicable to Flight Deck Crew Members, with the following differences:
a. Rostered flying duty periods shall not be more than one hour longer than those
permitted for Flight Deck Crew Members and contained in Chapter 7.4 Limitations on
Flying Duty Periods, Flight Deck Crew. In order to remove anomalies which might
arise when Cabin Crew and Flight Deck Crew Members report at different times for the
same flight, the maximum FDP for Cabin Crew shall be based on the time at which the
Flight Deck Crew Members start their flying duty period;
b. Rostered minimum rest periods shall not be more than one hour shorter than those
required by Flight Deck Crew Members and contained in Chapter 7.5.8 PICs Discretion
to Reduce Rest Period ;
c. The combined sum of stand-by time and following FDP shall not exceed 21 hours, refer
to Chapter 7.5.9 Stand-by Duty ;
d. The average weekly total of duty hours shall not exceed 55 hours, refer to Chapter 7.5.11
Accumulative Duty and Flying Hours ;
e. The annual and 30 days limit of flying hours need not to be applied, refer to Chapter
7.5.11 Accumulative Duty and Flying Hours ;
f. When any additional Cabin Crews are carried to provide in-flight relief for the purpose of
extending FDP, the required number of Cabin Crews shall be increased by 50% of the
minimum number of cabin crew stated in the table of Chapter 4.3.3.2 Reduction of
Minimum Cabin Crew , provided adequate seats are available on board the aircraft for
the additional Cabin Crews.
7.6.1 Cabin Crew Required

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The numbers of Cabin Crew required are stipulated in Chapter 4 Crew Composition.

7.6.2 Records to be Maintained

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Records must be kept of the duty and rest periods of all Crew Members. These records shall
include the following:
a. Duration of each flying duty period, and function performed during the period,
duration of each duty period whether or not it includes a flying duty period, duration
of each rest period prior to a flying duty stand-by duty period;
b. Daily and weekly flying hours for each Crew Member, and these records shall be
preserved for at least 15 calendar months from the date of the relevant entry.
Additionally, EGYPTAIR shall retain all PIC discretion reports of extended flying duty periods
and reduced rest periods for a period of at least five years.

8.1 FLIGHT PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
It is the Commander’s responsibility to ensure that the flight is planned to meet all Safety , Legal
and Economic requirements of EGYPTAIR.

In general, Flight Deck Crew Member, prior to the commencement of each flight, shall complete a
full review of the following:

ATL and the MEL/CDL for the purposes of:
a. Determining the airworthiness status of the aircraft;
b. Precluding a flight from departing until any defect affecting airworthiness is processed
in accordance with the MEL/CDL;
c. Ensuring the aircraft is operated in accordance with any applicable MEL/CDL
operational procedures.
The OFP;
Weather information to include en-route and departure, destination and alternate airports;
Relevant NOTAMS;
Aircraft performance;
Aircraft weight/mass and balance.
Apart from checking the technical status of the aeroplane, its components and equipment, careful
flight preparation shall include:

The preparation of an Operational Flight Plan (OFP) considering all aspects such as
minimum flight altitudes, routing, weather forecasts for en-route, destination and alternate
airports, fuel planning, etc. refer to Chapter 8.1.10 Operational Flight Plan (OFP) ;
The preparation of an Air Traffic Services (ATS) flight plan, refer to Chapter 8.1.9 ATS Flight
Plans ;
The preparation of the weight and balance sheet, refer to Chapter 8.1.8 Mass and Centre
of Gravity ;
The determination of the usability of aerodromes, including the evaluation of possible
performance limitations, refer to Chapter 8.1.2 Criteria and Responsibilities for
Determining the Adequacy of Aerodromes ;
The relevant Aeronautical Information Service (AIS) briefing, either by appropriate AIS
documentation, personal AIS briefing or by a flight dispatcher;
The relevant MET briefing, either by MET documentation, personal MET briefing or by a
flight dispatcher, refer to Chapter 8.1.3 Methods for Determination and Use of
Aerodrome Operating Minima and Chapter 8.1.6 Interpretation of Meteorological
Information ;
A check, whether "Special Loads" such as dangerous/hazardous goods or heavy cargo have
been loaded properly, refer to Chapter 8.2.2 Aeroplane, Passengers and Cargo Handling
Procedures Related to Safety and whether safety related handling instructions were
followed;
Ensuring that commercial and/or other company requirements are met;
A check, whether De-icing/Anti-icing procedures, if necessary, have been carried out
properly, refer to Chapter 8.2.4 De-Icing and Anti-Icing on the Ground ;

Ensuring the availability of instrument approach, arrival and departure charts, if the PIC has
not operated the airports or routes or route segments he shall qualify himself by reviewing
all related charts and plates before the beginning of the flight.
It's the PIC responsibility to reviews and prepare the flight.

NOTE These documents are essential for the safe conduct of the flight by examining and
signing the papers, the commander certifies that he is satisfied that the preparation of
his flight is adequate.
8.1.1 Minimum Flight Altitudes / Flight Levels

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
EGYPTAIR uses JEPPESEN as the main source for Minimum Flight Altitude information for all
phases of flight.

On VFR Flight
EGYPTAIR does not conduct VFR flights; therefore there is no need to establish the
minimum VFR altitudes/flight levels;
On IFR-Flights
Except when necessary for take-off or landing, or except when specifically authorized by
the appropriate Authority, an IFR flight shall be flown at a level which is not below the
minimum flight altitude established by the State whose territory is overflown or where no
such minimum flight altitude has been established:
a. Over high terrain or in mountainous areas, at a level which is at least 600 m (2.000 ft)
above the highest obstacle located within 8 km of the estimated position of the
aircraft;
b. Elsewhere than as specified in a., at a level which is at least 300 m (1.000 ft) above the
highest obstacle located within 8 km of the estimated position of the aircraft.
NOTE The estimated position of the aircraft will take account of the navigational
accuracy which can be achieved on the relevant route segment, having
regard to the navigational facilities available on the ground and in the
aircraft.
NOTE Local regulations may require higher minimum flight altitudes (for State
deviations refer to OM Part C).
For the practical application of those basic requirements (ICAO Annex 2), the following
terminologies are used:

MEA (Minimum En-route IFR Altitude)
Route MORA (Route Minimum Off-route Altitude)
Grid MORA (Grid Minimum Off-route Altitude)
MOCA (Minimum Obstruction Clearance Altitude)
MSA (Minimum Sector/Safe Altitude)
MRVA (Minimum Radar Vectoring Altitude)
NOTE For definitions of the above terminologies, see Chapter 0.8 Terms and Definitions.

NOTE As a company policy, the MORA shall be used as the minimum altitude for both, flight
planning and actual flight execution.
Cruising levels to be used, either even or odd, are published in the en-route charts/AlPs or
assigned by ATC, and must meet ICAO Annex 2 requirements.

IFR - Flights

Mag track 000°-179° = Odd flight levels

With 2.000 ft vertical separation up to and including FL290 (FL50, 70, ... 290);
With 4.000 ft vertical separation from FL290 and up (FL290, 330, 370, 420, ...);
Within RVSM airspace FL290, 310, 330, 350, 370, 390 and 410.
Mag track 180°-359° = Even flight levels

With 2.000 ft vertical separation up to and including FL280 (FL40, 60, ... 280);
With 4.000 ft vertical separation from FL290 and up (FL310, 350, 390, 430, ...);
Within RVSM airspace FL300, 320, 340, 360, 380 and 400.
When being radar vectored, Radar minimum Altitude chart shall be consulted checking the cleared
altitudes. Any time radar contact is lost, and immediate climb shall be initiated to the minimum
safe altitude (MSA, MORA, GRID MORA) and report intention to ATC.

8.1.1.1 Minimum Altitude/Flight Level Corrections

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.1.1.1.1 Flights Inside Controlled Airspace

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Pilots are responsible for altimeter corrections for temperature, pressure and, where appropriate,
wind and terrain effects.

In most countries, Pilots are responsible for performing the correction, except when under radar
control in a radar-vectoring environment. In this case the controller is normally responsible for
terrain clearance, including the cold temperature correction, when issuing altitude instructions.

Nevertheless, if any doubt exists, Pilots must clarify the issue with ATC. For corrections, refer to
Chapter 8.1.1.1.3 Checking for Terrain Clearance.

8.1.1.1.2 Flights Outside Controlled Airspace

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
It is EGYPTAIR’s policy that all flights will be planned and operated within controlled airspace.

When an aircraft operating under IFR encounters VMC, it shall not cancel its IFR flight plan.

NOTE A visual approach does not constitute cancellation of an IFR flight plan.
8.1.1.1.3 Checking for Terrain Clearance

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The cruising altitude/flight level shall always be equal to or higher than the published minimum
altitudes. When selecting cruising altitudes/levels the following factors must be taken into account:

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Temperature Correction:

The calculated minimum safe altitude/flight level must be adjusted when the ambient temperature
on the surface is much lower than that predicted by the standard atmosphere. In such conditions
an approximate correction is 4% height increase for every 10 °C below standard temperature.

NOTE This is safe for all altimeter setting source altitudes for temperatures above -15 °C. for
colder temperatures (below -15 °C), refer to Chapter 8.1.1.1.3.1 Temperature
Correction.
Pressure Correction:

When flying at levels with the altimeter set to 1013,2 hPa, the minimum safe altitude must be
corrected for deviations in pressure when the pressure is lower than the standard atmosphere
(1013 hPa). An appropriate correction is 30 ft (10 m) per 1 hPa below 1013 hPa.

NOTE Alternatively a more accurate data can be obtained from the table in Chapter
8.1.1.1.3.2 Pressure (QNH) Correction.
EXAMPLE:

FL160 OAT -30 °C

MEA 12.000 ft

Lowest QNH 977 hPa at sea level

Step 1: Temperature Correction:

Standard Temperature for FL160 = -17 °C
OAT FL160 = -30 °C
ISA Dev. = -13 °C
13 °C = 5%
12.000 + 5% = 12.600 ft
Step 2: Pressure Correction

1.013 - 977 = 36 hPa
12.600 + (36 x 30) = 13.680
Lowest usable flight level = FL140
8.1.1.1.3.1 Temperature Correction

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
When the surface ambient temperature en-route is well below the ISA value, MSA shall additionally
be corrected as follows:

Surface Temperature Correction to MORA
ISA -16 °C to ISA -30 °C MORA plus 10%
ISA -31 °C to ISA -50 °C MORA plus 20%
ISA -51 °C or below MORA plus 25%

EXAMPLE Indicated or planned FL is 160; ISA - temp; MEA = 15.000 ft; Local QNH = 975 hPa;
Results in a correction of minus 1.080 ft = true altitude only 14.920 ft. If MEA would be
15.000 ft, the min req. obstacle clearance would not be assured - then the next higher
flight level must be used.

8.1.1.1.3.4 Low Altitude Temperature Correction

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Under most unfavorable conditions, such as temperatures significantly lower than ISA, true altitude
will be lower than indicated. This altimetry error may be significant and can become extremely
important when considering obstacle clearance in very cold temperatures.

Altimeter errors become significantly larger when the surface temperature approaches -30 °C or
colder, and also become larger with increasing height above the altimeter reference source.

In this case, and only when following published procedure altitudes , Pilots should add the
values derived from the Altitude Correction Tables to the altitudes published in the approach
charts, such as MSA, MDA, DA and restricting altitudes relevant to the respective procedure.

The following guidelines should be observed:

No corrections are needed for reported temperatures above 0°C or if the airport
temperature is at or above the minimum published temperature for the procedure being
flown;

8.1.1.5 One Engine Inoperative En-route Flight Path

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In the event of the loss of one engine at the most critical point along the route and in the
meteorological conditions expected for the flight, the net flight path must:

Have a positive gradient at 1.500 ft above the aerodrome of intended landing;
Have a positive gradient at least 1.000 ft above all terrain and obstructions within 5 NM (9,3
km) either side of the intended track;
Permit the aeroplane to continue flight from the cruising altitude to an aerodrome at which
a landing can be made whilst clearing vertically, by at least 2.000 ft, all obstacles within 5
NM (9,3 km) either side of the intended track.

In approving an aerodrome, the following aspects shall be considered:

Aerodrome dimensions with regard to performance requirements;
Obstacle situation in the approach, missed approach and departure sectors;
Approach facilities (electronic and visual aids);
Local conditions such as special weather situations, night flying restrictions or even political
aspects which might affect operations;
Ground service facilities for fuelling/defuelling, loading, de/anti-icing, fire fighting and
rescue, catering, general handling and the availability of immigration authorities;
Runway/taxiway bearing strength; and;
Fuel freeze considerations during extended operations, if applicable.
The G.M. Flight Operations criteria to allow automatic approval for certain adequate airports shall
include:

Minimum runway length 3.000 m;
Minimum runway width 45 m;
Any runway at the aerodrome is approved for ILS operations;
Approaches path angle does not exceed 3.3°;
No performance limitation;
Within controlled airspace;
Not within a conflict zone;
No security threats;
Approved instrument approach and departure procedures are available for IFR flights;
Absence of critical obstacles within 15 NM from runways;
Minimum ground facilities; and
Adequate rescue and fire fighting services;
Field elevation is less than 2.500 ft.
NOTE If the above criteria is fulfilled, the aerodrome should be considered approved by the
G.M. Flight Operations and the IOCC may operate to the aerodrome automatically. If
the Above criteria are not fulfilled the aerodrome shall be reviewed by the G.M. Flight

8.1.2.5 Aerodrome Categories

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Aerodromes into which the Company operates have been categorised into one of three categories
as follows:

Category A Aerodromes

Aerodromes categorised as Category A are those that meet all of the following requirements:

An approved instrument approach procedure;
At least one runway with no performance limited procedure for take-off and/or landing;
Published circling minima not higher than 1.000 ft above aerodrome level; and
Night operations capability;
The airport is adjacent or similar to another airport at which the PIC is qualified to land.
There are no special requirements prior to operating to a Category A aerodrome.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.1 Flight Preparation Instructions
OM A
8-1-11
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Category B Aerodromes

Aerodromes categorised as Category B are those that does not meet the Category A requirements
or which requires extra considerations such as:

Non-standard approach aids and/or approach patterns;
Unusual local weather conditions;
Unusual characteristics or performance limitations; or
Any other relevant considerations including obstructions, physical layout, lighting etc.
Prior to operating to a Category B aerodrome, the Commander shall be briefed through
programmed instruction / chief pilot briefing or self-briefed through Airport Briefing Pages (ABP)
and navigational plates or charts.

Self-briefings are confirmed through the Commander's acceptance of an OFP involving Category B
aerodromes as destination or alternate aerodromes.

This recording must be accomplished after completion or confirmed by the Commander before
departure on a flight involving Category B aerodromes as destination or alternate aerodromes.

Category C Aerodromes

Aerodromes categorised as Category C are those that requires additional considerations to a
Category B aerodrome. Prior to operating to a Category C aerodrome, the Commander shall be
briefed and visit the aerodrome as an observer and/or undertake instruction in a suitable FSTD.
The completion of the briefing, visit and/or instruction shall be recorded in the commander's
training record.

Category C aerodromes require additional consideration because it has the most significant factors
affecting the complexity and workload of the flight.

Therefore, Prior to operating to a Category C aerodrome:

The Pilot-in-Command shall be briefed and visit the aerodrome for familiarization, either as
an observer with a qualified Pilot-in-Command for that aerodrome or occupying his
assigned seat with a Check Airman, and/or undertake instruction in a suitable FSTD;
The Second in Command shall be briefed and visit the aerodrome for familiarization, either
as an observer with a qualified Pilot-in-Command for that aerodrome or occupying his
assigned seat with a Check Airman or a qualified Pilot-in-Command for that aerodrome,
and/or undertake instruction in a suitable FSTD.
NOTE In case of operation to a new destination categorized as category C aerodrome which
is not available in simulator database, qualification shall be conducted by the following
methods:
a) By means of Programmed instructions and / or briefing that incorporates airport
briefing pages, navigational plates or charts and special briefing notes for special
routes and aerodromes addressing all threats and hazards (generated by Risk
assessments); and
b) Pilot-in-Command for First 3 flights shall be instructors.
The completion of the briefing, visit and/or instructions should be recorded in the Area,
Route and Airport Qualification Form followed by a Line Check for Pilot-in-Command only
using the Line Check Form.
