8.1.2.6 Performance Considerations – Performance Class “A” Aeroplanes

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
General

Performance class A aeroplanes (all multi engine jet aeroplanes, multi engine turbopropeller
aeroplanes with a maximum approved seating capacity of more than 9 or with an MTOM of more
than 5,7 tons) shall always be dispatched considering an engine failure in all flight phases. When
establishing the performance limits/criteria the data presented in the approved OM Part B -
including any approved supplements - or any other approved document shall be used. The
presentation of data in the OM Part B shall always be based upon AFM data and may contain
simplified and conservative data. When using electronic data for performance calculations, cross-
checks may become necessary to ensure that those data are in line with the OM Part B data, unless
the performance program is approved by the authorities.

Take-off Climb Limits (MAT/WAT-Limits)

Regardless of the obstacle situation at an aerodrome, the mass of the aeroplane shall not exceed
that mass which assures the minimum gross climb gradient as defined by the airworthiness
requirements (for the ambient temperature and pressure altitude).

Runway Length Requirements for Take-off

When commencing the take-off, any losses due to runway alignment shall be considered.
Furthermore the following parameters shall be used to determine the runway length mass limits:

Pressure altitude;
Temperature;
Runway slope;
Wind;
Runway condition (dry, wet, contaminated);
Runway surface (e.g. concrete, gravel, grass).
The TOR shall not exceed the TORA.

The TOD shall not exceed the TODA.

The ASD shall not exceed the ASDA. One single V 1 speed shall be established also when taking off
from a wet or contaminated runway.

Obstacle Clearance Requirements

The mass of the aeroplane at take-off must allow to clear all obstacles during the net flight path
(beginning at 35 ft above the take-off surface up to at least 1.500 ft or when the final en-route
configuration has been reached) by 35 ft vertically within the obstacle accountability area. The
ICAO accountability area starts at the end of the TODA at 90 m each side of the extended
centerline and opens with an angle of 0,125 x the distance from TODA until 300 m from centerline
are reached (VFR departures) or 600 m for straight-out IFR departures. For aeroplanes with a wing
span of less than 60 m, alternatively to the 90 m distance from center line, the minimum distance
of 90 m may be reduced to half wingspan plus 60 m (+ 0,125).

When plotting the net flight path respectively when calculating the mass limit, the “nettage factor”
as per the airworthiness requirements shall be observed (gross gradient - nettage factor = net
gradient).

OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.1 Flight Preparation Instructions
OM A
8-1-13
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
When establishing the net flight path limits the official source for obstacle data is the ICAO type A
chart as may be found in the AIP or any other acceptable documentation. The engine failure
procedure - as being briefed prior take-off - may at a given point divert from the published SID
usually based upon a procedure design gradient of 3,3% (without considering an engine failure) -
in case no higher gradient is promulgated. It is a requirement to check whether from this diverging
point the SID may also be followed in case the engine fails after passing this point.

When working out an engine failure procedure, allowing the net flight path to stay within the ICAO
obstacle accountability area (90 m + 0,125) then all obstacles are known. Should the engine failure
procedure however leave this area it may become difficult to identify obstacles outside the ICAO
type A area. Unfortunately the ICAO type C chart - as recommended by ICAO - is not available for
most of the airports!

So other sources (topographic charts, ICAO-VFR maps, etc.) need to be used. When using
topographic charts it must be realised that those charts may reflect the height/elevation contours
correctly but the height of trees, buildings, high voltage lines etc. may be missing!

En-route/Drift Down Requirements

The mass of the aeroplane shall not exceed that mass which allows to maintain or stay above the
minimum flight altitude (see 8.1.1 Minimum Flight Altitudes / Flight Levels ) with one engine
out (in case of 3- and 4-engined aeroplanes, see operations regulations). In case the single engine
service ceiling (as per the OM Part B) is less than the minimum flight altitude on a specific route
sector, a driftdown procedure shall be established or another route should be considered.

Missed Approach Requirements

The mass of the aeroplane during approach/missed approach for a particular runway for approach,
shall not exceed the lowest of the following:

Maximum certificated landing mass (structural limit);
The mass allowing a missed approach gradient of 2,5% (as per ICAO doc 9168);
A gradient promulgated for a particular approach/missed approach (could be higher than
2,5%);
The mass allowing a gradient of at least 2,5% for CAT II approaches (or higher, when required
for the particular runway);
A mass allowing the following gradients:
2,1% for twin-engined aeroplanes.
To be compliant with the operational rules as per EASA Air Ops, the above values shall be achieved
with one engine inoperative (unless small performance class B-aeroplanes are involved). The flap
setting during approach shall be consistent with the flap setting schedule (approach/landing) for
the type of aeroplane.

NOTE When employing a provider for performance data, the operator must make sure that
due consideration is given to the above missed approach requirements.
Balked / Rejected Landing Climb Gradients

The mass of the aeroplane shall not exceed that mass which allows a “landing climb” (landing
configuration) with all engines operating of at least 3,2%.

If the runway has specific friction-improving characteristics and the AFM/OM Part B includes

When the appropriate weather reports or forecasts indicate that the runway at the estimated time

On specially prepared winter runways, a landing distance shorter than that required by point
above, but not less than that required for wet runways, may be used if the AFM/OM Part B
includes specific additional information about landing distances on contaminated runways.
Such landing distance shall be at least 115% of the landing distance contained in the AFM/
OM Part B.
By way of derogation from point (2.), the increment of 15% needs not to be applied if it is
already included in the approved landing distance data or equivalent.

NOTE For short landing operations, EGYPTAIR shall use the landing distance data factored in
accordance with point 1. or 2., as applicable, and shall be approved for such
operations.
When determining the landing mass, EGYPTAIR shall take into account the following:

Not more than 50% of the headwind component or not less than 150% of the tailwind
component;
Corrections as provided in the AFM.
For dispatching the aeroplane, the aeroplane shall:

Land on the most favourable runway, in still air; and
Land on the runway most likely to be assigned, considering the probable wind speed and
direction, the ground-handling characteristics of the aeroplane and other conditions such as
landing aids and terrain.
In-flight Check of the Landing Distance at Time of Arrival

No approach to land shall be continued unless the landing distance available (LDA) on the
intended runway is at least 115% of the landing distance at the estimated time of landing,
determined in accordance with the performance information for the assessment of the landing
distance at time of arrival (LDTA).

Performance information for the assessment of the LDTA is based on approved manufacturer data
for various runway conditions as contained in the OM Part B including:

Runway slope;
Aerodrome elevation;
Wind;
Temperature;
Aeroplane mass and configuration;
Approach speed at threshold;
Eventual adjustments to the landing distance, such as autoland; and
Planned use of available and operative aeroplane ground deceleration devices.
The in-flight distance assessment shall be based on the latest available weather report and runway
condition report (RCR) or equivalent information.

The assessment shall be initially carried out when the weather report and the RCR are obtained,
usually around top of descent. If the planned duration of the flight does not allow the flight crew
to carry out the assessment in non-critical phases of flight, the assessment shall be carried out
before departure.

When updated meteorological conditions leads to a degradation of the runway surface condition,
another assessment shall be carried out above 1.000 ft AGL, so that a quick decision can be made
above 1.000 ft AGL otherwise a go-around shall be initiated, and a reassessment of the updated
available runway surface condition information shall be carried out to indicate if a safe landing can
be made or a diversion should be considered.

The flight crew shall monitor the evolution of the actual conditions during the approach, to ensure
that they do not degrade below the condition that was previously determined to be the minimum
acceptable.

The information provided in the RCR is divided in two sections:

The ‘aircraft performance’ section which contains information that is directly relevant in a
performance computation;
The ‘situational awareness’ section which contains information that the flight crew shall be
aware of for a safe operation, but which does not have a direct impact on the performance
assessment.

The ‘aircraft performance’ section of the RCR includes a runway condition code (RWYCC), the
contaminant type, depth and coverage for each third of the runway. The determination of the
RWYCC is based on the use of the runway condition assessment matrix (RCAM).

The new SNOWTAM is conform with the RCR in content and format. A SNOWTAM shall be issued
whenever a new RCR is received. Its maximum validity is 8 hours.

Sample RCR via D-ATIS
EDDF ARR-ATIS G
MET REPORT 221220
EXPECT ILS APPROACH
RWYS IN USE 25R 25L
RWY COND RWY 25R, AT TIME 1210,
RCC: TDZ 2, MID 3, END 3;
DEPOSIT: 6 MM SLUSH 25%, 12 MM WET SNOW 50%, 12 MM WET SNOW 25%;
TRL 70
Only the RWYCC will be communicated via ATC.

EXAMPLE RUNWAY SURFACE CONDITION RWY 25 LEFT
ISSUED AT TIME 1210
RUNWAY CONDITION CODE 2 3 3
When no RWYCC is available in winter conditions, the RCAM provides the flight crew with a
combination of the relevant information (runway surface conditions: state and/or contaminant or
pilot report of braking action (AIREP)) in order to determine the RWYCC.

Refer also to Chapter 8.3.9.13.3 Runway Assessment and Condition Reporting.

Short Landing Operations

Operations using longer landing distances other than the “Declared Landing Distance Available”
need prior authorisation/approval from the Competent Authority (for the airport) and from the
Operational Authority.

EGYPTAIR currently does not use Short Landing Operations procedures.

Steep Approach Procedures

Approach procedures where the glide-slope angle is 4,5° or higher do require special approval.
Apart from the operational approval, the type of aeroplane must be approved accordingly (OM
Part B supplement).

EGYPTAIR currently does not use steep approach procedures.

8.1.3 Methods for Determination and Use of Aerodrome Operating

Minima
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.1.3.1 Aerodrome Operating Minima

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Operating minima are established for each aerodrome planned to be used. Such minima will not
be lower than any that may be established for such aerodrome by the State in which the
aerodrome is located, except when specifically approved by that State.

When establishing the applicable aerodrome operating minima, full account is taken of:

Performance and handling characteristics of the aeroplane;
The composition of the Flight Deck Crew, their competence and experience;
The dimensions and characteristics of the runways which may be selected for use;
The adequacy and performance of the available visual and non-visual ground aids;
The equipment available on the aeroplane for the purpose of navigation and/or control of
the flight path, as appropriate, during the take-off, the approach, the flare, the landing and
the missed approach;
The obstacles in the approach and missed approach areas and the climb out areas and
necessary clearance;
The obstacle clearance altitude/height for the instrument approach procedures;
The means to determine and report meteorological conditions; and;
The Aeroplane Approach Category as derived from Chapter 8.1.3.3.1 Aeroplane Approach
Category.
8.1.3.1.1 Different Concepts of Minima

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Aircraft capability given in the AFM defines the lowest minima for which an aircraft has been
certified;
Aerodrome Operating Minima is the limits of usability of an aerodrome for either take-off
or landing, usually expressed in terms of RVR or Visibility, DA/H, MDA/MDH and cloud
conditions.
They are depicted on Jeppesen approach charts and are never below the State minima.

EGYPTAIR minima as approved by the ECAA, is the lowest minima that EGYPTAIR is allowed
to use on specified airports. They cannot be lower than the aircraft capability and the
minima required by the national authority of the aerodrome, except where specifically
approved by that authority;
Flight Deck Crew minima are the minima that the crew is authorised to use. They are based
upon the qualifications and/or experience of the Flight Deck Crew.
The applicable aerodrome operating minima shall be the highest of the above mentioned
minimums.

8.1.3.2 Take-off Minima

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.1.3.2.1 Take-off Alternate

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
For IFR flight initiation, an appropriate take-off alternate airport shall be selected, and specified on
the OFP, whenever either:

The meteorological conditions at the airport of departure are below the applicable airport
operating landing minima; or
Other operational conditions exist that would preclude a return to the departure airport.
The selected take-off alternate airport shall be located within a specified flying time from the
airport of departure as follows:

For aeroplanes with two engines, one hour of flight time at a one engine-inoperative cruising
speed, determined from the aircraft operating manual, calculated in ISA and still-air
conditions using the actual take-off mass; or
For aeroplanes engaged in EDTO operations where an alternate aerodrome meeting the
distance criteria of 1. (above) is not available, the first available alternate aerodrome located
within the distance of the operator’s approved maximum diversion time considering the
actual take-off mass.
NOTE Take-off alternates are typically selected during the planning stage but, when
necessary, may be selected after flight commencement via radio, ACARS, or any other
communication means.
NOTE For Planning Minima for Take-off Alternate, refer to Chapter 8.1.3.4.1 Planning
Minima for Take-off Alternate
8.1.3.2.2 Required RVR Visibility for Take-off

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
According to the information available to the Commander, the weather at the departure
aerodrome and the condition of the intended runway to be used should not prevent a safe
take-off and departure;
Take-off shall not be commenced unless weather conditions at the airport of departure are
equal to or better than the applicable landing minima at that airport, unless a suitable take-
off alternate aerodrome is available;
When the reported visibility is below that required for take-off and RVR is not reported, or
when neither reported visibility nor RVR is available, a take-off may only be commenced if
the Commander can determine that the RVR/Visibility along the take-off runway is equal to
or better than the required minimum.
The required RVR/Visibility for take-off are shown in the following table.

runway centerline lights once the aeroplane is lined up.

8.1.3.2.3 Low Visibility Take-off

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A low visibility take-off (LVTO) is a take-off in met. conditions with an RVR of less than 400 m. Low
visibility procedures (LVP) must be in effect at the relevant airport, see Chapter 8.4. If no LVP are
established, or LVP are not in force, the lowest RVR authorised for take-off is 400 m.

8.1.3.3.1 Aeroplane Approach Category

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
For approach, aircraft are classified as categories A, B, C, D, and E. EGYPTAIRaircraft are classified as
Category C and D.

The criteria taken into consideration for the classification of aircraft by categories is the indicated
airspeed at threshold (VAT) in landing configuration at the maximum certified landing weight i.e.
VAT = 1.3 VS or VAT = 1.23 VS1G (fly-by-wire aircraft).

If the reported RVR is not available, a CMV may be substituted for the RVR, except:
a. To satisfy take-off minima; or

If the minimum RVR for an approach is more than the maximum value assessed by the
aerodrome operator, then CMV shall be used;
In order to determine CMV from visibility:

8.1.3.3.3 Determination of RVR or VIS for Instrument Approach Operations

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The RVR or VIS for straight-in instrument approach operations shall not be less than the greatest
of the following:

The minimum RVR or VIS for the type of runway used according to Table A: Type of
Runway versus Minimum RVR or VIS below; or
The minimum RVR determined according to the MDH or DH and class of lighting facility
according to Table B: RVR versus DH/MDH below;
The minimum RVR according to the visual and non-visual aids and on-board equipment used
according to Table C: Visual and Non-Visual Aids and/or On-board Equipment versus
Minimum RVR below.
If the value determined in 1.-3. above is a VIS, then the result is a minimum VIS. In all other
cases, the result is a minimum RVR.
If the approach is flown with a level flight segment at or above the MDA/H, then 400 m should be
added to the RVR calculated in accordance with the requirements.

The visual aids should comprise standard runway day markings, runway edge lights, threshold
lights, runway end lights and approach lights as defined in Table D: Approach Lighting Systems
(ICAO and FAA specifications) below.

8.1.3.3.4 Non-Precision Approaches (NPAs) and System Minima

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
All non-precision approaches shall be flown using the continuous descent final approach
technique (CDFA) unless otherwise approved by the Authority for particular approach to particular
runway.

NOTE The optimum angle for the approach slope is 3 degrees and shall not exceed 3,77
degrees.
The missed approach, after an approach has been flown using CDFA technique, shall be
executed when reaching the decision altitude (height) or the MAP, whichever occurs first.
The lateral part of the missed approach procedure must be flown via the MAP unless
otherwise stated in the procedure.

The RVR is the higher value of Chapter 8.1.3.3.3 Determination of RVR or VIS for Instrument
Approach Operations (based on the table below) depending on fulfilling the following
requirements, but not above the maximum values from this table:

Approach is flown using CDFA technique;
Descent angle not above 3,77° for CAT C and D;
Final offset not more than 5° for CAT C and D;
Final approach segment of at least 3 NM;
FAF or appropriate fix where descent is initiated is available, or distance to threshold is
available by FMS, RNAV or DME;
If MAP is defined by timing, the distance from FAF to threshold is less than 8 NM.

8.1.3.4 Planning Minima

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.1.3.4.1 Planning Minima for Take-off Alternate

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
An aerodrome may be selected as a take-off alternate, if the appropriate weather reports or
forecasts or any combination thereof indicate that, during a period commencing one hour before
and ending one hour after the estimated time of arrival, the weather conditions will be at or above
the applicable landing minima, taking into account the status of ground equipment, aircraft
systems, crew qualification and any limitation related to one engine inoperative operation.

When only non-precision approaches are available, then the ceiling must be at or above the
applicable MDH.

8.1.3.4.2 Planning Minima for Destination

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An aerodrome is considered suitable as a destination, if the appropriate weather reports or
forecasts or any combination thereof indicate that, during a period commencing one hour before
and ending one hour after the estimated time of arrival, the weather conditions will be at or above
the applicable landing minima, taking into account the status of ground equipment, aircraft
systems and crew qualification.

When only non-precision approaches are available, then the ceiling must be at or above the
applicable MDH.

8.1.3.4.3 Planning Minima for En-route Alternate and Destination Alternate

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An aerodrome may be selected as a destination alternate, en-route alternate or a 3% ERA, if the
appropriate weather reports or forecasts or any combination thereof indicate that, during a period
commencing one hour before and ending one hour after the estimated time of arrival, the weather
conditions will be at or above the applicable planning minima, refer to Chapter 8.1.3.4.5 Planning
Minima Table.

8.1.3.4.4 Planning Minima for Isolated Aerodrome

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An isolated aerodrome is considered suitable as a destination, if the appropriate weather reports
or forecasts or any combination thereof indicate that, during a period commencing one hour
before and ending two hours after the estimated time of arrival, the weather conditions will be at
or above the applicable planning minima, refer to Chapter 8.1.3.4.5 Planning Minima Table.

8.1.3.4.6 Other Planning Procedures
Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Two destination alternate aerodromes must be selected if either:
The appropriate weather reports or forecasts or any combination thereof indicate that,
during a period commencing one hour before and ending one hour after the estimated
time of arrival at the destination aerodrome, the weather conditions will be below the
applicable landing minima; or;
No meteorological information is available for the destination aerodrome.
No destination alternate aerodrome is needed in the following cases:
Both:
The duration of the planned flight from take-off to landing or, in the event of in-
flight re-planning, the remaining flight time to the destination does not exceed 6
hours; and;
Two separate runways are available and usable at the destination aerodrome, and
the appropriate weather reports or forecasts or any combination thereof indicate
that, during a period commencing one hour before and ending one hour after the
estimated time of arrival, the visibility will be at least 5 km and the ceiling will be at
or above 2.000 ft or 500 ft above the circling height, whichever is greater; or.
The destination is isolated, refer to Chapter 8.1.7.5 Isolated Aerodrome Procedure.
NOTE OFP may contain additional destination alternates for information purpose. Planned
fuel must be checked before using any additional alternate.
NOTE For EDTO En-route Alternate Weather Planning Minima, refer to Chapter 8.5.7 EDTO
Flight Dispatch.
8.1.3.5 Newly Promoted Captains
Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
If the PIC of an aircraft has not served 100 hours as PIC on the type of aircraft he is operating; he
shall act as a pilot flying for the first 100 hours and the MDA(H) or DA(H) and visibility landing
minimums in the certificate holder’s operations specifications for airports are increased by 100 feet
and 800 meters (or the RVR equivalent).
The MDA(H) or DA(H) and visibility minimums need not be increased above those applicable to
the airport when used as an alternate airport but in no event may the landing minimums be less
than 300 feet and 1.600 meters visibility.
New promoted captains, the minima increase applies for both dispatch and actual flight execution.

8.1.6.2 Airport Meteorological DATA

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
METARS and TAFS are produced by airport MET offices and used by the Flight Deck Crew to
decide whether actual/forecast conditions would allow safe landing within the permitted
aerodrome operating minima.

METARS (Aviation routine weather reports) are compiled half-hourly or hourly and usually
contain the following coded information in regards to actual weather conditions:
Type of report (METAR or SPECI);
ICAO station identifier;
Day of the month and time of observation;
Wind direction and speed (kts or km/h);
G (gusts), if any;
Wind variability, if any;
Horizontal visibility or RVR (if visibility is less than 1.500 m);
RVR - if visibility is less than 1.500 m;
Weather phenomena (e.g. FG, SHRA), if any;
Clouds in six character groups, as follows;
a. The first three characters indicate the cloud amount
FEW = 1 to 2 oktas
SCT (scattered) = 3 to 4 oktas
BKN (broken) = 5 to 7 oktas
OVC (overcast) = 8 oktas
SKC = Sky Clear
NSC = No Significant Clouds
NOTE In some countries the cloud amount may still be given in oktas instead
of FEW, SCT, BKN, OVC.
b. The next three characters indicate the cloud layer in hundreds of feet above
aerodrome level;
c. Type of clouds:
CB (cumulonimbus) or TCU (towering cumulus) - if any -.
CAVOK replaces the group in case of:

8.1.7.1 Fuel Planning

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An Operational Flight Plan (OFP) is used to calculate the required fuel for a specific flight at the
planning stage. These calculations are based on the following operating conditions:

Anticipated aeroplane weight;
NOTAMs;
Current meteorological reports or a combination of current reports and forecasts;
ATS procedures, restrictions and anticipated delays;
Aircraft fuel consumption data e.g. performance degradation factor;
The effect of deferred maintenance items and/or configuration deviations; and;
Any other conditions that might increase fuel consumption.
It is EGYPTAIR’ policy to operate its flights using the Standard Fuel Planning procedure or in cases
of proven fuel savings, special fuel planning e.g. Reduced Contingency Fuel, may be considered.

Standard Fuel Planning requirements are only applicable until the aircraft starts push-back,
thereafter the minimum fuel requirements are determined as per item 8.3.8.2 In-flight Fuel
Management.

EGYPTAIR delegates the authority to the Commander to decide the final fuel uplift to complete the
planned flight safely. However, when the OFP planned fuel is carried, EGYPTAIR accepts
responsibility for any diversion as a result of unusual circumstances.

8.1.7.2 Standard Fuel Planning

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The pre-flight calculation of usable fuel required shall include the following:

Taxi Fuel:
Which shall not be less than the amount expected to be used prior to take-off. Local
conditions at the departure aerodrome and APU fuel consumption shall be taken into
account;
Trip Fuel:
Which is the amount of fuel required to enable the aircraft to fly from take-off or the point of
in-flight re-planning until landing at the destination airport, taking into account the operating
conditions specified in Chapter 8.1.7.1 Fuel Planning.
Trip Fuel shall include fuel:
a. For take-off and climb from departure aerodrome elevation to initial cruising level/
altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing;
b. From top of climb to top of descent, including any step climb/descent;
c. From top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the
expected arrival procedure; and
d. For approach and landing at the destination aerodrome.
Contingency Fuel:
Which shall be the amount of fuel required to compensate for unforeseen factors e.g.
deviations from the expected fuel consumption data, deviations from forecast meteorological
conditions, extended taxi times before take-off and deviations from planned routings and/or
cruising levels/altitudes;
Except as provided in Chapter 8.1.7.3 Reduced Contingency Fuel (RCF) Procedure ,
Contingency Fuel must be the higher of (a) or (b) below:
a. Either:
5% of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight re-planning, 5% of the trip
fuel for the remainder of the flight; or
3% of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight re-planning, 3% of the trip
fuel for the remainder of the flight, provided that a fuel en-route alternate is
available, in accordance with the note below (with special approval from ECAA); or
NOTE 3% Reduced contingency fuel will not be used for flights with flight time of 2
hours or less.
b. Fuel for 5 minutes flight time at holding speed at 1.500 ft (450 m) above the destination
aerodrome in standard conditions.
NOTE Location of the fuel en-route alternate: The fuel en-route alternate should be
located within a circle having a radius equal to 20% of the total flight plan
distance, the center of which lies on the planned route at a distance from the
destination of 25% of the total flight plan distance, or at 20% of the total flight
plan distance plus 50 NM, whichever is greater; as illustrated below.
OPERATING PROCEDURES

Destination Alternate Fuel which shall include:
a. Where a destination alternate aerodrome is required, the amount of fuel required to
enable the aeroplane to:
Climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account
the complete missed approach procedure;

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected
routing;
Descent from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking
into account the expected arrival procedure; and;
Executing an approach and landing at the destination alternate aerodrome.
b. Where two destination alternates are required, alternate fuel should be sufficient to
proceed to the alternate which requires the greater amount of alternate fuel;
c. Where a flight is operated without a destination alternate aerodrome, the amount of fuel
required to enable the aeroplane to hold for 15 minutes at 1.500 ft (450 m) above
destination aerodrome elevation in standard conditions;
d. Where the aerodrome of intended landing is an isolated aerodrome, the amount of fuel
required to fly for at least two hours at normal cruise consumption above the destination
aerodrome, including final reserve fuel.
Final Reserve Fuel:
Which is the fuel required to hold for 30 minutes at 1.500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome
elevation in standard conditions calculated with the estimated weight on arrival at the
destination alternate or when no destination alternate aerodrome is required at the
destination aerodrome;
Additional Fuel:
Which is the supplementary amount of fuel required if the minimum fuel calculated in
accordance with (2.) to (5.) above is not sufficient to allow the aeroplane to:
a. Descend as necessary and proceed to an adequate alternate aerodrome in the event of
an engine failure or loss of pressurization, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel
based on the assumption that such a failure occurs at the most critical point along the
route, and:
Hold there for 15 minutes at 1.500 ft (450m) in standard conditions; and;
Make an approach and landing.
b. Comply with the EDTO critical fuel scenario;
c. Meet other operational requirements.
Dispatch Extra Fuel:
It is additional fuel carried at the dispatcher's discretion for any operational reason that may
affect fuel consumption i.e: Wx, ATC, OPN, MEL restriction or hold.
PIC Extra Fuel:
It is additional fuel carried at the Commander's discretion and should only be carried for
sound commercial or operational reasons.
NOTE Refer to Chapter 14.2.33 Permissible Extra Fuel.

8.1.7.3 Reduced Contingency Fuel (RCF) Procedure

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Planning a flight using the Reduced Contingency Fuel Procedure requires pre-flight planning to a
destination aerodrome (destination 1 aerodrome) using a decision point along the route and an
optional refuel destination aerodrome (destination 2 aerodrome).

Using the RCF Procedure, the amount of usable fuel on board for departure shall be the greater of

or 2. below:
The sum of:
a. Taxi fuel; and
b. Trip fuel to the Destination 1 aerodrome, via the decision point; and
c. Contingency fuel equal to not less than 5% of the estimated fuel consumption from
the decision point to the Destination 1 aerodrome; and;
d. Alternate fuel or no alternate fuel if the decision point is at less than six hours from the
Destination 1 aerodrome; and
e. Final reserve fuel; and
f. Extra fuel, if required by the Commander; and
g. Additional fuel.
The sum of:
a. Taxi fuel; and
b. Trip fuel to the Destination 2 aerodrome, via the decision point; and
c. Contingency fuel equal to not less than the amount calculated in accordance with
Chapter 8.1.7.2 Standard Fuel Planning item 3 contingency fuel above from
departure aerodrome to the Destination 2 aerodrome; and
d. Alternate fuel, if a Destination 2 alternate aerodrome is required; and
e. Final reserve fuel; and
f. Extra fuel, if required by the Commander; and
g. Additional fuel.

8.1.7.4 Predetermined Point PDP Procedure

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
When planning a flight to a destination alternate where the distance between the destination
aerodrome and the destination alternate is such that a flight can only be routed via a
predetermined point to one of these aerodromes the amount of usable fuel required is the greater
of (1) or (2) below:

The sum of:
a. Taxi fuel; and
b. Trip fuel from the departure aerodrome to the destination aerodrome via the
predetermined point; and
c. Contingency fuel in accordance with Chapter 8.1.7.2 Standard Fuel Planning item 3;
and
d. Additional fuel if required, but not less than fuel to fly for two hours at normal cruise
consumption above the destination aerodrome (this shall not be less than final reserve
fuel); and
e. Extra fuel, at the discretion of the Commander.
The sum of:
a. Taxi fuel; and
b. Trip fuel from the departure aerodrome to the destination alternate aerodrome, via the
predetermined point; and;
c. Contingency fuel in accordance with Chapter 8.1.7.2 Standard Fuel Planning item 3;
and
d. Additional fuel if required, but not less than fuel to fly for 30 minutes flight time at
holding speed at 1.500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in Standard Conditions
(this shall not be less than final reserve fuel); and
e. Extra fuel, at the discretion of the Commander.
8.1.7.5 Isolated Aerodrome Procedure

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
A destination airport is typically considered isolated when the fuel required for go-around from
the DA/DH or the Missed Approach Point at the destination airport and then to divert to the
nearest alternate airport exceeds the fuel required to hold at the destination airport for two hours,
including final reserve fuel.

Isolated Aerodrome Procedure.

8.1.7.6 Oil

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Engine oil quantity will be sufficient for the Commander to ensure before flight that the engine oil
contents have been topped up in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations, and that
no excessive oil consumption has taken place. Minimum and maximum oil quantities and
maximum average estimated oil consumption are indicated in the relevant aircraft type FCOM.

The Commander shall not commence a flight unless he is satisfied that the airplane carries at least
the amount of oil to complete the flight safely, taking into account the expected operating
conditions.

Maximum Zero Fuel Weight

Maximum Take-off Weight
(MTOW)
It’s the maximum permissible structural (by design) total aero-
plane weight for take-off.
Regulated Take-off Weight
(RTOW)
It’s the maximum weight at which an aircraft can take off from a
particular runway under specific conditions e.g. winds, weather,
specific aircraft configuration...etc.
NOTE When filling the Fuel Docket, the RTOW for a
particular flight sector is determined by

Maximum landing weight plus trip fuel.

Maximum Landing Weight
(MLW)

plane weight upon landing.

Children are defined as persons of an age of two years and
above, but who are less than 12 years of age.
Infants are defined as persons who are less than two years of
age.
Payload (PL) The total weight of the revenue load (PAX, cargo or mail).
Take-off Fuel (TOF) Weight of the fuel on board minus the quantity needed for
taxiing to the point of brake release.
Take-off Weight (TOW) Weight of the equipped, loaded and fuelled aircraft at take-off.
Total Traffic Load Total weight of the load consisting of passengers, baggage,
cargo, and mail including the weight of the Unit Load Devices
(ULD), if applicable.
Trip Fuel (TF) Pre-calculated, estimated fuel consumption from take-off to
landing on the next scheduled destination airport.
Underload Remaining weight capacity still available for loading; difference
between the allowed traffic load and the total traffic load.
Zero Fuel Weight (ZFW) Weight of aircraft, cargo and/or passengers with no fuel.

8.1.8.4 Last Minute Changes Procedure

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Last minute changes to the load and trim sheet are only permitted if the changes of the load,
either plus or minus, are within the limits permitted by the type specific OM Part B. Whenever any
LMC occurs after the completion of the loadsheet, it must be brought to the attention of
Commander and the LMCs must be entered into the "LMC" column. In exceptional cases, changes
may be relayed to the Commander via radio or via the ground service interphone. In this case
Flight Deck Crew, Cabin Crew and ground staff shall amend their copies accordingly to reflect the
LMC value. In addition, the load message sent to the destination must contain the corrected
figures of PAX, cargo, crew, baggage or mail load.

After recording the LMC, Flight Deck Crew shall check that the ZFW, TOW and LW limits, whether
structural or performance, are not exceeded, and that take-off performance calculations are
validated using the revised data.

8.1.8.4.1 LMC Check

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Before recording the LMC, the person responsible for the LMC must ensure that:

The total weight of the “Last Minute Change” on load does not exceed the “Under Load”;

8.1.8.6 Seating Policy

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
The weight and balance sheet is prepared assuming a particular passenger seating distribution. If a
seat allocation system is used in connection with the preparation of the weight and balance sheet,
any possible errors in the CG position will be covered/compensated by the operational CG
envelope, provided the passengers are seated as allocated.

The Commander has the authority to instruct the SCC to re-position passengers so that the actual
seating distribution complies with the weight and balance sheet, e.g. in case of "Free Seating".

Restrictions near emergency exits for infants and some categories of special passengers must be
observed.

In case of all economy flight booking the business class zone may be used by the station in specific
cases such as:

Operational reason, to adjust the center of gravity within permissible limits;
Paid business class ticket and passenger is not informed that no business class available.

8.1.9 ATS Flight Plans

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An ATS flight plan (usually referred to as the ATC flight plan) shall be submitted to the appropriate
ATS unit for all EGYPTAIR flights.

8.1.9.1 EGYPTAIR Procedure

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
One of the purposes of an ATS flight plan is to ensure SAR action should a flight become overdue
at destination.

All EGYPTAIR flights are prohibited from operating out of controlled airspace/airports. The
Commander must ensure that an ATS flight plan is filed for any flight.

The ATC flight plan must be filed at least 1 hour before the ETD, unless national regulations state
otherwise.

The flight plan should be amended or a new flight plan submitted and the old flight plan
cancelled, whichever is applicable, in the event of a delay for which a flight plan has been
submitted of 30 minutes in excess of the estimated off-block time.

At home base the flight dispatcher, and at out side stations the handling agent, will file the ATC
flight plan.

NOTE For the description of the ATS flight plan, as well as the guidance for its use, refer to
OM Part C.
8.1.9.2 Repetitive Flight Plan – RPL

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A RPL is filed for flights that operate on a regular basis at the same time and/or day within a
specific period (e.g. winter/summer schedule or a series of flights for special events). It is essential
that the data upon which the OFP is calculated is identical to that specified in the RPL and vice
versa.

Flight dispatch is responsible for the contents of the RPL lists and their timely distribution to the
appropriate ATS unit.

8.1.9.3 Pilot ATC Agreement

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
A clearance issued by ATC and accepted by a Pilot constitutes an agreement between ATC and the
Commander as to the planned execution of the flight. This agreement is the current flight plan,
whether or not it is the same as the originally filed flight plan.

If at any point after take-off the Commander wishes to change the flight plan, he must request the
change and obtain the concurrence of ATC in the form of an amended clearance. Likewise, ATC
may initiate an amended clearance for traffic requirement.

When ATC issues a clearance, Flight Deck Crew are expected to comply promptly after acceptance.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.1 Flight Preparation Instructions
OM A
8-1-62

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
ATC may use the term "immediate" to communicate urgency and the requirement for expeditious
compliance

A Pilot shall not accept a clearance with which he cannot safely comply with or which exceeds the
capabilities of the aircraft. The Commander has the final authority as to the operation of the
aircraft.

An ATC clearance is not an authorization for a Pilot to deviate from any regulation or to conduct
an unsafe operation. If, due to severe weather, an immediate deviation is required, the Pilot’s
emergency authority will be exercised.

A Pilot should question any clearance or any part of a clearance that he does not understand. Each
PIC who is given priority by ATC in an emergency, shall submit a detailed report of that emergency
through an ASR.

NOTE Direct routing clearance does not relieve Commander from ensuring terrain clearance.
8.1.9.4 Clearance Limits

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An ATC clearance, issued before take-off, normally includes the destination airport as the clearance
limit. A flight may be cleared to a point short of the destination if ATC has no assurance that co-
ordination with a subsequent area control center will be accomplished before that flight enters its
FIR.

A flight must not continue beyond its clearance limit without further clearance.

It is the controller’s responsibility to give further clearance before a flight reaches the clearance
limit. This clearance may change the clearance limit to a point beyond, or it may include holding
instructions, at the clearance limit. In the latter case the controller should provide the Pilot with an
expected further clearance (EFC) time.

8.1.9.5 Clearance Recording/Read Back

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A written record of the initial airway clearance, any significant re-clearance and deviations from
planned figures shall be annotated on the OFP.

The PM must read back to the air traffic controller all safety-related parts of ATC clearances and/or
instructions which are transmitted by voice.

Read back of a clearance should never be replaced by the use of terms such as "Roger", "Wilco" or
"Copied".

All requested/received CPDLCs shall be printed.

For Hear Back/Read Back Policy, refer to Chapter 14.3.8.3 Read Back / Hear Back Policy.

8.1.10 Operational Flight Plan (OFP)

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
8.1.10.1 General

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
An Operational Flight Plan must be prepared for each intended flight by the responsible dispatcher
or by the flight crew. If no Electronic Data Processing OFP is available, the OFP shall be manually,
based on the regulations and policies stipulated in OM Part A, OM Part B, OM Part C and Flight
Dispatch Manual.

Format and Contents

A sample of the OFP will be presented in the AOM (flight planning-chapter) as the form might vary
from type to type. The form shall however contain at least the following:

Basic Data:
Airline’s ICAO Code & flight number;
Scheduled departure date of the flight;
ICAO/IATA code of departure airport, Name of departure airport;
ICAO/IATA code of destination airport;
Aircraft ICAO code;
Aircraft registration;
Released time (UTC) and date of OFP calculation;
OFP number;
Day and time of used weather prognosis (UTC);
Calculated take-off time;
Parking position.
Routing Information Section:
Company route name, or optimization policy, or NAT, or dispatch defined routing;
Routing description from departure to destination.
Threshold elevation in feet of the planned destination Airport’s runway.
ATC CLRNC Section:
Air traffic control clearance Authorize for an aircraft to proceed under conditions specified
by an air traffic control unit.
Weights, Procedures Section:
Standard dry operating index;
Crew configuration Flight Deck / Cabin;
Persons configuration;
CARGO;
Standard Dry Operating weight;
Load;

HECA/05C N0483F370 DCT CVO A727
LXR UM999 IMLER OEJN/34R
Routing description of the planned route to destination,
Routing from ATC f light plan Item 15.
For i nflight calculations the routing starts at inflight re-
planning point and ends with the ICAO code of the inflight
destination.
Note : In case no SID/STAR are published, the route will
start and/or end with DCT. Terminal procedures distance,
i.e. departure and arrival distances, will be determined by
LIDO flight planning system. This will be handled manually
by LIDO and indicated in the system. The calculated
distance will be according to the total distance expected to
be flown, based on available published procedures. It will
be named DCT, but it is not a great circle distance. This
aims to have a more accurate fuel calculation.
Note : Sometimes the route description and ATS flight plan
doesn't contain STAR name, although the flight log
contains STAR name, This occurs when ATC at arrival
airport does not require any STAR name in ATS flight plan.
ELEVATION 0015 Threshold Elevation in feet of the planned Destination Airport¶s runway.

4 - WEIGHTS AND PROCEDURES SECTION
STD DOI standard dry operating index, refer to load sheet.
CREW 01/00 Crew configuration cockpit/cabin, refer to load sheet.
PAX 00/00/000 Seat configuration of passenger cabin, refer to load sheet.
CGO Planned Cargo weight Kgs, refer to load sheet.
STD DOW Standard Dry Operating weight Kgs
LOAD Planned Payload Kgs
ZFW (170000) (Structure Max zero fuel weight) and planned ZFW Kgs
TOF Planned Take off fuel Kgs
TOW (233000) Maximum Structural Takeout Fuel: Max. Taxi weight -off Weight Kgs (Taking into account the value of Taxi – Taxi Fuel = MTOW) and the planned TOW.
TRIP Trip fuel Kgs
LAW (182000) Maximum Structural Landing Weight and planned. Kgs
FREM Fuel remaining over destination (calculated as TOF-TRIP). Kgs
TKOF ALTN ICAO code of Takeoff Alternate Airport
TTL POB Number of Total persons on board, refer to load sheet.
CRZ SYS CI50
Cruise system:
CI50 Cost Index 50 ,
M.82 Mach number .82,
LRC Long Range Cruise,
VRBL Variable speed. (VRBL is shown also when the flight is planned with more
than one cruise system or different CI or Mach number.
If the flight goes through a fixed mach airspace, but only one CI is planned, this CI
is shown.
GND DIST (^741) Total ground distance. NM
AIR DIST 766 Total air distance. NM
AVG W/C M014 Average Wind ComponentClimb and Descent M = minus^ from routing origin to (in (head wind), P = plus-flight) destination (tail wind) including
AVG ISA P016 Average (in-flight) destinationtemperature deviation from ISA component for routing from origin to M (minus) or P (plus)
AVG WIND 112 / 013 Average wind direction/speed for routing from origin to (in-flight) destination
Degree/knots
G/C DIST (^657) Great Circle distance. NM
PERF FACTOR P2.2
Performance Factor used in OFP calculation. Deviation from performance
published in OM Part B (= 100%).
Figures with P indicate a higher consumption and figures with M indicate a lower
consumption.
AVG FF KGS/HR (^6402) Calculated Average Fuel Flow for routing from origin to (in-flight) destination.
FUEL STATISTICS
No DATA AVAILABLE Statistical contingency Fuel –^ Not implemented

8.1.11 EGYPTAIR Aircraft Technical Log

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
EGYPTAIR Technical Log, is a record of reported or observed malfunctions, failures or defects in the
airframe, powerplant, or appliances on an aircraft, including information concerning repairs,
replacements, adjustments, or deferrals.

The ATL normally resides in the aircraft and shall be accessible to all Flight Deck Crew at all time.

Information entered in the ATL, either by fight crew or maintenance personnel, shall be written
with undeletable ink, up-to-date, legible "readable" and shall not, under any circumstances, be
erased.

In case of an error, it shall be corrected, provided each correction is identifiable and the error
remains legible, refer to Chapter 14.2.30 Paper Work.

The Commander shall record in the ATL a clear and detailed description of any known or
suspected defects that may affect the operation of the aircraft.

The ATL may be divided into two binders or combined in one binder:

Technical Log Book "Sector Record Pages";
Deferred Defect Log Book.
Technical Log "Sector Record Pages"

It shall contain details of all information considered necessary to ensure continued flight safety,
such details are:

The aeroplane type and registration mark;
The date and place of take-off and landing;
Name and signature of the PIC;
The take-off and landing times, in UTC in HH:MM format;
The running total of flying hours, such that the hours to the next scheduled maintenance can
be determined;
NOTE The Flight Deck Crew does not need to receive such details if the next scheduled
maintenance is controlled by other means acceptable to the Authority.
Details and description of known or suspected defects, affecting airworthiness or safe
operation of the aeroplane;
Details of rectification/actions taken;
Signature and identity of the person signing the release following maintenance;
NOTE All defects shall be properly recorded for the purpose of remediation and
processing in accordance with the MEL/CDL.

Deferred Defect Log Book

accordance with the MEL/CDL and to record the actions taken to rectify these items. Maintenance-
approved personnel shall fill out the log.

recorded;
Date of and the reason for deferral;
Interval of deferral;
Rectification date, action taken to rectify deferred discrepancy and reference to maintenance
data;
Record of extension, if applicable.

master copy shall remain onboard the relevant aircraft at least until rectification of deferrals.

8.2 GROUND HANDLING INSTRUCTIONS

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.2.1 Fuelling / Defuelling Procedures

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.2.1.1 General

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Chapter 8.1.7 Determination of the Quantities of Fuel, Oil and Water Methanol Carried
describes the calculation of the take-off fuel. Based upon the estimated zero fuel weight of the
aeroplane, possible performance limitations, and the maximum structural performance limiting
weights, a decision may be made to load "extra fuel" for the purpose of safety precaution or for
economical tankering.

The total requested fuel (block fuel) shall be entered in the "Fuelling Order" form, by the Flight
Deck Crew or, in some cases, by flight dispatch. When applicable for the aeroplane type
concerned, the "Fuel-ling Order" form may specify the fuel uplift for the various fuel tanks. Flight
Deck Crew must convert the fuel amount into Kilograms to check the uplifted fuel and the total
fuel on board.

NOTE The issuance of a "Fuelling Order", as a written document, may become redundant
when the Flight Deck Crew can supervise the fuelling/defuelling personally.
When calculating the fuel uplift, the actual specific gravity of the fuel shall be considered. If no
specific gravity is known, the values given under Chapter 8.1.8.5 Specific Gravity of Fuel and
Other Fluids shall be used.

Block and uplifted fuel shall be entered into the "Aeroplane Technical Log".

8.2.1.2 Safety Precautions During Fuelling / Defuelling

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
NO SMOKING shall be permitted on the ground;
Fuel hoses shall be positioned in the shortest distance from the fuel truck (or fuel pump
vehicle) to the fuelling/defuelling inlets, taking into consideration, sufficient clearance from
wheel brakes, (at least 1 meter), and from APU air intakes, where applicable;
Bonding connections from the fuel truck (or fuel pump vehicle) to the aircraft shall be
established for discharging any static electricity, before fuel hoses are connected;
Except for the fuel truck (or fuel pump vehicle), no vehicle shall be positioned within the
venting areas;
Cargo/baggage may be loaded, provided the loading equipment complies with the safety
regulations regarding the formation of sparks;
Spilled fuel shall be removed or dried up immediately in the attendance of fire services,
before passengers boarding;
APU or brake fans shall be switched ON or OFF, before starting the fuelling/defuelling. No
APU/ Engine starting is permitted during fuelling/defuelling;
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.2 Ground Handling Instructions
OM A
8-2-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
In case of over-wing fuelling/defuelling, ground power units and/or aircraft auxiliary power
units shall be connected and switched ON before commencement of fuelling/defuelling,
and shall not be switched OFF or disconnected until fuelling/defuelling is completed. No
electrical switch ON the aircraft or on the ground power unit shall be operated whilst over-
wing fuelling/defuelling is in progress, except such switches necessary for fuelling/
defuelling;
During pressure fuelling/defuelling, electrical and/or electronic systems may only be
operated as far as required for pre-flight activities, except WX-radar and HF-Transmitters;
Mobile phones shall not be used during fuelling/defuelling;
No fuelling/defuelling is permitted during thunderstorms.
NOTE Pressure fuelling/defuelling is considered to start, as soon as fuel hoses are connected
to the aeroplane, and to be terminated after all fuel hoses have been disconnected.
NOTE Gravity over wing fuelling/defuelling is considered to start, as soon as the filler caps
are opened and to be finished when they are closed.
8.2.1.3 Fuelling / Defuelling with Passengers on Board or Embarking /

Disembarking
* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The start of fuelling/defuelling must be coordinated with the Commander to allow him to brief the
entire crew concerning safety regulations and procedures. After fuelling/defuelling is completed,
the Commander must be informed. In addition, personnel and passengers shall be warned that
fuel-ling/defuelling will take place.

The following special safety precautions have to be strictly adhered to:

The aerodrome Operator/Authority shall be notified and when required by the aerodrome
Operator/Authority the fire brigade will be positioned at the aircraft;
Stairs and/or air jetties docked to the aircraft;
Fuelling/defuelling activities are restricted to one side of the aircraft;
One Flight Deck Crew Member remains on the Flight Deck;
FASTEN SEAT BELT signs should be OFF;
NO SMOKING signs shall be ON, together with interior lighting to enable emergency exits to
be identified;
Two-way communication shall be established and shall remain available, via the aircraft
Intercommunication system, between the ground crew supervising the fuelling/defuelling and
the Flight Deck Crew Member on-board the aircraft;
The minimum required number of Cabin Crew must be on board and be prepared for an
immediate emergency evacuation;
Flight Deck Crew shall verbally inform the Purser / SCC about the start and end of the
fuelling/de-fuel-ling procedures. The Purser / SCC shall rely the information to the Cabin Crew
via the PA / intercom;
Passengers shall be instructed, via PA, to remain seated, unfasten their seat belts, refrain from
smoking and not to operate any electronic device;
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.2 Ground Handling Instructions
OM A
8-2-3
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Ground servicing activities and work inside the aircraft, such as catering and cleaning, shall be
conducted in such a manner that they do not create a hazard and allow emergency
evacuation to take place through those aisles and exits intended for emergency evacuation;
If fuel vapors in the cabin or other dangerous situations are observed, Flight Deck Crew and
fuelling staff must be informed immediately and the fuelling/defuelling has to be stopped;
The ground area beneath the exits intended for emergency evacuation and slide deployment
areas shall be kept clear at doors where stairs are not in position for use in the event of
evacuation.
With respect to the emergency exits, the following conditions have to be adhered to:

If equal number of Cabin Crew to doors is available; all doors have to be occupied in order to:
Evacuate through assigned doors;
Block doors which cannot be used for an evacuation;
Secure open doors when loading vehicles are retracted.
If fewer Cabin Crew number than doors are available:
As a general rule, for all aircraft types, at least a minimum of two exit doors shall be
opened, and passenger stairs/air jetties must be positioned at these doors;
At least those emergency exits, indicated in the type specific OM Part B, have to be
occupied, and the opposite unoccupied doors have to be watched;
Unoccupied doors shall remain Disarmed. (They shall be set to ARMED before opening, if
an evacuation becomes necessary).
NOTE If only one passenger stair/air jetty is available, fuelling/defuelling with passengers on
board is allowed provided that the missing stair/air jetty can be replaced by an
evacuation slide.
NOTE If no passenger stair/air jetty is available, simultaneous catering or loading is not
permitted in order to allow the deployment of all escape slides.
NOTE In the event of an emergency (e.g. APU fire), during fuelling/defuelling, the operation
must be stopped and an immediate disembarkation initiated. The Flight Deck Crew will
decide whether this should be a rapid deplaning disembarkation or an (emergency
evacuation).

disembarkation of the passengers and the loading/unloading of baggage, cargo and mail.

It is every Crew Member’s responsibility to ensure that no person secretes himself or cargo on
board an aeroplane, additionally, Crew Members must ensure that no person is in any part of the
aeroplane in-flight which is not a part designed for the accommodation, unless temporary access
has been granted by the Commander.

8.2.2.1 Ground Operations with Passengers on Board

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Whenever passengers are on board an aeroplane, at least the minimum number of Cabin Crew as
per Chapter 4.3.6 Minimum Number of Cabin Crew to be Onboard an Aeroplane During
Operations has to be present in the cabin.

For ground operations with passengers on board, the following requirements must be met:

Electrical power is available on the aeroplane;
Means of initiating evacuation is available to the Senior Cabin Crew Member or at least one
Flight Deck Crew Member is on the flight deck; and
Cabin Crew Members remain aware of the position of servicing and loading vehicles, at and
near the exits.
8.2.2.2 Passengers Embarkation / Disembarkation

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Before embarking/disembarking passengers, ground staff/Flight Deck Crew must brief them on all
relevant safety aspects to be observed whilst boarding/leaving the aeroplane. When air jetties are
in use, ground staff must be positioned at appropriate locations in order to provide supervision
and assistance. When passengers are required to walk on the ramp, they shall be escorted by
ground staff to/from the aeroplane or to/from the approved transport; passenger routes shall be
clear of oil, ice, snow and other hazards and shall be selected in such a way as to prevent damages
and accidents (e.g. no passing below wings or engines).

Boarding shall not commence until the Commander or his representative has given clearance.
Disembarkation shall not commence until the crew has received confirmation from the ground
staff that passenger stairs/air jetties are safely positioned and that ground equipment will not be a
hazard.

Only in exceptional cases, and with the consent of the Commander, embarkation/disembarkation
is permissible with one engine running; in such case, passengers shall leave/enter the aeroplane on
the side opposite to the running engine.

NOTE For embarkation/disembarkation when fuelling/defuelling is in progress, refer to
Chapter 8.2.1.3 Fuelling / Defuelling with Passengers on Board or Embarking /
Disembarking.

Each person to be carried who is 2 years of age or older shall be allocated a separate seat or berth,
equipped with a proper safety belt/harness.

If the person has not reached his second birthday (infant), and is accompanied by a parent/
guardian, or attendant designated by the person’s parent/guardian to attend to his safety during

standards of the United Nations for aircraft or automobile, may be used, provided the certificate

and
The child must be properly secured in the restraint system and must not exceed the specified

8.2.2.3.1 Exit Row Seating Assignments

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Seats that permit direct access to emergency exits shall be assigned only to passengers who
appear to be reasonably fit, strong and able to assist the rapid evacuation of the aircraft in an
emergency, after an appropriate briefing by the crew.

In all cases, passengers who, because of their condition, might hinder other passengers during an
evacuation or who might impede the crew in carrying out their duties should not be allocated
seats, which permit direct access to emergency exits.

The following categories of passengers are among those who shall not be allocated to, or directed
to seats, which permit direct access to emergency exits:

Physically or mentally handicapped;
Blind or deaf;
Children or infants (whether or not accompanied by an adult);
Passengers whose physical size would prevent them from moving quickly;
Passengers who are elderly and frail;
Pregnant women;
Deportees or passengers in custody;
Passengers accompanied by guide dog/falcons;
Adults with infants.
In addition, designated exit row seats will not be assigned to passengers who are unwilling to
assist in the event of an emergency.

8.2.2.4 Sick/Injured Passengers and Persons with Reduced Mobility (PRMs)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The acceptance for transportation of sick, injured, disabled and handicapped passengers is
restricted in the interest of their own safety and that of other passengers.

A person with reduced mobility (PRM) is understood to mean a person whose mobility is reduced
due to physical inability (sensory or locomotory), an intellectual deficiency, age, illness or any other
cause of disability when using transport, and whose situation requires special attention and the
adaptation to his needs, of the service made available to all passengers.

In such cases, EGYPTAIR is entitled to insist on a written report, issued by a medical doctor of
EGYPTAIR or the medical officials at the airport, confirming that the passenger is fit to travel.

NOTE In order to accept PRMs, embarking from any Egyptian airport, they should possess a
valid medical certificate, issued from a hospital.
No transportation, under any circumstances, will be provided to a person who:

Has a contagious/infectious disease (e.g. open tuberculosis, infectious hepatitis, scarlet fever,
diphtheria, chicken pox, etc.);
Has suffered a heart attack or stroke within the last eight weeks;

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Requires medical treatment by pneumatically or electrically operated apparatus, which is not
allowed to be operated on board.
EGYPTAIR accepts passengers that have the potential need for therapeutic medical oxygen, for
usage during flight, refer to OM Part F.

The following definitions indicate the degree of immobility and the extent of assistance required:

MEDA (Medical Advise Signal) A passenger whose mobility is impaired, due to clinical cases with medical
pathology in progress, but is authorized to travel by medical authorities.
STCR (Stretcher Patient) Carriage of any stretcher patient is subject to the approval of the patient’s
physician and EGYPTAIR’ Medical Doctor. They will be boarded first and
disembarked last. Passengers on stretchers shall be accompanied by a doctor/
nurse, or a family member or other escort to provide him with the required
en-route care. The prescribed seating and the maximum number of stretcher
patients that are accepted, are type specific and given in the OM Part F.
WCHR (Wheel Chair Ramp) Passengers who can ascend/descend steps and move about in an aeroplane
cabin, but who require a wheelchair or other means for movement to manage
long distances.
WCHS (Wheel Chair Steps) Passengers who cannot ascend/descend steps and move about in an
aeroplane cabin, but who require a wheelchair or other means for movement
to manage steps.
WCHC (Wheel Chair Cabin) Passengers who are completely immobile, and require wheelchair to/from
aircraft and to/from cabin seat.
BLIND Blind
DEAF Mute passenger who is deaf without speech.
DEAF/BLIND Who can only move about with the help of an accompanying person.
MAAS (Meet and Assist) All other passengers in need of special help.
INCO Occupied infant incubator
INCU Unoccupied infant incubator
Before accepting such passengers for transportation, EGYPTAIR shall ascertain the availability of
trained and qualified staff and the appropriate medical equipment.

The number of PRM passengers should not exceed the number of able-bodied persons capable of
assisting with an emergency evacuation. Passengers with disabilities as circumscribed under,
WCHS and WCHC above, should be allocated seats in between two pairs of emergency exits; in
this way, when the aeroplane is being evacuated, they can, without impeding others, be assisted to
reach the end of the queue forming at the emergency exit(s) and to leave the aeroplane.

Sick and disabled passengers and PRMs should be boarded separately (normally prior to all other
passengers), as well as disembarked separately (normally after all other passengers have left the
cabin). The Commander shall be notified by special categories of passenger notification form,
when handicapped passengers and PRMs are to be carried on board; he shall brief his crew
accordingly.

Information on passengers requiring any assistance at transit or destination airports must be
forwarded by telex, telefax or phone to the ground staff or handling agent at the respective down
line station(s).

For the allocation of seats, refer to Chapter 8.2.2.3 Allocation of Seats to Adults, Children and
Infants.

8.2.2.5 Transportation of Inadmissible Passengers, Deportees or Persons in

Custody
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Inadmissible Passengers (INADs) are passengers who are refused admission to a country by
authorities of such country, e.g. due to lack of a visa, expired passport, lack of funds or suspected
intent to illegally take up employment. Unless explicitly ordered otherwise by the Authority
refusing entry, an INAD shall be carried outbound again on a flight (flights) of the inbound
carrier(s) to a country of his choice where there is no risk of his being refused entry again, but no
further than his home country or country of permanent residence.

Deportees are foreign persons who had legally been admitted to a country or who had entered a
country illegally, and who at some later time are formally ordered by the authorities to be removed
from that country. Apart from illegal entry, reasons for removal comprise expiry of residence
permit, offences or criminal acts committed in the deporting country or extradition at the request
of another country.

The company and the Commander (who shall be notified by Special Categories of Passenger
Notification form prior to departure of the intended carriage of inadmissible passengers,
deportees or persons in custody and of the reason for carriage) have not only the right, but the
duty to refuse transportation of such passengers if their carriage poses any risk to the safety of the
aeroplane or its occupants. Therefore, the company and (via the company) the Commander are
entitled to be informed of the reason for the deportation and, if necessary, to insist on the
passenger being escorted during the flight by a representative of the deporting country, with a
ticket at the applicable fare being provided for such representative by the deporting Authority.

In particular, inadmissible passengers or deportees who:

Will physically resist carriage; or
Have already been denied transportation by another company; or
Might endanger the safety of the aeroplane or of its load, of other passengers or of the
crew; or
Are deported after execution/suspension of a sentence for a crime of violence.
Shall be carried only under escort of a government official, or of a properly trained staff member of
the company, or of a similarly trained guard provided by a commercial agency.

The ECAA will determine, in coordination with the G.M. Flight Operations, if a deportee requires an
escorting official or guard, and they will also determine how many escorting officials or guards are
required to guarantee the safety of the flight. Whenever it has been determined that the passenger
requires an escort, such escorting person shall be present and on duty when the passenger is
checked in; and shall remain so until the company relinquishes responsibility for the passenger
after transportation.

The Commander, upon notification by "Special Categories of Passenger Notification", shall, prior to
departure, brief his entire crew accordingly.

Whenever feasible, such passengers shall be boarded prior to other passengers in order to provide
utmost discretion; if, at this stage, a deportee physically resists boarding the aeroplane,
embarkation and transportation shall be refused.

8.2.2.6 Permissible Size and Weight of Hand Baggage

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The secure stowage of hand baggage, as prescribed in Chapter 8.2.2.7.3 Securing of Load
"CABIN" , the size and weight limits for hand luggage given below should not be exceeded:

No. of pieces per person:
2 pieces for Business Class + 1 personal
1 piece for Economy Class + 1 personal
Star Alliance Gold, as per cabin class booked.
Maximum size: 118 cm (length + height + width)
Maximum mass: 8 kg
These limits vary with each aeroplane type/cabin layout combination (see OM Part B). The
company and its handling agent(s) shall brief passengers at check-in, by means of placards/posters
or verbally, about the maximum size and weight of hand baggage; where practicable, a receptacle
should serve as a gauge.

When boarding is in progress, ground staff and, at the aeroplane, Crew Members shall visually
scan the hand baggage held by passengers, in case check-in personnel were bypassed, and, where
such baggage exceeds the allowance, politely deny the passenger access to the aeroplane until
such baggage has been given up to be stowed in a baggage/cargo hold or suitable place outside
of the aeroplane’s cabin.

In exceptional cases, a passenger is prepared to pay for an extra seat (CBBG) cabin seat baggage in
order to carry valuable baggage (e.g. antiques, musical instruments, works of art, etc.) acceptance
is only permitted if the safety and comfort of other passengers will not be impaired and if the size
of such baggage permits it to be secured on the seat in such a manner as to prevent movement
forward, sideways or upwards under crash impact.

NOTE CBBG actual weight must be inserted in the load sheet, otherwise 45 kg shall be
inserted.
NOTE The gate controller should notify the Purser/SCC.

8.2.2.7 Loading and Securing of Items in the Aeroplane

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.2.2.7.1 Loading

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
All baggage, cargo, mail to be loaded, should be positioned on the ramp in sufficient time in order
to ensure an on-time departure and to reduce pressure upon staff that is detrimental to safety. The
load must be protected against the elements and all sources of contamination. All loading
equipment and material shall be handled carefully to avoid damage to the aeroplane or the load.

Only the appropriate compartments shall be used for loading. Loading in toilets, crew
compartments etc. is prohibited.

All aeroplane specific limitations and instructions (e.g. for loading unit load devices) shall be
observed (see OM Part B).

In compartments with pallet positions, no load shall be stowed on the floor beside the pallets.
Special handling instructions (e.g. "This Side Up") shall be observed for sensitive shipments, which
must be loaded carefully to prevent damage by other items. Heavy and solidly packed pieces must
be loaded at the bottom.

Cargo shall be excluded from carriage if:

It is not properly packed;
It may damage or contaminate the aeroplane or other load;
Special handling instructions/equipment cannot be observed/ supplied.
NOTE Any damage to the aeroplane skin or structure, however slight, which occurs or is
noticed, must be reported immediately.
NOTE Special loading/unloading procedures have been developed and published in each
OM Part B, which safeguards the aeroplane’s ground stability and prevents its tipping.
In principle, loading should start in the forward compartments and continue in the aft
ones, whilst offloading should start in the aft compartments and continue in the
forward ones. The same sequence applies for galleys. It is prohibited to use passenger
distribution for securing ground stability.
8.2.2.7.2 Unloading

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
For unloading, the same safety-relevant principles are valid as for loading. Personnel and
equipment should be available at the parking position upon arrival of the aeroplane. Passenger
baggage should normally be unloaded first. Cabin load, if any, shall be unloaded after all
passengers have disembarked. Mail shall be unloaded before other cargo. After completion of
unloading the cargo, compartments shall be carefully checked, by a designated staff member, for
damages, spilled liquids and contamination.

8.2.2.7.3 Securing of Load "CABIN"

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Cargo may only be carried in a passenger compartment if it is stowed and secured on an approved
cargo bin or seat container certificated to withstand specific load factors; the bin shall be attached
to the seat tracks/floor structure, the seat container to the passenger seat; maximum loading limits
shall be observed. Cabin loading shall be completed prior to boarding passengers; Emergency Exits
shall not be obstructed.

Installations are not permitted in a position that obscures any passenger’s view of any required
FASTEN SEAT BELT, NO SMOKING or EXIT signs, nor in a location that restricts access to, or use of,
any required emergency equipment or emergency exits, or of the aisle. Nor shall the equipment
hinder egress or impair the Cabin Crew’s view.

For hand baggage:

Each item carried in a cabin must be stowed in a location that is capable of restraining it;
Weight limitations placarded on or adjacent to stowage must not be exceeded;
Under seat stowage must not be used unless the seat is equipped with a restraint bar and
the baggage is of such size that it may adequately be restrained by this equipment;
Items must not be stowed in toilets or against bulkheads that are incapable of restraining
articles against movement forwards, sideways or upwards unless the bulkheads carry a
placard specifying the maximum weight that may be placed there;
Baggage placed in lockers must not prevent doors from being closed securely;
Baggage must not be placed where it can impede access to emergency equipment.
Items carried in passenger or crew compartment shall be secured in such a way as not to become
a hazard by shifting under the appropriate load factors corresponding to the ultimate inertia forces
specified in the emergency landing condition of type certification.

NOTE Serving carts must be stowed for take-off and landing.
8.2.2.7.3.1 Cabin Loading

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Loading of passengers checked baggage, or mail in the cabin of EGYPTAIR passenger aircraft is
allowed in exceptional cases and after IOCC approval. If loading is to be performed, the following
conditions must be adhered to:

Do not restrict access to, or use of, any required emergency or regular exit, or aisle in the
cabin;
Seats should be protected against dirt and tear by using a seat-cover before loading on a
seat;
Each seat must not accommodate more than 75 kg; also each package must not exceed
75 kg;
Only odorless, dry load to be accommodated in the cabin;
Load is properly secured by a safety belt or restraint device having to eliminate the
possibility of shifting under all normal anticipated flight and ground conditions and to avoid
possible injury to passengers and Cabin Crew;
Load is to be stacked not higher than the lower edge of the window;
The load on seats must be covered with blankets to conceal it from view;
