8-3-96

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
b. Supercooled water freezes on impact with an aircraft. Clear icing can occur at any
altitude above the freezing level but at high levels, icing from smaller droplets may be
rime or mixed rime and clear. The abundance of large, supercooled water droplets
makes clear icing very rapid between 0 °C and -15 °C, and encounters can be frequent
in a cluster of cells. Thunderstorm icing can be extremely hazardous.
Hail
a. Hail competes with turbulence as the greatest thunderstorm hazard to aircraft.
Supercooled drops above the freezing level begin to freeze. Once a drop has frozen,
other drops latch on and freeze to it, so the hailstone grows - sometimes into a huge
iceball. Large hail occurs with severe thunderstorms with strong updrafts that have
built to great heights. Eventually, the hailstones fall, possibly some distance from the
storm core. Hail may be encountered in clear air several miles from the thunderstorm;
b. As hailstones fall through air with temperatures above 0 °C, they begin to melt and
precipitation may reach the ground as either hail or rain. Rain at the surface does not
mean the absence of hail aloft.
Pilots should anticipate possible hail with any thunderstorm, especially beneath the
anvil of a large cumulonimbus. Hailstones larger than one-half inch in diameter can
significantly damage an aircraft in a few seconds.
Low Ceiling and Visibility
Generally, visibility is near zero within a thunderstorm cloud. Ceiling and visibility also may
be restricted in precipitation and dust between the cloud base and the ground. The
restrictions create the same problem as all ceiling and visibility restrictions, but the hazards
are increased when associated with the other thunderstorm hazards of turbulence, hail, and
lightning that make precision instrument flying virtually impossible;
Effect on Altimeters
Pressure usually falls rapidly with the approach of a thunderstorm. Pressure then usually
rises sharply with the onset of the first gust, and arrival of the cold downdraft and heavy
rain, falling back to normal as the thunderstorm passes. This cycle of pressure change may
occur in 15 minutes. If the pilot does not receive a corrected altimeter setting, the altimeter
may be more than 100 feet in error;
Lightning
A lightning strike can puncture the skin of an aircraft and can damage communications and
electronic navigational equipment. Lightning has been suspected of igniting fuel vapours
causing an explosion; however, serious accidents due to lightning strikes are extremely rare.
Nearby lightning can blind the pilot, rendering the pilot momentarily unable to navigate
either by instrument or by visual reference.
Nearby lightning can also induce permanent errors in the magnetic compass. Lightning
discharges, even distant ones, can disrupt radio communications on low and medium
frequencies. Though lightning intensity and frequency have no simple relationship to other
storm parameters, severe storms, as a rule, have a high frequency of lightning;
Engine Water Ingestion
a. Turbine engines have a limit on the amount of water they can ingest. Updrafts are
present in many thunderstorms, particularly those in the developing stages. If the
updraft velocity in the thunderstorm approaches or exceeds the velocity of the falling
raindrops, very high concentrations of water may occur. It is possible that these
concentrations can be in excess of the quantity of water that turbine engines are

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
designed to ingest. Therefore, severe thunderstorms may contain areas of high water
concentration which could result in flameout and/or structural failure of one or more
engines;
b. At the present time, there is no known operational procedure that can completely
eliminate the possibility of engine damage/flameout during massive water ingestion.
Although the exact mechanism of these water-induced engine stalls has not been
determined, it is felt that thrust changes may have an adverse effect on engine stall
margins in the presence of massive water ingestion;
c. Avoidance of severe storm systems is the only measure assured to be effective in
preventing exposure to this type of multiple engine damage/flameout. During an
unavoidable encounter with severe storms with extreme precipitation, the best known
recommendation is to follow the severe turbulence penetration procedure contained
in the approved AFM with special emphasis on avoiding thrust changes unless
excessive airspeed variations occur.

Pilots must continually monitor the weather radar, in order to select the safest track for
penetration;
If Thunderstorms have to be overflown, maintain at least 5.000 ft vertical separation from
cloud's top;
If the weather radar is inoperative, avoid by 10 miles any thunderstorm that by visual
inspection is tall, growing rapidly or has an anvil top;
Avoid flight under the anvil. The greatest possibility of encountering hail is downwind of the
cell, where hail falls from the anvil or is tossed out from the side of the storm. Hail has been
encountered as much as 20 NM downwind from large thunderstorms;
When it is necessary to fly parallel to a line of cells, the safest path is on the upwind side
(the side away from the direction of storm travel). Although severe turbulence and hail can
be encountered in any direction outside a thunderstorm, strong drafts and hail are more
often encountered outside the body of the cell on the downwind side.
In order to avoid thunderstorms, the following may be requested from ATC:
To deviate off course, by stating the number of miles and the direction of the requested
deviation;
A new route to avoid the affected area;

8.3.9.2.4 Thunderstorm Penetration

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Notwithstanding the advice that follows, gathered from research and operational experience, the
first and most basic advice for all pilots is:

Do not treat thunderstorms lightly and whenever possible AVOID them.

Thunderstorms should be avoided either visually, by the use of radar, or by other methods. If this
cannot be achieved, and in the absence of specific aircraft flight manual or operations manual
guidance, the following procedures and techniques are recommended.

If it is found necessary to penetrate an area of cloud which may contain cumulonimbus
clouds:
a. Ensure that crew members' safety belts or harnesses are firmly fastened and secure any
loose articles beforehand. Switch on the seat belt signs and make sure that all
passengers are securely strapped in and that loose equipment (e.g. cabin trolleys and
galley containers) are firmly secured. Pilots should remember that turbulence is
normally worse in the rear of an aircraft than on the flight deck;
b. Select an altitude for penetration, bearing in mind the importance of ensuring
adequate terrain clearance in likely downdraughts. Investigations have shown that
although in some thunderstorms there is very little turbulence at the lower levels, in
others there is a great deal; altitude is not necessarily a guide to the degree of
turbulence. Increasing height will decrease the buffet margin and up-currents may
force the aircraft into buffet owing to an increased angle of attack;
c. Set autothrust on and fly turbulence penetration speed as per OM Part B, monitor trim
and its position so that any excessive changes due to autopilot or Mach trim operation
can be quickly assessed. Turbulence speeds quoted in flight or operations manuals
provide a single speed or a speed bracket;
d. Check all flight instruments and electrical supplies;
e. Ensure that the pitot heaters are switched on;
f. Check the operation of all anti-icing and de-icing equipment and operate all these
systems in accordance with OM Part B. The operation of leading edge, expanding boot
type deicers should be delayed until some ice has formed, otherwise their effectiveness
will be greatly reduced. In the absence of specific instructions, ensure that all anti-icing
systems, including windscreen heaters, are on;
g. Disregard any radio navigation indications subject to interference from static, e.g. ADF;
h. Turn the flight deck lighting fully on and lower the crew seats and sun visors to
minimise the effect of any lightning flashes;
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures
OM A
8-3-99
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
i. Follow the manufacturer's or operator's recommendations on the use of the flight
director, autopilot and manometric locks. If these are not stated, height, Mach, rate of
climb or descent, and airspeed locks should be disengaged but the yaw damper,
should remain operative. On many aircraft the autopilot, is likely to produce lower
structural loads than would result from manual flight. However, if major trim
movements occur due to the autopilot's automatic trim the autopilot should be
disengaged. Note that Mach trim operation may also occur on some aircraft but the
Mach trim should remain engaged;
j. Continue operating, not just monitoring, the weather radar, or other on-board systems,
in order to select the safest track for penetration, and to minimise the time of exposure
whilst avoiding areas of intense activity;
k. Be prepared for turbulence, rain, hail, snow, icing, lightning, static discharge and
windshear. Switch on the continuous ignition system (to reduce the possibility of
engine flameout due to water ingestion) ensuring that limitations on its use, if any, are
not exceeded;
l. Avoid flying over the top of a thunderstorm whenever possible. Overflying small
convective cells close to large storms should also be avoided, particularly if they are on
the upwind side of a large storm, because they may grow very quickly. Similarly, do not
contemplate flying beneath the cumulonimbus cloud. In addition to the dangers
associated with turbulence, rain, hail, snow or lightning, there may well be low cloud
base, poor visibility and possibly low-level windshear.
Within the Storm Area:
a. Control the aircraft regardless of all else;
b. Concentrate on maintaining a constant pitch attitude appropriate to climb, cruise or
descent, by reference to the attitude indicators, carefully avoiding harsh or excessive
control movements. Do not be misled by conflicting indications on other instruments.
Do not allow large attitude excursions in the rolling plane to persist because these may
result in nose down pitch changes;
c. Maintain the original heading - it is usually the quickest way out. Do not attempt any
turns;
d. Do not correct for altitude gained or lost through up and down draughts unless
absolutely necessary;
e. Maintain the trim settings and avoid changing the power setting except when
necessary to restore margins from stall warning or high-speed buffet. The target pitch
attitude should not be changed unless the mean IAS differs significantly from the
recommended penetration speed;
f. If trim variations due to the autopilot (auto-trim) are large, the autopilot should be
disengaged. However, movement of the Mach trim, where it occurs, is necessary and
desirable. Check that the yaw-damper remains engaged;
g. If negative 'G' is experienced, temporary warnings (e.g. low oil pressure) may occur.
These should be ignored;
h. On no account climb in an attempt to get over the top of the storm.
After a Thunderstorm Encounter - In flight:
a. If hail has been encountered, considerable damage to the airframe, not visible from the
flight deck or cabin, may have occurred. Consideration should therefore be given to
diverting to a suitable and nearby aerodrome where the aircraft can be inspected for
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
damage. If this damage has occurred to aerodynamically significant areas, e.g. a nose
radome, the increased drag will affect fuel burn. Thus the aircraft, if continuing to its
destination, may burn considerably more fuel than expected or planned. Actual fuel
usage should now be monitored very closely, bearing in mind that some FMS calculate
‘expected overhead destination’ fuel, based on data that assumes normal (planned)
conditions and normal (i.e. fully clean) aircraft aerodynamic states;
b. If the aircraft has been struck by lightning, treat all magnetic information (e.g. from
direct or remote indicating compasses) with extreme caution. The large electric
currents associated with a lightning strike can severely and permanently distort the
magnetic field of an aircraft rendering all such information highly inaccurate.
Air Traffic Control Considerations:
a. Modern ATC radars in general do not display the build up of weather that may
constitute a hazard to aircraft and ATC advice on weather avoidance may, therefore, be
limited;
b. If, as recommended above, a pilot intends to detour round observed weather when in
receipt of an Air Traffic Service that involves ATC responsibility for separation,
clearance should first be obtained from ATC so that separation from other aircraft can
be maintained. If for any reason the pilot is unable to contact ATC to inform the
controller of his/her intended action, any manoeuvre should be limited to the extent
necessary to avoid immediate danger and ATC must be informed as soon as possible.
In oceanic airspace specific weather deviation procedures should be followed;
c. Because of the constraints on airspeed and flight path and the increased workload of
the crew when flying in a Terminal Manoeuvring Area, pilots should consider making a
diversion from, or delaying entry to, a Terminal Manoeuvring Area if a storm encounter
seems probable.
Take-off and Landing Problems:
a. The take-off, initial climb, final approach and landing phases of flight present the pilot
with additional problems because of the aircraft's proximity to the ground, thus the
maintenance of a safe flight path in these phases can be very difficult;
b. Some operators give advice on the airspeed adjustments to be made to allow for
windshear or turbulence (a speed increase of up to 20 knots according to the type of
aircraft and the degree of turbulence may be required). The best advice that can be
given to the pilot is that, when there are thunderstorms over or near the aerodrome,
he should delay take-off or, when approaching to land, hold in an unaffected area or
divert to a suitable alternate;
c. Airworthiness and Maintenance Considerations:
i. Severe weather conditions may cause damage to aircraft and power plant
installations, some of which may be invisible to the naked eye. Flight Manuals and
Maintenance documents may quantify levels of turbulence which would trigger a
maintenance inspection, similar to those that may be applicable to ‘heavy landings’.
Hail and lightning damage may often be obvious to crews; however, there will be
occasions where damage may be restricted to parts of the airframe not normally
visible from the ground, or from the flight deck, immediately following a
thunderstorm encounter;

ii. In the event that crews believe that an aircraft has been exposed to hail, lightning,

8.3.9.3 Icing Conditions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
General

Icing of the aircraft is one of the most dangerous flight hazards; procedures for operating in icing
conditions are given in the relevant aircraft OM Part B and Chapter 8.2.4 De-Icing and Anti-Icing
on the Ground.

In addition, the following procedures may assist Pilots while operating in icing conditions:

During taxiing, greatest caution shall be exercised and slow speed shall be maintained on
slippery surfaces. Taxiing in deep snow or slush should be avoided.
NOTE For taxi speeds, see Chapter 14.3.35 Company Speed Restrictions.
Power changes should be carried out very carefully.

During turns, brakes shall not be applied to get optimum side force by the tiers. A greater distance
than normal should be maintained from other aeroplanes.

It is EGYPTAIR’ policy that take-off is prohibited if any of the following conditions exist:

Snow, ice or frost deposits are adhering to the wings, control surfaces, engines or propellers
of the aeroplane;
Heavy fall of wet snow with ambient temperature around freezing point;
Moderate or heavy freezing rain;
When the runway braking action is reported to be "poor" (brake co-efficient is equal to or
less than 0,25).
During take-off, forward pressure on the control column can increase the effectiveness of
the nose wheel steering;
During approach, whenever possible a straight, stabilized, final approach shall be
performed;
For landing, available runway length and runway condition must be checked carefully.
Whenever there is any doubt about the runway condition, the best solution is to divert or to
stay in the holding until the uncertainties are cleared;
During landing, a positive touchdown should be made in the touchdown zone on the
centerline without slip and with the lowest possible approach speed;
NOTE Landing with tailwind should be avoided.
NOTE If problems occur with directional control during landing roll or rejected take-off,
reverse thrust shall be reduced to idle.
NOTE With anti-skid operative brakes should not be pumped;
Before vacating the runway, speed should be brought down to taxi speed to avoid skidding
on contaminated surfaces during turns;

Approaching the parking position brakes should be used very carefully.
8.3.9.4 Turbulence

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
If the weather conditions and route forecast indicate that turbulence is likely, the Cabin Crew
should be pre-warned, and passengers advised to return to, and/or remain seated and to ensure
that their seat belts are securely fastened. Catering and other loose equipment should be stowed
and secured.

When encountering turbulence, Pilots are urgently requested to report such conditions to ATC
(PIREP) as soon as practicable.

If turbulence is expected or experienced, aeroplane should be flown at the recommended
turbulence penetration Speed/Mach Number, in accordance to OM Part B.

At maximum cruise altitude, the margin between low-speed and high-speed buffet is small and
any increase of "g" loads, whether caused by maneuvering or by turbulence, may lead to serious
difficulties. This shall be considered when intending to climb over a turbulent region. Avoid
altitudes approaching maximum cruise altitude in such circumstances.

Turbulence may be one of the following types:

Convective turbulence:
Caused by thermal instability and is met in connection with the development and activity of
thunderstorms.
Orographic turbulence:
Mountain waves at the lee side of a mountain may cause severe turbulence, Typical signs
are lenticulars, rotor clouds and clouds with "water-fall" appearance. The strongest
turbulence may be found in rotor clouds
Clear air turbulence:
Is of special significance, since its presence cannot be detected before it is encountered. It
is caused by large windshears with rapid changes of wind direction horizontally and/or
vertically. Further, large horizontal and vertical shears of wind speed in the transition zone
between cold and warm air masses, as well as, at the tropopause associated with Jetstreams
may cause severe CAT.
To avoid or to leave the areas of CAT the following procedures should be applied:
Reducing airspeed, to reduce the acceleration due to windshears;
When flying parallel with the Jetstream, changing altitude up to 1.000 ft;
When flying perpendicular to the Jetstream, changing altitude by 1.000 ft (from the warm
to the cold side downwards, from the cold to the warm side upwards);
If the temperature is changing in the CAT area, the flight should be continued on course;
If the temperature remains constant, the course should be varied not to stay in the CAT
area.

8.3.9.5 Windshear

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Windshear is a rapid variation in wind velocity and/or direction along the flight path of an aircraft.

Procedures for "Operation in Windshear/Downburst Conditions" are given in the relevant aircraft
type OM Part B.

When encountering Windshear conditions, Pilots are urgently requested to report such conditions
to ATC (PIREP), as soon as practicable, stating the loss or gain of speed and the altitude at which it
was encountered.

8.3.9.5.1 Precautions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Avoiding windshear is the best precaution. In case of unexpected severe windshear encounter
during take-off or on approach, the following precautions should be taken into consideration:

Thrust Setting:
Maximum take-off thrust should be used for take-off.
During approach, thrust reductions should be minimized.
Runway Selection:
The longest suitable runway should be used taking into consideration crosswind, tailwind
limitations, and obstacles in take-off or landing path.
Flap Selection:
The flap setting is dependent on the type of aeroplane; refer to the specific type OM Part B.
Airspeed:
Take-off and/or landing airspeed should be increased according to the specific type OM
Part B.
Use of Autothrottle, Autopilot and Flight Director:
For take-off only speed-referenced flight directors with windshear recovery guidance should
be used.

8.3 Flight Procedures

During approach, flight director, autopilot and auto-throttle should be used to the
maximum extent practical. When the use of autopilot and/or auto-throttle becomes
unproductive they should be disconnected.
8.3.9.6 Jetstream

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Jetstreams are narrow bands with extreme high wind speeds up to 300 kts, which can extend up to
several thousand miles in length with a width of several miles.

Avoid flying along the edge of Jetstreams due to possible associated turbulence. Pilots should also
be aware of the effect of increased fuel consumption due to unexpected significant head wind
components that can be encountered.

8.3.9.7 Volcanic Ash Clouds

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.3.9.7.1 Description of Hazard

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Volcanic ash mostly consists of sharp-edged, hard glass particles and pulverized rock, which is very
abrasive and, being largely composed of siliceous materials, has a melting temperature below the
operating temperature of modern turbine engines at cruise thrust. A volcanic ash cloud may be
accompanied by gaseous solutions of sulphur dioxide, chlorine and other chemicals which are
corrosive to the airframe and hazardous to health. Given these facts, it is self evident, that volcanic
ash in the atmosphere may pose a serious hazard to aeroplane in-flight. Thus, volcanic ash
encounters by aeroplane should be avoided.

Volcanic ash may extend for several hundred miles, and eruptions may send ash plumes up to
40.000 ft.

For preventing flights into potential ash environments, EGYPTAIR will ensure that:

Dispatch will provide Flight Crews with information about volcanic events, such as
potentially eruptive volcanoes and known ash sightings, that could affect a particular route;
Dispatch will identify alternate routes to help Flight Crews avoid airspace containing
volcanic ash.
NOTE It’s EGYPTAIR’ policy that all flights shall avoid airspaces containing volcanic ash,
regardless of the contamination level reported.
8.3.9.7.2 Ash Encounter Indicators and Effects

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
In day VMC a precursor to a volcanic ash encounter will likely be a visual indication of a volcanic
ash cloud or haze. If a flight crew observes a cloud or haze suspect of containing volcanic ash they
shall be alerted that a volcanic ash encounter is imminent and action shall be initiated to avoid the
contaminated airspace.

Indicators that an aircraft is encountering volcanic ash are related principally to odor, haze,
changing engine conditions, airspeed, pressurization and static discharges.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures
OM A
8-3-105
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Odor. When encountering volcanic ash, flight crews usually notice a smoky or acrid odor
that can smell like electrical smoke, burned dust or sulphur;
Haze. Most flight crews, as well as passengers, see a haze develop within the aircraft (flight
deck and/or cabin). Dust can settle on surfaces;
Changing engine conditions. Surging, torching from the tailpipe, and flameouts can occur.
Engine temperatures can change unexpectedly, and a white glow can appear at the engine
inlet;
Airspeed. If volcanic ash fouls the pitot tube, the indicated airspeed can decrease or
fluctuate erratically;
Pressurization. Cabin pressure can change, including possible loss of cabin pressurization;
Static discharges. A phenomenon similar to St. Elmo's fire or glow can occur. In these
instances, blue-coloured sparks can appear to flow up the outside of the windshield or a
white glow can appear at the leading edges of the wings or at the front of the engine inlets;
Windscreen. May become opaque caused by ash particles.
Any of these indicators shall suffice to alert the flight crew of an ash encounter and appropriate
action shall be taken to vacate the contaminated airspace as safely and expeditiously as possible.

NOTE Do not rely on weather radar to detect ash clouds or volcanic dust as they cannot be
detected by weather radar.
8.3.9.7.3 Recommended Actions

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
When encountering ash cloud, the following procedures are recommended:

Fly on the upwind side;
Turn on continuous ignition;
Declare an emergency;
Inform ATC and other traffic on the position, extension, height and density of the volcanic
cloud;
Do not climb in order to overfly the ash cloud;
Reduce power to idle to provide additional engine stall margin and lower turbine
temperature;
Try to escape the ash cloud by descending and flying a 180° turn (if terrain clearance
permits);
Monitor attitude versus airspeed;
Keep as many engines running as possible;
Restart any engine that was shut down due to EGT exceeding the limits. If an engine fails to
restart repeated attempts should be made immediately, to avoid solidification of molten ash
on the turbine blades;
Turn on all accessory air-bleeds including all air conditioning packs, nacelles, and wing anti-
ice. This will provide an additional engine stall margin by reducing engine pressure.
For additional procedures the OM Part B/Emergency checklist of the respective type of aeroplane
must be checked.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures

8-3-106

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Following encounter with an ash cloud, a landing at the next suitable airport is recommended. If
the visibility through the windshield is impaired a runway with autoland capability should be
considered.

Flight Deck Crews are requested to make special air-reports when volcanic eruption is observed or
when volcanic ash cloud is observed or encountered (see reporting forms in Chapter 11 Handling,
Notifying and Reporting Occurrences ).

Information on volcanic activities, including pre-eruption activity, volcanic eruption and volcanic
ash clouds is transmitted to aeroplanes operating on routes that could be affected (ASHTAM,
VAA).

This information may also be published by NOTAMS and SIGMETS up to a 12 hours validity period
and, if necessary, recommendations on re-routings will be included.

8.3.9.7.4 Flights in or into Areas where a Risk of the Presence of Volcanic Ash

Clouds does exist - Risk Assessment
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The safety risk assessment for operation in areas possibly contaminated by volcanic ash is part of
the Safety Management System.

Before initiating operations into airspace forecast to be or aerodromes known to be contaminated
with volcanic ash, the risk assessment shall be reviewed.

In addition to this the company will:

Take into account data published by the relevant aeroplane and engine type certificate
holders regarding the susceptibility to volcanic cloud-related airworthiness effects of the
aeroplane they operate, the nature of these effects and the related pre-flight, in-flight and
post-flight precautions to be observed by the company;
Ensure that those of its personnel needing to be familiar with the details of the safety risk
assessments receive all relevant information (both pre-flight and in-flight) in order to be in a
position to apply appropriate mitigation measures as specified by the safety risk
assessments, especially when the situation deviates from any scenario contemplated in the
safety risk assessments;
Ensure that reports are immediately submitted to the nearest ATS unit using the Volcanic
Activity Report (VAR) procedures followed up by a more detailed VAR on landing together
with, as applicable, an ASR and Tech Log entry for:
Any incidents related to volcanic clouds;
Any observation of volcanic ash activity; and
Anytime that volcanic ash is not encountered in an area(s) where it was forecast to be.
When a flight is intended to transition contaminated airspace or planned to an airport in
contaminated airspace, then the process involves:

Identifying the hazard (e.g. arising from the generic hazard of airspace or aerodromes with
known or forecast contamination by volcanic ash clouds with characteristics harmful to the
airworthiness and operation of the aeroplane);
Considering the seriousness of the hazard occurring (e.g. the actual level of damage
expected to be inflicted on the particular aeroplane from exposure to that volcanic ash
cloud);

The Civil Aviation Authority will issue NOTAMs and ASHTAMs specifying airspace predicted to
contain medium and high contaminations of volcanic ash. Areas of high contamination will be
promulgated as Volcanic Ash Temporary Danger Areas (TDAs). This term should not be confused
with the Initial Danger Zone, which is established with a 120 NM radius in the vicinity of the
volcanic eruption.

The boundaries of the Temporary Danger Areas will be communicated via NOTAMs/ASHTAMs.

Only NOTAMs/ASHTAMs issued by the Authority should be used to determine areas of medium
and high contamination and the associated TDAs.

There might be an inconsistency between these areas and the Volcanic Ash Concentration Charts
published by the MET Office. Some reasons for this are:

Smoothing of the contamination area for ease of interpretation in the NOTAM/ASHTAM;
Observational evidence received since the forecast has been issued and prior to any revised
or updated forecast being issued, this may include:
Old ash has dispersed more quickly than expected in the models;
Small areas of high contamination, which may be considered unrealistic; and
Detached areas of ash from a main plume that are incorrectly modeled.
It should also be noted that on occasions it may be necessary to amend the NOTAM/ASHTAM that
is in force when updated information is received.

8.3.9.7.6 Advice to the Flight Deck Crew

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Pilots can expect ATS providers to inform them of the presence of a Volcanic Ash TDA before the
aeroplane enters such an area and to ask them about their intentions. The following phraseology
should be expected:

“ YOU ARE ABOUT TO ENTER A NOTIFIED VOLCANIC ASH TEMPORARY DANGER AREA IN

8.3.9.7.7 Report of Volcanic Ash Activity During Flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
If volcanic ash activity is identified during a flight, the following information shall be transmitted to
the nearest ATS unit:

Call sign;
Position;
Time;
Flight level;
Position, bearing, distance to the volcanic activity;
Level of contamination expected;
Vertical and lateral extent of the ash cloud, rate of growth etc.;
Air temperature;
Wind.
The report shall be transmitted as soon as the Commander deems that it is safe to do so.

8.3.9.7.8 Records

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Whenever a safety risk assessment in regards to volcanic activity or in regards to flying into
volcanic ash clouds was carried out, this shall be documented and submitted to the ECAA.
Mitigating actions should be completed, verified and supported prior to the start of operations.

Any assumption should be clearly stated, and the safety risk assessment reviewed at regular
intervals, to ensure that the assumptions and decisions remain valid.

Any safety performance monitoring requirements should also be identified and undertaken
through the organisation's safety risk management processes.

8.3.9.8 Heavy Precipitation

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Heavy precipitation may occur as rain showers, snow showers and hail. The greatest hazards to
flight are the reduced visibility and the risk of icing in combination with low temperature.

On ground, contaminated runways may influence the performance, crosswind limitations and
increase the risk of aquaplaning. The special procedures of the respective OM Part B must be
followed.

NOTE Especially in snow showers, blowing snow, partial loss of orientation may occur after

NOTE In falling or blowing snow, landing lights should be used with caution as the reflected

drift during flare and rollout
8.3.9.9 Sand Storms

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Avoid flying in active sandstorms wherever possible. Considerable damage can be done to an
aeroplane's windscreen, leading edges and engine compressor blades by the abrasive action of
sand particles.

8.3.9.10 Mountain Waves

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Mountain waves can form in the lee of a range of mountains, and are usually in the form of
standing waves, with several miles between peaks and troughs; they can extend to 10.000 or
20.000 ft above the range and for up to 200 or 300 NM downwind.

Mountain waves can be recognized by long-term variations in aeroplane speed and pitch attitude
in level cruise.

The effect of mountain waves reduces with increase in height. At normal cruise altitudes mountain
waves are usually free from clear air turbulence, unless associated with jet streams or
thunderstorms.

Near the ground in a mountain wave area, however, severe turbulence and windshear may be
encountered. This region is known as the "lee wave rotor", and is caused by flow separation behind
the mountain range.

In some airports, relief or obstacles may cause special wind conditions with severe turbulence and
windshear on approach or during take-off.

Special procedures or recommendations are indicated on airport charts when appropriate. They
must be taken into account by the Flight Deck Crews when choosing the landing/take-off runway.

8.3.9.11 Significant Temperature Inversions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Ambient temperature variations have an effect on aeroplane performance and inversions will
usually affect performance adversely.

Large temperature inversions encountered shortly after take-off can seriously degrade an
aero-plane’s climb performance, particularly at high operating mass. Similarly, if the
aeroplane is operating to a maximum landing mass limited by go-around climb
performance considerations, the required gradient may not be achieved;
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures
OM A
8-3-111
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
The maximum cruising altitude capability of the aeroplane can be significantly reduced if a
temperature inversion of even small magnitude exists in the upper levels. This may prevent
an aeroplane reaching its preferred cruising altitude. Should an aeroplane encounter an
area of inversion once in the cruise at limiting altitude, its buffet margins may be so eroded
that a descent is necessary;
Temperature inversions at lower levels in the atmosphere are frequently associated with
deteriorating visibility and can prevent the clearance of fog for prolonged periods. Light
wind conditions and clear skies at night can lead to rapid cooling of the earth and a
morning temperature inversion at ground level.
8.3.9.12 Wind Policy

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
For performance calculation, lee wind direction and velocities expressed as “light and variable”
must be considered as tailwind.

The tailwind, steady crosswind and gust component for take-off, approach and landing must not
exceed the limits or the demonstrated or the guidelines values, specified in the applicable OM
Part B.

Flight Deck Crew shall take into consideration if the aircrafts’ stopping capability is degraded, and
incorporate any new wind limitations into the take-off and landing performance calculations, as
specified in the applicable OM Part B.

Where no gust limit is specified, gusts exceeding crosswind limitations must be considered
whenever judged operationally significant.

If surface mean wind speeds of 65 kts (including gusts) or above are reported by the Aerodrome
Authority, the aerodrome shall be considered closed.

8.3.9.13 Adverse Runway Conditions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.3.9.13.1 Runway Surface Conditions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
For take-off and landing performance purposes, runway surfaces are categorized as dry, wet or
contaminated, for definitions, see Chapter 0.8 Terms and Definitions.

8.3.9.13.2 Runway Braking Action / Crosswind Limitations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Runway braking action is reported using a standard terminology or, when requested, numerical
values. Three numerical values are reported, one for each third of the runway, starting at the
approach end.

When touchdown, midpoint and rollout zones are reported then the most restrictive of either
midpoint or rollout will be controlling; should only one report be given, this will be controlling.

Runway braking action information should be provided by ATC or it may be transmitted on the
ATIS frequency.

When measured braking action reported by ATC or ATIS is poor or when the reported braking
friction co-efficient is equal or less than 0,25, then a take-off or landing is prohibited.

Pilot reports, runway surface condition reports, and meteorological reports are only advisory. This
constitutes additional information to help the Commander decide whether to land/take-off or not.

The following table illustrates the maximum crosswind limitation according to the braking action:

8.3.9.13.3 Runway Assessment and Condition Reporting

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The Global Reporting Format (GRF) enables a harmonized assessment and reporting of runway
surface conditions and an improved flight crew assessment of take-off and landing performance.
GRF is a globally standardized language reporting format for runway surface conditions. The report
is developed based on a Runway Condition Assessment Matrix (RCAM).

The RCAM (Runway Condition Assessment Matrix) braking action codes and definitions are shown
below. The Assessment Criteria is associated with how an airport operator conducts and reports a
runway condition assessment for a paved runway. The Control/Braking Assessment Criteria is
associated with the pilot’s experience with braking action.

A resulting RWYCC will be determined for each third of the evaluated runway. The worst RWYCC
shall be used for performance calculations if no other method is described in OM Part B.

In context of the RCR, the following runway surface condition descriptions apply:

Compacted Snow Snow that has been compacted into a solid mass such that aeroplane tyres, at
operating pressures and loadings, will run on the surface without significant
further compaction or rutting of the surface.
Dry Snow Snow from which a snowball cannot readily be made.
Frost Ice crystals formed from airborne moisture on a surface whose temperature is
at or below freezing; frost differs from ice in that the frost crystals grow
independently and, therefore, have a more granular texture.
Ice Water that has frozen or compacted snow that has transitioned into ice in
cold and dry conditions.
Slush Snow that is so water-saturated that water will drain from it when a handful is
picked up or will splatter if stepped on forcefully.
Standing Water Water of depth greater than 3 mm.
Wet Ice Ice with water on top of it or ice that is melting.
Wet Snow Snow that contains enough water to be able to make a well compacted, solid
snowball, but water will not squeeze out.

The pilot’s version of the RCAM will be used to assess the effects of a given contaminant(s) as
indicated by the associated Runway Condition Code (RwyCC) for take-off and landing performance
calculations. The RwyCC cannot be adjusted, but Flight crews shall report the runway braking
action encountered when it is not as expected according to the values previously reported to
them. The airport operator then may adjust (downgrade or upgrade) the RwyCC based on multiple
variables in their overall assessment. This may cause the RwyCC to differ from the category of the
reported contaminant(s).

Flight crew reports shall be consistent with the format in use at the aerodrome being operated as
they may be used by the aerodrome operator to update the runway condition. They may be used
also by the flight crews of subsequent flights arriving on the same runway.

Whenever the runway braking action encountered during the landing roll is not as good as that
reported in the runway condition report, the Commander shall notify ATC by means of a special
air-report (AIREP) as soon as practicable. ATC will forward such special air-reports received by
voice communications without delay to the appropriate aerodrome operator.

When a field condition (FICON) NOTAM includes RwyCCs, it is an indicator that more than 25% of
the overall runway coverage or cleared width is contaminated and performance impacts are likely.
When a runway is less than 25% contaminated, RwyCCs will not be generated, and performance
impacts are less likely.

8.3.10 Wake Turbulence

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
8.3.10.1 General

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
To create safe separation margins between aeroplanes landing/departing the same runway,
international authorities have established minimum separation criteria taking into account the
relation between aeroplane weight and the strength of wake turbulences being generated.

In case encountering wake turbulence inadvertently:

Follow upset recovery maneuvers as per QRH and FCTM guidance;
Check with Cabin Crew for any injuries to crew members and/or passengers and
possible cabin damage;
Take decision based on the situation;
Inform ATC;
After landing, make an entry in Aircraft Technical Log of the incident and Cabin defect
(if any);
Inform IOCC and report as per Chapter 11.5.4 Air Safety Reports – Mandatory
Occurrence Reporting for mandatory occurrence report.
8.3.10.2 Wake Turbulence Categories and Groups of Aircraft

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Except as provided in wake turbulence groups below, wake turbulence separation minima shall be
based on a grouping of aircraft types into four categories according to the maximum certificated
take-off mass as follows:

SUPER (J) – aircraft types specified as such in ICAO Doc 8643, “Aircraft Type Designators”
E.g. A380-800 and Antonov 225.
HEAVY (H) – aircraft types of 136.000 kg or more, with the exception of aircraft types listed
in the SUPER (J) category;
MEDIUM (M) – aircraft types less than 136.000 kg but more than 7.000 kg; and
LIGHT (L) – aircraft types of 7.000 kg or less.
NOTE The wake turbulence category for each aircraft type is contained in Doc 8643, Aircraft
Type Designators.
When approved by the appropriate ATS authority, wake turbulence separation minima may be
applied utilizing wake turbulence groups and shall be based on wake generation and resistance
characteristics of the aircraft.

These depend primarily on maximum certificated take-off mass, wing characteristics and speeds.

The group designators are described as follows:

GROUP A – aircraft types of 136.000 kg or more, and a wing span less than or equal to 80
m but greater than 74,68 m;
GROUP B – aircraft types of 136.000 kg or more, and a wing span less than or equal to
74,68 m but greater than 53,34 m;

For aircraft in the SUPER or HEAVY wake turbulence categories, the word “super” or “heavy” shall

NOTE Wake turbulence Group A is equivalent to the SUPER wake turbulence category, and
Groups B and C are equivalent to the HEAVY category.
8.3.10.3 Distance-based Separation Minima Based on ATS Surveillance

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
When using wake turbulence categories or groups, the following distance-based wake turbulence
separation minima shall be applied to aircraft being provided with an ATS surveillance service in
the approach and departure phases of flight in the following circumstances:

An aircraft is operating directly behind another aircraft at the same altitude or less than 300
m (1.000 ft) below; or
Both aircraft are using the same runway, or parallel runways separated by less than 760 m
(2.500 ft); or
An aircraft is crossing behind another aircraft, at the same altitude or less than 300 m (1.000
ft) below.

8.3.10.4 Time-based Wake Turbulence Longitudinal Separation Minima

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
8.3.10.4.1 Applicability

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The ATC unit concerned shall not be required to apply wake turbulence separation:

For arriving VFR flights landing on the same runway as a preceding landing SUPER, HEAVY
or MEDIUM aircraft; and
Between arriving IFR flights executing visual approach when the aircraft has reported the
preceding aircraft in sight and has been instructed to follow and maintain own separation
from that aircraft.
The ATC unit shall, in respect of the flights specified above, as well as when otherwise deemed
necessary, issue a caution of possible wake turbulence. The Pilot-in-Command of the aircraft
concerned shall be responsible for ensuring that the spacing from a preceding aircraft of a heavier
wake turbulence category is acceptable. If it is determined that additional spacing is required, the
flight crew shall inform the ATC unit accordingly, stating their requirements.

8.3.10.4.2 Arriving Aircraft

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The following minima shall be applied to aircraft landing behind a SUPER, a HEAVY or a MEDIUM
aircraft:

HEAVY aircraft landing behind SUPER aircraft – 2 minutes;
MEDIUM aircraft landing behind SUPER aircraft – 3 minutes;
MEDIUM aircraft landing behind HEAVY aircraft – 2 minutes;
LIGHT aircraft landing behind SUPER aircraft – 4 minutes;
LIGHT aircraft landing behind a HEAVY or MEDIUM aircraft – 3 minutes.
8.3.10.4.3 Departing Aircraft

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
When aircraft are using:

The same runway;
Parallel runways separated by less than 760 m (2.500 ft);
Crossing runways if the projected flight path of the second aircraft will cross the projected
flight path of the first aircraft at the same altitude or less than 300 m (1.000 ft) below;
Parallel runways separated by 760 m (2.500 ft) or more, if the projected flight path of the
second aircraft will cross the projected flight path of the first aircraft at the same altitude or
less than 300 m (1.000 ft) below.
The following minimum separations shall be applied when wake turbulence categories are used:

HEAVY aircraft taking off behind a SUPER aircraft – 2 minutes;
LIGHT or MEDIUM aircraft taking off behind a SUPER aircraft – 3 minutes;
LIGHT or MEDIUM aircraft taking off behind a HEAVY aircraft – 2 minutes;
LIGHT aircraft taking off behind a MEDIUM aircraft – 2 minutes.

8.3.10.4.5 Displaced Landing Threshold

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
When operating a displaced landing threshold, the following minimum separations shall be
applied if the projected flight paths are expected to cross.

When wake turbulence categories are used:

A departing HEAVY aircraft following a SUPER aircraft arrival – 2 minutes;
A departing LIGHT or MEDIUM aircraft following a SUPER aircraft arrival – 3 minutes;
A departing LIGHT or MEDIUM aircraft following a HEAVY aircraft arrival – 2 minutes;

8.3.10.6 En-route

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
Wake Turbulence events are more frequent in the RVSM airspace even with very distant aircraft (20
NM). They may be encountered in cruise where the aircraft is flying in the same direction and
vertically separated by 1.000 ft only. In such a case the flight crew must consider keeping the seat
belt signs ON when the aircraft proximity is known.

If considered necessary, the flight crew may offset UPWIND from the cleared track by up to
a maximum of 2 NM to the right, in order to alleviate the effects of wake turbulence. ATC
must be informed of this contingency action however the ATC will not issue clearance for
this type of lateral offset. The aircraft should be returned to the cleared track as soon as
possible;
It is important to note that wake turbulence can cause variation in pitch. When crossing a
vortex perpendicularly, these pitch variations are sometimes accompanied by a loud
thumping noise. During an approach at night, passengers may have the sensation that the
aircraft has touched the ground.
The vortices evolve in altitudes at which the rate of decay leads to a typical persistence of 2-3
minutes, with a typical sink rate of about 400 ft/min. Wakes will also be transported by wind. When
possible, condensation trails should be used to visualize wakes and estimate if their flight path
brings them across.

Considering the high operating air speeds in cruise and the standard 1.000 ft vertical separation in
RVSM airspace, wake can be encountered up to 25 nautical miles (NM) behind the generating
aeroplane. The most significant encounters are reported within 15 NM.

In the en-route phase of flight, three major factors contribute to increase the likelihood of wake
turbulence:

Crossing traffic situation: In the case that crossing traffic is climbing or descending in
proximity (either the generating or following aeroplane), the wake generated might cross
the follower’s trajectory with minimum time for decay, so stronger wake turbulence might
be encountered;
Thermal tropopause altitude: Wake vortex decays more slowly below the tropopause where
there is therefore an increased risk of encountering severe wake turbulence. Tropopause
height (at TOC) is found on the OFP. Flying above the tropopause height decreases the risk
of encountering severe wake turbulence;
Weight of the generating aeroplane: Heavier aeroplane types generate stronger wake
vortices and are likely to induce more severe wake turbulence encounters, especially for
smaller aeroplane types.

8.3.10.7 Approach and Landing

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
Approach:

If feasible, check the spacing with the leading aircraft by using TCAS display. A visual
estimation of the horizontal spacing is not sufficient and should not be trusted;
If flying a medium or heavy aircraft, the flight crew should pay particular attention to being
exactly on the glide path, not above it. This will keep the wake turbulence below the glide
path and may protect other aircraft from being trapped in the wake vortex.
NOTE If the flight crew accepts a visual separation, they are also responsible for wake
turbulence avoidance.
Landing:

When possible, the flight crew should land the aircraft beyond the touchdown point of the
preceding aircraft while still being within the touchdown zone.
NOTE If another aircraft crosses the active runway shortly before landing, a lateral jerk may
result from crossing the jet blast.
8.3.11 Crew Members at their Stations

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
During take-off and landing each Flight Deck Crew member required to be on duty in the flight
crew compartment shall be at the assigned station.

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
During all other phases of flight each Flight Deck Crew member required to be on duty in the flight
crew compartment shall remain at the assigned station, unless absence is necessary for the
performance of duties in connection with the operation, or for physiological needs provided at
least one suitably qualified pilot remains at the controls of the aeroplane at all times.

No other person than active Flight Deck Crew shall occupy designated pilot seats.

During critical phases of flight, each Cabin Crew member shall be seated at the assigned station
and shall not perform any activities other than those required for the safe operation of the aircraft.

Commanders must be aware that they are responsible for all aspects of the operation of the
aircraft, regardless of whether they are present on the flight deck or not.

Flight Deck Crew Members shall not leave their seats below 10.000 ft AGL for the purpose of
transferring duties to another Flight Deck Crew Member.

For leaving the flight deck during flight, see Chapter 14.3.29 Leaving Flight Deck during Flight.

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Seat Belts:
Any Flight Deck Crew Member on flight deck duty shall remain at his station with his seat
belt fastened from prior to push-back/engine start, whichever is earlier, throughout the
entire flight and until the engines have been shut down after completion of the flight.
Shoulder Harnesses:
Shall be fastened, under the following conditions:
During all operations below 10.000 ft AGL;
From TOD until engine shutdown at the gate;
Any time an assigned Flight Deck Crew Member has to leave the flight deck;
During moderate or severe turbulence and adverse weather operations;
When deemed necessary by the Commander.

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Cabin Crew shall be secured by wearing their seat belt and shoulder harness provided at their
assigned seat/station, during take-off and landing and whenever deemed necessary by the
Commander in the interest of safety.

During turbulence, Cabin Crew Members are required to secure the cabin and unless otherwise
directed by the Commander, take their seats. The Commander determines severity of turbulence
and releases them, if appropriate.

When ( CABIN SECURE ) is given to the Flight Deck Crew, it is expected that all Crew Members be
seated at their stations with their seat belt and shoulder harnesses fastened.

8.3.12.3 Passengers

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Before take-off, landing, during taxiing and whenever deemed necessary in the interest of safety,
the Commander shall ensure, that each passenger on board occupies a seat with his seat belt, or
harness where provided, properly secured.

The Commander shall ensure, through the Cabin Crew or handling staff, that multiple occupancy
of aeroplane seats may only be allowed on specified seats and does not occur other than by one
adult and one infant who is properly secured by a supplementary loop belt or other restraint
device, see Chapter 8.2.2.3 Allocation of Seats to Adults, Children and Infants.

NOTE When occupying their seats, passengers are required to fasten their safety/restraining
belts secured during the entire flight.
NOTE Unused seat belts/shoulder harnesses, shall be secured so as not to interfere with

occupants in an emergency.
8.3.13 Admission to Flight Deck

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
No person may admit any person to the flight deck of an aircraft, in-flight or on the ground,
unless the person being admitted is:
a. A Flight Deck Crew Member;
b. An ECAA inspector, who is performing official duties;
c. An employee of the ECAA; the certificate holder, or an aeronautical enterprise who has
the permission of the PIC and whose duties are such that admission to the flight deck
is necessary or advantageous for safe operation; or
d. Any person who has the permission of the PIC and is specifically authorized by the
certificate management or by the ECAA. Subparagraph 1.b. of this paragraph does not
limit the emergency authority of the PIC to exclude any person from the flight deck in
the interests of safety.
For the purposes of item 1.c. of this section, employees of the ECAA who deal with matters
relating to safety and employees of the certificate holder whose efficiency would be
increased by familiarity with flight conditions may be admitted by the certificate holder.
However, the certificate holder may not admit employees of traffic, sales, or other
departments that are not directly related to flight operations, unless they are eligible under
item 1.d. of this section;
No person may admit any person to the flight deck unless there is a seat available for his
use in the passenger compartment except:
a. An ECAA inspector who is checking or observing flight operations;
b. An air traffic controller who is authorized by the ECAA to observe ATS procedures;
c. A licensed Crew Member employed by the certificate holder whose duties require a
license;
d. A licensed Crew Member employed by another certificate holder whose duties with
that carrier require a license and who is authorized by the certificate holder operating
the aircraft to make specific trips over a route;

8.3.13.1 Flight Deck Door Principles

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
On all flights, the Flight Deck door shall be closed and locked from the time all external doors are
closed following embarkation until any such door is opened for disembarkation, except when
necessary to allow routine access or permit access and way out by authorized persons.

Before each flight, the Commander shall brief the SCC about the Flight Deck door emergency
access code.

NOTE The Commander should ensure that the code is not written down on any paperwork
by the SCC to guard against the code falling into the wrong hands.
NOTE The Emergency Access Code must only be used if Flight Deck Crew incapacitation is
suspected.
General Rules

Access to the Flight Deck should be limited;
Prior leaving the Flight Deck, Crew Members must ensure, through the video surveillance
system, viewing lens or by communicating with the Cabin Crew through the interphone
system, that the area around the Flight Deck door is clear and that Cabin Crew Members are
positioned to prevent passenger access to the Flight Deck while the door is open for crew exit
or entry;
Prior permitting access to the Flight Deck, Flight Deck Crew must positively identify the fact
that the area around the Flight Deck door is clear and that the person requesting entry is
authorized to enter the Flight Deck;
Cabin Crew should be vigilant and observe the surroundings carefully before entering the
Flight Deck;
Passengers shall be discouraged from wandering in the area in front of the Flight Deck;
In case of a passenger disturbance, the Flight Deck door should remain closed and locked
until the situation is under control, every effort shall be made to make the Flight Deck door
area/adjacent lavatory a "clear-zone";

8.3.14 Use of Vacant Crew Seats

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Chapter 8.3.13 Admission to Flight Deck contains the relevant provisions as to the disposition of
vacant crew seats on the flight deck. The final decision as to the disposition of other vacant crew
seats, again, rests solely with the Commander. Normally, such permission will only be granted to
employees of the operator, or of other operators, or to employees of aeronautical or other
authorities, holding reduced-fare transportation. Crew seats (e.g. crew rest seats on a non-
passenger carrying deck) which are not certificated for occupation by Crew Members during take-
off/ landing or specified other phases of flight (e.g. because of emergency evacuation problems),
shall, of course, not be occupied by other persons during such phases of flight. Vacant crew seats
(except those on the flight deck), in order to be occupied by other persons, shall at least meet the
emergency relevant requirements for passenger seats (oxygen, seat belt/harness, instruction card,
accessibility to all verbal or other instructions given to passengers by cabin or Flight Deck Crew at
all times, visibility of EXIT signs). Normally, the Commander shall not grant permission for
occupation of a vacant crew seat located at an emergency exit (see also Chapter 8.2.2.3
Allocation of Seats to Adults, Children and Infants ) to:

A person lacking sufficient strength or dexterity to operate and open the emergency exit, to
exit expeditiously, and to assist others in getting off an escape slide (if any);
A person lacking the ability to read, hear or understand emergency relevant instructions.
The Crew Member responsible for safety in the cabin shall brief a person who has been granted
permission to occupy a vacant crew seat, on all safety relevant aspects connected with that seat
and, if it is at an emergency exit, on how to operate and open the door in an emergency (stressing,
however, that the door shall be opened only after the appropriate command has been given).

8.3.15 Incapacitation of Crew Members

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.3.15.1 General

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Incapacitation of a Crew Member is defined as "any condition that affects the health of a Crew
Member during the performance of duties, which renders him incapable of performing the
assigned duties".

OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures
OM A
8-3-135
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Incapacitation is a real air safety hazard, which occurs more frequently than many of the other
emergencies that are the subject of routine training. Incapacitation can occur in many forms
varying from obvious sudden death to subtle partial loss of function. It occurs in all age groups
and during all phases of flight and may not be preceded by any warning.

8.3.15.2 Types of Incapacitation

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Obvious
incapacitation
Means total functional failure and loss of capabilities. This generally will be easily
detectable and will be a prolonged condition.
Subtle
incapacitation
This is a more significant operational hazard, because it is difficult to detect and the
effects can range from partial loss of functions to complete unconsciousness.
8.3.15.3 Recognition of an Incapacity

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The most important preventive measure is to maintain a high standard of alertness. Routine
adherence to SOP's, Standard Callouts and flight deck discipline is stressed because a procedural
deviation might provide the first indication of an arising problem.

EGYPTAIR utilizes a special rule that will help in identifying incapacity:

(Two Way Communication Rule)

It simply means, that a challenged Crew Member must respond (by corrective action and verbally)
to the other Crew Member's verbal challenges. If the comments were not answered properly after
being challenged “twice”, incapacity of the Crew Member shall be suspected and the other Crew
Member will assume control of the aeroplane.

NOTE Flight Crew Members shall inform their colleagues if they are in a state of extreme
fatigue or indisposition. It is then the Commanders’ duty to organize teamwork on the
Flight Deck for short recovery periods.
Other symptoms of the beginning of an incapacitation are:

Incoherent speech;
Strange behavior;
Irregular breathing;
Pale fixed facial expression;
Jerky motions that are either delayed or too rapid.
If any of these are present, incapacitation must be suspected and action taken to check the state of
the concerned Crew Member.

8.3.15.4 Actions

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Actions to be taken when an incapacity is recognized:

Take over control of the aeroplane by announcing ( I HAVE CONTROLS );
Engage autopilot;
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures
OM A
8-3-136

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Declare emergency;
Summon a Cabin Crew immediately for assistance (Purser to Cockpit via PA);
Have the incapacitated Flight Deck Crew Member removed from his seat, if applicable;
NOTE In all cases, his seat should be moved fully back to prevent obstruction of flight
controls, switches, levers, etc.
NOTE For Cabin Crew procedures refer to OM Part F.
Medical assistance in-flight and after landing should be arranged for the incapacitated Crew
Member;
Evaluate all aspects of the flight, and determine the suitability of an en-route aerodrome for
an emergency landing;
The remaining Pilot shall fly the aircraft from their normal position, no seat change is
permitted and consideration must be given to the following items:
Allow sufficient time to prepare the flight deck for landing;
Request whenever possible a long, straight-in approach;
Perform the approach checks earlier than normal;
Request radar vectoring whenever possible.
After landing, a change of seats for taxiing is authorized, provided the Crew Member is
qualified for taxiing the aircraft, otherwise, the aircraft shall be towed to the parking bay;
NOTE Seat changing shall only be accomplished only after the aeroplane has come to a
complete stop.
After parking, the incapacitated Flight Deck Crew Member shall be offloaded as quickly as
possible.
NOTE EGYPTAIR’s operations department must be kept informed at all times regarding the
above circumstances for immediate relay to the G.M. Flight Operations.
8.3.15.5 Incapacitation of a Cabin Crew Member

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
In the event of the incapacitation of a SCC/Cabin Crew, Cabin Crew shall immediately inform the
PIC, administer first aid and/or provide medical assistance to the incapacitated SCC/Cabin Crew.

In the event of the initial SCC becoming unable to perform his duties, the Commander shall
delegate the duties and responsibilities of the SCC to the Cabin Crew Member holding the highest
seniority. In addition, he shall assess whether further crew responsibilities should be reassigned
amongst the remaining Cabin Crew e.g. Cabin Crew seating positions and emergency exit
responsibilities.

NOTE For more details refer to OM Part F.

8.3.16 Cabin Safety Requirements

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.3.16.1 General

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
In general, Cabin Crew shall notify the Flight Deck Crew, e.g. via intercom, whenever safety-related
or emergency situation has been identified. These situations include, but are not limited to, unruly
behavior by passengers, injury to passenger or crew member, medical emergency, use of first aid
or medical equipment, smoke or fumes in the cabin, failure of any emergency equipment or
suspicious activity or security breaches in the cabin.

During the critical phases of flight Cabin Crew must refrain from performing any activities other
than those required for the safe operation of the aeroplane.

They shall concentrate on their designated task of securing the cabin and, if necessary, shall firmly
and politely refuse service requests by passengers. During such phases, Cabin Crew must not
distract the Flight Deck Crew, unless safety requires such distraction.

During critical phases communication between cabin crew and flight deck crew shall be done using
intercom unless it is in the interest of safety to physically enter the cockpit.

NOTE If the intercom is unserviceable, an alternative communication procedure shall be
established between the cabin crew and the flight deck crew members before the
commencement of the flight.
NOTE:

For Passengers Embarkation/Disembarkation, see Chapter 8.2.2.2 Passengers Embarkation /
Disembarkation ;
For Critical Phases of Flight, see Chapter 14.3.23 Critical Phases of Flight (Sterile Flight
Deck / DND) ;
For Exit Row Seating Assignments, see Chapter 8.2.2.3.1 Exit Row Seating Assignments ;
For Carriage of Special Categories of Passengers, see Chapter 8.2.2.4 Sick/Injured
Passengers and Persons with Reduced Mobility (PRMs) and Chapter 8.2.2.5
Transportation of Inadmissible Passengers, Deportees or Persons in Custody ; and
For Fuelling/Defuelling with Passengers on Board or Embarking/Disembarking, see Chapter
8.2.1.3 Fuelling / Defuelling with Passengers on Board or Embarking / Disembarking.

Any suspicious item(s) shall be reported;
Service carts/trolleys which are used for serving passengers are equipped with a serviceable
braking device;

All cabin and exit doors window shades are open;
Galleys and all service equipment are secured;
Galley electrics (e.g. ovens) are switched OFF (except fridges and chillers);
Cabin cleared from service equipment;
All lavatories are free from passengers or baggage, and lavatory doors are locked;
Galley and cabin lighting intensity is adjusted to reflect external light intensity and conditions;
NOTE At night, the cabin lights shall be dimmed in order to improve the night vision of
cabin staff and passengers.
Portable Electronic Devices are switched OFF;
Curtains/rope class dividers are secured in the open position;
No loose objects (e.g. headsets, plastic bags, blankets, pillows, debris, etc.) in the cabin;
Flight deck cleared from debris and service equipment;
All Cabin Crew (including additional crew) are seated in their assigned seats with their belts
and harnesses fastened;
Crew Rest compartments where fitted are secured and unoccupied.
After completion of the above checks, Cabin Crew shall report (CABIN SECURE).

The Term (CABIN SECURE) is used from the Cabin Crew to the Senior Cabin Crew and from the
Senior Cabin Crew to the Flight Deck Crew indicating that:

Passengers seated with their seat belts fastened, backrests upright and tables/trays in the
stowed position;
Equipment and baggage properly secured;
Galleys and lavatories checked, locked and secured;
Stowage spaces and bins closed;
All exits and escape paths are unobstructed;
Curtains secured in the (OPEN) position;
All doors (ARMED) ;
Cabin lights dimmed (night);
Passenger briefing completed.
The Commander shall acknowledge the (CABIN SECURE) report.

NOTE If the (CABIN SECURE) report is not given in a timely manner, the Commander shall
inquire, and advise time remaining till take-off/landing.
During Flight, the Cabin Crew shall ensure that:

They remain seated with seat belt/harnesses fastened until FASTEN SEAT BELT sign has been
switched OFF;

Clogged/overflowing basins, water leaks and other cabin defects are reported to the SCC who
shall report the same to the Flight Deck Crew and make the appropriate entry in the Cabin

8.3.16.3 Smoking on Board

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Smoking, including electronic or other artificial forms of smoking, is not permitted onboard
EGYPTAIR aeroplanes.

8.3.16.4 Carriage of Passengers with Infectious / Contagious Diseases

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Passengers suffering from common Infectious/Contagious Diseases shall not be carried while the
disease is still in its infectious/contagious period (e.g. smallpox, typhus, cholera, yellow fever,
diphtheria, scarlet fever, tuberculosis and measles).

Examples of the infectious periods for some illnesses are:

Chicken pox: infectious until the spots are dry;
Measles: infectious until 4 days after the appearance of rash;
German measles (Rubella): infectious until after the appearance of rash;
Mumps: infectious until 1 week after the appearance of swelling.
Once the infectious period is over, passengers can be accepted for travel, but ideally should be in
possession of a “Certificate of Fitness to Fly”.

8.3.16.5 Portable Electronic Devices

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
PEDs are any kind of electronic device, typically but not limited to consumer electronics, brought
on board the aircraft by Crew Members, passengers, or as part of the cargo and that are not
included in the approved aircraft configuration. All equipment that is able to consume electrical
energy falls under this definition. The electrical energy can be provided from internal sources as
batteries (chargeable or non-rechargeable) or the devices may also be connected to specific
aircraft power sources.

Portable Electronic devices may cause Electro Magnetic Interferences (EMI) with the navigation/
communication system of the aircraft on which they are used.

To avoid any risk of interference, the operation of these electronic devices is prohibited from the
start of the flight when passengers have boarded and all doors have been closed, until a passenger
door has been opened at the end of the flight.

The following devices may be used at any time without restrictions:

Electronic shavers;
Electronic calculators/computers;
Electronic games without remote control;
Hearing aids;

8.3.16.5.1 Large PEDs

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Passengers will be informed that large PEDs (e.g. computers, tablets, cameras and other lithium
battery powered devices) should be carried in the passenger cabin whenever possible.

Any large PED that cannot be carried in the passenger cabin (e.g. due to its size), and therefore has
to be carried in checked baggage, has to be:

Completely switched off and effectively protected from accidental activation. To ensure the
device is never powered on during its transport, any application, alarm or pre-set
configuration that may activate it shall be disabled or deactivated;
Protected from the risk of accidental damage by applying suitable packaging or casing or
by being placed in a rigid bag protected by adequate cushioning (e.g. clothing);
Not carried in the same baggage together with flammable material (e.g. perfumes, aerosols,
etc.).
Make the carriage of large PEDs in checked baggage in Class D cargo compartments subject to
measures effectively mitigating the associated risks.

Furthermore, where carry-on bags are put in the hold (e.g. due to the lack of space) passengers are
requested to remove from the bag any spare batteries or e-cigarettes.

8.3.18 Cosmic Radiation

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
EGYPTAIR, based on the average total yearly flight time and route network, ensures that in-flight
exposure to cosmic radiation of its Crew Members while on-duty, does not exceed 6 mSv per year,
which is the maximum permissible value as per CAR-OPS 1.390(a)(2), therefore no record keeping
is required.

WARNING Female Crew Members should be aware of the need to avoid doses during pregnancy,
thus they must notify EGYPTAIR once they become pregnant.
The maximum operating altitude of EGYPTAIR aircraft is below 49.000 ft, therefore its aircraft are
not required to be equipped with cosmic radiation measuring equipment.

The exposure level for cosmic radiation depends upon:

Altitude;
Latitude; and
Time spent at altitude.
The following table shows the hours of exposure for a dose of 1 mSv per year:

Latitude
Altitude (ft)
30.000 33.000 36.000 39.000 42.000 45.000
60° 440 hrs 320 hrs 250 hrs 200 hrs 165 hrs 140 hrs
50° 530 hrs 392 hrs 314 hrs 248 hrs 209 hrs 180 hrs
40° 620 hrs 463 hrs 373 hrs 297 hrs 252 hrs 220 hrs
From the above table, it shall be noted that a Crew Member spending 200 hrs. per year at an
altitude of approximately 39.000 ft at latitudes of 60°North, will be exposed to a radiation dose of
1 mSv.

8.3.19 Policy for Use of Automation during Flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The Company’s policy during line operation is a maximum use of the auto flight system.

With auto flight system in use, it must be operated in such a way that optimum benefit is achieved
from its capabilities. Examples for optimum benefits are:

Reduction of workload;
Precision of navigation;
Availability of protection modes;
Passenger comfort;
Economic flight.
The overall aim is to reach an appropriate balance between the use of automation and the need to
maintain pilot manual flying skills, needed in case of automation failure or disconnection, or when
an aircraft is dispatched with an inoperative auto-flight system.

NOTE When the use of autopilot and/or auto-throttle becomes unproductive they shall be
disconnected.
NOTE For detailed policies and procedures, refer to the OM Part B and Chapter 14.3.7
Autopilot / Auto-throttle Use.
Operational Principles

In abnormal situations, flight crew members shall make use of automatic capabilities as much as
possible in order to minimize flight deck workload. If the selected automation is not adequately
controlling flight parameters, it must be deselected and the PF has to assume manual control.

As manual flying is a required skill, commanders are authorized to allow pilots to practice their
manual flying skills, when appropriate, taking into account the following factors:

Phase of flight
Only during initial departure and approach.
Workload condition
Individual condition of both flight crew members;
PF has to declare the “use of automation level” during the departure and approach
briefing;
Not permitted in case of fatigue (PF and PM).
Altitude/flight level (RVSM)
Not permitted within airspace with reduced separation.
Meteorological conditions
Not permitted, if visibility < 5 km or cloud ceiling < 1.000 ft or in case of adverse wind
conditions.
Traffic density

Not permitted within airspace E around;
Not permitted at airports with high traffic density;

Air Traffic Control and Air Traffic Management procedures
Not permitted on airports, where you can expect low initial altitudes, many step climbs,

Pilot and crew experience
Do not overestimate your skills;

irregular pre-threshold terrain, runway slope, displaced threshold);

Levels of Automated Flights

Managed Automatic

The aircraft is operated by use of autopilot and auto thrust with inputs from the FMS as
programmed or modified by the pilots;
The objective is to provide assistance to the pilots by freeing the pilot flying from routine
handling tasks and thus giving him time and resources to assess the overall operational
situation.
Selected Automatic

The aircraft is operated by use of autopilot and auto thrust with inputs from an auto flight
control unit as selected by the pilots, e.g. speed, heading, vertical speed;
The objective is to allow deviations from the programmed FMS profile to meet operational
requirement.
Managed Manual

The aircraft is operated by use of manual flight control inputs with or without auto thrust.
The pilot follows the flight director indications generated by the FMS as programmed or
modified;
The objective is to provide the pilot flying with adequate attitude or flight path orders with
the flight director symbols so as to facilitate accurate manual flying of the aircraft.

Selected Manual

The aircraft is operated by use of manual flight control inputs with or without auto thrust.
The pilot follows the flight director indications as selected by the pilots on an auto flight
control unit;
The objective is to allow deviations from the programmed FMS-profile while manual flying
the aircraft.
Basic Manual

The aircraft is operated by use of manual inputs. The pilot controls altitude, heading, speed
and positions by applying attitude and thrust as required;
The objective is to maintain the desired flight path, while automatic guidance is not
available or not desirable.
