8.3.20 Crew Coordination Concept

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Good communication and cooperation among all Crew Members is of extreme importance during
all phases of the flight.

The Commander is responsible for all standard communications with the Cabin Crew. He may
delegate required communication as necessary.

The Cabin Crew should always bear in mind that an aeroplane emergency could occur without the
Flight Deck Crew being immediately aware of the situation e.g. APU fire, fuel truck fire, cabin fire,
engine fire, smoke in the cabin, noise and vibrations. The Cabin Crew must not disregard any
observation made by the passengers regarding any irregularity and must check if there is any
cause for concern.

Vigilance in detecting any unusual situations in the early stages is essential.

Cabin Crew must report any such occurrences to the Flight Deck Crew immediately, even if the
Flight Deck Crew has already made an associated passenger address announcement.

The Cabin Crew must inform the Commander when emergency equipment is used or when it is
inoperative.

8.3.21 Crew Resource Management (CRM)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Crew resource management is the application of team management concepts and the effective
use of all available resources to operate a flight safely.

In addition to the crew, it includes all other groups routinely working with the crew who are
involved in decisions required to operate a flight.

These groups include, but are not limited to, flight dispatchers, Cabin Crew, security personnel,
maintenance personnel, and ATC.

It is important that all Crew Members identify and communicate any situation that appears unsafe
or out of the ordinary. Experience has proven that the most effective way to maintain safety of
flight and resolve these situations is to combine the skills and experience of all Crew Members in
the decision making process to determine the safest course of action.

It is EGYPTAIR’ policy to perform a CRM FORDEC, to analyze and to cope with non-normal
situations.

Execution of a CRM FORDEC procedure could be initiated by any Crew Member and it may not be
negated by the other Crew Members.

CRM FORDEC includes the following parts:

F acts (what is the problem),
O ptions (hold, divert, immediate landing, etc.)
R isks/Benefits
(what is the downside of each option, what is the
upside, e.g. a runway may be further away but is longer
or if all options are equally safe, an airport with
maintenance or company support has greater benefit)
D ecision (which option is selected)
E xecution (carrying out selected option)
C heck/Re-Check
(did everything work as planned, and what else needs
to be done)
8.3.22 Prevention of Runway Incursions

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Runway incursion prevention mitigating strategies include:

The use of all available resources (heading indicators, airport diagrams, airport signs,
markings, lighting and air traffic control) to keep the aircraft on its assigned flight and/or
taxi route;
Being familiar with, and including in the approach briefing, the destination airport's lay out
and relationship to other ground features;
Correctly identified the destination airport, before reporting the airport/runway is in sight;
Full briefing of the airport diagram and airport signage;
Not crossing (red) stop bars during taxi;
Monitoring of taxi progress and/or verbal callouts after taxiway passage;
Briefing of a pre-taxi plan and route;
Writing down ATC taxi instructions;
Maintaining situational awareness at night and during times of reduced visibility;

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Not stopping on a runway and, if possible, taxiing off an active runway and then initiating
communications with ATC to regain orientation;
Visually and verbally confirming that the final approach path is clear, prior to taxiing into the
take-off position on the runway;
Managing workload prior to take-off and before landing;
Avoiding administrative tasks until non-critical phases of flight;
Applying Sterile Flight Deck concept,
Using standard phraseology and standard callouts;
Reading back clearances and confirming changes;
Monitoring clearances given to other aircraft;
Obtaining directions or progressive taxi instructions when taxi route is in doubt;
Take-off and landing runway verification and crosschecking;
Take-off and landing clearance verification;
Questioning clearances when holding or lined up in position for take-off on the runway, and
take-off clearance has not been received within the expected period of time;
Appropriate use of aircraft lighting during taxi, runway crossing, take-off, and landing;
Appropriate transponder use at airports with ground surveillance radar;
Appropriate use of TCAS when on the runway and holding in the take-off position (e.g.
center mode on Navigation Display to display traffic on final approach);
Identifying potential incursion areas or points (e.g. hot spots) on airport diagrams;
Being aware of the presence of Land and Hold Short Operations (LAHSO);
Delaying checklists until the aircraft is stopped, if applicable.
8.3.23 Approach and Landing General Considerations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The normal unfactored landing distance is defined as the distance from 50 ft above threshold to a
full stop. The VREF speed is assumed at this 50 ft point. Furthermore, it is assumed that the
approach to the 50 ft point is stabilized and that a normal flare maneuver is carried out following a
normal/standard descent angle of 3°.

Glide path, VASI, PAPI and specific runway markings will assist Pilots to stay within the following
distances:

Aiming Point (instrument runway and non-instrument runways longer than 1.200 m); and
Touch Down Zone Marking (precision approach runways longer than 1.200 m).
It should be noted that the aiming point for a runway length of 1.200 to 2.400 m is located 300 m
from threshold, for longer runways the distance is 400 m from threshold. The touch down zone
markings, if provided, starts at a distance of 150 m from threshold.

It is EGYPTAIR’ policy that all landings shall be made within the touch down zone. If not, a go-
around should normally be initiated with due regard to the remaining runway length.

Every effort must be made to land on and along the runway centerline, this provides the best
margin to recover from lateral control difficulties occurring after touchdown.

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In general, no flight may be operated below minimum safe altitudes, see Chapter 8.1.1 Minimum

8.3.25 Medical Situation In-flight

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The Commander must be informed, and kept up-to-date, in the event of any medical situation
inflight. When a passenger or Crew Member becomes acutely ill and apprehension exists about the
passenger's/crew's ability to survive during the flight, diversion to the nearest appropriate
aerodrome should be considered.

In an attempt to limit the number of diversions to those that are essential, effort should be made
to obtain qualified medical opinion from a physician or a nurse among passengers.

Cabin Crew shall provide First Aid as per procedures given in the OM Part F.

If diversion is necessary, the Commander shall inform ATC of intention and the type of medical
situation onboard.

NOTE In a diversion to an alternate aerodrome, the Commander should consider that an
hour might elapse before the patient gets medical attention at that aerodrome. It may
often be wiser to continue to the destination and radio ahead for medical facilities on
arrival.
If possible, operations should be contacted at the earliest opportunity stating the nature of the
problem and the intentions of the Commander.

If applicable, operations should be asked to alert the Medical Unit at the destination aerodrome,
giving relevant medical details and whether or not an ambulance is required.

8.3.26 Birth

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
If a birth occurs on an EGYPTAIR aircraft, the Commander shall notify the next scheduled point of
landing via ATC, requesting an ambulance to meet the aircraft to ensure immediate medical
assistance.

8.3.27 Death On Board

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The aim of the following procedures is to provide both Flight and Cabin Crew with guidelines on
how to handle a death/presumed death (unconscious, non-breathing) on board situation.

If a passenger is presumed dead, then such a case shall be treated as a medical emergency
and Cabin Crew shall immediately commence Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR)/AED;
The Commander must be informed as soon as possible;
The Purser/SCC shall make a PA announcement, asking for a qualified licensed doctor;
The Commander shall notify the next point of landing via ATC, requesting an ambulance to
meet the aircraft;
The CPR should continue until one of the following occurs:

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Spontaneous breathing or normal breathing returns (any signs of life); or
All rescuers are too exhausted to continue; or
The Commander advises of any adverse conditions or limitations which would threaten
the safety of the flight; or
The person is declared dead by a qualified licensed doctor by filling and signing a death
on board report;
The aircraft has landed and care is transferred to emergency medical services.
NOTE For legal reasons, a doctor may pronounce, but shall not certify, death, as this will be
done by the relevant medical authority at the destination.
NOTE If the cause of death is suspected to be anything other than natural death,
passengers shall not disembark the aircraft prior to the arrival of police
authorities.
Upon arrival, the Commander shall submit a report, with full details using the form inside the
emergency medical kit to the station manager, except in Cairo the forms must be submitted
to the Public Relations upon arrival. In addition, an ASR has to be filed.
8.3.28 Emergency Medical Kit

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
An Emergency Medical Kit (EMK) contains life saving equipment and medication which is carried
on-board the aircraft and can be opened only with the explicit instructions and authorization of
the aircraft Commander.

The Commander shall ensure that the EMK drugs are not administered except by qualified doctors,
nurses or similarly qualified personnel.

When a casualty has been declared dead the following protocol is suggested:

Move the person to an area of privacy or to a seat with few other passengers nearby. If the
aircraft is full, put the person back into his own seat, or at the crew's discretion, into another
area not obstructing an aisle or exit;
If any medical devices such as electro pads (AED) are attached to the deceased person, they
should not be removed;
Take extra care when moving the body and be aware of the difficulty of the situation for
companions and onlookers;
Do not place the body in the lavatory or in the Crew Rest Compartment;
Restrain the body with seat belt or other equipment;
Close the eyes, and cover the body with a blanket up to the neck;
If the onboard body bag is used, the zipper of the body bag must not be completely closed,
and the head must be exposed;
If possible, place waterproof material under the body in case of seepage of bodily fluid;
Request contact information from travelling companions;
The body should remain on board until all passengers have been disembarked (Where
passengers are required to remain on board, consult the station).

8.3.29 Carriage of Stretcher (STCR) / Incubator (INCO/INCU)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Carriage of any stretcher patient/incubator is subject to the approval of EGYPTAIR. They will be
boarded first and disembarked last. Passengers on stretcher shall be accompanied by a doctor/
nurse, or a family member or other escort to provide him with the required en-route care, and
should be seated next to the customer they are escorting in an aisle seat.

The prescribed seating and the maximum number of stretcher patients/incubator that can be
accepted are type specific and are as mentioned in OM Part F.

The concerned departments shall arrange the availability and installation of the on-board stretcher
and oxygen bottles (if required).

The Commander and the Purser / SCC must be advised that the stretcher passenger is on board
and the Purser / SCC shall be briefed on any special conditions that apply.

On the aircraft, the stretcher must be fitted with the shoulder harness towards the front of the
aircraft. For take-off and landing and whenever the Seat Belt sign is ON. If the patient’s condition
permits, the stretcher must be in the flattest position and all safety belts and harnesses must be
fastened securely. The curtains around the stretcher must be closed at all times, except for take-off
and landing.

NOTE In case of occupied incubator, it must be escorted by a physician or a qualified person.
NOTE Only 2 STCR/INCU/INCO are allowed on board.
NOTE For further details refer to OM Part F.
8.3.30 Diversions

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The PIC shall observe and evaluate the development of the metrological situation
specifically forecast for the route to be flown, for en-route alternates and the destination
aerodrome and its alternates. All en-route alternates on the OFP are fulfilling the criteria for
determining the adequacy of aerodrome in item 8.1.2 Criteria and Responsibilities for
Determining the Adequacy of Aerodromes ;
The flight is not continued to the destination and a diversion to an en-route alternate
should be made but not limited to any of the following;
Unless the latest information available indicates that, at the expected time of arrival, the
weather conditions at the destination, or at least one destination alternate aerodrome, are
at or above the applicable aerodrome operating minima;
The amount of usable fuel remaining suffices to proceed to an aerodrome, where a safe
landing can be made, with the final reserve fuel remaining;

8.3.31 Runway Excursions

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
8.3.31.1 Definition

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
When an aircraft on the runway surface departs the end or the side of the runway surface, runway
excursions can occur on take-off or landing and they consist of two types of events:

Veer-off : a runway excursion in which an aircraft departs the side of a runway;
Overrun : a runway excursion in which an aircraft departs the end of a runway.
8.3.31.2 General

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
EGYPTAIR monitor aircraft parameters related to potential runway excursions in their Flight
Data Analysis (FDA) program. Whenever standardised FDA markers are provided through
trend analysis, the industry best practices, should be used with priority to ensure the
effectiveness of risk mitigation and safety assurance associated with runway excursion
barriers and to allow comparability on industry level;
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.3 Flight Procedures
OM A
8-3-154

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
EGYPTAIR should incorporate appropriate technical solutions to reduce runway excursion
risks, where available (including Runway Overrun Awareness and Alerting System (ROAAS),
and runway veer off awareness and alerting systems, when and if available);
Flight Deck Crew shall not accept ATC procedures and clearances which have the potential
to decrease safety margins to an unacceptable level for the flight crew thereby increasing
the risk of runway excursions. This includes such procedures and clearances which increase
the likelihood of having an unsafe approach path management with consequences for safe
landing, e.g. which bear the risk of being un-stabilized at the landing gate or high-energy
approaches. Flight Deck Crew should report such risks within their reporting process;
Training includes realistic, scenarios into the training programs requiring threat and error
management for runway excursion prevention during both take-off and landing. This should
include evidence of recurrent simulator training programs which are representative in terms
of environmental conditions, including crosswind, landing on contaminated/slippery
runways and poor visibility adapted with simulator representativeness. Representativeness
of simulators should be assessed and their limitations communicated (in order to avoid
negative training).
8.3.31.3 Recommendations to Prevent Runway Excursion Risk are:

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
A mishandled rejected take-off (RTO) increases the risk of take-off runway excursion – Flight
Deck Crew shall strictly adhere to the procedures of 14.6.5.1 Rejected Take-off ;
Take-off performance calculation errors increase the risk of a take-off runway excursion –
Flight Deck Crew shall strictly adhere to the procedures of 14.6 Task Sharing ;
In flight landing distance calculation errors and runway conditions changes increase the risk
of a landing runway excursion – Flight Deck Crew shall strictly adhere to the procedures of
14.4.6.3 Approach Briefing.

8.4 ALL WEATHER OPERATIONS

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.4.1 Definitions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
For definitions relating to Low Visibility Operations, refer to Chapter 0.8 Terms and Definitions.

8.4.2 General

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
All Weather Operations (AWO) means any take-off or landing operations in conditions where
visual reference is limited by weather conditions.

This Chapter provides a compact reference for AWO and highlights the differences in terminology
not normally covered in other operations. The term AWO refers to operations in weather
conditions for take-off that are below the take-off minima, and in weather conditions for landing
that are below the CAT I approach minima. Under these conditions special crew authorization and
qualification is required.

The term AWO includes:

Low Visibility Take-off (LVTO). (RVR values less than 400 m);
CAT II Landing. (Decision altitudes below 200 ft but not less than 100 ft and RVR less than
550 m but not less than 300 m).
LVTOs and CAT II operations shall not be conducted, unless:

DH is determined by means of a radio altimeter;
Specific approval/authorization for CAT II operations is granted by the Authority;
Crew Members are qualified for Low Visibility Operations;
Taxi, take-off and landing are carried out by the Commander;
To conduct Low Visibility Operations (LVO), Low Visibility Procedures (LVP) must be in force
at the aerodrome of intended use;
The Commander satisfies himself that the status of the visual and non-visual facilities are
sufficient for commencing a LVTO or a CAT II approach, and that all Crew Members are
briefed on the local LVPs.
Procedures and instructions to be used for LVTO and CAT II operations are prescribed in the
OM Part B and in OM Part D.

NOTE When visibility for landing is less than 800 meters, approach and landing are not
authorized unless RVR reporting is available for the runway of intended use.
NOTE Failure of CAT II approaches, visual, or non-visual facilities, must be reported using an
adequate reporting form (e.g. ASR).

8.4.7.3 Take-off

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
Judgment should be exercised regarding the use of interior and exterior lights;
It must be ensured that the aircraft does not pass the CAT II holding point until cleared to
enter the runway;
If available, an ILS shall be tuned and identified and the localizer indication centered and
cross-checked by both Pilots to ensure that the aircraft is on the runway centerline;
The Commander shall satisfy himself that, under the prevailing meteorological conditions,
the visual references are sufficient for the take-off to be completed safely;
TOGA shall be used for take-off;
If visual cues are lost below 80 kts (Boeing)/100 kts (Airbus), the take-off shall be rejected;
If visual cues are lost above 80 kts (Boeing)/100 kts (Airbus), the take-off shall be continued
provided no other abnormal situation warrants a rejected take-off in the high-speed phase.
NOTE Maximum crosswind for low visibility take-off is 15 kts.
NOTE Standard runway centerline lights change from white to alternating red and white
when the remaining of the runway is approximately 3.000 ft (900 m) and to steady red
when the remaining is only 1.000 ft (300 m).

8.4.11 Incapacitation During CAT II

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
In case of Commander incapacitation, the F/O should divert to a CAT A or B aerodrome
where weather conditions are at or above CAT I minima;
In case of F/O incapacitation, the Commander, after assessing the situation, will decide
whether to continue the CAT II approach or to divert.
8.4.12 Decision Height Concept

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Decision height is a specified point in space at which the Commander must make an operational
decision. He must decide if the visual references, adequate to safely continue the approach, have
been established.

If the visual references have not been established, a go-around must be executed;
If the visual references have been established, the approach can be continued. However, the
Commander may always decide to execute a go-around if sudden degradations in the visual
references or a sudden flight path deviation occur.
8.4.13 Loss of Visual References

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Before Touchdown

If the required visual reference was acquired before DH but it subsequently becomes insufficient
following the decision to continue the approach, or the flight path deviates unacceptably, an
immediate go-around shall be initiated.

CAUTION A go-around initiated close to the runway may result in ground contact. In this case,
the go-around shall be continued. Strict adherence to the relevant content of the
OM Part B is mandatory.
After Touchdown

If the required visual reference is lost after touchdown, a go-around should not be attempted.

maneuver is not protected and may need to be discontinued should any abnormality

Threshold Time

The threshold time is not an operating limit. It is a flight time to an en-route alternate aerodrome,
which is established by the State of the Operator as being the EDTO threshold beyond which
particular consideration should be given to the aeroplane capability as well as the operator's
relevant operational experience, before granting an EDTO approval.

Maximum Diversion Time

The maximum diversion time is the range (expressed in time) from a point on a route to an en-
route alternate aerodrome up to which the State of the Operator will grant approval. When
approving the operator’s maximum diversion time, States will need to consider not only the
capable range of the aircraft, taking into consideration any limitation of the aeroplanes type
certificate, but also the operator’s previous experience on similar aircraft types and routes.

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24 (A)
Configuration Maintenance
and Procedure (CMP)
ETOPS/EDTO Configuration/Maintenance/Procedures document
also referred to as the Standards for Extended Range Operation.

aspects associated with EDTO operations:
Configurations Standards, Maintenance Standards;
Dispatch Standards;
Procedures Standards.

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Critical Point (CP) The EDTO CP is the point, along the route, for which the
difference between the standard fuel expected to be on board
(fuel to continue) and the required EDTO diversion fuel (fuel to
divert) is minimum or negative, thus requiring the carriage of
additional EDTO fuel reserves. The CP is usually, but not
necessarily, the last ETP within the EDTO segment.
EDTO Capability The EDTO capability of the aircraft is declared in the following
documents approved by the ECAA:
OM Part B;
CMP Standard;
MEL.
EDTO Entry Point (EEP) The EEP is the first point on the route, located at one hour flying
time (at the declared one-engine-out diversion speed, in still
air) from a suitable en-route alternate airport (i.e. the last
suitable en-route alternate airport prior to entering the EDTO
segment).
The EEP materializes the beginning of the EDTO segment.
EDTO Exit Point (EXP) The EXP is the last point on the route, located at one hour flying
time (at the declared one-engine-out diversion speed, in still
air) from a suitable en-route alternate airport (i.e. the first
suitable en-route alternate airport located beyond the EDTO
segment).
The EXP materializes the end of the EDTO segment.
EDTO Operation The EDTO operation is allowed if:
The aircraft is EDTO certificated;
The operator has been granted EDTO operational
approval.
EDTO Segment An EDTO segment is a portion of a route located further than
60 minutes flying time (at the selected one-engine-out
diversion speed, in still air) from a suitable airport. The EDTO
segment extends between the EEP and the EXP. An EDTO route
may contain more than one EDTO segment.
Equal Time Point (ETP) An ETP is a point on the route which is located at the same
flying time (considering the day wind and temperatures
conditions) from the two associated suitable en-route alternate
airports.
The location of the ETPs is usually defined by the CFP but can
be also assessed by locating the midpoints (equidistant points)
on a plotting chart or orientation chart and by applying a wind
correction (e.g. using the equitime number method or a wind
correction scale).

8.5.3 EDTO Aircraft Configuration

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The configuration of the aircraft, such as the components fitted, Service Bulletins accomplished, is
defined by the CMP. The CMP standards apply when the aircraft is to be used for extended range
operations. Procedures to control this configuration are contained in the operator's EDTO
maintenance procedures manual or equivalent.

Significant defects which cannot be rectified before further flight, or which re-occur, may require a
re-grading of the aircraft to a “NON-EDTO” standard.

8.5.4 Granted EDTO Area of Operations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.5.4.1 Maximum Diversion Time

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The Maximum Diversion time from an en-route alternate airport (e.g. 75, 90, 120, 138, 180
minutes) is granted to EGYPTAIR within and as a function of the following factors:

The Maximum Diversion time defined for the airframe/engine combination and set forth in
the aircraft TDA and in the OM Part B reduced by an operational safety margin, commonly
15 minutes, specified by the State of the Operator;
The airline’s prior experience with the aircraft in NON-EDTO or EDTO operation.
For determining the maximum diversion distance to an en-route alternate, the operator should use
the approved speed for the appropriate aircraft type as described in the Chapter below.

The granted Maximum Diversion Time cannot exceed the aircraft certified Maximum Diversion
Time.

8.5.4.2 Diversion Speeds OEI/AEO

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The EDTO diversion speeds are a Mach/IAS speed schedule selected and declared by the operator
and approved by the ECAA.

This diversion speeds can be any speed within the aircraft operating limits. i.e. between minimum
drag speed and MMO/VMO. The selected diversion speed is used for the following purposes:

Establishing the area of operation (maximum diversion distance);
Establishing the diversion fuel requirements;

Establishing the net level-off altitude to safely clear any en-route obstacle by the

8.5.4.3 Adequate Airport

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
To qualify as adequate for the purpose of EDTO, an airport must satisfy the performance
requirements applicable at the expected landing weight.

The following conditions are also considered at the expected time of use:

Availability of the airport;
Wind and weather conditions en-route at the diversion altitude, minimum altitudes en-
route and fuel consumption to the en-route alternate aerodrome;
Runways available, runway surface condition, weather, wind and terrain, in proximity of the
en-route alternate aerodrome;
Instrument approaches (ILS/VOR/DME, VOR, NDB, ASR, PAR or GPS/GNSS) and approach/
runway lighting available, RFFS at the en-route alternate aerodrome;
The pilot’s familiarity with that aerodrome and information about that aerodrome provided
to the pilot by the operator; and
Facilities for passenger and crew disembarkation and accommodation.
8.5.4.4 En-route Alternate Airport

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In addition to the provisions described in 8.1.3.4 Planning Minima and the requirements
described in 8.5.4.3 Adequate Airport above, the following applies:

For route planning purposes, identified en-route alternate aerodromes need to be located
at a distance within the maximum diversion time from the route and which could be used if
necessary; and
In extended diversion time operations, before an aeroplane crosses its threshold time
during flight, there should always be an en-route alternate aerodrome within the approved
maximum diversion time whose conditions will be at or above the operator’s established
aerodrome operating minima for the operation during the estimated time of use.

The Maximum Diversion Distance is the distance covered, in still air and ISA conditions (unless the
area of operation is eligible for the consideration of an average yearly positive temperature
deviation from ISA), within the Maximum Diversion Time granted to the operator, at the declared
diversion cruise speed and reference gross weight and at the associated optimum diversion
altitude.

This distance starts from the descent point, considered to be at the CP, and takes into account the
descent profile from the initial cruise altitude down to the diversion cruise altitude.

The Maximum Diversion Distance is used to define the Area of Operation (and correspondingly, as
applicable, the area or areas of unauthorized operation, also referred to as exclusion zones) by
drawing circles centered on each declared suitable en-route alternate airport with a radius equal to
the Maximum Diversion Distance.

The maximum diversion distance measured from an adequate airport is based on:

OEI speed, ISA, still air for aircraft with two turbine engines;
AEO speed, ISA, still air for aircraft with more than two turbine engines.

8.5.4.6 Area of Operations

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The EDTO Area of Operation is the area in which it is permitted to conduct a flight under the EDTO
regulations. It is defined by the declared maximum diversion distance from an adequate airport -
or set of adequate airports - and is represented by the area enclosed within the circles centred on
the selected adequate airports, the radius of which is the declared maximum diversion distance.

The area of operation (hence the maximum diversion distance) is defined in still air and, generally,
in ISA conditions. However, whenever for a given area of operation the temperature deviation is
essentially constant throughout the year, credit can be taken for a positive temperature deviation
from ISA in order to take benefit of the corresponding higher TAS and, thus, of the higher
maximum diversion distance (at given diversion time).

NOTE The EDTO area boundary for route planning purposes is based on constant, still-air
diversion distance radius from overhead the aerodrome location and neither considers
potential routing nor approach path and descent profile, wind and temperature
variations which may be encountered during an actual diversion.
Therefore, actual diversion times may be higher than the diversion times used to
establish the corresponding area of operation, this is Normal and does not constitute
an area of operation exceedance as long as the planned route of flight remains within
the applicable still-air range from an en-route alternate aerodrome.
8.5.5 EDTO Fuel Supply & Critical Fuel

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
All flights engaged in EDTO operations should carry enough fuel to fly to an en-route alternate
aerodrome as described above while considering wind and other weather conditions expected. The
EDTO critical fuel corresponds to the additional fuel that may be required to comply with Chapter
8.1.7.2 Standard Fuel Planning and should cover:

For more than two turbine engines:
Fuel sufficient to fly to an en-route alternate aerodrome, considering at the most critical
point of the route, simultaneous engine failure and depressurisation or depressurisation
alone, whichever is more limiting; the speed selected for the diversions (i.e.
depressurisation, combined or not with an engine failure) may be different from the
approved all-engine operative speed used to determine the EDTO threshold and maximum
diversion distance.
For two turbine engines:
Fuel sufficient to fly to an en-route alternate aerodrome, considering at the most critical
point of the route, failure of one engine or simultaneous engine failure and
depressurisation or depressurisation alone, whichever is more limiting;
a. The speed selected for the all-engine-operative diversion (i.e. depressurisation alone)
may be different from the approved one-engine-inoperative speed used to determine
the EDTO threshold and maximum diversion distance;
b. The speed selected for the one-engine-inoperative diversions (i.e. engine failure alone
and combined engine failure and depressurisation) should be the approved one-
engine-inoperative speed used to determine the EDTO threshold and maximum
diversion distance.
Fuel to account for icing;

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The operational application of the EDTO critical fuel requirement consists of the requisite flight

system (LIDO) are capable of determining the critical fuel required (CFR) and the normal planned

8.5.6.2 Regrading to “NON-EDTO” Status

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
If the MEL cannot be complied with for EDTO, or if the aircraft configuration does not comply with

8.5.7 EDTO Flight Dispatch

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Before each EDTO flight, in addition to the normal preparation of any flight the dispatcher on duty
must pay particular attention to the conditions which might prevail any time that the operation is
beyond 60 minutes to an en-route alternate aerodrome, e.g. systems degradation, reduced flight
altitude, etc. In addition to the standard dispatch aspects, the following are considered:

Identify en-route alternate airports (adequate airports);
Ensure that prior to departure the flight crew is provided with the most up-to-date
information on the identified en-route alternate aerodromes, including operational status
and meteorological conditions and, in-flight, make available means for the flight crew to
obtain the most up-to date weather information;
Methods to enable two-way communications between the aeroplane and the operator’s
operational control centre;
Ensure that the operator has a means to monitor conditions along the planned route
including the identified alternate airports and ensure that procedures are in place so that
the flight crew are advised of any situation that may affect the safety of flight;
Ensure that the intended route does not exceed the established aeroplane threshold time
unless the operator is approved for EDTO operations;
Pre-flight system serviceability including the status of items in the minimum equipment list;
Communication and navigation facilities and capabilities;
Fuel requirements; and
Availability of relevant performance information for the identified en-route alternate
aerodrome(s).

Prior to departure and in-flight, the meteorological conditions at identified en-route alternate
aerodromes are required to be at or above the aerodrome operating minima required for the
operation during the estimated time of use.

8.5.7.1 Suitable Airports

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A suitable airport, for dispatch purposes, is an airport confirmed to be adequate and which
satisfies the EDTO Dispatch Weather Minima in terms of ceiling and visibility within the required
validity period (also referred to as window of suitability).

The required validity period starts from the earliest estimated time of arrival and ends one hour
after the latest estimated time of arrival (refers to Weather Minima and Window of Suitability).

In addition, crosswind conditions forecast must be checked to be within the performance
capability of the aircraft during the required validity period.

Field conditions should also be checked to ensure that a safe landing can be conducted with one
engine being inoperative or with an aircraft system being inoperative (NOTAMs and SNOWTAMs
should, therefore, be also reviewed in assessing the suitability of an adequate en-route alternate
airport).

8.5.7.2 EDTO Dispatch Weather Minima

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Planning minima for an EDTO en-route alternate aerodrome. An operator shall only select an
aerodrome as an EDTO en-route alternate aerodrome when the appropriate weather reports or
forecasts, or any combination thereof, indicate that, between the anticipated time of landing until
one hour after the latest possible time of landing, conditions calculated by adding the additional
limits of Table "EDTO Planning Minima" will exist.

Approach Facility Alternate Airfield Ceiling Weather Minimum (VIS/RVR)
Precision approach Authorised DH + 200 ft Authorised VIS + 800 m
Non-precision approach Authorised MDH + 400 ft Authorised VIS + 1.500 m
8.5.7.3 Window of Suitability

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
(Period of Validity) To declare an adequate en-route alternate airport as suitable to support a given
flight, the ceiling and visibility forecast must be checked to meet the EDTO dispatch weather
minima during a required period of validity, also referred to as the window of suitability.

The required period of validity starts at the earliest estimated time of arrival at the considered en-
route alternate airport and ends one hour after the latest estimated time of arrival at this airport.

The earliest estimated time of arrival is computed considering an all-engine operating diversion
from the first ETP (along the outbound route) associated with the considered en-route alternate, at
the normally planned cruise altitude and speed (i.e. assuming a diversion for any reason other than
an engine or pressurisation failure).

The latest estimated time of arrival is computed considering an all-engine operating diversion
from the second ETP associated with the considered en-route alternate, at FL100 or at the MORA
and at the LRC speed (i.e. assuming a pressurization failure only).

The time window between the earliest and latest possible use of the alternates is normally
indicated in the computerized flight plan. If necessary, a simplified conservative method may be
used by the dispatcher on duty to determine this time - window under the day's conditions or to
confirm the validity of the planning in case of flight delay. For delay in excess of one hour, a new
time window is defined. The following conservative method may be used to define it manually:

Beginning of the time window:
(take-off time) + (Flight time to equitime point before alternate) + (diversion time at normal
cruise speed and altitude);
End of the time window:
(take-off time) + (flight time to equitime point after alternate) + (diversion time at long
range speed FL100) + (one hour).
8.5.7.4 Communication and Navigation Facilities

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An aircraft shall not be dispatched on an EDTO flight unless:

Communications facilities are available to provide, under all expected conditions of
propagation at the one-engine-inoperative cruise altitudes, reliable two way voice
communications between the aircraft and the appropriate air traffic control unit over the
planned route of flight and the routes to any suitable alternate to be used in the event of
diversion; and
Non-visual ground navigation aids (ILS-VOR-SRE-ADF) are available and located so as to
provide, taking into account the navigation equipment installed in the aircraft, the
navigation accuracy required over the route and altitude of flight, and the routes to any
alternate and altitudes to be used in the event of a diversion for whatever reason; and
Approved visual and non-visual aids are available at the specified alternates for the
authorized types of approaches and operating minima.
8.5.8 Dispatch Fuel Requirements

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The fuel planning should be in line with the Critical Fuel Scenario requirement. A computerised
flight plan is normally used to calculate the fuel requirements.

In case of necessity the fuel calculation may be manually performed by the dispatcher on duty or
the flight crew using the OM Part B, the following should be considered:

Critical Fuel Scenario for EDTO;
Considering the following possible failure scenarios occurring at the CP;
Engine failure only;
Engine failure + pressurisation failure;
Pressurisation failure only.

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
The EDTO Critical Fuel Scenario (CFS) is the scenario requiring the highest diversion fuel. The
engine failure only is never fuel critical because of the diversion being conducted at higher flight
levels.

Depending on the selected diversion speed either one of the last two scenarios (i.e. engine failure
and all-engine diversion at FL100 or MEA/

MORA) may happen to be the critical fuel scenario. The critical fuel scenario is assessed by
computing the required diversion fuel (for the respective diversion scenarios) in accordance with
the diversion profiles defined in the Manufacturers Operating Manual.

EDTO Fuel Reserves

In addition to the fuel uplift defined in 8.1.7 Determination of the Quantities of Fuel, Oil and
Water Methanol Carried , EDTO regulations require the addition of specific fuel reserves to the
EDTO diversion fuel.

The fuel provisions associated with the effects of anti-ice systems and the ice accretion are
adjusted as a function of the horizontal extension of the forecast icing areas (exposure time).

The fuel provision for ice accretion on the unheated surfaces is (in percentage) a function (typically,
three times for a severe icing forecast) of the ice accretion exposure time forecast in hours.

For example, assuming a one-and-a-half hour exposure time en-route or on diversion and a fuel
provision of three times the exposure time, the fuel provision is 4,5 % of the fuel burnt during the
considered exposure time. However, in case of moderate icing forecast, the above-mentioned fuel
provision is divided by two.

For operations above 138 minutes diversion time, if the effect of ice accretion is less than 5%, it
should be rounded-up to 5% to provide a provision for weather avoidance.

8.5.10 EDTO In-flight

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.5.10.1 Pre-flight Checklist and In-flight Procedures

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Pre-flight checklist and in-flight procedures are adapted for EDTO. The items of the checklist and
procedures which are specific to EDTO are identified. The flight crew must verify that the aircraft
has not been regraded to NON-EDTO and must acknowledge the EDTO release from line
maintenance.

All EDTO crew procedures are provided in the OM Part B, if applicable.

8.5.10.2 In-flight Weather Forecast Monitoring

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The applicable en-route minima at each alternate airport (ceiling and visibility) for en-route
decisions are the normal published minima or company minima, taking into account serviceable
landing navaids and crew qualification. The EDTO dispatch minima do not apply once in-flight.

During the flight, the flight crew must obtain the latest weather forecasts and check the weather
conditions and minima for the relevant alternate airports.

Before reaching the EDTO sector entry point, weather forecasts must satisfy the normal published
minima. Any alternate airport where the normal minima are no longer satisfied may no longer be
considered suitable and the area of operations must be modified accordingly. In the case of EDTO
up to 120 minutes, a reroute or turn back is not required, but a new alternate should be selected,
preferably within the 75/90/120 minutes of the selected route as the case may be for the specific
aeroplane type. In the case of 180 minutes EDTO operation a reroute or turn back is required if a
suitable alternate within 180 minutes of the selected route cannot be found. Once in the EDTO
sector of the flight, even if an en-route alternate airport falls below the normal minima, the flight
can be continued as planned.

Flight information updates will periodically be obtained by the dispatcher on duty and
communicated via HF or ACARS to the flight crew.

The crew must establish contact with flight operations in case of rerouting, diversion or in-flight
incident for in-flight assistance.

8.5.10.3 Fuel Monitoring

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
During an EDTO flight the fuel monitoring procedure is the same as for a NON-EDTO flight. There
are no special requirements at the CP, the fuel on board must be enough to apply the fuel policy
at destination and at the destination alternate. There are no special requirements for en-route
alternateairports.

In case of a diversion, the Commander has the authority to deviate from the planned one engine

8.5.10.5 Rectification of Aircraft Defects

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The crew must report in the Aircraft Technical Log any aircraft and engine defects which are
significant to EDTO flights. Such entries must be fully investigated and rectified before the next
EDTO flight.

Rectification may be verified by:

Specified ground checks, i.e. system or function checks with the aircraft on the ground;
NON-EDTO flight;
An EDTO flight subject to verification of an outstanding rectification during the first 90
minutes of flight before reaching the EEP;
A specific verification flight.
Defects which occur only during flight or which are intermittent in nature require verification as per
(2), (3) or (4) above.

Verification as per (2), (3) or (4) above is also required:

Following an engine change;
After an engine or oil system breakdown or major component change;
If verification action is to be carried out as prescribed in (c) above, the rectification must be
certified in the Aircraft Technical Log and the following statement added: “Aircraft certified
for EDTO subject to verification of (system/component, etc.) in the first 90 minutes of next
flight”.
Maintenance control must inform flight operations and the flight crew should be contacted at least
one hour before departure to get their agreement and to allow the normal dispatch of the aircraft.

8.6 USE OF THE MINIMUM EQUIPMENT LISTS AND THE

CONFIGURATION DEVIATION LISTS
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.6.1 Minimum Equipment List (MEL)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The MEL is approved by the ECAA and permits the operation with specific inoperative items or
equipment for a period of time, or a number of flights, until repairs can be accomplished.

The basis for establishing and approving the MEL is the Master Minimum Equipment List (MMEL).
In addition to the MMEL, the MEL considers operational regulations and increased safety standards
applicable to EGYPTAIR commercial operations.

The decision of the Commander of the flight to have allowable inoperative items corrected prior to
flight will take precedence over the provision contained in the MEL. The Commander may request
requirements above the minimum listed whenever, in his judgment, such added equipment is
essential to the safety of a particular flight under the special conditions prevailing at the time, he
shall, however, never accept requirements below the minimum required.

Maintenance, ferry, and base training flights may be dispatched with less than the equipment
specified in the MEL, provided all equipment expected to be utilized in that flight is operable. The
recommendation in favor or against such a flight must be requested from the technical
department, flight operations and the Authority.

Equipment obviously basic to the aeroplane's airworthiness (such as wings, rudders, etc.) is not
listed in the MEL and must be operative for all flights. On the other hand, equipment obviously not
required for the safe operation of the aeroplane, such as passenger's convenience items, are not
listed and may be unserviceable. For more details refer to the type specific OM Part B.

NOTE MEL requirements and/or restrictions remain applicable until take-off power is set. Any
System failure that occurs after all engines have been started requires completion of
the associated non-normal checklist; thereafter, the MEL must be consulted to
determine if dispatch relief is available.
8.6.2 Configuration Deviation List CDL

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A configuration deviation list is a list, which identifies any external parts of an aircraft type which
may be missing at the commencement of a flight, and which contains, where necessary, any
information on associated operating limitations and performance correction, for additional
information, refer to the type specific AFM.

8.6.3 Dispatch

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The MEL is not intended to provide for continued operation of an aircraft for an unlimited period
of time. Repairs should be made as soon as possible within the time limit imposed by Rectification
Intervals.

The MEL provides categories A, B, C and D, Rectification Intervals:

Category A:
No standard interval is specified, however, items in this category shall be rectified in

Category B:

Category C: Items in this category shall be rectified within ten consecutive calendar days, excluding

Category D:

Dispatch of the aircraft is not allowed after expiry of the Rectification Interval specified, unless the
Rectification Interval is extended.

Engineering personnel, if applicable, will provide placarding of inoperative items.

For flight planning, the OFP shall take account for take-off and/or landing performance and fuel

8.7 NON-REVENUE FLIGHTS – PROCEDURES AND LIMITATIONS

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
All non-revenue flights shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures and policies
described in the Operations Manual unless specific alleviations allow otherwise.

A loadsheet is required for all non-revenue flights in accordance with normal procedures. It is
prohibited to carry passengers on non-revenue flights unless the necessary approvals have been
obtained.

Whenever Cabin Crew Members are not carried, the Commander shall nominate one crew member
to be responsible for performing the cabin safety checks and for conducting the supernumerary
personnel safety briefing.

The following flights are considered as non-revenue flights:

Training flights;
Test/Airworthiness Flights;
Delivery flights;
Ferry flights;
Demonstration flights;
Positioning flights.
Flight Deck Crew shall perform all the above stated flights in compliance with any limitations and
procedures contained in the type specific AFM / FCOM. Adherence is a must to any additional
limitation and/or procedures specified by the manufacturer and/or indicated in the Technical Log
Book.

NOTE EGYPTAIR does not conduct passenger’s flights without cabin crew.
8.7.1 Training Flights

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Base Training flights, also known as Zero Flight Time Training (ZFTT), are conducted in accordance
with the guidance provided in OM Part D.

8.7.2 Test / Airworthiness Flights

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Test flights must be performed after special maintenance and/or repair work on the aeroplane, or
upon the Authority's request. Test flights shall be performed according to programs issued by the
responsible Technical Department in agreement with the Flight Operations Department.

Test flights shall be performed by the minimum Flight Deck Crew according to OM Part B. Flight
Operations Department shall assign only experienced instructor Pilots to conduct test flights. If it is
required by the kind of test flight, there might be, in addition to the minimum crew, engineers,
mechanics or inspectors on board who are directly involved in the preceding work/inspection of
the aeroplane. They must be recorded in the technical flight log as additional Crew Members.

The responsible engineer shall give the Flight Deck Crew a briefing on:

The reason of the test flight;
The test program; and

8.7.3 Delivery Flights

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Delivery flights are flights where an aircraft is flown from the seller's facility to EGYPTAIR home
base or vice versa.

Provided all normal requirements are fulfilled, non-revenue passengers may be carried, if this is
not excluded on the Certificate of Airworthiness and Certificate of Registration. Full insurance
coverage must be assured. For some delivery flights, the ECAA might only issue a “Ferry Permit” in
lieu of the Certificate of Airworthiness and the Certificate of Registration. This ferry permit may
exclude the carriage of persons other than Flight Deck Crew and engineers.

8.7.4 Ferry Flights

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
A ferry flight is a flight to position an aircraft for maintenance where the airworthiness is degraded.
This flight may be conducted with minimum Flight Deck Crew (see NOTE below) and reduced
airworthiness as permitted by AFM or its supplements or by special approval from the
manufacturer and ECAA.

NOTE At anytime there are company employees on board other than crew, minimum cabin
crew is required.
8.7.5 Demonstration Flights

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A demonstration flight may be for a sale/advertising purpose or to demonstrate flight
characteristics. It may also be a flight with journalists and customers to introduce a new type of
aircraft.

All demonstration flights will comply with the requirements laid down in this manual, as far as
practical. Any deviations will require prior permission from the G.M. Flight Operations and, if
appropriate, the ECAA.

In any case, all flights with passengers aboard require full and normal crew complement.

8.7.6 Positioning Flights

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
A positioning flight is a flight to bring an aeroplane to an aerodrome from which it will be
scheduled for flight.

Company Crew Members may be transported on the way from or to flight duty (Dead Head
Crews). When dead head crews are carried on positioning flights, there must be at least one
qualified Cabin Crew Member assigned on duty; except when there are company employees on
board other than crew members; minimum cabin crew is required.

8.8 OXYGEN REQUIREMENTS

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.8.1 Condition under which Oxygen must be Provided and Used

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Adequate breathing oxygen must be provided to the crew and passengers for sustenance in case
of depressurization, smoke or toxic gas emission.

The Commander shall ensure that Flight Deck Crew Members engaged in performing duties
essential to the safe operation of the flight, use supplemental oxygen continuously whenever cabin
altitude exceeds 10.000 ft. Additional First Aid Oxygen is required for passengers when the flight is
planned to fly above 25.000 ft. This First Aid Oxygen must still be available after a depressurization.

Description and use of Oxygen system and equipment are indicated in the relevant aircraft type
OM Part B and OM Part F.

8.8.2 Requirement for Crew and Passengers

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
8.8.2.1 First Aid Oxygen

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The quantity of oxygen required as first aid must be enough to provide 2% of passengers, and no
less than 2 passengers, with undiluted oxygen at a flow rate of at least 3 liters per minute
(Standard Temperature Pressure Dry - STPD) for the part of the flight above 8.000 ft but does not
exceed 15.000 ft following a depressurization.

This quantity of oxygen must be added to the required oxygen quantity for the case of emergency
descent.

The first-aid oxygen equipment shall be capable of generating a mass flow to each user of at least
4 liters per minute (STPD). Means may be provided to decrease the flow to not less than 2 liters
per minute (STPD) at any altitude.

8.8.2.2 Oxygen Equipment and Supply Requirements

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
Flight Crew Members
a. Each member of the flight crew on flight deck duty shall be supplied with
supplemental oxygen as specified in the table below. If all occupants of flight deck
seats are supplied from the flight crew source of oxygen supply then they shall be
considered as flight crew members on flight deck duty for the purpose of oxygen
supply. Flight deck seat occupants, not supplied by the flight crew source, are
considered to be passengers for the purpose of oxygen supply;
b. Flight crew members, not covered by (a.) above (e.g.: SNY, DHD or relief crew), are for
the purpose of oxygen supply, to be considered as:
i. Cabin crew members , if they are on call or are definitely going to have flight deck
duty before completing the flight;
OPERATING PROCEDURES
8.8 Oxygen Requirements
OM A
8-8-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
ii. Passengers , if they are not on call and will not be on flight deck duty during the
remainder of the flight.
c. Oxygen masks shall be located so as to be within the immediate reach of flight crew
members whilst at their assigned duty stations;
d. Oxygen masks for use by flight crew members in pressurised aeroplanes operating
above 25.000 ft shall be a quick donning type of mask;
e. Oxygen supply shall be equipped with a warning indication to the flight crew for any
loss of pressurisation.
Cabin Crew Members and Passengers
a. Cabin crew members and passengers shall be supplied with supplemental oxygen in
accordance with the table below. Cabin crew members carried above the minimum
number of cabin crew members required shall be considered as passengers for the
purpose of oxygen supply;
b. When operating above 25.000 ft there shall be provided sufficient spare outlets and
masks and/or sufficient portable oxygen units with masks for use by all required cabin
crew members. The spare outlets and/or units are to be distributed evenly throughout
the cabin to ensure immediate availability of oxygen to each required cabin crew
member regardless of his or her location at the time of cabin pressurisation failure;
c. When operating above 25.000 ft there shall be provided an oxygen dispensing unit
connected to oxygen supply terminals immediately available to each occupant,
wherever seated. The total number of dispensing units and outlets shall exceed the
number of seats by at least 10%. The extra units are to be evenly distributed
throughout the cabin;
d. The oxygen supply requirements, as specified in the table below, for aeroplanes not
certified to fly at altitudes above 25.000 ft may be reduced to the entire flight time
between 10.000 ft and 13.000 ft cabin pressure altitude for all required cabin crew
members and for at least 10% of the passengers if, at all points along the route to be
flown, the aeroplane is able to descend safely within 4 minutes to a cabin
pressure altitude of 13.000 ft ;
e. When operating above 25.000 ft or, if operating below, and unable to descent safely
within 4 minutes to 13.000 ft, the aeroplane shall be provided with automatically
deployable oxygen equipment immediately available to each occupant. The total
number of dispensing units shall exceed the number of seats by at least 10%. The extra
units are to be evenly distributed throughout the cabin.
NOTE Only applicable, when the individual certificate of airworthiness was first issued on or
after 9 November 1998.
NOTE When flying over high terrain where a descent to 13.000 ft may not be possible (e.g.
MEA/MORA above 13.000 ft), oxygen shall be provided to all passengers and cabin
attendants for the entire flight above 13.000 ft.

The supply provided must take account of the cabin pressure altitude descent profile for the
routes concerned.
The required minimum supply is that quantity of oxygen necessary for a constant rate of
descent from the aeroplane's maximum certificated operating altitude to 10.000 ft in 10
minutes and followed by 20 minutes at 10.000 ft.
The required minimum supply is that quantity of oxygen necessary for a constant rate of
descent from the aeroplane’s maximum certificated operating altitude to 10.000 ft in 10
minutes and followed by 110 minutes at 10.000 ft.
The required minimum supply is that quantity of oxygen necessary for a constant rate of
descent from the aeroplane’s maximum certificated operating altitude to 15.000 ft in 10
minutes.
For the purpose of this table “passengers” means passengers actually carried and includes
infants.

9.1 INTRODUCTION

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
This chapter complies with IATA DGRs and with the ICAO Technical Instructions;
For additional information cross references with IATA Dangerous Goods Manual as (DGR...)
has been added to paragraphs;
The Word "Operator" in this chapter applies for EGYPTAIR, EGYPTAIR’ Agents and/or
Subcontractors.
9.1.1 Objective of this Chapter

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
The objective of this chapter is to help Pilots (and Dispatchers) to comply with The IATA
"Dangerous Goods Regulations" (latest edition), which based on ICAO " Technical Instructions for
the Safe Transport of Dangerous Goods" (latest edition).

The PIC must be familiar with the general philosophy of the regulations, limitations on dangerous
goods, the marking and labeling requirements, loading procedures and compatibility, the Special
Load, Notification to Captain (NOTOC), and emergency procedures, including reporting of
dangerous goods incidents or accidents.

9.1.2 Definition of Dangerous Goods

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Dangerous Goods are articles or substances which are capable of posing a hazard to health, safety,
property and/or the environment and which are shown in the list of dangerous goods in these
Regulations or which are classified according; to these regulations (IATA Dangerous Goods
Regulations).

9.2 EGYPTAIR'S POLICY OF CARRIAGE DANGEROUS GOODS

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
EGYPTAIR has declared the policy of carrying dangerous goods as flows:

The transport of dangerous goods must be performed according to the ICAO Technical
Instructions for the Safe Transport of Dangerous Goods by Air (DOC 9284-AN/905) and
IATA-Dangerous Goods Regulations;
EGYPTAIR ensures that no person offers or deals with dangerous goods for transport by air
unless the person has been trained and the goods are properly classified, documented,
certificated, described, packaged, marked, labeled and in a fit condition for transport as
required by IATA-Dangerous Goods Regulations.
9.2.1 Carrying Dangerous Goods with Passengers or Crew

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
According to IATA Dangerous Goods Regulations, dangerous goods must not be carried by
passengers or crew except the items shown in Chapter 9.8.6 Provisions for Dangerous Goods
Carried by Passenger or Crew (Table 2.3.A):

EGYPTAIR should have information on those dangerous goods which may be carried by
passengers in accordance with DGR 2.3.2 to 2.3.5 available prior to the check-in process on their
websites or other sources of information.

9.2.2 Carrying Dangerous Goods as a Cargo Shipment

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
EGYPTAIR accepts Shipping of Dangerous Goods according to the requirements of ECAR 175 and
ICAO/IATA Regulations.

9.2.3 EGYPTAIR Compliance

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
EGYPTAIR must comply with the following (Ref. DGR 2.8.3 operator Variation (MS)):

MS-01
The transport of dangerous goods on board EGYPTAIR NETWORK must comply with IATA DGR
current edition.
MS-02
Additional information is required as the following:
The name, address and telephone number of the shipper/consignee must be written in full
on the Air Waybill, Shipper Declaration and on the package(s);
The shipper must provide a 24-hour emergency telephone number of a person who is
knowledgeable of the hazards, characteristics and actions to be taken in case of an accident
or incident concerning each of the dangerous goods being transported. This telephone
number, including the country and area code, preceded by the words “Emergency Contact
24-hour number” must be inserted on the Shipper Declaration for Dangerous Goods in the
“Additional Handling Information” box. This must be applied to all dangerous goods
shipments to, from or transiting through Egypt. The number must be monitored by a person
who:
Speaks English fluently;
Is knowledgeable of the hazard(s) and characteristics of the dangerous goods being
transported;
Has comprehensive emergency response and accident mitigation information for the
dangerous goods; or
Has immediate access to a person who possesses such knowledge and information.
MS-03
The shipper/agent must provide the Martial Safety Data Sheet, which must include the transport
information, or a declaration on company letterhead confirming the classification and ASSUMING
FULL LIABILITY (see DGR 8.0.1 and DGR 8.3).
MS-04 Advance arrangements and Reservation must be made for all shipments of dangerous goods as
defined in these Regulations (see DGR 1.3.2 and DGR 9.1.2).
MS-05
Dangerous goods consignments must be delivered early enough to allow sufficient time for the
completion of the acceptance checks and document preparation. Shippers/Agents should contact
Egyptair Acceptance Office to confirm the cut-off time.
MS-06
For Interline transfer of dangerous goods, a copy of the acceptance checklist accompanies the
consignment together with the DGD and the AWB is required.
MS-07 Dangerous goods as defined in these Regulations will not be accepted by post.
MS-08
Dangerous goods in excepted quantities originating in Egypt will be accepted as dangerous goods,
according to the IATA Dangerous Goods Regulations. This provision does not apply to radioactive
materials in excepted packages.
MS-09 Infected animals, dead or alive, will not be accepted on board EGYPTAIR network.
MS-10
Infectious Substances Div. 6.2 are prohibited from carriage as cargo unless approved by Egyptian
Ministry of Health and Egyptian Civil Aviation Authority.

9.2.4 Carrying of Weapons, Munitions of War and Sporting Weapons

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
For the transport of weapons of war or munitions of war and radioactive materials
permission must be granted by the ECAA;
a. Weapons of war or munitions of war must be stowed in the aeroplane in a place which
is inaccessible to passengers during the flight.
Exceptions may be granted by all States concerned before the commencement of the
flight that such weapons of war or munitions of war may be carried in circumstances
that differ in part or in total from the procedures mentioned in this paragraph above.
Passengers and Crew Members are not permitted to carry firearms in the cabin or on the
flight deck;
Eyptian police officers on escort duty shall hand over their unloaded weapons to a Crew
Member to be stored for the duration of the flight, on the flight deck. The ammunition shall
be carried by the in flight security officer.
Upon arrival, weapons and ammunitions shall be handed to police authorities who in turn
with return them to foreign escorts;
In case of foreign police on escort duty, the following shall apply:
At departure weapons and ammunition should be placed in aircraft holds.
At arrival EGYPTAIR Security will hand over weapons to police authorities who in turn will
return them to foreign escorts.
The operator has to take all reasonable measures to ensure that it will be notified about any
intended transportation of sports weapons or ammunition on one of the aeroplanes;
Sports rifles, shotguns and pistols belonging to accompanying passengers for their own
use, and any other kind of small arms may not be carried aboard the aeroplane except as
checked baggage stowed in one of the belly compartments, unloaded and suitably
packed.
When the company accepts the carrying of sports weapons, the company shall ensure
that they are:
a. Stowed in the aeroplane in a place which is inaccessible to passengers during the
flight unless the Authority has determined that compliance is impracticable and has
accepted that other procedures might apply;
b. Unloaded, in the case of firearms or other weapons that can contain ammunition.
Securely packed ammunition in Division 1.4S may be carried in quantities not exceeding 5
kg gross weight per person for that own person's use, excluding ammunition with
explosive or incendiary projectiles.
Allowance for inure than one passenger must not be combined into one or more
packages.
Before the flight the Commander must be notified by the ground handling staff of details of
weapons or ammunition intended to be carried on board, including its location;
Electro Shock Weapons (e.g., tasers) and/or dangerous goods such as explosives, etc., are
forbidden in carry-on baggage or checked baggage or on the person according to Chapter
9.8.6 Provisions for Dangerous Goods Carried by Passenger or Crew (Table 2.3.A).

9.3.1 Shipper's Responsibilities

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
9.3.1.1 Compliance

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A shipper must fully comply with these regulations when offering a consignment of
dangerous goods to any IATA Member and/or associate Member airlines, and to airlines
participating in IATA interline agreements for cargo. In addition, shippers must comply with
any applicable regulations set forth by the States of origin, transit and destination;
It is the shipper's responsibility to ensure that all of the applicable air transport
requirements are met.
9.3.1.2 Specific Responsibilities

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
Before any package or over pack of dangerous goods is offered for air transport, the
shipper must comply with the following specific responsibilities:
A shipper must provide such information to his employees, as this will enable them to
carry out their responsibilities with regards to the transport of dangerous goods by air;
The shipper must ensure that the articles or substances are not prohibited for transport
by air;
The articles or substances must be properly identified, classified, packed, marked,
labeled, documented and in the suitable condition for transport in accordance with IATA
DGR;
Before a consignment of dangerous goods is offered for air transport, all relevant
persons involved in its preparation must have received training to enable them to carry
out their responsibilities, as detailed in DGR Subsection 1.5.
Where a shipper does not have trained staff, the “relevant persons” may be interpreted
as applying to those employed to act on the shipper's behalf and undertake the
shipper's responsibilities in the preparation of the consignment. However, such persons
must be trained as required by DGR Subsection 1.5;
The dangerous goods are packaged in compliance with all applicable air transport
requirements including:
Inner packaging and the maximum quantity per package limits;
Appropriate types of packaging according to the packing instructions;
Other applicable requirements indicated in the packing instructions include:
Single packaging may be forbidden;
Only inner and outer packaging indicated in the packing instructions are
permitted;
Inner packaging may need to be packed in intermediate packaging;

9.3.1.3 Dangerous Goods in Consolidations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Dangerous Goods are accepted in consolidations under the conditions specified in the following:

Dangerous goods may be consolidated with goods not subject to these Regulations.
Dangerous goods in consolidations are subject to the acceptance check described in
Chapter. Any delays caused by discrepancies found during the check may result in a delay
in the complete consolidation;
Dangerous goods in consolidations must be identified, classified, packed, marked, labelled
and documented in accordance with these Regulations and be free from any indication of
damage or leakage;
Packages and over packs containing dangerous goods must be offered to the operator
separately from the goods in the consolidation that are not subject to these Regulations.
Dangerous goods in consolidations are not acceptable in unit load devices, unless
specifically permitted by these Regulations (see DGR 9.1.4.1);
A Shipper's Declaration for Dangerous Goods is required for each component consignment;
Consolidations containing any “Cargo Aircraft only” dangerous goods must be shipped on
Cargo Aircraft;
Before a consignment is offered to an operator for transport, the shipper, the freight
forwarder and the cargo agent must:
Ensure that the dangerous goods are in full compliance with the DGR;
Segregate dangerous goods contained in a consolidation from goods which are not
subject to the DGR, and offer them separately;
Ensure that the dangerous goods are not loaded in a unit load device other than those
permitted under DGR 9.1.4.1;
For all consignments, check documents and the exterior of packages for indication of
hidden hazards.

9.3.2.3 Provision of Information to Passengers

EGYPTAIR ensures that information as to the types of dangerous goods which a passenger is
forbidden from transporting aboard an aircraft is presented at the point of ticket purchase or, if
this is not practical, made available in another manner to passengers before the check-in process.
Information provided via the Internet may be in text or pictorial form but must be such that ticket
purchase cannot be completed until he passenger, or a person acting on their behalf, has been
presented with this information, and indicated that they have understood the restrictions on
dangerous goods in baggage.

EGYPTAIR or EGYPTAIR’s handling agent and the airport operator must ensure that notices
warning passengers as to the type of dangerous goods which are forbidden for transport aboard
an aircraft are available and:

Must be prominently displayed in sufficient number at each of the places at an airport:
Where tickets are issued;
Where passengers check-in;
In aircraft boarding areas.
Prominently displayed at any other location where passengers are checked in; and
Should be prominently displayed in sufficient numbers in baggage claim areas.
These notices must include visual examples of dangerous goods forbidden from transport aboard
an aircraft.

When provision is made for the check-in process to be completed remotely (e.g. via the Internet),
EGYPTAIR must ensure that information on the types of dangerous goods which a passenger is
forbidden to transport aboard an aircraft is presented to passengers.

Information may be in text or pictorial form but must be such that the check-in process cannot be
completed until the passenger, or a person acting on their behalf, has been presented with this
information, and indicated that they have understood the restrictions on dangerous goods in
baggage.

Any organization or enterprise other than EGYPTAIR (such as a travel agent) involved in the air
transport of passengers, should provide passengers with information about the types of
dangerous goods which are forbidden from transporting aboard an aircraft.

This information should consist as a minimum of notices at those locations where there is an
interface with the passengers.

9.4 TRAINING OF CREW MEMBERS AND GROUND STAFF FOR

HANDLING DANGEROUS GOODS
Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
Personnel must receive training in the requirements commensurate with their responsibilities
according to IATA Dangerous Goods Regulations.

9.4.1 General

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
The goal of competency-based training and assessment is to produce a competent workforce by
providing focused training. Training concentrates on functions and responsibilities rather than a
job title or description ensuring, that personnel is competent to perform its duties.

Competency factors are described as:

Knowledge
is the theoretical information of a subject that enables a person to understand the concepts
and principles.
Skills
Are the abilities to perform an activity or action, which can be developed through the
process of acquiring knowledge and continuous practice.
Attitude
is a persistent internal mental state that influences an individual's choice of action, such as
the level of commitment.
Level of proficiency is considered to be as follows:

Introductory ():*

Simple work activities, most of it routine and predictable. Guidance is required. The final product is
highly supervised.

Basic ():**

Various work activities, various contexts. The individual has some responsibility or autonomy and
there is limited guidance needed. Spot check results are reviewed for quality but not in detail.

Intermediate ():*

Broad range of activities, complex and non-routine context. High confidence in results, work tested
against broader business context. Significant personal autonomy. Team authority in some areas
(e.g. supervisor).

Advanced (****):

Broad range of work. Complex technical and professional activities in a wide variety of contexts.
From substantial to wide scope for personal autonomy. Regional and divisional authority in some
areas. Regarded as a consultant in some areas.
