Amplified Cabin Crew Checklist for Dangerous Goods Incidents in the Passenger Cabin during
Flight
INITIAL ACTION
NOTIFY PIC
Any incident concerning dangerous goods should be notified immediately to the PIC who should be kept
informed of all actions taken and of their effect. It is essential that the Cabin Crew and the Flight Deck Crew co-
ordinate their actions and that each be kept fully informed of the other’s actions and intentions:
IDENTIFY THE ITEM
Ask the passenger concerned to identify the item and indicate its potential hazards. The passenger may be able
to give some guidance on the hazard(s) involved and how these could be dealt with. If the passenger can
identify the item (to Section 4 for the appropriate emergency response drill in ICAO Emergency Response
Guidance). On aircraft with only one Cabin Crew Member, consult with the PIC as to whether the aid of a
passenger should be sought in dealing with the incident.
IN CASE OF FIRE
USE STANDARD PROCEDURE/CHECK USE OF WATER
Standard emergency procedures must be used to deal with any fire. In general, water should not be used on a
spillage or when fumes are present since it may spread the spillage or increase the rate of fuming.
Consideration should also be given to the possible presence of electrical components when using water
extinguishers.
IN CASE OF SPILLAGE OR LEAKAGE
COLLECT EMERGENCY RESPONSE KIT OR OTHER USEFUL ITEMS
DANGEROUS GOODS AND WEAPONS
9.18 Dangerous Goods Emergency Response
OM A
9-18-4

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Collect emergency response kit, if provided, or collect for use in dealing with the spillage or leak age:
A supply of paper towels or newspapers or other absorbent paper or absorbent fabric (e.g. seat cushion
covers, head rest protectors);
Oven gloves or fire-resistant gloves, if available;
At least two large polyethylene waste bin bags; and
At least three smaller polyethylene bags, such as those used for duty-free or bar sales or, if none
available, airsickness bags.
DON RUBBER GLOVES AND SMOKE HOOD OR SMOKE MASK PORTABLE OXYGEN
The hands should always be protected before touching suspicious packages or items. Fire-resistant gloves or
oven gloves covered by polyethylene bags are likely to give suitable protection. Gas-tight breathing equipment
should always be worn when attending to an incident involving fire, fumes or smoke.
MOVE PASSENGERS AWAY FROM AREA
The use of therapeutic masks with portable oxygen bottles or the passenger dropout oxygen system to assist
passengers in a smoke- or fume-filled passenger cabin should not be considered since considerable quantities
of fumes or smoke would be inhaled through the valves or holes in the masks. A more effective aid to
passengers in a smoke- or fume-filled environment would be the use of a wet towel or cloth held over the
mouth and nose. A wet towel or cloth aids in filtering and is more effective at doing this than a dry towel or
cloth. Cabin Crew should take prompt action if smoke or fumes develop and move passengers away from the
area involved and, if necessary, provide wet towels or cloths and give instructions to breathe through them.
PLACE DANGEROUS GOODS ITEMS IN POLYETHYLENE BAGS
NOTE:
In the case of a spill of known or suspected dangerous goods in powder form:
Leave everything undisturbed;
Do not use fire agent or water;
Cover area with polyethylene or other plastic bags and blankets;
Keep area isolated until after landing.
With emergency response kit
If it is absolutely certain that the item will not create a problem the decision may be made not to move it. In
most circumstances, however, it will be better to move the item and this should be done as suggested below.
Place the item in a polyethylene bag as follows:
Prepare two bags by rolling up the sides and placing them on the floor;
Place the item inside the first bag with the closure of the item, or the point from which it is leaking from
its container, at the top;
Take-off the rubber gloves whilst avoiding skin contact with any contamination on them;
Place the rubber gloves in the second bag;
Close the first bag whilst squeezing out the excess air;
Twist the open end of the first bag and use a bag tie to tie it sufficiently tight to be secure but not so
tight that pressure equalization cannot take place;
Place the first bag (containing the item) in the second bag, which already contains the rubber gloves
and secure the open end in the same manner as that used for the first bag.
With no emergency response kit
Pick up the item and place it in a polyethylene bag. Ensure the receptacle containing the dangerous goods is
kept upright or the area of leakage is at the top. Using paper towels, newspaper, etc., mop up the spillage, after
having ascertained there will be no reaction between what is to be used to mop up and the dangerous goods.
Place the soiled towels, etc., in another polyethylene bag. Place the gloves and bags used to protect the hands
either in a separate small polyethylene bag or with the soiled towels. If extra bags are not available, place the
towels, gloves, etc., in the same bag as the item. Expel excess air from the bags and close tightly so as to be
secure but not so fight that pressure equalization cannot take place.

9-18-5
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
STOW POLYETHYLENE BAGS
If there is a catering or bar box on board, empty any contents and place the box on the floor, with the door
upward. Place the bag(s) containing the item and any soiled towels, etc., in the box and close the door. Take the
box or, if there is no box, the bag(s) to a position as far away as possible from the flight deck and passengers. If
a galley or toilet is fitted, consider taking the box or bag(s) there, unless it is close to the flight deck. Use a rear
galley or toilet wherever possible, but do not place the box or bag(s) against the pressure bulkhead or fuselage
wall. If a galley is used, the box or bag(s) can be stowed in an empty waste bin container. If a toilet is used, the
box can be placed on the floor or the bag(s) stowed in an empty waste container. The toilet door should be
locked from the outside. In a pressurized aircraft, if a toilet is used, any fumes will be vented away from
passengers. However, if the aircraft is unpressurized, there may not be positive pressure in a toilet to prevent
fumes from entering the passenger cabin. Ensure when moving a box that the opening is kept upward or when
moving a bag that either receptacle containing the dangerous goods is kept upright or the area of leakage is
kept at the top. Wherever the box or bag(s) have been located, wedge them firmly in place to prevent them
from moving and to keep the item upright. Ensure that the position of the box or bags will not impede
disembarkation from the aircraft.
TREAT AFFECTED SEAT CUSHIONS/COVERS IN THE SAME MANNER AS DANGEROUS GOODS ITEMS
Seat cushions, seat backs or other furnishings which have been contaminated by a spillage should be removed
from their fixtures and placed in a large bin bag or other polyethylene bag, together with any bags used initially
to cover them. They should be stowed away in the same manner as the dangerous goods item causing the
incident.
COVER SPILLAGE ON CARPET/FLOOR
Cover any spillage on the carpet or furnishings with a waste bag or other polyethylene bags, if available. If not,
use airsickness bags opened out so that the plastic side covers the spillage or use the plastic-covered
emergency information cards. Carpet which has been contaminated by a spillage and which is still causing
fumes despite being covered, should be rolled up, if possible, and placed in a large bin bag or other
polyethylene bag. It should be placed in a waste bin and stowed, when possible, either in the rear toilet or rear
galley. If the carpet cannot be removed it should remain covered by a large bin bag or polyethylene bags, etc.,
and additional bags should be used to reduce the fumes.
REGULARLY INSPECT ITEMS STOWED AWAY/CONTAMINATED FURNISHINGS
Any dangerous goods, contaminated furnishings or equipment which have been removed and stowed away or
covered for safety should be subject to regular inspection.
AFTER LANDING
IDENTIFY TO GROUND PERSONNEL DANGEROUS GOODS ITEM AND WHERE STOWED
Upon arrival, take the necessary steps to identify to the ground staff where the item is stowed. Pass on all
information about the item.
MAKE APPROPRIATE ENTRY IN MAINTENANCE LOG
Make an entry in the aircraft maintenance log so that proper maintenance action is undertaken and that the
emergency response kit or any aircraft equipment used is replenished or replaced when appropriate.
9.18.3 Dangerous Goods in the Under Floor Cargo Compartments

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Dangerous goods may be carried as cargo in the under floor cargo compartments. Spillages or
leakages are unlikely to be detected during flight unless they cause noticeable fumes in the
passenger cabin or on the flight deck. In the event of leakage, the air in the passenger cabin and
on the flight deck may have become flammable, irritating or toxic. Non-essential electrics should
be turned OFF and smoking should be prohibited. Also, the crew should use full face masks, (100
per cent oxygen) or smoke hoods. Wherever possible, the passengers should be provided with wet
towels or cloths for use over the nose and mouth.

DANGEROUS GOODS AND WEAPONS
9.18 Dangerous Goods Emergency Response
OM A
9-18-6

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Smoke or fire in an under floor cargo compartment may not have originated from any dangerous
goods loaded in that compartment. Such goods, however, may be affected by any fire. Standard
aircraft emergency procedures should always be followed to deal with the smoke or fire.

In some aircraft there is access from inside the aircraft to under floor Class D cargo compartments.
In general, even if access is possible, an entry should not be made since this will allow air to enter
the compartment, which may cause a worsening of the situation.

If an incident has arisen in an under floor cargo compartment, the passengers and crew should be
evacuated from the aircraft before any attempt is made to open the cargo compartment doors.
The cargo compartment doors should be opened with the emergency services in attendance.

9.18.4 Dangerous Goods on Cargo Aircraft

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Dangerous goods may be carried on cargo aircraft in either the under floor cargo compartments
or on the main deck.

Incidents in an Under Floor Cargo Compartment.

See Chapter 9.18.3 Dangerous Goods in the Under Floor Cargo Compartments.

Incidents in the Main Deck Cargo Compartment. Dangerous goods carried on the main deck of
a cargo aircraft fall into two broad categories; those which are required to be accessible (the full
requirements for accessibility are set out in the Technical Instructions, Part 5, Chapter 2 in ICAO
Emergency Response Guidance) and those which are not, but which may still be cargo aircraft only
(CAO) goods or quantities. Dangerous goods required to be accessible must be loaded so that
they can be seen, handled and, where size and mass permit, separated from other cargo. However,
other dangerous goods on the main deck may, depending on circumstances [position on main
deck, types of unit load devices (ULDs) used, etc.], be completely inaccessible. In the event of an
incident occurring involving these dangerous goods, an assessment will have to be made of the
practicality of attempting direct physical intervention. In any event, both for accessible and non-
accessible dangerous goods, standard aircraft emergency procedures should always be followed.

An attempt should be made to establish the cause of an incident occurring on the main deck. The
following actions can be considered:

Attempt to locate the source of the incident and identify whether there are fumes or smoke
or evidence of spillage or leakage;
Follow the appropriate aircraft emergency procedures for fire or for smoke removal if fumes
or smoke are present;
Identify the dangerous goods involved and use the notification to PIC (see Technical
Instructions, Part 5, Chapter 4 in ICAO Emergency Response Guidance) to confirm the name
and/or UN number of the goods;
After establishing the identity of the dangerous goods, refer to Section 4 and from either
the alphabetical or numerical list of dangerous goods note the drill assigned to the
particular item;
To the chart in Section 4 and use the guidance in ICAO Emergency Response Guidance that
given against the appropriate emergency response drill to deal with the incident (see
Chapter 9.18.6 Aircraft Emergency Response Drills ).

Checklists for Dangerous Goods Incidents
Follow the appropriate aircraft emergency procedures for fire or smoke removal;
NO SMOKING sign ON;
Consider landing as soon as possible;
Consider turning off non-essential electrical power;
Determine source of smoke/ fumes/ fire;
For dangerous goods incidents in the passenger cabin, see Cabin Crew checklist; and
Coordinate Flight Deck Crew/Cabin Crew actions;
Determine emergency response drill code;
Use guidance from aircraft emergency response drills chart to help deal with incident;
If the situation permits, notify ATC of the dangerous goods being carried.
AFTER LANDING
Disembark passengers and crew before opening any cargo compartment doors;
Inform ground personnel/ emergency services of nature of item and where stowed;
Make appropriate entry in maintenance log.
Amplified Checklist for Dangerous Goods Incidents - Follow Appropriate Aeroplane Emergency
Procedures for Fire or Smoke Removal
Self explanatory
NO SMOKING ON
A smoking ban should be introduced when fumes or vapours are present and be continued for the remainder of
the flight.
CONSIDER LANDING AS SOON AS POSSIBLE
Because of the difficulties and possibly disastrous consequences of any dangerous goods incident,
consideration should be given to landing as soon as possible. The decision to land at the nearest suitable
aerodrome should be made early rather than late, when an incident may have developed to a very critical point,
severely restricting operational flexibility.
CONSIDER TURNING OFF NON-ESSENTIAL ELECTRONIC POWER
As the incident may be caused by electrical problems or as electrical systems may be affected by any incident,
and particularly as fire-fighting activities, etc., may damage electric systems, turn off all non-essential electrical
items. Retain power only to those instruments, systems and controls necessary for the continued safety of the
aircraft. Do not restore power until it is positively safe to do so.
DETERMINE SOURCE OF SMOKE/FUMES/FIRE
The source of any smoke/ fumes/ fire may be difficult to determine. Effective fire fighting or containment
procedures can best be accomplished when the source of the incident is identified.
FOR DANGEROUS GOODS INCIDENTS IN THE PASSENGER CABIN
Incidents in the passenger cabin should be dealt with by the Cabin Crew using the appropriate checklist and
procedures. It is essential that the Cabin Crew and the Flight Deck Crew coordinate their actions and that each
be kept fully informed of the other's actions and intentions.
DANGEROUS GOODS AND WEAPONS
9.18 Dangerous Goods Emergency Response
OM A
9-18-8

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
DETERMINE EMERGENCY RESPONSE DRILL CODE
When the item has been identified, the corresponding entry on the PIC's dangerous goods notification form
should be found. The applicable emergency response drill code may be given on the notification form, or if not
given, can be found by noting the proper shipping name or the UN number on the notification form and using
the alphabetical or numerical list of dangerous goods. If the item causing the incident is not listed on the
notification form, an attempt should be made to determine the name or the nature of the substance. The
alphabetical list can then be used to determine the emergency response drill code.
NOTE
The alphabetical and numerical lists referred to are those in Section 4 of this document.
USE GUIDANCE FROM AEROPLANE EMERGENCY RESPONSE DRILLS CHART TO HELP DEAL WITH
INCIDENT
The drill code assigned to an item of dangerous goods consists of a number from 1 to 10, plus a single letter.
Referring to the chart of emergency response drills, each drill number corresponds to a line of information
concerning the risk posed by that substance and guidance on the preferable action that should be taken. The
drill letter is shown separately on the drill chart; it indicates other possible hazards of the substance. In some
cases the guidance given by the drill number may be further refined by the information given by the drill letter.
IF TIME AVAILABLE, NOTIFY ATC OF AT LEAST UN NUMBER OF ANY DANGEROUS GOODS BEING
CARRIED
If an in-flight emergency occurs, the PIC should inform the appropriate air traffic services unit, for the
information of aerodrome authorities, of any dangerous goods on board. If the situation permits, the
information should include the proper shipping names, class and subsidiary hazard for which labels are
required, the compatibility group for Class 1 and the quantity and location aboard the aircraft of the dangerous
goods. If a lengthy message is impossible, identify the dangerous goods on board by transmitting the UN
numbers (Annex 18, 9.5).
AFTER LANDING
DISEMBARK PASSENGERS AND CREW BEFORE OPENING ANY CARGO COMPARTMENT DOORS
Even if it has not been necessary to complete an emergency evacuation after landing, passengers and crew
should disembark before any attempt is made to open the cargo compartment doors and before any further
action is taken to deal with a dangerous goods incident. The cargo compartment doors should be opened with
the emergency services in attendance.
INFORM GROUND PERSONNEL/EMERGENCY SERVICES OF NATURE OF ITEM AND WHERE STOWED
Upon arrival, take the necessary steps to identify to the ground staff where the item is stowed. Pass on by the
quickest available means all information about the item including, when appropriate, copy of the notification to
PIC.
MAKE APPROPRIATE ENTRY IN MAINTENANCE LOG
An entry should be made in the maintenance log that a check needs to be carried out to ensure that any
leakage or spillage of dangerous goods has not damaged the aircraft structure or systems and that some
aircraft equipment (e.g. fire extinguishers, emergency response kit, etc.) may need replenishing or replacing.

9.19 REPORTING OF INCIDENTS AND ACCIDENTS

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
9.19.1 General

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The operator must report dangerous goods incidents and accidents to the appropriate authorities
of the State of the operator and the State in which the accident or incident occurred, in accordance
with the reporting requirements of those appropriate authorities. (DGR 9.6.1).

For example of an accident and incident reporting form, see Chapter 9.19.3 Reporting of
Undeclared or Miss-declared Dangerous Goods.

NOTE This includes incidents involving dangerous goods that are not subject to all or part of
DGR Regulations through the application of an exception or of a special provision (for
example, an incident involving the short circuiting of a dry cell battery that is required
to meet short circuit prevention conditions in a special provision of DGR 4.4).
9.19.2 Incidents and Accidents

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A dangerous goods accident is defined as an occurrence associated with and related to the
transport of dangerous goods by air which results in fatal or serious injury to a person or major
property or environmental damage (See DGR Appendix A under "Dangerous Goods Accident").

A dangerous goods incident is an occurrence other than a dangerous goods accident associated
with and related to the transport of dangerous goods by air, not necessarily occurring on board an
aircraft, which results in injury to a person, property or environmental damage, fire, breakage, spill-
age, leakage of fluid or radiation or other evidence that the integrity of the packaging has not
been maintained. Any occurrence relating to the transport of dangerous goods which seriously
Jeopardizes an aircraft or its occupants is also deemed to be a dangerous goods incident. (A
dangerous goods accident or incident may also constitute an aircraft accident or incident as
specified in Annex 13 to the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation-Aircraft Accident
Investigation.) (See DGR Appendix A under "Dangerous Goods Incident").

9.19.3 Reporting of Undeclared or Miss-declared Dangerous Goods

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
An operator must report any occasion when undeclared or miss-declared dangerous goods are
discovered in cargo. Such a report must be made to the appropriate authorities of the State of the
operator and the State in which this occurred. An operator must also report any occasion when
dangerous goods not permitted under DGR 2.3 are discovered in passengers' baggage. Such a
report must be made to the appropriate Authority of the State in which this occurred. (DGR 9.6.2).

9.20 NUMERICAL LIST OF DANGEROUS GOODS WITH DRILL CODES

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
9.20.1 Introduction

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The list of proper shipping names used for dangerous goods, arranged in numerical order of the
associated UN identification number, is shown in 9.20.2 List of Dangerous Goods. For each entry
a drill code is shown and this should be used to find the appropriate drill on the chart of Aircraft
Emergency Response Drills.

In a few cases, besides the UN number, the class or division, the packing group or the subsidiary
hazard must also be used to identify the correct drill code where this is necessary, the possible
classes or divisions, packing groups or subsidiary risks are given below the UN number and the
relevant drill code can be selected. These additional details are shown on the PIC’s notification
form.

Where alternative proper shipping names can be used with the same UN number these are all
shown separated by oblique lines. Those dangerous goods which have not yet been allocated a
UN identification number are listed first.

NOTE In case the Alphabetical List of Dangerous Goods with drill codes and the Numerical
List of Dangerous Goods with drill codes (UN or ID No.) mentioned in Numerical Cross
Reference List of Dangerous goods is not found in OM Part A, the Captain shall ask for
a copy from the updated IATA reference from the handling agent or the station
manager;
All Dangerous Goods carried on board aeroplanes shall be accompanied with:
NOTOC’s
And copies of:
Emergency Response Drill Code;
Updated IATA Reference of (UN or ID No.) mentioned in Numerical Cross Reference
List of Dangerous goods.
By the handling agent or the station manager.

10.1 DEFINITIONS

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24 (A)
Act of Unlawful Interference Any act or attempted act that may jeopardize the security of
civil aviation, including, but not limited to:
Unlawful seizure of an aircraft;
Destruction of an aircraft in service;
Hostage-taking on board an aircraft or at an airport;
Forcible intrusion on board an aircraft, at an airport or on
the premises of a related civil aviation facility;
Introduction on board an aircraft or at an airport of a
weapon, a hazardous device or material intended for
criminal purposes;
Use of an aircraft in service for the purpose of causing
death, serious bodily injury, or serious damage to
property or the environment;
Communication of false information that jeopardizes the
safety of an aircraft in flight or on the ground, or the
safety of passengers, crew, ground personnel or the
general public at an airport or on the premises of a
related civil aviation facility;
Any other actions not mentioned above that affect the
security and safety of civil aviation.
Aircraft Security Check An inspection of the interior of an aircraft to which passengers
may have had access and an inspection of the hold for the
purposes of discovering suspicious objects, weapons, explosives
or other dangerous devices, articles and substances.
Aircraft Security Search A thorough inspection of the interior and exterior of the aircraft
for the purpose of discovering suspicious objects, weapons,
explosives or other dangerous devices, articles or substances.
Baggage Reconciliation A security process that matches a passenger with his or her
checked baggage and ensures the passenger and baggage
travel together on the same aircraft as accompanied baggage,
or in different flights if the unaccompanied baggage is properly
identified, screened to the appropriate standard and accepted
for carriage by the operator.
Bomb Threat A communicated threat, anonymous or otherwise, which
suggests, or infers, whether true or false that the safety of an
aeroplane in-flight or on ground, or any airport or civil aviation
facility or any person may be in danger from an explosive or
other item or device.
SECURITY
10.1 Definitions
OM A
10-1-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Cyber Hazards A potential unwanted state of a system, data, or information
resulting from failures, malfunctions, errors, natural events, or a
combination thereof.
Cyber Risk Potential for an unwanted outcome resulting from a cyber
incident, event, or occurrence. Risk can be estimated by
considering the likelihood of threats, hazards, vulnerabilities
and consequences or impacts.
Cyber Threat A potential cyber incident on an asset, with the possibility to
cause harm to life, assets, operations, the environment and/or
property.
Cyber-Attack The intentional use of electronic means to interrupt, alter,
destroy, or gain unauthorized access or control, to information
or assets.
Cyber-Incident Single or series of unauthorized, unlawful or unexpected cyber
event(s) that jeopardize(s), or is reasonably likely to jeopardize,
the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of critical assets and
have the potential to adversely impact aviation safety and/or
security.
Cybersecurity The body of technologies, controls and measures, and
processes and practices designed to ensure confidentiality,
integrity, availability and overall protection of systems,
networks, programs, devices, information and data from attack,
damage, unauthorized access, use and/or exploitation.
Disruptive / Unruly Passenger A passenger who fails to respect the rules of conduct at an
airport or on board an aircraft or to follow the instructions of
the airport staff or crew members and thereby disturbs the
good order and discipline at an airport or on board the aircraft.
High-risk Cargo or Mail Cargo or mail which is deemed to pose a threat to civil aviation
as a result of specific intelligence; or shows anomalies or signs
of tampering which give rise to suspicion.
In-flight Security Officer (IFSO) A person who is employed and trained by EGYPTAIR, the
government of the State of the Operator or by the government
of the State of registration to be deployed on an aircraft with
the purpose of protecting that aircraft and its occupants against
acts of unlawful interference. This excludes persons employed
to provide exclusive personal protection for one or more
specific people travelling on the aircraft, such as personal
bodyguards.
SECURITY
10.1 Definitions
OM A
10-1-3
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Permits Cards or other documentation issued to individual persons
employed on airports or who otherwise have need for
authorised access to airports or to any part(s) thereof, for the
purposes of facilitating access and identifying the individual and
includes vehicle documentation issued for similar purposes.
Permits are sometimes referred to as airport identity cards or
passes.
Sabotage An act or omission, intended to cause malicious or wanton
destruction of property, endangering or resulting in unlawful
interference with international civil aviation and its facilities.
Security Control A means by which the introduction of weapons, explosives or
other dangerous devices which may be utilised to commit an
act of unlawful interference can be prevented.
Security Culture A set of security-related norms, values, attitudes and
assumptions that are inherent in the daily operation of an
organization and are reflected by the actions and behaviours of
all entities and personnel within the organization.
Security Equipment Devices of a specialised nature for use, individually or as part of
a system, in the prevention or detection of acts of unlawful
interference with civil aviation and its facilities.
Security Program A program consisting of requirements and/or standards
adopted for the purpose of safeguarding international civil
aviation against acts of unlawful interference.
The Security Program of an operator is compliant with the
requirements of civil aviation security authorities in the State of
the Operator and states where operations are conducted.
The security program of a ground services provider is compliant
with the security program of its customer airline(s) and
requirements of civil aviation security authorities in states where
operations are conducted.
Supplementary Station
Procedures
Supplementary Station Procedures (SSP, a new concept recently
introduced in ICAO Amendment 18 to Annex 17) are designed
to be country-specific security procedures that are not already
incorporated in the main AOSP in order to operate into third
country. In such a scenario, the operator will typically have an
AOSP approved by its state of registry and a number of SSPs
approved by third country regulators.
Unpredictability Means the implementation of security measures in order to
increase their deterrent effect and their efficiency, by applying
them at irregular frequencies, different locations and/or with
varying means, in accordance with a defined framework.

10.2 GENERAL PREFERENCES AND PROCEDURES

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
10.2.1 General

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Security is defined as combination of measures and human and material resources intended to
assure the protection and safety of passengers, crew, ground personnel, the general public, aircraft
and facilities of an airport serving civil aviation, against acts of unlawful interference perpetrated
on the ground or in flight.

This chapter is intended to provide crews with information relevant to security measures on board
EGYPTAIR aircraft. It must be stressed that constant vigilance with respect to security is necessary
by all Flight and Cabin Crew Members.

Crew shall take all reasonable measures to ensure that no person secretes himself or secretes
cargo on board an aircraft.

Regulations pertaining to security on ground and procedures for ground staff for handling an
emergency including sabotage, bomb threat, hijacking, and unlawful interference are laid down in
the EGYPTAIR SECURITY PROGRAM.

NOTE The Company Contingency Plan is included in EGYPTAIR SECURITY PROGRAM “SP”.
NOTE The IFSOs are directly involved in the implementation of the Security Program /
Supplementary Station Procedures “SSPs” and security measures on all EGYPTAIR
passenger aircraft and cargo aircraft.
10.2.2 Authority of the Commander

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The Commander of an aircraft has the ultimate authority over crew, passengers, aircraft and load.

He may, when he has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has committed or is about to
commit any offence on board the aircraft and that may jeopardies the:

Safety and Security of the aircraft or of persons or property therein;
Good order and discipline on board.
Take all reasonable measures to:

Protect the safety and security of the aircraft;
Protect persons or property on board;
Maintain good order and discipline on board;
Disembark or deliver disruptive, unruly or violent passengers to local Authorities.
The Commander is empowered to take any steps he deems necessary to ensure the continued safe
and secure operation of the aircraft.

This may result in refusal of service, or even physical restraint or an en-route diversion in order to
off-load disruptive, unruly or violent passengers.

See 10.2.10 Disruptive/Unruly Passengers.

SECURITY
10.2 General Preferences and Procedures
OM A
10-2-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
10.2.3 Crime on Board

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
If a crime is committed on board between "doors closed" and "doors opened", the Commander is
responsible for ensuring that action is taken to protect lives, the aircraft and cargo and to
safeguard any available evidence.

In urgent cases, the Commander may arrange a preliminary inquiry until official personnel take
control. Should he consider it necessary, and with the agreement of the owner of the property, the
Commander may instigate a search of clothes and belongings to safeguard pieces of evidence.

If there is any special risk, the Commander has the authority to detain any person on suspicion of
having committed an offence. He must hand over the suspect together with any evidence to the
law enforcement authorities at the destination.

Written reports by the Commander and any witnesses must be submitted to the authorities as
soon as possible. If away from home base, the Commander must also advise flight operations as
soon as possible.

The Commander shall notify the next landing place in advance if he considers a crime has been
committed on board the aircraft.

After landing, he must report the case to the local police authorities via ground staff. The
Commander shall complete and submit an Air Safety Report detailing the actions taken.

10.2.4 Reporting

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
In the event of an Occurrence or an Act of Unlawful Interference on board an EGYPTAIR aircraft the
Commander or the G.M. Flight Operations or Vice President Security will submit, without delay, a
report of such an act to the designated local Authority of the State concerned and the ECAA as
described in Chapter 11 Handling, Notifying and Reporting Occurrences.

10.2.5 Company Permits

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Each Crew Member must be in possession of a valid Company ID card. This permit must be worn
visibly.

In order to prevent misuse, the loss of a Company permit must be reported immediately to the
Security Department.

10.2.6 Security Checks

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Security measures in force on the ground are intended to reduce the possibility of potential
sabotage. Careful pre-flight checks by Flight Crew, in-flight security officers (IFSOs), Technical
Personnel, Ground Handling and Senior Supernumeraries as well as watchful observation of the
surroundings of the parked aircraft can prevent sabotage or can help detect attempted sabotage
in time.

The "Aircraft Security Checklist", is to be performed and filled out prior to each departure. This
checklist requires the names and signature of persons completing the required checks. The
Commander shall sign the checklist once satisfied that it has been properly completed.

10.2 General Preferences and Procedures
OM A
10-2-3
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
NOTE Completion of the Aircraft Security Checklist is mandatory for all flights. The original
copy of the Aircraft Security Checklist remains at the departure station, while a copy is
retained in the flight envelope.
10.2.6.1 Flight Deck

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Before each flight to which they are assigned, the Flight Deck Crew shall carry out a security search
of the flight deck to ensure that nothing has been placed there that could jeopardize the safety
and security of the aircraft.

The search shall include, but is not limited to:

Entire floor, including area formed of rudder pedals and beneath all flight deck seats;
Seats including pouches, cushions and underside of seats;
Ceiling, side and rear walls;
Horizontal control panel between Captain and First Officer seats;
Life-jacket stowage;
Emergency Exit Access and Escape Devices Stowage;
Logbook and flight manual stowage;
Crew coatroom and luggage stowage area;
Oxygen mask stowage;
Crew Rest, Check Area “If Applicable”.
10.2.6.2 Cabin Security Checks

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Sections to be completed by Cabin Crew shall be done before the checklist is supplied to the Flight
Deck for completion of flight deck items and signature of the PIC.

The search shall include, but is not limited to:

Fire extinguisher stowage, oxygen mask compartment and any shelves;
Door and lock arms;
All containers, food boxes and ovens in their locations;
Stairway;
All galley compartments, bar and refrigerator;
Escape Slide stowage;
Emergency Equipment stowage (upper and lower stowage) and any shelves, Bassinet
stowage;
Galley service door;
Cabin Crew seats, lifejacket stowage and seatback.
NOTE At transit stops, where passengers disembark the aircraft, the remaining passengers
on-board should be asked to identify their personal belongings so that any item left
on-board by the disembarked passengers can be readily identified.

10-2-4

15 OCT 24

NOTE After passengers disembark the aircraft a search must be performed in the areas
accessed by the passengers i.e. cabin, toilets, galley, etc. during the flight, to ensure
that no items have been left on-board by the disembarked passengers.
10.2.6.3 Cargo/Baggage Hold Security Checks

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
A cargo/baggage hold security search will be completed by an authorized ground staff, who will
sign the checklist certifying that a check has been completed.

10.2.6.4 Exterior Security Checks

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Engineers will complete the exterior aircraft security check and will sign the checklist certifying that
the check has been completed.

10.2.6.5 Responsibilities of Crew Members

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The Commander is responsible for:

Ensuring safety and security procedures at the aircraft, relevant to the particular flight, have been
completed prior to departure, during transit and before leaving the aircraft.

The Purser/SCC and IFSO are responsible for:

The completion of Cabin Security check before passenger boarding. This check consists of an
inspection of galleys, cabin, toilets, Crew Rest Compartment where fitted and aircraft interior.

Pre-flight Security Check performed on every originating aircraft as well as at the destination
station during turnaround, checks and searches are typically carried out in a good lighting
condition.

The objective is to ensure that no unauthorized personnel or any prohibited items are left on-
board the aircraft.

10.2.6.6 Crew Baggage, Other Non-Passengers and Supernumeraries

Security
* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
10.2.6.6.1 Standards of Screening and Searching

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Crew Members, airport staff (including EGYPTAIR staff), supernumeraries and other non-
passengers passing through the security checkpoint shall be screened in the same manner as
passengers, Strict adherence shall be given to regulations governing carriage of liquids, aerosols
and gels.

SECURITY
10.2 General Preferences and Procedures
OM A
10-2-5
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Additional screening can be performed by hand or by technical means, such as explosive trace
detection (ETD), full-body X-ray, explosive particle or vapor detection portals and/or other
approved advanced technological methods.

Crew Members on duty shall clearly display their company ID while at an airport and should always
comply with local authorities in respect of personal and baggage screening, personal identification,
immigration and customs regulations.

Crew Members, Other Non-Passengers and Supernumeraries must:

Avoid accepting items from unknown people;
Personally search all gifts received before packing them;
Ensure gifts bought overseas are wrapped in front of them;
Always pack their own bags;
Not to leave their bags unattended or unprotected at any moment after they have been
packed;
Report immediately theft of crew uniforms or identification cards;
Lock their Crew bags;
Beware of bag substitutions, ensuring that the bag they are bringing on board is in fact theirs.
10.2.6.6.2 Crew Members, Other Non-Passengers and Supernumeraries Hold

Baggage
* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Crew Members, Other Non-Passengers and Supernumeraries Baggage shall be identified by a label
and shall additionally be issued a bag tag for the specific flight on which that crew will be
performing their duties. Hold baggage of operating crew shall be kept secure and separate from
passenger's baggage. Each Crew Member must ensure that his baggage is correctly tagged.

10.2.6.7 Control of Access to Aircraft

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Stringent control of access to the aircraft must be carried out to:

Prevent weapons or explosive or other dangerous devices or items being placed on an aircraft
after it has been searched; and
Prevent unauthorized persons gaining access to aircraft.
All Company staff in ramp areas or in the airport restricted zone must wear an Identity card.

If there is any doubt about the identity or authority of a person attempting to board the aircraft,
then EGYPTAIR ramp security, law enforcement agencies and the airport authorities must be
informed immediately.

10.2.6.8 Guarding and Searching of Aircraft

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The Crew Members /IFSOs shall:

Checking the credentials (proper identification card) of all persons seeking access to the
aircraft to make sure that only crew members, authorized representatives and officials, and
bona fide passengers are permitted access to the aircraft for the respective flight;
Stopping and reporting to the Commander or EGYPTAIR representative / EGYPTAIR ramp
security any person suspected of endeavouring to take on board any weapon or potential
explosive.
Generally, the aircraft must be guarded or sealed using the procedures given in the OM Part B
during overnight stops and/or when the aircraft is parked unattended.

NOTE If the aircraft has been left unattended/parked, then full search of the aircraft (i.e.
exterior and interior) must be carried out.
NOTE The aircraft is considered left unattended when the aircraft doors are left opened and
there are no Crew Members, maintenance personnel, IFSOs or ground personnel on-
board the aircraft, or whenever the aircraft is parked without guarding.
NOTE When the aircraft is left unattended, procedures are applied according to EGYPTAIR’s
Security Program.

10.2.8 Head Count

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
It is the responsibility of the station personnel to ensure that the head count of passengers
onboard the aircraft matches the number of passenger checked in at the departure counter;
In case of a missing passenger, ground staff shall ask the crew to check the allocated seat
and to page the passenger, if the passenger is still not located, then crew may be asked to
do a head count;
At transit stops, in case of a missing passenger, the Cabin Crew may complete a headcount
of passengers remaining onboard. In case of a crew change, then the passenger headcount
shall be handed over to the inbound crew.
NOTE Headcount must be reported to station personnel.

10.2.10 Disruptive/Unruly Passengers

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
10.2.10.1 General

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
EGYPTAIR has zero tolerance towards any disruptive/unruly behavior at check-in counter, boarding
gate or on-board the aircraft.

Disruptive/Unruly Passenger:

A passenger who fails to respect the rules of conduct at an airport or on board an aircraft or to
follow the instructions of the airport staff or crew members and thereby disturbs the good order
and discipline at an airport or on board the aircraft.

The unruly behavior may include but is not limited to the following:

Refusal to follow a lawful instruction given by or on behalf of the aircraft Commander for the
purpose of:
a. Protecting the safety or security of the aircraft or of persons or property therein; or
b. Maintaining good order and discipline on board.
Physical assault or threat to commit such assault against a crew member or passengers;
Intentionally causing damage to, or destruction of, property (Sabotage);
Communication of information which is known to be false, thereby endangering the safety of
an aircraft in flight;

Verbal intimidation or threat against a crew member if such act interferes with the

Verbal intimidation against other passengers;

a) Moving in slow motion;
b) Slow to respond to questions;
c) Glassy-eyed;
d) Making irrational statements;
e) Spilling drinks;
f) Walking awkwardly;
g) Unable to sit up straight;
h) Aggressive behavior.
10.2.10.2 Role of the Commander

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The Commander must be notified by the SCC about any incidents that can endanger the safety of
the flight. He has the ultimate authority on any issue and must be informed of all further
developments, in order to be able to take further actions and communicate these actions to the
appropriate stations.

The Commander must be fully aware of the legal powers bestowed upon him, to assess and
effectively deal with any form of disruptive behavior.

In repeated cases of disruptive/unruly/violent behavior or non-compliance with crew instructions,
these legal powers include the possibility of imposing reasonable measures upon such persons.
These measures may include restraining of such passengers when the Commander assesses that a
situation will affect the safety of the aeroplane, its passengers or the crew.

The Commander should communicate his decisions to the Flight Operations Department and the
destination station, as soon as possible, so that suitable arrangements are made with local
authorities. The same applies in case of diversion due to an unruly passenger.

Upon arrival, the passenger(s) must be handed over to the appropriate authorities/law
enforcement.

The "Flight Disturbance Incident Report", to be filed by the Commander/SCC, can be found in
Chapter 10.2.10.3.4 Passenger Disturbance Report , additionally, an ASR may be required.

10.2.11 Hijacking/Unlawful Seizure of Aircraft

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
10.2.11.1 General

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The circumstances surrounding a hijacking/unlawful seizure of an aircraft are highly variable, hence
it is not possible to provide specific information to Flight Deck Crew. However, the safety of aircraft
and its occupants must be of paramount consideration and any occurrence must be dealt in
accordance with the Commander's judgment of the prevailing circumstances.

10.2.11.2 Quick Reference Guide for Cabin Crew

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Keep hijackers out of the flight deck, attempt to divert their attention;
Comply with the initial demands of the hijackers, avoiding conflict and arguments;
Do not 'talk down' to them or appear to be superior;
Attempt to identify the type of hijacker and relay the information to the PIC;
Attempt to identify the number of hijackers and the type of weapons they hold and they
claim to hold; attention should be paid to accomplices who might not have disclosed
themselves yet;
Use the code words agreed upon during the joint briefing, to communicate the emergency to
the PIC, if possible;
Never open the flight deck door;
Keep passenger manifest and other flight related paperwork away from the hijackers;
Efforts should be made to keep a sense of normalcy in the cabin;
Restrict the amount of crew dealing with each hijacker to one;
Divert hijacker anger by assigning blame to local authorities if demands are not met;
Locate medically qualified passengers and seek approval for them to tend to the sick;
Keep passengers calm and quiet;
Seek approval from hijackers to provide service to passengers;
Prepare for a prolonged incident by allocating cutlery and cups to passengers, negotiating for
passenger's use of the toilets and rationing meals and beverages;
Maintain the hygiene and sanitary conditions of the cabin;
On the ground, negotiate with hijackers to request toilet and water service and fresh supplies
of water and food;
Negotiate the release of the elderly, the sick and the minors;
Do not become mentally aligned with the hijacker.
10.2.11.3 Quick Reference for Flight Deck Crew

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Keep flight deck door closed;
Set the transponder to the appropriate code and/or relay the code to the ATC;

Transmit all information gathered to ATC;
Turn the SEAT BELT sign ON to limit passenger movement;
Instruct passengers through the public address system to remain seated and cooperate;
Use all reasonable measures to ensure hijackers do not access the flight deck;
Consider landing at the nearest suitable airport;
On the ground, maintain lockdown of the flight deck door. Do not open the door until
confirmation from the authorities is received that it is safe to do so;
Consider parking or pulling fire switches and disconnecting generators, thereby making the
aircraft non-flyable;
Upon balancing the various aspects of the threat situation of the specific incident, it may, in
the judgment of the PIC, be in the overall interest of passengers, crew, and others, for the
Flight Deck Crew to escape from the aircraft. This decision shall be determined by the PIC
upon evaluation of the situation.
10.2.11.4 Hijacker Profile

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Hijackers can generally be categorized into four main types based on their motives and
methods:

Political Hijackers : These individuals hijack planes to make political statements or demands.
They often seek to draw attention to their cause or force governments to release prisoners or
change policies;
Criminal Hijackers : These hijackers are motivated by financial gain. They may demand
ransom money or use the hijacking as a means to escape from law enforcement;
Psychological Hijackers : These individuals may have personal grievances or mental health
issues that drive them to hijack a plane. Their actions are often unpredictable and not
necessarily linked to broader political or financial motives;
Terrorist Hijackers : These hijackers are typically part of organized groups with the intent to
cause mass casualties and spread fear.
The crew should attempt to determine the hijacker's intended destination. A hijacker with no firm
destination or a clearly impossible destination in mind may be considering suicide. This person
creates a high-risk situation. A hijacker with a firm, reasonable destination in mind probably
creates a situation of less immediate risk.

10.2.11.5 Guidelines in Dealing with Hijackers

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
If information is received that a suspected or declared hijacker is onboard before take-off, the
aircraft should be returned to the gate. The crew will not attempt to evaluate or search suspicious
persons.

Any Crew Member who gets the opportunity shall inform the Commander on the interphone
system of a hijacker(s) presence in the cabin.

If the hijacker(s) is in the flight deck, crew should endeavor to communicate the situation to ATC.

Generally, hijackers are aware of the need for communication although they may be suspicious
and demand that communications are monitored. He should be informed that no resistance will be
offered, although he should be instructed not to touch any aircraft controls, systems or
instruments.

If the hijacker(s) demands endanger the flight, the consequences of such demand should be
explained in a manner which does not aggravate the situation.

Full account should be taken of the probability of the hijacker(s) being in a highly emotional state
of mind. Pilots are advised to refrain from unnecessary conversation or actions which may irritate
the hijacker(s).

The Commander should endeavor to land the aircraft using the pretext of fuel, weather, etc. as a
reason.

Crew Members should not disagree with the hijacker(s); rather every effort should be made to
relieve his anxiety in order to maintain an effective dialogue.

An attempt to disarm or disable the hijacker, shall only be made if this action is deemed to be the
adequate measure to avoid a disaster.

After landing, the Commander should attempt to stall for time and try to negotiate the
disembarkation of the passengers and Cabin Crew Members.

After any incident of this nature, crew is likely to face official enquiries and severe media and press
attention.

No statement should be made without the permission of EGYPTAIR’s Accountable Manager.

10.2.11.7 Communication Procedures

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Where possible an attempt should be made to transmit ATC a description of the hijacking/unlawful
seizure of the aircraft. ATC will maintain normal responses to the aircraft without any reference to
the emergency and will immediately activate the appropriate emergency procedures.

A Pilot having selected Code 7500 and subsequently requested to confirm this code by ATC shall
according to circumstances either confirm this or not reply at all. The absence of a reply from the
Pilot will be taken by ATC as an indication that the use of Code 7500 is not due to an inadvertent
false code selection.

Aircraft being hijacked or subjected to unlawful interference.
Transponder to code 7500 "Transponder code seven five zero zero";
In the air, when the situation is grave and immediate assistance is required.
Transponder to code 7700 "Transponder code seven seven zero zero".

10.2.12 Bomb Threat

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
10.2.12.1 Precautionary Measures

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Threats made against aircraft on the ground may justify some or all of the measures in the
following list:

Disembark all passengers and crew and their cabin baggage;
Move the threatened aircraft to the bomb search area;
Isolated aircraft parking positions should be located at the maximum distance possible from
other aircraft parking positions, buildings or public areas and the airport fence;
Consideration should also be given to the prevailing wind direction and aircraft landing and
take-off routing at the airport, to minimize disruption to airport operations and the
surrounding locality in the event of an aircraft fire or release of dangerous substances from
the aircraft;
When the threatened aircraft cannot be moved, the passengers and crew shall be
disembarked and an area of 200 m UPWIND shall be cleared of all people other than those
involved in the search;
Unloading of hold baggage;
Unloading of cargo, courier material and mail;
Checking the integrity of catering and aircraft stores;
Searching the aircraft;
Requiring passengers to identify their baggage;
Re-screening or searching hold bags before re-loading;
Re-screening and searching passengers and hand baggage before re-loading;
Re-loading cargo, courier material, mail and diplomatic bags only if they have been screened
and searched;
Close off fueling hydrants. Remove fuel tenders from the area of threat.
10.2.12.2 Threat On-ground

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
If a bomb warning threatening the aircraft is received while the aircraft is on-ground, the
Commander shall consider the following:

Information shall be relayed to ATC and Flight Operations of the situation as soon as possible;
Disembark the passengers either at the gate or at a suitable area nominated by ATC. If the
aircraft is away from the gate, disembarkation is to be via stairs rather than escape slides,
unless there is a reason to believe that an explosion and/or aircraft damage is imminent;
In a rapid deplaning via stairs or a jetway, passengers and crew should take all their baggage;
this requirement should be reflected in a PA announcement by the Crew;
If an evacuation via the slides is required passengers and crew shall leave all their baggage
on-board the aircraft.

10.2.12.3 Threat In-flight

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
If a bomb warning threatening the aircraft is received during flight, the Commander shall consider
one or more of the following:

Recalling the aircraft to the departure airfield;
Divert and land as soon as possible;
Perform an onboard search;
Continue to destination.
Additionally the following procedures will be adopted:

The PIC will make an announcement ( PURSER TO COCKPIT ) and pass on all known
information to the Purser/SCC and explain his intention;
Information shall be relayed to Flight Operations;
Flight and Cabin Crew will carry out an onboard search with the help of the IFSO, according to
the "Suspicious Article Checklist" contained in this chapter;
The Cabin Crew will direct passengers to identify and check their hand baggage and
wardrobe;
If suspicious article is found, the Commander will make a PA announcement asking for an
( EOD ) (Bomb Disposal Expert), and ATC shall be informed of the situation as soon as possible;
If a diversion is needed, the Commander shall inform passengers that the diversion ordered
by the company, without mentioning the Bomb Threat;
It is not necessary to declare emergency.
Refer to Chapter 11.3.4 Reporting Hazardous Flight Conditions to ATC.

NOTE OM Part B Bomb onboard procedures must be applied, if applicable.
NOTE For Bomb/suspicious article handling procedures, refer to the OM Part F.
NOTE For Least Risk Bomb Location, refer to OM Part B and the Suspicious Article Search
checklist.
The action to be taken after landing will depend on whether or not a suspect item has been found
or the information gathered indicates that an immediate evacuation is necessary.

Item Found : Immediate evacuation required: Aircraft to be stopped as soon as possible in
a location agreed with ATC and passengers disembarked using emergency
slides on the side of the aircraft away from the Least Risk Bomb Location
(LRBL). Passengers and crew must leave all cabin baggage onboard the
aircraft. Cabin Crew and ground personnel will assist in moving the
passengers to a safe location. The Ground authorities will then assume
control of the incident.
No Item Found : Immediate evacuation not required: A rapid deplaning via the aircraft stairs
should be carried out with passengers taking all their cabin baggage with
them.
NOTE After landing passengers should be assembled clear of aircraft (500 m UPWIND).

10.2.13 Threat or Discovery of Chemical or Biological Weapons In-flight

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Any suspicious substance, combination of substances or package discovered on-board an aircraft
must be considered hazardous until proven otherwise. A suspicious substance or package not
normally found on the aircraft and that meets certain criteria should alert a crew member that
precautions must be taken.

A suspicious package may:
Have oily stains, discolorations or odors;
Be unclaimed by anyone on board; and/or
Have fumes or vapors emanating from it.
A suspicious substance may:
Be a white, tan or beige colored powder; and/or
Have the consistency and texture ranging from fine powder (e.g. talc powder) to a coarse
substance (e.g. sugar).
Depending on the agent a person suffering the effects of exposure to a chemical or
biological agent may include:
Choking;
Discolorations;
Fainting;
Blistering;
Vomiting;
Convulsions;
Skin irritation;
Headaches;
Respiratory difficulty; and/or
Flu-like symptoms (making it difficult to differentiate from a common cold).
NOTE Generally, many biological agents will generate symptoms less rapidly than will
chemical agents, many of which cause immediate symptoms.
NOTE For appropriate Flight and Cabin crew checklists refer to Chapter 10.3 Checklist for
In-flight Chemical / Biological Weapons.

10.2.13.1 Threats of Chemical or Biological Weapons without Apparent

Activation
Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Should a chemical or biological weapon be reported as being on an EGYPTAIR aircraft in-flight,
either through a warning received or through the discovery of a suspected item and no apparent
activation of the weapon is noticeable (no visible physical symptoms are reported), the crew
should take the following measures:

Cabin Crew

Must NOT touch or move the item. Any movement may activate the spreading of the agent;
Inform the Commander about the characteristics of the item;
Cover nose and mouth with a mask or cloth; minimize exposure by covering arms with a
longsleeve shirt and/or a jacket and gloves;
Cover the item with polyethylene bags and seal it in such a manner as to prevent any
spreading of the agent;
If Commander decides to land, ensure passengers use oxygen masks and cover exposed
skin. Consider distributing blankets to passengers who cannot cover themselves otherwise;
Upon landing, wait for Commander's directions on what doors to open, then direct
passengers to those doors;
Close all doors immediately after disembarkation.
Flight Deck Crew

Immediately don masks, goggles, select 100% oxygen and minimize exposure by covering
arms with a long-sleeve shirt and/or jacket;
Reduce cabin temperature to the lowest practical setting;
Turn OFF recirculation fans;
Liaise with the IOCC and relay description of the item;
Request Cabin Crew to cover the item with polyethylene bags and seal it in such a manner
as to prevent any dispersion of the agent;
Upon consultation with IOCC, consider landing at the first available airport;
If landing at the first available airport is decided, release passenger oxygen masks and
instruct passengers to use the oxygen masks and cover all exposed skin;
Initiate gradual descent of the aircraft using a descent that minimizes the rate of cabin
pressure change;
Upon landing, taxi to the airport's minimum risk location and park the aircraft on the
diagonal to the surface winds;
Advise Cabin Crew to have passengers disembark through upwind aircraft exits;
Ensure Cabin Crew closes all aircraft doors immediately after all passengers and crew have
disembarked.

10.2.13.2 Threats of Chemical or Biological Weapons with Activation

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Should the release of a chemical or biological weapon on board an EGYPTAIR aircraft in-flight
becomes apparent due to several passengers displaying similar symptoms and the number of sick
passenger rapidly increasing, the crew should take the following measures:

Cabin Crew

Inform the Captain about the symptoms and the approximate number of sick passengers
and crew;
Cover nose and mouth with a mask or cloth; minimize exposure by covering arms with a
longsleeve shirt and/or a jacket and gloves;
Ensure passengers use oxygen masks and cover exposed skin. Consider distributing
blankets to passengers who cannot cover themselves otherwise;
After securing the cabin, don oxygen masks and prepare for landing;
Upon landing, wait for Captain's directions on what doors to open, then direct passengers
to those doors. Passengers and crew displaying symptoms of contamination by the
chemical or biological agent should remain on board;
Close all aircraft doors after the last apparently uncontaminated person disembarks;
Stand-by for local Authority's directions.
Flight Deck Crew

Immediately don masks, goggles, select 100% oxygen and minimize exposure by covering
arms with a long-sleeve shirt and/or jacket;
Secure the flight deck door and restrict entry from the cabin;
Reduce cabin temperature to the lowest practical setting;
Turn OFF recirculation fans;
Release passenger oxygen masks and instruct passengers to use them and to cover all
exposed skin;
Declare the emergency;
Initiate procedures to land at the next available airport, ensure emergency services are
available;
Initiate gradual descent of the aircraft using a descent that minimizes the rate of cabin
pressure change;
Upon landing, taxi to the airport's minimum risk location and park the aircraft on the
diagonal to the surface winds;
Advise Cabin Crew to have passengers disembark through upwind aircraft exits. This is
subject to the Authority's decision;
Instruct ground staff not to open cargo holds;
Ensure passengers and crew who display symptoms of contamination remain on board;
Ensure Cabin Crew closes all aircraft doors immediately after all uncontaminated passengers
and crew disembark;
Stand-by for local authorities' directions.

11.1 DEFINITIONS

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The following definitions are taken from ICAO Annex 13 “Aircraft Accident and Incident
Investigation”:

Accident

An occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft which, in the case of a manned aircraft,
takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such
time as all such persons have disembarked, or in the case of an unmanned aircraft, takes place
between the time the aircraft is ready to move with the purpose of flight until such time as it
comes to rest at the end of the flight and the primary propulsion system is shut down, in which:

A person is fatally or seriously injured as a result of:
Being in the aircraft; or
Direct contact with any part of the aircraft, including parts which have become detached
from the aircraft; or
Direct exposure to jet blast,
except when the injuries are from natural causes, self-inflicted or inflicted by other
persons, or when the injuries are to stowaways hiding outside the areas normally
available to the passengers and crew; or
The aircraft sustains damage or structural failure which:
Adversely affects the structural strength, performance or flight characteristics of the
aircraft; and
Would normally require major repair or replacement of the affected component,
except for engine failure or damage, when the damage is limited to a single engine
(including its cowlings or accessories), to propellers, wing tips, antennas, probes, vanes,
tires, brakes, wheels, fairings, panels, landing gear doors, windscreens, the aircraft skin
(such as small dents or puncture holes), or for minor damages to main rotor blades, tail
rotor blades, landing gear, and those resulting from hail or bird strike (including holes in
the radome); or
The aircraft is missing or is completely inaccessible.
NOTE For statistical uniformity only, an injury resulting in death within thirty days of the date
of the accident is classified, by ICAO, as a fatal injury.
NOTE An aircraft is considered to be missing when the official search has been terminated
and the wreckage has not been located.
Incident

An occurrence, other than an accident, associated with the operation of an aircraft which affects or
could affect the safety of operation.

Serious Incident

An incident involving circumstances indicating that there was a high probability of an accident and
associated with the operation of an aircraft which, in the case of a manned aircraft, takes place
between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as all

such persons have disembarked, or in the case of an unmanned aircraft, takes place between the
time the aircraft is ready to move with the purpose of flight until such time as it comes to rest at
the end of the flight and the primary propulsion system is shut down.

NOTE The difference between an accident and a serious incident lies only in the result.
Examples include:

Loss of engine cowlings, portions of flap or control surfaces, items of ancillary equipment or
fuselage panels;
A significant altitude excursion;
A minor taxiing accident;
Damage due to collision with ground equipment, take-off from or landing on the wrong
runway, declaration of emergency, etc.
Serious Injury

An injury which is sustained by a person in an accident and which:

a. Requires hospitalization for more than 48 hours, commencing within seven days from the
date the injury was received; or

b. Results in a fracture of any bone (except simple fractures of fingers, toes or nose); or

c. Involves lacerations which cause severe haemorrhage, nerve, muscle or tendon damage; or

d. Involves injury to any internal organ; or

e. Involves second or third degree burns, or any burns affecting more than 5 per cent of the
body surface; or

f. Involves verified exposure to infectious substances or injurious radiation.

11.2 AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT / SERIOUS INCIDENT / INCIDENT

PROCEDURES
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
11.2.1 EGYPTAIR Post Accident Procedures

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Refer to ERP Manual.

11.2.2 Commander / Crew Member Post Accident Procedures

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Immediately after an accident, and following the evacuation of passengers from the aircraft, the
Commander or the next surviving Crew Member (refer to Chapter 4.3.1 Chain of Command )
must carry out the following duties subject to safety considerations and the prevailing situation:

The aircraft must be secured in as safe a condition as possible;
Any emergency transmitter must be activated and pyrotechnics, if available, prepared for
immediate use;
A headcount must be made to account for all persons on board the aircraft;
The needs of any injured persons must be attended to;
The remains of any deceased persons should be decently set apart and covered;
If people, residences or communication facilities are close to the accident site, efforts must be
made to obtain assistance, having regard to the local situation;
The wreckage of the aircraft must be preserved and unauthorized persons shall not be
allowed access to it.
NOTE An authorized person is any person nominated by the accident investigation Authority
or regulatory Authority and usually includes police, fire and rescue services.
11.2.3 Preservation of Flight Data

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Following an accident or serious incident identified by the investigating authority, EGYPTAIR shall
preserve the original recorded data for 60 days or until otherwise directed by the investigating
authority.

The Commander shall ensure that:

Flight recorders’ recordings are not intentionally erased;
Flight recorders are deactivated or switched off immediately after the flight is completed; by
making an entry in ATL “Remove Flight Data Recorder and/or Cockpit Voice Recorder for
investigation”; and
The relevant personnel are informed that the recording of the flight recorders should be
preserved;
Inadvertent reactivation, test, repair or re-installation of the flight recorders by operator
personnel or during maintenance or ground handling activities performed by third parties is
prevented;

Precautionary measures to preserve the recordings of flight recorders are taken before
leaving the flight crew compartment.
NOTE If accessible on the flight deck, the flight data recorders’ circuit breakers may be
pulled. This should however be done only as a last resort, as it will render the flight
data recorders as unserviceable for the rest of the flight or series of flights.
All evidence shall be secured, originals and copies of documents (e.g. mass and balance
documents, ATL, OFP, take-off data, passenger lists, cargo papers, manuals) to be seized and
safeguarded.

NOTE The FDR, DLR and CVR shall never be intentionally switched off by the Flight Deck
Crew, unless required to preserve data after an accident or serious incident.

11.3 ACCIDENT / SERIOUS INCIDENT / INCIDENT / AIRPROX REPORTING

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
11.3.1 Accident / Serious Incident Reporting

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
When a reportable accident/serious incident occurs, the Commander of the aircraft involved at the
time of the accident or, in cases where the Commander is unable to report the occurrence, the
next Crew Member in the chain of command or EGYPTAIR, shall notify the nearest Authority, by
the quickest available means, of any accident or serious incident resulting in injury, death or
substantial aircraft damage.

In addition, a report shall be submitted to the ECAA within 72 hrs of the time when the accident/
serious incident was identified.

The report must include the following information:

Aircraft model, call sign and registration;
Name of Commander and crew particulars;
Date, time (UTC) and location of the occurrence;
Number of persons on board at the time of the occurrence;
Number of persons killed or seriously injured;
Type of occurrence;
Brief particulars of aircraft or third party damage;
Details of any dangerous goods on board.
11.3.2 Incident Reporting

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The Commander shall:

Notify the appropriate local Authority without delay in the event of any emergency situation;
Submit, if required by the State of occurrence, a report to the appropriate local Authority.
NOTE A report shall be submitted to the ECAA within 72 hrs of the time when the incident
was identified.
All Crew Members must

Report to the Commander any fault, failure, malfunction or defect which they believe may
affect the airworthiness or safe operation of the aircraft or its emergency systems/equipment;
Report to the Commander any incident that endangered or could have endangered the safety
of operation;
Make full use of EGYPTAIR’s Air Safety Reporting System.

11.3.3 AIRPROX Reporting

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
An AIRPROX report must be filed whenever a Pilot considers that the aircraft may have been
endangered during flight by the proximity of another aircraft to the extent that a risk of collision
existed.

An initial report of the incident must be made by radio to the ATC unit with which the aircraft is in
communication at the time.

The following format should be used:

Call sign;
"AIRPROX report";
Position and time of the incident;
Altitude/flight level;
Heading;
Weather conditions
If it is not possible to report the incident by radio, a report should be made by telephone or fax to
any ATC unit immediately after landing.

The initial report must be confirmed as soon as possible by submitting an ASR.

11.3.4 Reporting Hazardous Flight Conditions to ATC

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The PIC shall without delay verbally report any hazardous flight condition to the appropriate ATC
facility.

Such required reports may include types of hazards, as described in the following table:
Generic Hazard Report Description
Meteorological Conditions Un-forecast or severe weather, icing, windshear, severe turbulence
Geophysical Events Volcanic ash observed or encountered
Security Breaches Air Piracy or other hostile acts that threaten the safety of the aircraft or its
passengers or bomb threats
Wildlife Birds or large animals in the vicinity of the airport or runways
Facilities and Infrastructure
Inadequacy of navigational facilities or undesirable navigation aid
performance, braking action or other irregularity in navigational or ground
facilities
Aircraft Performance Unable to accept or maintain RVSM and reason (e.g. turbulence, mountain
wave, wake turbulence, etc.) loss of navigational capability
Lasers Illumination activities, events or exposure
Dangerous Goods Dangerous goods on board the aircraft in the case of an in-flight emergency
and for the information of airport authorities
GPS Anomalies Locations of GPS interference/jamming
Other Unmanned free balloons, downed aircraft observation or ELT broadcast

11.4 INVESTIGATION OF ACCIDENTS, SERIOUS INCIDENTS AND

INCIDENTS
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In case of an accident, the National Authorities of the State on whose territory the accident occurs
will decide how and by whom the investigation is to be conducted. Although it is possible that an
EGYPTAIR representative (e.g. nominated potholders and/or senior company personnel) will be
invited to observe the official investigation, it is assumed that EGYPTAIR will be excluded to
preserve independence of interest.

For incidents and serious incidents in Arab Republic of Egypt, EGYPTAIR shall normally investigate
the cause.

The objective of an investigation is to discover the facts and, if possible, establish the cause of an
incident. It is not the function of investigators to decide whether any person has been negligent or
to allocate blame. The presence or absence of negligence has to be decided by others after the
investigators have finished their work and all the facts are known. Disciplinary proceedings are
outside the realm of flight safety and beyond the scope of this manual.

11.4.1 State Investigations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
When an aircraft accident/serious incident occurs in a foreign State, the procedures involving
investigation are described in ICAO Annex 13 - "Aircraft Accident and Incident Investigation".

11.4.2 Investigations within the Arab Republic of Egypt

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The International procedures involving aircraft accident or serious incident investigations are
described in ICAO Annex 13 - "Aircraft Accident and Incident Investigation" and to be performed
by the Central Directorate of Air Accident Investigation.

11.4.3 EGYPTAIR Air Safety Investigations

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Air Safety investigation is a non-disciplinary process that is undertaken by the nominated
managers. The primary purpose of such investigations is to determine the facts surrounding an
event and make safety recommendations where appropriate to prevent a recurrence.

Crew Members will be removed from flying duties pending investigation, if the aircraft on which
they are acting as members of the crew is involved in an accident/serious incident while in motion
which results in:

Death or serious injury to any person;
Damage to property, either company or a third party;
Structural damage to the aircraft;
A serious breach of air safety or security.
This initial removal from duty following an incident does not have any disciplinary connotation and
is solely to facilitate the investigation.

The G.M. Flight Operations and/or the G.M. Safety, Quality and Standardization, will decide if a
hearing is required or helpful in order to uncover the course of events which led to the accident.

If a hearing is called, the participation of the Commander is mandatory. G.M. Flight Operations will
decide the composition of the hearing panel; the Commander is entitled to have a Pilot of his
confidence to attend the hearing. The Commander of an aircraft involved in an accident or serious
incident resulting in damage to the aircraft shall not commence another flight until he receives
authorization from EGYPTAIR.
