Any time a Flight Deck Crew Member is transitioning from his rest period into active duty, he
must be in uniform before assuming his duties on the aircraft;
Seat Belt/Bed Belts shall be worn at all times when occupying the bunks;
When occupied, the lighting in the crew rest compartment area shall remain dim. Operation
of individual reading lights or IFE screens is permitted only with privacy curtains drawn;
Resting crew should be woken 15 minutes prior to their on-duty time;
Prior to leaving the crew rest compartment ensure that all personal items have been removed
and that the facility is ready for occupation by the next Crew Member.
14.2.10 Personal Documents

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Crew Members have to carry the following documents while on duty:

Valid license;
Valid passport;
Valid EGYPTAIR identity card.;
Valid Crew Member Certificate (CMC), if required;
Valid visa, if required;
Valid medical certificate, if required;
Vaccination card, if required.
Each Crew Member is responsible for the validity, issuance, renewal, and extension of his personal
documents.

Crew Members are also responsible for ensuring that they are in possession of the applicable
documents, qualifications and certifications required for any particular duty or series of duties and
that those documents are valid until the planned date of return to base.

The loss of any personal document must be reported immediately to EGYPTAIR.

Upon leaving EGYPTAIR, all documents, which have been provided by EGYPTAIR, must be returned.

NOTE It's the flight crew member responsibility to send a copy of any updates to their
passport and/or type of license (ie; CPL to ATPL) to scheduling department, chief pilot
and passport department at the IOCC.
14.2.11 Aeroplane Document Briefcase

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
The station of a departing flight prepares a Document Briefcase, marked with the aeroplane
registration. It is handed to the SCC, who ensures that the briefcase and its contents are delivered
at destination.

Contents

Company Mail: Letters and documents sent from one EGYPTAIR office to another and which
do not fall under the postal law.
NOTE It is not allowed to transport private letters of employees as Company Mail.
Accompanying Postal Documents: Mail that falls under the postal law;
POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES
14.2 EGYPTAIR Policies
OM A
14-2-8

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Load plan: Information in advance for the Flight Deck Crew, e.g. number of the crew, fuel
figures, etc;
Mass and Balance Sheet: It is the basis for the distribution of passengers and load in relation
to the center of gravity, see Chapter 8.1.8 Mass and Centre of Gravity.
Distribution of the Mass and Balance Sheet:
Original remains with the Flight Deck Crew;
One copy for the destination airport;
One copy for the station of the departure airport.
General Declaration: Contains the number and names of the crew revised and signed by the
Pilot-in-Command;
Health Declaration, if required;
Passenger Manifest: A list containing the names of all passengers on board;
Cargo Manifest: Contains a list of all Air Waybills on board.
NOTE Air Waybill number must be affixed to every piece of airfreight.
14.2.12 Handling of Company Materials

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Crew Members shall handle EGYPTAIR’ material with great care.

EGYPTAIR may claim compensation from a Crew Member for any damage caused by him.

The aircraft documents are legal documents and must be maintained in immaculate conditions at
all times.

Crew Member shall not write/scribble on the manuals, Jeppesen plates/charts or any other flight
documentation kept onboard the aircraft.

Crew Members are not allowed to take any articles, such as small gifts (e.g. toys), catering items,
parts of cabin or galley equipment from the aircraft.

NOTE When the employment contract terminates, everything belonging to EGYPTAIR shall
be returned.
14.2.13 Bulletin Boards Bulletins

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Bulletin boards are provided at the flight operations building and at the IOCC. Certain information
will be posted on the bulletin boards e.g. Airworthiness Directives, manufacturer bulletins,
announcements related to the latest Operations Manual amendments/revisions and safety/security
related issues.

Urgent and/or critical changes will be published by Flight Operations Bulletins while waiting for the
authority approval. Those bulletins will always override any other instructions in the Operations
Manual; they remain valid for their validity period or until being inserted in the relevant Operations
Manual.

14.2.14 Customs and Currency Regulations

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
All Crew Members must pass through local customs, immigration and currency control, as required
by the local authorities.

All Crew Members must comply with the local customs and other special immigration regulations,
which may often be more restrictive for Crew Members than for passengers. Crew Members must
declare all goods liable for duty and are responsible for duty charges. The same policy applies to
restrictions on import/export of currencies.

It must be clearly understood that non-compliance with immigration, customs or currency
regulations or any other official controls is a serious offence against the laws and regulations of a
country, and a breach of EGYPTAIR regulations.

Crew Members found in violation of this policy will be subject to disciplinary action, including
termination, with the penalties applicable under the law.

NOTE Certain countries require immigration officials to retain possession of Crew passports.
Flight Deck Crew are kindly requested to cooperate with officials and to adhere to
these requirements.
14.2.15 Duty Free Shopping

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Duty free shopping is not allowed:

Without the permission of the Commander;
When ground time is, or due to the late arrival became, 30 minutes or less;
At intermediate stops where passengers remain on board;
In case the handling agent requests a departure earlier than the scheduled time of
departure and the duty free shopping would not allow this;
On ambulance flights.
NOTE A departure should never be delayed because the crew is duty free shopping, nor
should passengers get such impression.
NOTE Fuelling/defuelling procedures with passengers on board shall be attended by at least
one Fight Crew Member, while running APU and/or maintenance actions performed
during transit stops shall, before leaving the aircraft for duty free shopping, be
coordinated with the maintenance personnel.
NOTE The number of Cabin Crew to remain on board is the minimum Cabin Crew for the
type specific, refer to Chapter 4.3.3.1 Minimum Cabin Crew.
14.2.16 Passport/Visa and Health Requirements

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Refer to OM Part C, Entry Requirements section.

14.2.17 Crew Accommodation

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
All Crew Members shall comply with the instructions required by the specific country before
leaving the aircraft.( EGYPTAIR ID, PASSPORT,ENTRY VISA, Vaccination if required, etc) EGYPTAIR
will provide hotel accommodation for the crew when away from base.

EGYPTAIR will pay for the room and breakfast charges only. All other expenses are the
responsibility of the individual Crew Member. All personal bills must be settled by the Crew
Member prior to checking out.

Usually, all Crew Members will use crew accommodation provided by the Company. Should a Crew
Member not require accommodation, he must inform and obtain a prior permission from the
Commander. He must leave his contact details with the Commander and must report at the hotel
at least 2 hours before the pick-up time.

At check-in for flight duty, Crew Members shall present themselves to the Commander.

When staying in hotel accommodation, all Crew Members shall refrain from any action or behavior
that could lead to complaints from the hotel management; and refrain from making direct
complaints to hotel personnel. All complaints should be made in writing to EGYPTAIR.

When out of base, Crew Members must report any irregularity to the Commander, and any contact
with the station or any possible crew change shall be relayed to him. Where the Commander is
unavailable, the next most senior Flight Deck Crew Member assumes this responsibility.

NOTE Selecting or changing crew hotels is the responsibility of the V.P. Flight Operations,
this responsibility can be delegated to the G.M. Flight Operations or Chief Pilots.
NOTE List of EGYPTAIR hotels, is available at Chief Pilots offices, flight dispatch office, crew
scheduling department, fleet notes, G.M. Flight Operations office and intranet website.
In case of unforeseen night stops, or when there is no reservation made by the Company, the
Commander will decide which hotel is to be taken by the crew.

Each Crew Member shall always observe the requirements of Chapter 7 Flight Time

14.2.22 Changes in the Flight Deck Crew Scheduling

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Due to the size and nature of EGYPTAIR operations, or due to unforeseen situations, changes to
the published Flight Deck Crew schedule might become necessary.

The Flight Deck Crew Member shall accept any revised assigned duty after leaving their
place of rest provided that the end of the revised duty does not exceed the maximum FDP
limitations;
NOTE If the flight deck crew member is notified of any revised duty after leaving their
place of rest and his original flight was a turn around and the new assigned duty
is a layover, the flight deck crew member has the right to accept or refuse the
layover flight but he must accept any turn around flights.
If Flight Deck Crew Members are given a notice of any flight cancellation before leaving
their place of rest, Flight Deck Crew member shall act as standby during the period which
the original reporting time falls within as per Chapter 14.2.24 Stand-by Periods (Flight
Deck Crew) ;
If Flight Deck Crew Members are given 10 hours or more notice of any flight delay from
original reporting time, Flight Deck Crew member shall accept the delayed flight duty;
NOTE In case of a flight delay and the Flight Deck Crew Members are given less than10
hours notice of a new reporting time the FDP limitations shall be in compliance
with Chapter 7.5.6 Delayed Reporting Time.
If a Flight Deck Crew Member took an emergency leave on a flight that extends for more
than one day (i.e.: layover flights) he will be rescheduled for standby duty as per operations
needs for each consecutive day after the emergency leave ends till the end of his original
duty, provided the new duties are following Flying duty limitations;
If a Flight Deck Crew Member took a sick leave on a flight that extends for more than one
day (i.e.: layover flights) he will be rescheduled for standby duty as per operations needs for
each consecutive day after the sick leave ends till the end of his original duty, provided the
new duties are following Flying duty limitations.

14.2.23 Reporting for Duty

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Reporting for Duty on-time is the responsibility of each individual Crew Member;
Flight Crew Members shall report to the flight dispatch 1 ½ hour before the expected time of
departure for international and domestic flights;
Cabin Crew Members shall report to the flight dispatch 2 hours before the expected time of
departure for international flights and 1 ½ hour for domestic flights;
NOTE a) Reporting Time for Positioning Crew from Cairo is 1 hour;
b) Reporting Time for Positioning Crew from Outside Stations is 1 ¼ hours.
During their flying duty period, whether at home base or when out of base, crew members
shall always be ready for any possible change in their rostering/assigned duties;
For the purpose of determining required rest periods and calculating duty time limitations the
following are considered as duty time:
Entire duration of the flight;
Pre-operating deadhead time;
Training periods prior to a flight;
Administrative or office time prior to a flight, for Crew Members who serve in
management positions;
If required by the state, flight time accrued by flight crew members in operations other
than those of EGYPTAIR (i.e. inspection for other operators). It is the responsibility of the
crew member to inform the Chief Pilot and the scheduling department by official means
of communications (i.e. E-mail, etc.) with his assigned duty to determine the required rest
period and re-calculate the duty time limitation for operating Flight Crew Members.

14.2.25 Extra Crew

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
Extra Crew will be issued in accordance with the prescribed administrative procedures of
EGYPTAIR;
The crew member shall obtain a regular leave from the direct head or to be free from all
duties before requesting an Extra Crew;
The extra crew duration must be according to each destination regulation unless an entry
visa is obtained;
Extra Crew application is filed and authorized by Chief Pilots or the concerned head of
department, then approved by the V.P. Flight Operations;
The concerned Crew Member must have a valid travel visa for the destination, if required;
The Crew Member shall strictly adhere to the instructions written on the extra crew
application form;
A copy of the original application form must be presented to the Manager on Duty at the
IOCC;
Vacant seats on the flight must be assured (e.g. jump seat or cabin seat);
Upon check-in, the original copy of the extra crew should be handed to the station
personnel;
The concerned Crew Member must be in uniform;
The concerned Crew Member joins the active crew on the scheduled time, where he submits
the Extra Crew form to the Commander, to be kept in the flight envelope;
Upon arrival, the concerned Crew Member should notify the station representative about
the intended departure date and time.
These administrative and legal procedures are used in order to authorize the traveling of Crew
Members as extra crew; any violation made, cancels the application and subjects the Crew Member
to investigation.

14.2.29 Crew Reading Material/Flight Deck Discipline

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
In order to maintain a “State of Readiness” on the flight deck, there are a number of strategies that
one can develop; among them is “READING”. However, it must be emphasized that the habit of
reading on the flight deck can be detrimental to the overall flight deck discipline, and must
therefore be very closely controlled by the Commander.

Apart from the reading of necessary operational material, one's attention should never be devoted
to reading in any phase of flight, which can be described as busy (e.g. during climb, descent,
approach, or during cruise in reasonably crowded airspaces with the requirement to closely
monitor VHF radios, etc.).

No more then one Flight Deck Crew Member should be engrossed in reading at any time. If one
Crew Member is reading or doing paper work, the other Crew Member should closely monitor the
flight instruments, communication and flight path.

Crew Members are not allowed, under any circumstances, to use MP3 players, Video players or
computer games at any time during flight.

Flight Deck Crew Members are prohibited from using a personal wireless communications device
or laptop computer for personal use while at their duty station on the flight deck while the aircraft
is being operated.

This prohibition is intended to ensure that non-essential activities do not affect flight deck task
management or cause a loss of situational awareness during aircraft operation.

NOTE In the interest of safety, it is the responsibility of the Commander to control the flight
deck in the utmost disciplined manner.
NOTE Cabin Crew Members are not allowed to read newspapers, magazines, books or
private literature while on duty.
14.2.30 Paper Work

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
It is EGYPTAIR’ policy to minimize the paper work required during the flight. However, certain
information must be recorded and shall be properly evaluated and reported.

The Captain should establish the time for paper work and in no case should paper work be done
while:

Any member of the crew is not at his seat and strapped in;
The other Crew Member(s) is not monitoring the flight, e.g. reading, eating or making PA
announcements etc.;
Climbing or descending, it should be during a stabilized cruise phase and where no critical
situation exists;

NOTE OFP entries:
An RVSM entry shall be made in the OFP before pushback and prior to enter

14.2.31 Aircraft Lights

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Exterior Lighting

Logo light should be on during all night operations below 10.000 ft AGL;
Navigation light should be on during all operations;
Beacon/Anti-collision light should be on from before engine start and until all engines are
shut down;
Strobe light should be on from before entering the departure runway and until vacating the
landing runway. In addition, it should be on while crossing/backtracking any runway, even if it
is closed;
Aircraft landing lights should be on when take-off clearance is obtained and should be off
after vacating the runway. In addition, they should remain on during all operations below
10.000 ft AGL;
Taxi light should be on whenever the aeroplane is in motion on ground;
Runway turn-off lights should be on whenever the aeroplane is in motion on ground during
night operations.
NOTE While using Taxi light, care should be taken not to dazzle other aircraft or marshallers.
NOTE On ground, the use of Wing light should be limited to inspecting the wings and slats
for any ice accretion that might build up.

NOTE During fog, snowfall, etc., care should be taken while using aircraft lights, as they may

Flight Deck Lighting

Dark adaptation is the process by which the eyes adapt for optimum night visual acuity, under
conditions of low ambient illumination; the eyes require about 20 to 30 minutes to fully adapt to
minimal lighting conditions. To minimize the time necessary to achieve complete dark adaptation
and to maintain it:

Adjust instrument and flight deck lighting to the lowest level possible;
Avoid prolonged exposure to bright light;
High intensity lights (e.g. white dome light, circuit breaker, etc.) should be turned OFF;
During approach and landing, spotlight or map light may be used if situation requires.
NOTE Any time during night operation and when the FASTEN SEAT BELT sign is ON, Cabin
Crew Members are not allowed to open the Flight Deck door without dimming the
galley light. Every precaution should be taken not to dazzle the Flight Deck Crew with
bright lights during night operations.

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The Commander shall not permit the First Officer to conduct take-off and/or landing unless the
following conditions exist:

Runway braking action is RWYCC 5 or good;

Visibility/RVR is more than 1.000 m; and
Airport category is A or B; and
Any related operational restrictions require the Captain to be Pilot Flying; and
No VIP on board.

14.2.34 Crew Commitment Towards EGYPTAIR

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
EGYPTAIR crew shall be prohibited to do by themselves, or through a third party any activity
similar to that being exercised by EGYPTAIR, during the validity period of their contract, or
participate in an activity of that sort, whether in their quality as partner or worker;

14.2.35 Media / Social Media

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Media includes TV interviews, News paper interviews, and Articles , etc.

Social media includes social networking sites such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube
etc.

It is important that EGYPTAIR employees who choose to participate in these types of activities,
whether in their personal or professional lives, understand EGYPTAIR expectations and
requirements.

It is EGYPTAIR' policy that employees:

Must ensure, when using media/social media, that they do not present themselves as a
representative of any entity within EGYPTAIR,
Have an obligation to protect the company's reputation and its confidential information;
Are prohibited from sharing any information relating to customers;
Should not post or publish any material that could be viewed as defamatory, obscene,
threatening, harassing, discriminatory, sexual or hateful to another person or entity;
Should be polite and respectful of all individuals and communities they interact with online;
Should not make any negative, critical or disparaging remarks about EGYPTAIR or any
remarks that would harm its reputation;
Are personally responsible and legally liable for anything they write, publish or present, and
will be held accountable for anything posted which could damage EGYPTAIR' image.
Shall obtain a prior written authorization from management before publishing, presenting
or writing any media / social media content related to EGYPTAIR.
Employees found in violation of the above policy will be subjected to disciplinary action.

14.2.37 Emergency Authority of the Commander

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The Commander is permitted to deviate from prescribed rules, minima, regulations and
procedures as required for flight safety considerations during an emergency.

If an emergency situation warrants a deviation from an ATC clearance, the crew shall notify ATC of
that deviation as soon as possible.

If an emergency situation necessitates the taking of action, which involves a violation of EGYPTAIR’
or local regulations or procedures, the Commander shall notify the appropriate local authority
without delay in accordance with the procedures detailed in Chapter 11 Handling, Notifying and
Reporting Occurrences.

14.2.38 Flight Delay / Cancellation Policy

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
When the Flight Deck Crew scheduling department is unable to assign a current and
qualified Flight Deck Crew Member to a certain flight, the IOCC shall immediately be
notified;
The IOCC person in charge shall, in coordination with all other relevant parties, review all
available options e.g. aircraft type change, flight consolidation, etc.;
If after discussing an reviewing all the available options, the problem of dispatching the
flight still exists, the G.M. IOCC or his deputy/representative shall notify the G.M. Flight
Operations, who shall review the case and decide the next course of action e.g. delaying or
cancelling the flight;
If the decision has been taken to delay/cancel a certain flight, the G.M. Flight Operations
shall coordinate with the V.P. Flight operations, who in turn has to coordinate with the
Chairman to agree on the decision. The G.M. IOCC shall notify all concerned and relevant
parties and shall take all required steps to manage the schedule disruption and to handle
customers.

14.2.39 VIP Flights

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Flights will be classified as VIP based on management evaluation;
Flight deck crew will be assigned by G.M. Flight Operations or by delegation to Chief Pilot;
Cabin crew will be assigned by V.P Cabin Crew.
NOTE The management has the right to remove any crew member from his flight as needed
for VIP flight operations, the crew should accept any revised duty.
Boarding Protocol to VIP and Entourage

By delegation from the Commander:
The Purser/SCC welcomes the VIP at the aircraft door in full uniform;
Once on board the Purser/SCC briefs the VIP entourage principal about the flight details.
NOTE Flight deck crew members shall not inform the ATC that a VIP is on-board or request
any shortcuts or priorities related to VIP on-board unless it is listed in ATS flight plan in
field 18, the remarks section, the word (HEAD) which means Head of state, Head of
government or equivalent dignitaries are on-board.
Confidentiality Agreement and Non-disclosure

All crew members including Flight Crew, Cabin Crew, Flight Station Engineer and any other staff
member assigned to the VIP flight are bound to this Confidentiality and Non-Disclosure
Agreement.

Each employee agrees not to disclose, reveal to anyone or use, other than for the purpose of
carrying his duties, any information which he knows or should know as a result of his role as a VIP
flight Crew Member, or the context in which the information was imparted to him that constitutes
private, personal, confidential, privileged, proprietary or restricted information without first
obtaining the specific written permission of the VP Flight Operations, or his delegate.

14.2.40 Not to Fly Together Policy

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
In the interest of the application of team management concept and the effective use of all
available resources to operate the flight safely in compliance with the CRM concepts.

Experience has proven that the most effective way to maintain safety of flights is to combine the
skills and experience of all crew members in the decision-making process to determine the safest
course of action. Thus, to assure that CRM concepts and safety flight envelope is maintained
throughout all of our flights and simulator training, EGYPTAIR’ policy allows any of its crew
members to submit a request for not Flying together with any other crew member under the
following conditions:

Crew member shall submit the Not to fly together request to his direct manager in person
within a maximum of 15 days of the last flight or the last simulator training with the other
crew member;
The Maximum allowable number of Not to fly together for each crew member is three;
The request shall be submitted for sound operational or safety reasons.

14.3.1 Manuals Policy

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Refer to Chapter 0.5 Introduction.

14.3.2 Compliance with GSOP

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The GSOP must be adhered to by all Crew Members. However, under certain circumstances
e.g. ATC speed and/or altitude constrains, deviations are allowed provided a full briefing is
conducted, understood and agreed upon by the Flight Deck Crew Members;
Specific aircraft type SOPs that are not conflicting with the GSOP shall be adhered to by all
Crew Members.
14.3.3 Common Language

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The common languages to be used by Crew Members for communication are English and Arabic.

English and/or Arabic shall be used:

On the flight deck during line operations;
Between the Flight Deck Crew and Cabin Crew during line operations;
During Flight Deck Crew/Cabin Crew training and evaluation activities.
In all cases standard callouts must be used as defined by the standard operation procedures.

The first choice of language for all verbal communication is English.

14.3.4 Use of Available Resources

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The Commander of the flight must use all resources available to him during the flight;
The optimum management of available resources is the key factor to achieve safe flight
operation;
Briefings in general and Cabin Crew briefings in particular are key-planning elements;
Well-briefed and informed Crew Members will have more focus on their duties, simply
because they are aware of the situation and they know what is expected from them;
Standard callouts are a very powerful communication tool. They are short, precise and
contain specific messages that are crucial during time critical and emergency situations;
Available resources can be categorized as follows:
Human resources (Flight Deck Crew, dispatchers, ground handling personnel, etc.);
Information resources (rules, polices, procedures, manuals, etc.);
Hardware resources (the aircraft, ground equipment, etc.).

14.3.5 Mobile Phones

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Mobile phones are a great communication tool; however, they can distract the crew from
performing their duties.

To limit the negative safety effects of mobile phones, the following rules shall apply:

All Crew Members shall switch OFF their mobile phones during dispatch briefing, and
during fuelling/defuelling procedures;
All active Flight Deck Crew Members must switch OFF their mobile phones before initiating
Flight Deck preparation;
The use of mobile phones after the completion of Flight Deck preparation and until engine
start or pushback, whichever is earlier, is permitted, however, it has to be closely monitored
by the Commander so as not to impede Flight Deck discipline;
Mobile phones must remain OFF until the completion of the shut down checklist at
destination;
All active Cabin Crew Members must switch OFF their mobile phones upon boarding the
aircraft and until the completion of cabin preparation.
Mobile phones may be used by Cabin Crew after the completion of cabin preparation and
shall be turned OFF before passengers embarkation and must remain OFF until all
passengers disembarkation;
Mobile phones are prohibited in the apron safety line during fueling/defueling.
14.3.6 Public Address (PA) Announcements

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The Commander’s voice over the PA, carrying welcome and/or information messages, is a
powerful tool to show how much the airline cares about providing the best service to their
passengers;
PA announcements shall not be attempted when any member of the Flight Deck Crew is
outside the Flight Deck;
PA announcements required while taxiing shall be conducted only when the aircraft is at a
complete stop and the parking brakes are set. However, when a situation dictates
continuous aircraft motion, the Captain may delegate the announcement to the SCC;
PA announcements must be short, clear, precise, and informative;
During flight and when weather conditions permit, PA announcements shall normally be
conducted at the beginning of cruise, when workload is low;
Overdoing PA announcements, in length or frequency, defies its purpose and becomes a
burden on passengers;
It is strictly forbidden to announce the SIC’s name as the PIC of the flight or even
announcing that the SIC is the PF;
During PA, the provisions of Chapter 14.3.8.7 Use of Different Communication
Frequencies and Chapter 14.3.13 Transfer of Control shall be applied;
PA announcements must be coordinated between Flight Deck and Cabin Crew;
A timely PA announcement shall be conducted, with the proper explanation of the situation,
in the following cases:

14.3.8 Communication Policies

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
14.3.8.1 Company Call Sign

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew shall use ( EGYPTAIR ) and then the flight number as a company call sign, if and
when there is difficulty in understanding the call sign by ATC, call sign ( M ike S ierra R omeo) then
the flight number should be used.

On first contact with ATC, Flight Deck Crew shall report the cleared flight level unless specifically
requested otherwise by ATC.

14.3.8.2 Call Sign Confusion

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
All Crew Members must be certain that an ATC instruction was for their aircraft. If there is any
doubt at all about call sign, Flight Deck Crew shall request clarification from ATC. In particular,
cleared altitudes, flight levels, headings and runway crossing clearance are critical. Always listen
out before transmitting.

14.3.8.3 Read Back / Hear Back Policy

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The PM shall read back the clearance to ATC, exactly as it was received;

Company name and flight number must follow the read back;
The other Pilot shall repeat aloud his understanding of the clearance;
Both Pilots must confirm that they have the same understanding of clearances and radio
communication messages;
When in doubt, it is essential to confirm the clearance with the ATC;
Only standard radio phraseology should be used for communication;
The following items must always be read back:
ATC route clearances;
Clearances and instructions to enter, land on, take-off from, hold short of, cross or

Runway-in-use, altimeter settings, SSR codes, level instructions, heading and speed
instructions and, whether issued by the controller or contained in the ATIS broadcasts,
transition levels.
Other clearances or instructions, including conditional clearances, must be read back or
acknowledged in a manner to clearly indicate that they have been understood and will be
complied with.

14.3.8.4 Headsets / Boom Microphones and Loudspeakers

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Headsets / boom microphones must be used during all operations until the top of climb
and from the top of descent until all engines are shutdown at the gate;
Headsets / boom microphones must be used when operations require the use of two
different frequencies at the same time;
Headsets / boom microphones shall be used when any of the Crew Members is making a
PA announcement;
Headsets / boom microphones shall be used when one of the Crew Members leaves the
Flight Deck;
Headsets / boom microphones shall be used during all ground operations that require ATC
communication;
Loudspeakers must be set at the lowest audible volume, when using headsets;
Headsets / boom microphones shall be used whenever deemed necessary by the
Commander;
The boom microphone shall be in a position that permits its use for two-way radio
communications.
NOTE The PM should not use the PTT button on the control wheel/side stick when the PF is
flying manually.

14.3.8.5 VHF Communication

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Flight Deck Crew shall maintain radio listening watch on the frequencies appropriate for the area
of operation, in addition, and if required by the applicable authorities e.g when flying in class G
airspace, they shall continuously monitor / use the appropriate common frequency used for in-
flight communication in designated airspace i.e. IFBP and TIBA.

In general, Flight Deck Crew shall use the VHF boxes as follows:

VHF box No.1 shall be used for ATC communication;
VHF box No.2 shall be used to monitor the emergency communication frequency
(121.5 MHz) during all flight operations, unless it is temporary required for other
communication;
VHF box No.3 or VHF center shall be used for DATA;
When a third frequency needs to be monitored e.g. VOLMET, ATIS, IFBP, VHF box No.3/VHF
center may be used for this specific requirement, provided that once the additional voice
frequency is no longer needed, the DATA setting must be resumed for efficient use of
ACARS;
After changing to a new frequency, the last frequency displayed on the non-active window
must not be changed until contact has been established on the new frequency.
14.3.8.6 HF Communication

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
HF radio boxes must be checked for all flights requiring the use of HF along the route or
portions thereof;
During flights over African non-radar controlled airspace at least one HF box must be set to
one of the following HF emergency frequencies: 500 kHz, 2.182 kHz or 8.364 kHz;
A SELCAL check has to be performed for all flights on one of the following flight operations
frequencies: 6.805 kHz or 10.947 kHz.
14.3.8.7 Use of Different Communication Frequencies

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
In order to reduce flight deck workload and crew distraction, the provisions of Chapter
14.3.8.4 Headsets / Boom Microphones and Loudspeakers shall be applied;
The call: (I AM OFF VHF No.1, YOU HAVE COMMUNICATIONS) shall be announced by
the concerned Crew Member, when he switches OFF VHF No 1, to increase the other Crew
Member's awareness that he is listening alone to the ATC communication frequency;
The call: (I AM BACK TO VHF No.1) shall be announced by the concerned Crew Member to
indicate that he is back to the operating ATC communication frequency;
The call: (LOUD SPEAKERS ON and HEADSETS OFF) shall be announced by both Crew
Members, and the volume of the loudspeakers has to be readjusted;
Both Pilots must conduct a complete briefing to update each other with the latest
information, or received clearances.

14.3.8.8 Stockholm Radio Procedures

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The main purpose of using Stockholm Radio is to provide the company with an accurate flight
following system that enables the tracking of its aircraft. It can also be notified any time the Flight
Deck Crew need to contact the Flight Operations when they are out of coverage area of standard
Flight Operations frequencies. Stockholm Radio also provides additional services, such as, phone
patches (billed on personal credit cards), and medical advices when needed.

For aircraft that are not equipped with ACARS, Stockholm Radio shall be notified on its allocated
HF frequencies when the flight time exceeds 3 hours of cruise at the following positions:

Europe: At the FIR boundary of Cairo and one hour before the ETA at destination;
North Atlantic: At the FIR boundary of Cairo, at the oceanic entrance, 30 W, and at the
oceanic exit;
Africa: At the FIR boundary of Cairo and every two hours thereafter;
Middle East: At the FIR boundary of Cairo and one hour before the ETA at destination;
Far East: At the FIR boundary of Cairo and every two hours thereafter.
At first contact with Stockholm radio a SELCAL check has to be performed, in addition

The latest weather report for destination and alternate shall be acquired;
An actual position report and an estimate for the next FIR boundary shall be relayed;
ETA at destination and estimated fuel remaining after landing shall be relayed.
NOTE Stockholm Radio frequencies are periodically changed every three months and are
readily available at the IOCC.

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Communications with the Flight Operations concerning requests, inquiries and departure,

Technical issues, diversion, declaring emergency and irregularities/matters that might

14.3.10 Declaring Emergency / Urgency

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
14.3.10.1 Emergency (Distress)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The decision to declare an emergency rests with the Commander, after assessment of the relevant
abnormal or imminent dangerous situation.

An emergency is a condition of being threatened by serious and/or imminent danger and/or
requiring immediate assistance. Such conditions could be, but are not limited to:

The requirement to consider an immediate landing;
Loss of one engine in a twin engine aircraft;
An emergency descent;
Any uncontrollable smoke or fire situation;
Difficulties controlling the aeroplane (e.g. flight control);
One AC source remaining;
Landing with less than the planned Final Reserve fuel;
Any situation that could lead to a passenger evacuation;
Medical conditions that may require declaring emergency are cardiopulmonary arrest, severe
shock, heart attack, recurrent epileptic fits, retained placenta, unconsciousness, internal
bleeding or uncontrollable bleeding.
14.3.10.2 Urgency

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Urgency is a condition concerning the safety of an aircraft, or of a person on board, but which
does not require immediate assistance (e.g. passenger medical related issues, etc.).

NOTE There should be no reluctance to declare distress or urgency, assistance can be alerted
immediately and canceled later if appropriate.
NOTE For Distress and Urgency Radiotelephony Communication Procedures, refer to
Chapter 12.3.1 Distress and Urgency Radiotelephony Communication
Procedures.

14.3.10.3.2 Operation During Emergencies

Flight Deck Crew should indicate when a state of emergency exists; in addition, the SSR

14.3.11 Checklists

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
14.3.11.1 Checklists Usage

Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22
The use of checklists is mandatory; they shall be used before, during and after all phases of flight
and in abnormal and emergency situations, in accordance with the type specific OM Part B
instructions.

Except for the recall items, reciting the checklist from memory is strictly forbidden.

After completing any checklist, the Crew Member reading it shall call the checklist name followed
by the word (Complete) and the other Crew Member should confirm completion of the checklist
by announcing (Checklist Complete).

If a checklist is interrupted for any reason, stopped for a long time or if one of the Flight Deck
Crew is not sure where the checklist was stopped, the checklist must be restarted from the
beginning.

The following table shows which pilot calls for the checklist and which pilot reads the checklist.
Both pilots shall visually verify that each item is in the needed configuration or that the step is
done.

14.3.11.2 Checklists Priority

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
EMERGENCY CHECKLISTS shall always be performed immediately, in accordance with the

The checklists priority shall be as follows:

Failure Checklist shall be performed prior to the normal or abnormal checklist.

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
In general, both Pilots must crosscheck and confirm any FMS changes before the change is applied
or executed.

Changing the FMS setup is not allowed below 10.000 ft AGL, except in the following cases:

Immediate ATC clearance requirements;
A change of ATC departure clearance;
A change of the landing runway;
During diversion;
Any system failure that requires a change in the FMS.
NOTE After confirmation with the PF, the PM shall conduct all FMS changes below 10.000 ft
AGL

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
During flight the PF shall assume the responsibility of flight path control;
(^76) Some checklist items will be according to the area of responsibility e.g. windows, oxygen tests...etc, refer to the type specific OM
Part B.

Before the PF is engaged in any other activity (approach briefing, ATIS, PA announcement
etc.) he must transfer controls to the PM by announcing ( YOU HAVE CONTROLS ), the PM
confirms flight path control by announcing ( I HAVE CONTROLS );
The PF shall call ( I HAVE CONTROLS ) when he is ready to re-assume control of the aircraft,

watch, navigating and flying the aeroplane, at all times with his head up.
14.3.14 Flight Path Monitoring

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Any change in the current heading, altitude, flight level or speed must be announced aloud
and crosschecked by all Crew Members;
All Crew Members must ensure that the clearance has been correctly selected on the
corresponding altitude, heading or speed window;
All Crew Members must crosscheck that the above mentioned changes are reflected on the
primary flight display (PFD) and/or the navigation display (ND);
Any changes on the flight mode annunciator (FMA) must be announced and crosschecked
by all Crew Members.
14.3.15 Altitude and Height Determination

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
It is EGYPTAIR’ policy that QNH shall be used below transition levels as the sole barometric
reference to determine aircraft indicated altitudes for take-off, approach and landing;
The pressure altimeter shall be the main indicator for the determination of all altitudes or
heights AGL during the departure and approach flight phases.
NOTE When the aircraft is vectored for approach, ATC shall take into account the effect of
extremely low temperatures on the obstacle clearance altitudes. However, when radar
coverage is not available, obstacle clearance may be sharply degraded. Aircraft true
altitude is reduced by 4% per 10 °C deviation from ISA.
NOTE The PIC is the only person responsible for the overall obstacle clearance.
For more details, see Chapter 8.1 Flight Preparation Instructions.

14.3.16 Radio Altimeter Use

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The use of radio altimeters to determine "Engine Out Acceleration" is not authorized;
Radio altimeters shall only be used for the determination of CAT II ILS minima;
Aircraft with no auto-callout function installed, or if the auto-callout function is inoperative,
the PM shall call the first readout of the radio altimeter by announcing:
(RADIO ALTIMETER ALIVE)

14.3.17 Engine-out Acceleration Height

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
800 ft AGL shall be used as EGYPTAIR’ minimum flap retraction height for engine out acceleration,
unless a higher altitude is required for obstacle clearance.

14.3.18 Maneuvering Height

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
When no constraints are dictated by ATC, 800 ft AGL shall be used as EGYPTAIR’ policy for
maneuvering height after take-off during normal operations;
Turns may be conducted below 800 ft AGL, only when deemed necessary to comply with
SIDs, noise abatement procedures, or obstacle clearance constraints;
15 degrees bank angle shall be used until clearing 400 ft AGL.
14.3.19 Action Height

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
400 ft AGL shall be used as EGYPTAIR’ action height.

However, it is the Commander's responsibility to take all necessary actions to maintain safe flight
path control at any height after take-off.

14.3.20 Fuel Jettisoning

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
5.000 ft AGL is the minimum height for fuel jettisoning;
Racetrack holding patterns should be avoided during fuel jettisoning, unless otherwise
instructed by ATC.
14.3.21 Flight Deck Door

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Flight Deck door must be closed and locked during all phases of flight;
During Cabin Crew briefing, the Captain shall agree with the Cabin Crew on a signal for their
identification;
Positive identification and forward area check should be established before opening the
Flight Deck door (e.g. through the eyehole or identification cameras);
Flight deck door must be closed and locked when any member of the flight deck crew is
outside the Flight deck; and a minimum of two crew members (i.e., one flight deck crew and
one cabin crew member) shall be in the flight deck.
NOTE For more details, see Chapter 8.3.13.1 Flight Deck Door Principles.
NOTE Door Area from either pilots’ seats should be monitored at all times.
If the video surveillance system on both pilots seats is U/S, the presence in the Flight
Deck of an additional crew member during all phases of the flight is mandatory.
NOTE For cargo aircraft, refer to Cargo Appendix item Flight Deck Door.

14.3.23 Critical Phases of Flight (Sterile Flight Deck / DND)

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Critical Phases of Flight

Critical Phases of Flight means the take-off run, the take-off flight path, the final approach, the
missed approach, the landing, including the landing roll, and any other phases of flight as
determined by the Pilot-in-Command or Commander.

(Sterile Flight Deck / DND):

(Sterile Flight Deck / DND) include all ground and flight operations involving pushback, engine
start, taxi out, take-off, landing, taxi in and engines shut down. In addition, all other flight
operations conducted below 10.000 ft AGL or any other phases deemed by the Commander.

NOTE For the interest of safety and to avoid crew distraction, during Sterile Flight Deck
(DND) dead head crew must limit the time of their courtesy visits to the Flight Deck.
However, it is the Commander's responsibility to stop any distraction and to maintain a
safety oriented Flight Deck atmosphere during all flight phases.
Two policies should be enforced during the critical phases of flight:

Sterile Flight Deck

It is a Flight Deck free from any interruptions or unrelated conversations during the critical
phases of flight;
All conversations between the Flight Deck Crew during these phases must be related to the
safe conduct of the flight;
Cabin Crew Members are not allowed to call or enter the Flight Deck during these phases,
except for matters affecting the safe operation of the flight;
The Purser/SCC shall, in due time, report (CABIN SECURE) physically or via the intercom
system, unless the aircraft is equipped with a Cabin Ready function;
Smoking cigarettes, drinking or eating is strictly forbidden during the critical phases of flight.
NOTE All Crew Members shall strictly adhere to the Sterile Flight Deck policy.
Do Not Disturb (DND)

The DND policy is designed to meet the provisions of Sterile Flight Deck.

DND During Departure:
Shall commence at the start of push back or engine start;
Shall end when the SEAT BELT sign is switched OFF during climb at 10.000 ft AGL.
NOTE If the SEAT BELT sign must remain on due to turbulence, the seat belt shall
be recycled so as to give two sound chimes indicating the end of DND.

NOTE All Cabin Crew inquiries and requests (destination weather, wheel chairs,

before the start of descend.

be done using intercom, unless it is in the interest of safety to physically enter the
cockpit.

14.3.26 Crew Meals / Refreshments on the Flight Deck

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The PIC and the SIC shall not have the same meal nor tray and shall not consume their
meals at the same time;
Crew Members are not allowed to have their meals during climb or descend;
Drinks and meal trays must be handed directly to the pilots and not left unattended on the
flight deck;
Beverages should be served separately from the meal and should not be passed over the
central pedestal area to avoid spillage and consequential damage to electronics;
Cabin Crew shall serve drinks via window side i.e. to the PIC from the left side and to the SIC
from the right side;
All beverages should be served 2/3 of the cup to avoid spillage;
Drinks served on the flight deck must be wrapped with a napkin;
All catering items shall be removed from the flight deck before take-off and landing and
cleared during the flight as necessary.
For additional information, refer to Chapter 8.2.2.17.5 Flight Deck Housekeeping.

14.3.27 Turbulence

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
When turbulence is expected or encountered during any phase of flight, the Commander shall
apply the following procedures:

Turn ON the SEAT BELT sign. In this case the Cabin Crew may continue meals and/or
beverages service in the cabin;
When deemed necessary by the Commander, he shall recycle the SEAT BELT sign OFF/ON to
give an indication to the Cabin Crew to stop service and, if the situation permits, secure the
passenger cabin and inform the Purser/SCC, who shall in turn inform the Commander, via
INTERCOM, that the cabin is secured. In this case, the Commander should brief the Purser/
SCC of the nature and expected duration of the turbulence.
NOTE During severe turbulence, Cabin Crew shall not attempt to secure the cabin and It is
imperative that they sit down immediately on the nearest available seat, fit full harness
or fasten seat belt when using a passenger seat or sit on the floor secured to seat
structure/bulkhead.
14.3.28 Lookout / Flight Deck Sunshades

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Flight Deck Crew shall maintain a constant lookout and avoid other traffic during all phases
of flight;
For the interest of safety, Flight Deck Crew Members are required to use the sunshades
provided by the manufacturer. Covering the flight deck windows with newspapers or any
other materials that might obscure vision is strictly forbidden;
Flight Deck Crew Members are required to continuously monitor the TCAS display.

14.3.29 Leaving Flight Deck during Flight

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Flight Deck Crew Members are only permitted to leave their duty stations in the performance of
duties in connection with the operation or to meet physiological needs.

The Flight Deck Crew Member leaving his duty station must ensure that:

Minimum of two crew members (i.e., one flight deck crew and one cabin crew member) are
in the flight deck.
The remaining active Flight Deck Crew Member:

Has unobstructed access to the flight controls;
Is aware of the flight situation and fuel status;
Is alert and ready to take-over controls; and
Makes sure the Flight Deck door is closed, locked and is not obstructed by any means.
The remaining Flight Deck Crew Member must remain in his assigned duty station with his:

Seat Belt and shoulder harness fastened; and
Headset on.
When the absent Flight Deck Crew Member returns to his duty station, he shall be briefed about
the current flight status.

Except for duties in connection with the operation, visiting the Mid/Aft sections of the aircraft is
forbidden.

An active Flight Deck Crew Member who intentionally stays outside the Flight Deck for prolonged
periods of time is committing a serious safety violation.

Flight Deck Crew Members deviating from the above rules shall be subjected to disciplinary action.

CAUTION No person other than the active Flight Deck Crew Members shall occupy designated
pilots seats.
NOTE For cargo aircraft, refer to Cargo Appendix item Leaving Flight Deck during Flight.
14.3.30 Augmented and Double Crew

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
To extend the duty time limitation of long-range operations, an additional Captain or F/O
(augmented crew), or an additional complete Flight Deck Crew (double crew), shall be
added to the standard crew complement. Also, an additional number of Cabin Crew
Members may be added to the standard Cabin Crew complement, in accordance with the
provisions of ECARs;
A Commander and a SIC shall be assigned for each augmented or double crew flight sector
and shall be called the Operating Crew;
The Commander of the flight shall be responsible for all decisions affecting the safe
operation of the flight, even during his rest period;
The operating crew shall perform take-off and landing for the assigned flight sector;
The additional crew is called the Cruise Crew;

Should a situation develop during flight (major system failure, destination weather
deterioration, etc) that must be brought to the attention of the Commander during his rest
period, the cruise crew shall apply the required immediate actions or procedures, if any, to
maintain full control of the situation. The Commander must be immediately notified with
the situation and all available information;
In case of augmented crew, and in the interest of safety, it is strictly forbidden to divide the
flight time between the two Captains without allowing the F/O to take his legal rest period;
In case of augmented or double crew, allowing Crew Members to rest is a very important
safety issue; therefore, it is the Commander's responsibility to insure strict enforcement of
crew rest periods during long-range operation;
The augmented and double crew rest period must be applied for all Flight Deck and Cabin
Crew, even if one of the flight sectors is within the limits of one crew's duty period. Any
deviation from the above rule shall be considered a serious safety violation;
Approximately 10 to 15 minutes shall be allocated as an overlap period between any crew
changes for briefing.
The briefing shall include, but is not limited to the following items:
ATC clearance and ATC constraints, if any;
Fuel remaining compared to the OFP calculations;
En-route, destination, and alternate weather reports;
Aircraft technical status;
Special loads;
Any additional information relevant to the optimum operation of the flight.
Before transferring controls and in order to leave the Pilot seat, the Pilot leaving has to
ensure that the remaining Pilot is alert and ready to take-over.
NOTE The above work and duty period distribution must be in full compliance with the
requirements of Chapter 7 Flight Time Limitations for each flight sector in question.
Should a conflict arise, it is the responsibility of the fleet's chief Pilot to issue a written
duty and rest time distribution for the particular flight sector, in compliance with the
regulation.

Under normal circumstances, the Cabin Crew shall not leave the aircraft when any
passenger remains on board;
When a crew change is due to take place and the new crew has not arrived at the aircraft

The number of Cabin Crew that must remain on board is at least the minimum number of
Cabin Crew required, according to the aircraft type, see Chapter 4.3.3.1 Minimum Cabin

The Cabin Crew shall be spaced throughout the cabin, to provide the most effective

14.3.32 Drift Down Policy

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
As a general policy, the drift down speed, resulting from the FMS calculations shall initially
be used to initiate the drift down procedure;
To satisfy EDTO regulations and to reduce time to alternate, use Company Drift Down
Speed (Boeing) or Long Range Cruise Speed (Airbus), provided that:
Drift down altitude is higher than the obstacle clearance altitude;
No traffic is conflicting with the aircraft flight path.
14.3.33 Reduced Thrust Take-off

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilizing less thrust than the engines
are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude.

The primary advantage to a reduced thrust take-off is cost savings through increased engine life
and reduced overhaul costs.

Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be
possible to increase the maximum take-off weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust
profile.

There are two methods of achieving an accurately controlled reduction in engine thrust:

De-rate; and
Assumed/Flex temperature.
De-rate

De-rate reduces the rated thrust of the engine to either one or more pre-specified values or by a
selectable percentage of the normal flat rated thrust, to the type specific OM Part B.

Critical speeds such as V MCG and VMCA differs from those associated with full rated thrust.

CAUTION When using De-Rate power, it is strictly forbidden to increase engine thrust by
canceling the De-rate.
Assumed/Flex Temperature

For assumed/flex temperature, the full thrust values of V MCG and VMCA must be considered limiting
since the full rated thrust for the actual OAT can be commanded by moving the thrust levers
appropriately.

NOTE Both de-rate and assumed temperature can be used simultaneously.
NOTE When using de-rate and/or assumed/flex for take-off, use FMS reduced climb thrust, if
applicable.
NOTE It is EGYPTAIR’ policy to use the maximum reduced thrust for take-off, if applicable.
POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES
14.3 General Standard Operating Procedures (GSOP)

Reduced thrust take-off should not be used in adverse operating conditions such as:

Runway surface conditions are adversely affected (e.g. snow, slush, ice etc..);
Visibility is less than 1.900 meters;
Crosswind component, including gusts, exceeds 15 kts;
Tail wind component, including gusts, exceeds 5 kts;
Windshear has been reported or forecasted, or when adverse weather conditions (e.g.
Thunderstorms) are expected to affect the departure.
14.3.34 Noise Abatement Procedures

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
Nothing in this procedure shall prevent the Pilot-in-Command from exercising authority for the
safe operation of the aeroplane. Safety has priority over noise abatement.

NOTE Unless otherwise stated for a specific airport PIC shall use either NADP1 or NADP2.
NADP1
Procedure Alleviating Noise Close to the Aerodrome

This procedure involves a power or thrust reduction at or above the prescribed minimum altitude
(800 ft above aerodrome elevation) and the delay of flap/slat retraction until the prescribed
maximum altitude is attained. At the prescribed maximum altitude (3.000 ft above aerodrome
elevation), the aircraft is accelerated and the flaps/slats are retracted on schedule while
maintaining a positive rate of climb, to complete the transition to normal en-route climb speed.
The initial climbing speed to the noise abatement initiation point is not less than V 2 + 10 kts.

In the graphic below, on reaching an altitude 800 ft above aerodrome elevation, engine power or
thrust is adjusted in accordance with the noise abatement power thrust schedule provided in the
aircraft operating manual. A climb speed of V 2 + 10 to 20 kts is maintained with flaps and slats in
the take-off configuration. On reaching an altitude of 3.000 ft above aerodrome elevation, the
aircraft is accelerated and the flaps/slats are retracted on schedule while maintaining a positive
rate of climb to complete the transition to normal en-route climb speed.

POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES
14.3 General Standard Operating Procedures (GSOP)
OM A
14-3-19
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
NADP 2
Procedure Alleviating Noise Distant From the Aerodrome

This procedure involves initiation of flap/slat retraction at or above the prescribed minimum
altitude (800 ft above aerodrome elevation) but before reaching the prescribed maximum altitude
(3.000 ft above aerodrome elevation). The flaps/slats are to be retracted on schedule while
maintaining a positive rate of climb. Intermediate flap retraction, if required for performance, may
be accomplished below the prescribed minimum altitude. The power or thrust reduction is initiated
at a point along the acceleration segment that ensures satisfactory acceleration performance. At
the prescribed maximum altitude, a transition is made to normal en-route climb procedures. The
initial climbing speed to the noise abatement initiation point is not less than V 2 + 10 kts.

In the graphic below, on reaching 800 ft above aerodrome elevation, the aircraft body angle/angle
of pitch is decreased, the aeroplane is accelerated towards VZF and the flaps/slats are retracted on
schedule. Power or thrust reduction is initiated at a point along the acceleration segment that
ensures satisfactory acceleration performance. A positive rate of climb is maintained to 3.000 ft
above aerodrome elevation. On reaching this altitude, a transition is made to normal en-route
climb speed.

14.3.35 Company Speed Restrictions

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
A disciplined speed control is mandatory for the economy and safety of flight operations.
Exceeding the speed limits detailed in the type specific OM Part B is totally prohibited.

During Taxi

Unless otherwise stated as a limitation in the aircraft type OM Part B, maximum taxi speeds shall
be as follows:

Straight taxiing: Up to 30 kts
Wide turns (less than 90°): Up to 20 kts
Tight turns (90° or more): Up to 10 kts
Wet/Contaminated runways: Up to 10 kts
Low visibility: Up to 10 kts
NOTE When backtracking or taxiing on a runway, the above speed limits shall apply.
NOTE SIC shall alert the PIC of any taxi speed exceedance.
During Climb

The maximum speed below 5.000 ft AGL shall be limited to 250 kts;
After passing 5.000 ft AGL, and unless otherwise instructed by ATC, the aircraft shall be
accelerated to Best Rate Climb Speed (Boeing) or Economy Speed (Airbus).
During Cruise

FMS Economy Speed, resulting from the variable cost index indicated on the OFP, shall be
used, unless otherwise instructed by ATC.

During Descend

Unless otherwise instructed by ATC:

The descend speed schedule indicated in the type specific OM Part B shall be used;
The maximum speed below 10.000 ft AGL shall be limited to 250 kts.
NOTE The maximum speed limit of 250 kts is mandatory below 5.000 ft AGL.
14.3.36 Policy for Handling Abnormal Situations

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Circuit Breakers

On-ground:
Flight Deck Crew may re-engage tripped circuit breakers, provided that the action is
coordinated with maintenance, and the cause of the tripped circuit breaker is identified.
In-flight:
Flight Deck Crew should not re-engage tripped circuit breakers, unless in the Commander's
judgment, and for the safe continuation of the flight, it is necessary to do so.
Flight Deck Crew cycling (pulling and resetting) of circuit breakers to clear abnormal conditions is
not recommended unless directed by a checklist.

For circuit breaker restrictions and procedures, refer to the respective OM Part B.

Critical Aeroplane System Controls

Whenever an abnormal procedure dictates the operation of critical aeroplane system controls,
these switches shall only be operated after verbal confirmation of the PF that the PM, for the
operation of the correct control or switch before the execution of the checklist item.

Critical system controls, in this context, are:

Engine thrust levers;
Fuel master and control switches;
Engine fire handles and switches;
IDG/CSD disconnect switch; and
IRS switches.

14.3.41 Calculated Take-off Time

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
The CFMU issues delays by means of a CTOT, also known as slot time. The slot time is
actually a period of time within which take-off has to take place; it is defined between ‑5
and +10 minutes from the CTOT;
If a slot is missed (or if it is already certain in advance that it will be missed), CFMU assigns a
new one. A different aircraft which has a slot because of the same regulation, may be issued
an improvement on its slot. The slot and any revisions are communicated to the aircraft
operator as well as the air traffic control unit at the departure airport;
Commanders should plan the departure of their flights so that the aircraft will be ready for
start in sufficient time to comply with the exact CTOT.
NOTE CTOT = EOBT + Expected Taxi Time;
For aircraft exempted from the CTOT, ATC has a tolerance for any scheduled departure; of
+/‑ 15 minutes, called departure tolerance window. Although the departure tolerance
window is not considered a slot time, yet it should always be monitored by Pilots.

14.3.42 SAFA / Authority Inspections

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
The inspector(s) should identify themselves to the Commander, or in his absence, to a member of
the Flight Deck Crew or to the most senior representative of EGYPTAIR, prior to commencing the
inspection.

At outstations, as soon as practical, Flight Deck Crew shall advise the handling agent that an
inspection is being conducted.

Crew Members shall cooperate with the inspectors to complete the inspection as quickly as
possible in order to minimize delay.

Upon completion of the inspection, a Proof of Inspection (POI) form will be completed by the
inspectors, and it shall be signed by the Commander.

The SAFA program requires that the inspectors provide the Commander with a copy of the form,
and if not provided, it shall be requested by the Commander.

If findings are raised as a result of the inspection, rectification or deferral may be necessary before
departure.

When a SAFA or Authority inspection has been conducted, the commander shall complete the
following actions:

All technical/airworthiness findings shall be entered in the Aircraft Technical Log before
departure, and prefixed with the text "SAFA Inspection Defect" or "Authority Inspection
Defect", and either rectified or deferred in accordance with the established procedures;
If no technical findings have been raised as a result of the inspection, no technical log entry
is required;
A Captain Report shall be completed to record the event and shall be returned, with the
Proof of Inspection form, in the flight envelope;
A copy/picture of the proof of inspection form (POI) shall be sent to the Chief Pilot via
mobile or email as soon as possible
NOTE Comprehensively completing the Ramp Inspection Guide (Flight deck and Cabin) is
mandatory before each sector.

14.4.1.4.1 Fuel Docket and Dispatch Release

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The Commander is responsible for the correct filling of the relevant Fuel Docket/Dispatch Release
sections and should adhere to the below guidelines:

If the EZFW is not provided, enter the EZFW from the latest issued OFP;
RTOW must be calculated and recorded on the fuel docket.
NOTE RTOW is the maximum weight at which an aircraft can take off from a particular
runway under specific conditions e.g. winds, weather, specific aircraft
configuration...etc.
When filling the Fuel Docket, the RTOW for a particular flight sector is determined by
comparison of:
Maximum zero fuel weight plus take-off fuel;
Maximum weight for take-off;
Maximum landing weight plus trip fuel.
The lowest figure of 1., 2. and 3. is the maximum permitted take-off weight.
In the Fuel Docket, Enter the Crew Complement based on the planned crew seat
assignments at take-off. The Crew complement will be reflected on the Load and Trim sheet;
Both Flight Deck Crew Members must cross-check and compare the values of the Fuel
Docket / Dispatch Release against the OFP;
If corrections are required, a new Fuel Docket / Dispatch Release form must be completed;
Avoid crossing or writing over previous figures;
Write clear and legible numbers, the use of BLOCK letters is preferred; and
Review Briefing package crew bulletin.

14.4.1.5 Commander / Cabin Crew Briefing
Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The main objective of the Cabin Crew briefing (Joint Briefing) is to enhance team spirit
between the Flight Deck and Cabin Crew, which in turn has a positive impact on the overall
safety of the flight;
The Commander of the flight must conduct a Cabin Crew briefing before the first departure
of the day;
Due to the special nature of EGYPTAIR operations and its large network, it might be difficult
to allocate a specific place to conduct Cabin Crew briefings;
Briefings may be conducted in, but are not limited to, the following places:
Briefing rooms;
Business class area, in this case it should not interfere with pre-flight activity and shall be
completed before passenger boarding;
Suitable place before leaving the hotel, if transit passengers are expected to be on
board.
When Flight Deck Crew and Cabin Crew are not following the same flight schedule and
transit passengers are on board, or for any unforeseen circumstances, the Commander shall
brief the Purser / SCC, who in turn shall brief the rest of the Cabin Crew;
Emergency code for Flight Deck door opening must be communicated to the Purser / SCC
before the flight.
As a part of the crew briefing the commander shall ensure that all crew members aware and
have the latest updates of the manuals.
The briefing shall contain, but is not limited to the following:
a. Flight Crew introduction;

b. State clearly the main objective of the briefing (ONE TEAM – ONE CREW);

c. Indicate the chain of command and crew roles (such as for Augmented Crew operation, Flight
Crew rest strategy, etc.);

d. Expected taxi time before take-off;

e. Expected flight time(s) and cruise altitudes;

f. Expected weather conditions including periods of turbulence;

g. Policy to access the flight deck;

h. Any flight duty or layover related security requirements, as needed;

i. Any other normal/non-normal procedures;

j. Review security procedures i.e hijacking.

NOTE The Commander shall assure that the briefing is not an oral test and allocate 7 minutes
for the cabin crew briefing.

any Crew Member shall be considered a serious safety violation;
Flight Deck Crew Members shall arrive at the aeroplane at least 50 minutes before the
expected time of departure;

14.4.1.7 Emergency Systems / Equipment Inspection

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Prior to the first flight, Flight Deck Crew Members shall inspect the availability, accessibility and
serviceability of aircraft flight deck emergency systems and equipment. In addition, this inspection
shall be conducted if the aircraft has been left unattended by the Flight Deck Crew for any period
of time.

14.4.1.8 Maintenance Release

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew Members are not allowed to start their pre-flight duties unless the aircraft
is released for flight by maintenance;
Flight Deck Crew Members must check the technical logbook, Deferred Defects Log and if
required the MEL and CDL;
The aircraft shall be under the responsibility of maintenance personnel until the technical
logbook is signed and the aircraft is released for flight;
If during pre-flight preparation, or upon arrival at destination, a defect is found:
The Commander must conduct a technical logbook entry, with the time of the entry
noted beside the defect, and the technical logbook must be signed ́;
After the Commander signs the technical logbook, the aircraft is handed over to
maintenance personnel until the technical defect is cleared, the technical log is signed
(PDC) and the aircraft is airworthy for flight;
When the maintenance personnel signs the Technical Logbook (PDC) and the aircraft
status is within the provisions of the MEL, The Commander shall resume responsibility of
the aircraft.
At outside stations, where crew remains onboard for the return flight, it is the Commander's
responsibility to facilitate the maintenance personnel duties, preferably from the observer
seat, provided that the position at which the maintenance engineer is seated, allows
adequate accessibility to all necessary equipment to perform the required checks.
CAUTION It is strictly forbidden for any Crew Member to interfere or interact with the
maintenance personnel (e.g. starting engines for trouble shooting).
NOTE To report technical defects at home base, use Maintenance Control Center frequency
131.8 MHz.
In unforeseen situation, the commander may sign the airplane for transit check under the
following conditions:

Approval required per case from ECAA through IOCC;
If no engineer is present in unforeseen situations, example En-route diversion;

14.4.1.9 Seat Adjustment and Check

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Seat positioning and the correct eye height are significant factors that affect the visual
segment during operations; therefore, it is mandatory that Pilots have their seats correctly
adjusted in accordance with the markers located on the flight deck for this purpose, refer to
the type specific OM Part B;
Forward and aft manual seat adjustment must be checked before the first departure of the
day.
14.4.1.10 Flight Deck Pre-flight Procedures

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The Commander of the flight is responsible for preventing any kind of interference that
might distract the Flight Deck Crew from performing their duties during pre-flight
preparation, therefore, it is imperative that the Flight Deck door remains closed and locked
during this phase;
The security checklist items has to be carried out by the SIC and signed by the Commander;
The SIC shall carry out power up procedures, in accordance with the type specific OM Part
B;
The SIC shall obtain the ATIS and review the expected departure, runway and weather data
with the PlC;
Scan flow and all required checks must be performed as stated in the type specific OM Part
B;
FASTEN SEAT BELT and NO SMOKING signs shall be set ON, for all aircraft types, regardless
of the automatic function of the switches;
The PIC shall check that the fuel on board corresponds to the requested fuel;
The PIC must obtain clearance from ground personnel before pressurizing any hydraulic
system;
To increase APU lifetime, it is highly recommended to use ground equipment i.e. air
conditioning and ground power units;
Unless otherwise prescribed by local authorities:
If the airconditioning unit is connected to the aircraft, the APU should be started 10
minutes before the expected time of departure;
If no airconditioning unit is available, the APU should be started before passengers
boarding.
NOTE For PlC and SIC areas of responsibility, see Chapter 14.6.1.1 On-ground.

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24

14.4.1.12 Waypoints Check

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Flight plans activated in the navigation system shall be checked by both Pilots waypoint by
waypoint against the OFP.

The following procedures shall be used:

The SIC shall complete the insertion of waypoints in FMS in accordance with the OFP;
The PlC must double-check that the total FMS flight plan distance and OFP distance are
within an acceptable margin. The difference should be within the margin of departure and
arrival routing;
The PlC must double-check that the OFP is in compliance with the ATC flight plan.
North Atlantic Waypoint Check

In addition to the above:

Check that the track message and Track Message Identification (TMI) are correct;
Check that the ATC flight plan and the OFP on North Atlantic track waypoint coordinates
are in compliance with the selected Atlantic tracks;
The PlC and SIC must separately double check the FMS and OFP North Atlantic track
waypoint coordinates, and that the track/distance between the waypoints are correctly
inserted.

The most important principle governing the performance of all navigation tasks is redundancy, as

Whether navigating on manually tuned navigation aid, automatic navigation system or while being
radar vectored, crosschecking of the primary aids is essential.

Notwithstanding the overall responsibility of the Commander for precise navigation and proper
use of the navigation system, the PF will direct the PM to set the required navigation aids. The PM

Any missing or inoperative emergency equipment item must be immediately reported to

14.4.1.17 Take-off Briefing

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Take-off briefing General guidelines:

a. Take-off briefing must be conducted before each leg, Normally after the completion of the
flight deck preparation and before engine start;

b. Take-off briefing should focus on the identification of threats that might affect the intended
operations and agreement on mitigation of those threats as it is an integral element of the
threat and error management process;

c. Commanders are required to enhance team spirit by encouraging SICs to indicate any
deviations from GSOPs or SOPs, and to encourage them to ask questions for the clarification
of any confusion or misunderstanding;

d. Low visibility taxiing and take-off briefings must be conducted when LVP are in force or
anticipated;

e. The briefing shall start without the load sheet;

14.4.2.2 Push Back and Engine Start

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Entry door(s) shall only be closed upon Commander's permission. The Purser/SCC shall not
report “READY TO MOVE” and request the “CLEAREANCE TO CLOSE DOOR(S)” unless all
passengers are seated, cabin baggage are securely stowed in permitted stowage
compartments and overhead bins are closed. This is to ensure passengers’ safety prior to

the Ground Personnel confirms via Interphone that Handling Operations COMPLETED,

start;

clearance;
Before push back, the PlC shall use standard phraseology when communicating with the
Ground Personnel, see Chapter 14.7 Standard Callouts ;
The PlC shall start his clock for Chocks off elapsed time from the start of push back;
