14.4.3 Taxiing SOPs

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Taxiing is considered one of the highest risk phases of the flight; therefore it is mandatory to
strictly adhere to the following provisions:

Aircraft taxiing shall be conducted in accordance with EGYPTAIR SOPs and the type specific
OM Part B;
A complete taxi briefing must be conducted before all departures. Two sets of taxi charts
must be used during all taxi operations, if applicable;
Only Commanders are permitted to taxi the aeroplanes;
Upon the request of the PlC, the SIC will obtain the taxi clearance;
Before commencing taxi, Flight Deck Crew must ensure that their respective left and right
areas around the aircraft, within their field of vision, are clear from ground personnel,
ground equipment or any other obstacles. This confirmation will normally be signalled by
the ground person holding the steering by-pass pin with one hand for the Flight Deck Crew
to see, and giving a thumbs-up signal with his other hand;
POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES
14.4 Flight Phases
OM A
14-4-16

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Ground Maneuvering Camera system should be switched ON before commencing taxi and
switched OFF before take-off, if applicable;
SIC must cross-check that the PlC has selected VHF No.1 on the left audio selector panel
before taxiing;
Yellow taxi lines or green taxi lights must be closely followed. Cutting corners during turns
sharply reduces wing tip obstacle clearance and shall be considered a serious safety
violation;
Taxiway stop bars are a series of unidirectional amber lights embedded in the pavement, at
right angles to the taxiway centreline;
Runway stop bars are a series of unidirectional red lights embedded in the pavement, at
right angles to the taxiway centreline, at the associated runway holding position;
Stop bars are intended to provide additional protection of runway/taxiway intersections and
to reduce runway/taxiway incursions;
While on the manoeuvring area, the aircraft shall be stopped to hold at all runway holding
positions, unless otherwise authorized by ATC;
While on the manoeuvring area, the aircraft shall be stopped to hold at all lighted stop bars
and may only proceed further when the lights are switched off, unless otherwise authorized
by ATC;
The SIC must closely monitor taxi routing, and must inform the PIC immediately if he
doubts that they are not following the prescribed routing;
If any doubt exists, the PIC must stop the aircraft and ask for progressive taxi instructions or
“Follow Me” assistance;
Any means of distraction is strictly forbidden during taxiing. Total crew concentration is
required for traffic awareness, amended clearances and taxi routing, etc.;
If amended clearance requires significant FMS changes, performance calculations or
configuration changes etc., the Commander shall not start nor continue taxiing, unless the
required changes and a complete new taxi briefing have been carried out;
If the visual cues are lost at any time, the PIC shall stop the aircraft and ask for “Follow Me”
assistance;
During taxi-in operations, engine out taxi shall be conducted in accordance with type
specific OM Part B or fleet bulletins except in the following cases:
Aircraft with technical condition i.e. APU inoperative, hydraulic failure, etc.;
Local Airport restrictions;
Aircraft is crossing active runway;
Taxiways and Aprons are wet, slippery or contaminated;
Icing conditions exists;
Low Visibility operations;
The crew is not familiar with the airport.
NOTE For Visual Ground Signals and Marshalling Signals, refer to Chapter 12.5.2.2 Visual
Ground Signals , Chapter 12.5.3 Marshalling Signals and OM Part C.
CAUTION In order to prevent the unintentional movement of the aircraft, the parking brake shall
be set whenever the aeroplane is brought to a complete stop.
NOTE See Chapter 8.3.22 Prevention of Runway Incursions.

14.4.3.1 Approaching the Departure Runway

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Both Pilots must review and check at least the following items:
Flaps setting;
De-Rate engine thrust setting and/or Assumed/Flex temperature;
The first waypoint and the departure runway on the ND;

14.4.4 Take-off

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The PlC should use, as much as possible, all available runway length and line-up the aircraft
on runway centerline before starting the take-off roll;
NOTE Before commencing take-off, any losses due to runway alignment shall be
considered.
Before commencing take-off, the PlC shall announce ( TAKE-OFF );
The SIC shall start his elapsed time from the start of take-off roll;
The PIC, acting as PF or PM, shall set take-off thrust and must keep his hand on the thrust
levers until V 1 ;
CAUTION The PIC hand is the only hand allowed to be on the thrust levers during take-off.
CAUTION The PIC must assure that the aircraft is aligned with the runway center line and
that both engines parameters are stabilized and symmetrical before setting the
Take-Off power.
When the SIC is the PF, he must keep his left hand on his left leg until the call ( V 1 );
The PM shall call ( EIGHTY/ONE HUNDRED ) according to aircraft type;
The decision to reject the take-off shall be in accordance with the provisions of the task
sharing part of this Chapter.
CAUTION Rolling take-offs are not permitted on slippery or contaminated runways, or during
low visibility procedures.

14.4.4.1 Intersection Take-off

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The full runway length should be used for take-off.

Intersection take-off may be performed if operationally advantageous (e.g., holding point blocked,
to avoid departure delay, for operations efficiency reasons, ATC requirement/request) and if there
is no significant reduction in safety margins.

14.4.5 Climb

Issue: 5-Revision: 1 - 1 OCT 21
After departure, the PM shall engage the autopilot upon the command of PF;
Switching OFF the appropriate aircraft exterior lights shall be performed upon the
completion of the respective after take-off checklist, to avoid distraction from the aircraft’s
systems and flight path monitoring;
At 10.000 ft AGL, The PM shall manually clear tuned NAV AIDS (as applicable).
NOTE Shoulder harness shall not be removed until the Commander turns off the SEAT BELT
sign.
For situational awareness, a call will be made when passing through 10.000 ft AGL on climb
and descent, announcing the altitude or flight level passing.

The called out altitude/flight level shall be amended to departure/destination altitude
+10.000 ft or +FL100.

The altitude callout shall be made when passing through the amended altitude/flight level,
followed by the SOP actions, related to the callout (e.g. lights, signs).

14.4.6 Cruise

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
During cruise, and when flight conditions permit, Flight Deck Crew are required to conduct a cruise
briefing.

The briefing should include, as a minimum, the following aspects;

Strategy in case of engine failure e.g. drift down procedures and the suitability of the en-route
alternates;
Strategy in case of cabin depressurization e.g. terrain considerations, MORA, etc.;
ATC procedures e.g. Nicosia FIR, MNPS, CPDLC, etc.

NOTE Appropriate en-route charts and escape routes shall be consulted. Refer to OM

NOTE The cruise briefing should be updated as the flight progresses and whenever
required. In addition, this briefing is also required whenever there is a transfer of
duties to the Cruise Crew.
Time, fuel and RVSM checks must be conducted throughout the flight by the SIC and
recorded on the OFP (hard copy). Those checks must be evaluated against the OFP. Time and
fuel checks shall be carried out at least once every 30 minutes or the nearest available
waypoint on the OFP in case there is no waypoint within the 30-minute interval, while RVSM
checks shall be carried out at least once every 1 hour. A written record of any significant
reclearance and deviations from planned figures, whether initiated by the Commander or
requested by ATC, shall be annotated on the OFP.
NOTE When operating even slightly off the OFP route, MORAs may no longer be
applicable.
Flight Deck Crew shall continuously monitor weather information during the en-route phase
of flight, to include current weather and forecasts for:
Destination aerodrome, destination alternate aerodrome(s), en-route alternate
aerodrome(s), as applicable;
En-route weather by the use of WX radar, especially during night flights;
For Stockholm Radio procedures, see Chapter 14.3.8.8 Stockholm Radio Procedures.
14.4.6.1 Engine Failure / Shutdown During Flight

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew should consider restarting a failed engine in accordance with the type specific
OM Part B recommendations.

It is EGYPTAIR policy that, following an engine failure/shutdown, the aircraft shall be landed at the
nearest suitable aerodrome at which a safe landing can be made, even if the engine restarts
attempt has been successfully completed.

14.4.6.2 Approach Type Selection

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew should fly the most operationally suitable approach, taking into consideration
weather conditions, that allow for the lowest available approach minima.

To reduce workload, and when the weather conditions are not a factor, Flight Deck Crew should
choose an equally safe and more efficient approach that utilises the highest level of automation.

Order Approach Type
1 Precision Approach (PA) i.e. ILS Approach
2 Approach procedure with vertical guidance (APV) e.g. LNAV / VNAV
3 Non-Precision Approach (NPA) e.g. LOC, VOR, NDB...etc
4 Visual Approach

14.4.6.3 Approach Briefing

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
a. Approach briefing shall be conducted before the end of cruise and as soon as latest
destination weather or ATIS is obtained by PM;

NOTE It is mandatory that approach briefing be completed before top of descent,
unless a change of the landing runway takes place during descent.
b. Commanders are required to enhance team spirit by encouraging SICs to indicate any
deviations from GSOPs or SOPs, and to encourage them to ask questions for the clarification
of any confusion or misunderstanding;

c. Approach briefing shall be conducted only for one instrument approach procedure for the
same landing runway. It is strictly forbidden to brief, for example, on a VOR or any other
instrument approach following an ILS approach briefing, on the assumption that the ILS signal
may fail during final approach phase of the flight;

d. Landing performance assessment shall be performed, and inserted in the FMS, EFB by the PF,
PM and crosschecked to assure sufficient landing distance exists, see Chapter 8.1.2.6
Performance Considerations – Performance Class “A” Aeroplanes ;

e. A safety briefing shall be conducted to a flight deck jump seat occupant (Oxygen, escape
route, sterile flight deck, emergency equipment location, etc.). Such safety briefing shall be
conducted by the Commander prior the sterile flight deck concept is applied;

f. The PF shall use all available resources to conduct the approach briefing, e.g. approach plates,
EFB, FMS, etc.;

g. Approach briefing should focus on the identification of threats that might affect the intended
operations and agreement on mitigation of those threats as it is an integral element of the
threat and error management process;

h. There should be a variation in the amount of detail and in the length of a briefing. A longer,
more detailed briefing may be necessary, such as in the following situations:

A flight crew not familiar with the airport or the approach;
Complex airport (e.g. CAT C);
Procedures or techniques that are rarely flown or applied.
i. A shorter briefing restricted to the minimum items is possible for example:

Operating at a well familiar airport;
Repetitive operations by the same crew;
No or limited threats identified.
NOTE For the Approach briefing refer to APPROACH BRIEFING CARD available on iPads.

14.4.7 Descent and Approach

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
14.4.7.1 Descent Below Prescribed Minimum Altitudes

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Crew shall continuously monitor navigation performance, verify aircraft position and monitor
RNP to ensure adequate terrain clearance by reference to prescribed minimum altitudes.

It is strictly prohibited to descend below the prescribed minimum altitudes (e.g. MORA, MOCA,
MSA etc.) unless:

Positive radar control is assured and the clearance has been given by ATC, radar minimum
alt chart shall be consulted if present; or
When following a published instrument approach or arrival procedure provided that:
Aircraft's position and height is positively identified;
The required visual reference has been established, see Chapter 8 Operating
Procedures.
Visual descent below MSA to the circuit altitude (1.500 ft AGL) is only permitted if the
descent can be continued so as to ensure clearance from all obstacles of the intended track,
provided that, upon reaching the circuit altitude, sufficient visual reference is maintained, if
this condition cannot be satisfied the aircraft must be climbed to the MSA immediately.
CAUTION Capturing and following an ILS glide slope is only authorized after being established
on the localizer.
14.4.7.2 Rate of Descent Restrictions

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
For the purpose of reducing terrain closure rate and increasing recognition/response time in the
event of an unintentional conflict with terrain, Flight Deck Crew shall, when operating an aircraft at
low heights AGL, restrict rates of descend as follows:

Down to an Altitude of Max. Rate of Descent
5.000 ft above terrain 4.000 ft/min
4.000 ft above terrain 4.000 ft/min
3.000 ft above terrain 3.000 ft/min
2.000 ft above terrain 2.000 ft/min
1.000 ft above terrain 1.500 ft/min
Below 1.000 ft above terrain 1.000 ft/min
NOTE Some published approach profiles may require a higher rate of descent than the
specified above. In this case, higher rates of descent are acceptable, provided the
aeroplane is in a stabilized descent when passing 1.000 ft AGL.

14.4.7.3 Approach

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew shall, before accepting an approach, review the minimum meteorological
conditions, including the visibility required to continue the approach;
Flight Deck Crew must closely monitor the approach flight path and the terrain clearance
limits;
If the weather is deteriorating during approach, especially during high workload situations,
the weather information may be requested directly from ATC;
When the aircraft is established on the final approach descent path, the PF shall review:
The GA standard callouts;
The GA flaps configuration;
The GA altitude;
The initial lateral and vertical GA profile.
NOTE The PM shall call (LOCALIZER) or (GLIDE SLOPE) when either localizer or glide slope
deviation is:
½ dot LOC;
½ dot G/S.
NOTE For the proper execution of ILS approaches, non-ILS approaches, and GA procedures,
refer to type specific OM Part B.
NOTE Circling approach is prohibited at EGYPTAIR.
14.4.7.4 Setting Missed Approach Altitude

Type of Approach When to Set the Missed Approach Altitude
Precision and Non Precision Approaches Refer to the type specific OM Part B
Visual Approach Keep Circuit Altitude
14.4.7.5 Stabilized/Low Drag Approach

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Stabilized approaches shall be conducted in the following conditions:
Tail wind;
Poor visibility;
Windshear;
High field elevation;
Non-normal aircraft procedures requiring special precautions and early final approach
speed stabilization.
NOTE Poor visibility is when visibility is less than 1.900 m;

NOTE High field elevation is when elevation is above 2.500 ft.
The basic idea of a low drag approach, is to delay approach and landing "Flaps/Gear"
configuration, until reaching a prescribed distance or height;
Whenever possible it is recommended to conduct low drag approaches to reduce engine
noise pollution, air pollution and operating costs.
NOTE For Stabilized/Low Drag Approach procedures and techniques, refer to the type
specific OM Part B.
NOTE The Pilot Monitoring (PM) should apply an effective cross-check by scanning flight
path, navigational aids, visual clues and energy management. If something does not
look right, the PM is responsible for raising the Pilot Flying’s (PF) awareness and
prepare for a possible go-around.
14.4.7.6 Non-Precision Approach (NPA)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The final segment of non-ILS (including non-precision) approaches shall be executed using the
Continuous Descent Final Approach (CDFA) technique e.g. using FPA or VNAV.

The target rate of descent (ROD) may need to be initiated prior to reaching the required descent
point, typically 0.3 NM before the descent point, dependent upon ground speed.

During descent the PM should announce crossing altitudes as published fixes and other
designated points are crossed, giving the appropriate altitude or height for the appropriate range
as depicted on the chart. The PF should promptly adjust the ROD as appropriate.

The missed approach, after an approach has been flown using CDFA technique, shall be executed
when reaching MDA plus increment or the MAP, whichever occurs first. The lateral portion of the
missed approach procedure must be flown via the MAP unless otherwise stated on the approach
chart.

NOTE An increment of 50 ft must be added to the MDA for all CDFA non-precision
approaches.
NOTE For CDFA execution, refer to the specific aircraft OM Part B.
14.4.7.7 Visual Approach

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Visual approaches shall be conducted in accordance with the visual flight pattern and procedures
contained in the type-specific OM Part B or as a part of a published RNAV to Visual Approach
procedure.

It is EGYPTAIR’ policy that; during night operations, visual approaches/visual patterns may only be
requested / carried out when:

There are no other available instrument approach procedure for the applicable runway;
It is clearly determined that the meteorological conditions are adequate for the approach;
TCAS and EGPWS are serviceable;

or
When expeditious returns following emergency or abnormal situations are mandatory.

Visual approaches are to be specifically cleared by ATC and should not be requested or

14.4.7.7.1 Visual Approach Weather Minima

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
If circling minima is published, then the cloud ceiling must be at least the MDH specified
under "CIRCLE-TOLAND" or 2.000 ft whichever is greater and the reported visibility must be
at least 5 km;
If no circling minimum is specified, then the cloud ceiling must be at least 2.000 ft and the
reported visibility must be at least 5 km.
NOTE Visual contact with the landing runway environment e.g. runway threshold, approach
lighting or any other markings must be maintained throughout the approach, and the
approach shall be discontinued if the specified visual reference is lost.
14.4.7.7.2 Visual Approach Go-around

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Unless otherwise cleared by ATC, the visual approach GA procedures shall be as follows:
Maintain runway heading until a minimum of 400 ft AGL;
Turn to downwind heading while climbing to circuit height (1,500 ft AGL);
Obtain ATC clearance for your intended course of action.
NOTE Flight Deck Crew shall confirm with ATC the missed approach procedures.
14.4.7.8 Commencement and Continuation of Approach Approach Ban

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
The Pilot-in-Command may commence an instrument approach regardless of the reported RVR/
VIS.

If the reported RVR/VIS is less than the applicable minimum the approach shall not be continued:

Below 1.000 ft above the aerodrome; or
Into the final approach segment in the case where the DA/H or MDA/H is more than 1.000
ft above the aerodrome.
Where the RVR is not available, RVR values may be derived by converting the reported visibility.

If, after passing 1.000 ft above the aerodrome, the reported RVR/VIS falls below the applicable
minimum, the approach may be continued to DA/H or MDA/H.

The approach may be continued below DA/H or MDA/H and the landing may be completed
provided that the visual reference adequate for the type of approach operation and for the
intended runway is established at the DA/H or MDA/H and is maintained.

The touchdown zone RVR shall always be controlling. If reported and relevant, the midpoint and
stop-end RVR shall also be controlling. The minimum RVR value for the midpoint shall be 125 m or
the RVR required for the touchdown zone if less, and 75 m for the stop-end. For aircraft equipped
with a rollout guidance control system, the minimum RVR value for the mid-point shall be 75 m.

Relevant in this context means that part of the runway used during the high-speed phase of the
landing down to a speed of approximately 60 kts.

NOTE For state differences, refer to OM Part C.
14.4.7.9 Orbits/360 Turns

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
Orbit/360 Turns is considered an acceptable means to lose altitude and shall only be conducted as
follows:

Under radar control and via ATC clearance;
AT or Above 1.500 AGL;
AP engaged;
Compliance with the approach stabilization criteria ensured;
Adequate terrain clearance is ensured.
14.4.7.10 Means of Stabilization

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
An approach is considered to be stable when all of the following conditions are met at the
approach gate and maintained throughout the approach:

The aircraft is on the correct flight path (the published instrument approach path or a
constant flight path angle (3°) to the touchdown point);
POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES
14.4 Flight Phases
OM A
14-4-26

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
Only small changes in heading and pitch are required to maintain the correct flight path;
Sink rate is not more than 1.000 fpm;
The aircraft is in the correct landing configuration (landing gear down and locked, landing
flaps set, and speedbrake armed);
For ILS approaches: not more than 1 dot deviation from LOC or G/S;
For NPAs: course deviation must remain within ½ dot or 2,5° for VOR approaches, and 5°
(ADF) for NDB approaches;
All briefings are conducted;
NOTE For instrument approaches the following stabilization criteria shall be achieved by
1.000  ft AAL, but may be delayed for operational reasons i.e. (ATC speed
restrictions) until 500 ft AAL if needed:
a) The aircraft speed is not more than VREF +20 kts and not less than VREF
(considering gust, windshear and ground speed mini effect);
b) Power setting is appropriate for the aircraft configuration;
c) All checklists completed.
The landing gear should be selected down not later than 1.500 ft AAL;
Unique approach procedures or abnormal conditions requiring deviation from the above
elements require a special briefing;
An instrument approach that becomes unstabilized below 1.000 ft AAL requires an immediate
go-around AND any visual approach that becomes unstabilized below 500 ft AAL requires an
immediate go-around;
The above conditions shall be maintained throughout the rest of the approach for it to be
considered a stabilized approach. If the above criteria cannot be established and maintained
until approaching the flare, initiate a go-around.
NOTE An approach in gusty conditions may be continued where airspeed and descent rate
fluctuations exceed the stabilized approach criteria if the excursions are brief and in
the judgment of the flight crew, it is safe to continue.
CAUTION EGYPTAIR has Zero tolerance for landing following an unstabilized approach, if
performed it will be considered a serious safety violation.

14.4.7.12 Missed Approach

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
For missed approach procedure, refer to the type-specific OM Part B.

The missed approach procedure is published on each approach chart;
The decision to initiate a go-around and conduct a missed approach shall be clearly
announced by the PF or PM;
Once the decision has been made to conduct a go-around, it is irrevocable and the
procedure shall be completed;
ATC shall be advised as soon as practicable;
A missed approach shall be initiated:
If the required visual reference has not been established upon reaching the applicable
landing minima;
If the aircraft reaches the Approach Ban point and the reported RVR/Vis is below the
required minima;
If at any time after descending below the applicable minima the required visual reference
cannot be maintained;
On instructions from ATC;
If the approach stabilization requirements are not achieved and maintained;
If any required element of the ground navigation system or airborne equipment
becomes inoperative or is suspected to be malfunctioning while in IMC conditions;
If it becomes apparent that the approach cannot be completed as briefed or the landing
will not be safely completed;
If communication is lost during a radar approach;
For any other reason mentioned in the type-specific OM Part B;
When deemed necessary by the Commander.
CAUTION Strictly adherence for the type specific missed approach procedures including thrust,
pitch, bank, FMA, etc.
The go-around procedure shall be followed for all engines operating and engine failure, the go-
around gradient should be covered as per performance calculations in all conditions. Refer to
14.4.6.3 Approach Briefing.

14.4.7.13 Maximum Number of Approaches

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
CAUTION While applying the below policy, it is the Commander's responsibility to fully comply
with and consider the provisions of Chapter 8.3.8.2 In-flight Fuel Management
Following a go-around or a missed approach, it is the Commander's responsibility to determine if
a subsequent approach is to be conducted to the same aerodrome.

If a second approach is unsuccessful, the aircraft should divert to the destination alternate.

A third approach may only be attempted, if the commander is certain that a safe landing can be
achieved, provided the following conditions are met:

Reported ceiling and/or visibility represent an improvement from the previous reports;

14.4.8 Landing

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Landings shall be manually performed; however, autoland may be performed provided that
the provisions of Chapter 8.4 All Weather Operations and the type specific OM Part B are
applied;
Ground speed shall be scanned during approach and landing;
Maintain centerline, wings level, constant indicated airspeed and with an approximate ROD of
700 to 900 fpm, until the correct flare height;
High or continuous flare and floating, rapidly depletes the available runway. Using the above
technique for intentional smooth touchdown is strictly forbidden;
Immediately after main landing gear touch down, the PM must verify auto speed brake/
spoiler deployment;
Without delay, fly the nose wheel to the ground, holding the nose might result in a tail strike;
Use of autobrakes is highly recommended;
Reverse thrust other than idle shall not be used, the use of full reverse thrust is mandatory
when:
Landing with Failures;
A tailwind is present;
The LDA is less than 2.500 m.
CAUTION Pilots shall use maximum reverse thrust at any time it deems necessary for safety
reasons.
Pilots shall aim for touchdown on the runway touchdown zone markings or at a point
approximately 300 m down the runway from the landing threshold where such markings do
not exist;
Landing shall be made within the touch down zone. If not, a go-around should normally
be initiated with due regard to the remaining runway length;
If a valid aeroplane system generated alert, such as Runway Overrun Warning (ROW),
Runway Awareness Advisory System (RAAS) alert or similar, occurs, a go-around shall be
conducted.
It is strictly forbidden to select brake fans ON during the landing roll. Brake fans shall be
selected ON after clearing the active runway, if applicable.
NOTE See Chapter 8.3.23 Approach and Landing General Considerations.
NOTE Land and Hold Short Operations (LAHSO) shall be refused if requested by ATC.
Overweight Landing

Every effort should be made to land at or below the Maximum Structural Landing Weight
(MLW);
POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES
14.4 Flight Phases

14-4-29
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

In exceptional conditions, the Commander may decide to perform an overweight landing,
provided the crew applies the respective type-specific procedures of the OM Part B. He shall
consider the overall risk of an overweight landing to the safety of the aeroplane, including the
required maintenance actions prior to the next departure. An overweight landing with the
respective actual landing weight shall be documented in the Aircraft Technical Log;
In the absence of an abnormal/non-normal situation, fuel jettison shall not be considered
without IOCC approval.
Hard Landing

Only the Commander shall determine if a landing shall be classified as a hard landing. ATL entry
shall be made using the term “Hard Landing”.

In case of a hard landing is suspected; the Commander shall make an ATL entry using the term
“Hard Landing suspected” to ensure the aircraft is airworthy.

If the hard landing has been confirmed, an ASR shall be filed also.

NOTE The above procedures fall under the non-punitive policy umbrella.

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
At taxi speed and after clearing the active runway, the PIC shall select speed brake lever to

After selecting the speed brake lever down, the SIC shall carry out the after landing

Ground Maneuvering Camera system should be switched ON, if applicable.

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21

To save the APU lifetime, the APU should be shut down 5 minutes after the ground power
unit is connected to the aircraft, and the APU is no longer needed.
NOTE At home base, complete securing of the aircraft shall be carried out, e.g. APU shut
down and batteries switched OFF, before leaving the aircraft.

14.5 ELECTRONIC FLIGHT BAG (EFB)

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
14.5.1 Introduction

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
This section contains policies, guidance and procedures for the use of portable EFBs and installed
EFBs (Electronic Flight Bags).

14.5.2 Definitions

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24 (A)
EFB Electronic display system intended primarily for flight deck
member use that includes the hardware and software necessary
to support an intended function. EFB devices can display a
variety of aviation data or perform basic calculations (e.g.,
performance data, fuel calculations, etc.).
Installed EFB Fixed and integrated to the aircraft avionics and information
systems (by the airplane manufacturer), has received type
design approval and is installed in accordance with applicable
airworthiness regulations.
Portable EFB Portable electronic devices (PED) that are not mounted to the
aircraft, connected to aircraft systems for data, or connected to
a dedicated aircraft power supply. However, they can be
temporarily connected to an existing aircraft power supply for
battery recharging. They shall be secured and viewable during
critical phase of flight. At no time shall it affect performance of
aircraft systems, equipment or the ability to operate flight
controls or it's movement.
Software Applications Type A Paper replacement applications primarily intended for use
during flight planning on the ground or during non-critical
phases of flight. This includes pre-composed, fixed
presentations of data currently presented in paper format.
Software Applications Type B Paper replacement applications that provide aeronautical
information primarily intended for use during flight planning
and all phases of flight. They can manipulate data and
presentation for operationally required (and other paper
reference) materials and are used to display pre-composed or
interactive information such as navigation or approach charts.
Software Applications Type C Approved “non EFB” software applications found in navigation,
and surveillance that require design, production, and installation
approval.
POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES

14.5.5 Redundancy

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Two functional and updated EFBs are necessary to ensure proper redundancy for less paper
operation. For Boeing aircraft equipped with installed EFBs, the portable EFB (iPad) is considered as
an additional tool that complements and increases redundancy on board the aircraft during line
operations.

14.5.6 Battery

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Portable EFB battery is an internal rechargeable lithium-ion polymer.

Battery must be at least 70% prior to the first flight of the day.

When the iPad battery is fully charged, the battery will be good for 8 to 10 hours of continuous
use.

There are several ways to enhance the battery usage during operations, these include:

Turning off the Cellular/3G/Bluetooth/Wi-Fi connectivity;
Closing unused applications running in the background;
Adjusting the device brightness to a lower setting (if appropriate);
During cruise flight, one unit shall stay in standby mode to allow battery power
conservation and to be used as a backup if one primary portable EFB failed.
Close Running Applications: Double click the home button to show the screen with running
applications, each application icon will have a sample page above it, Swipe this sample page
upwards, the sample page will fly away and the application item will disappear.

NOTE If the battery is very low on power, it might need to be charged for up to 10 minutes
before you can use it (the screen might go black for about 1-2 minutes).
NOTE If there is a suspicion of a battery problem, contact ( ipadsupport@EGYPTAIR.com ).
14.5.7 Battery Charging

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
The iPad must be charged via the approved charger (and cable) handed to the crew by EGYPTAIR.

The crew must ensure that both the charger and the cable are in a good condition. Charging
during critical phases of flight is prohibited.

The crew should not charge the device when it is hot or in an extreme hot environment.

The device should be unplugged when the battery reaches 100%.

14.5.11 Airport Moving Map and Own-Ship Position

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
During taxi, primary means of navigation should be with reference to the published Jeppesen
airport diagram chart (10-9) and the crew shall use direct visual observation out of the flight deck
windows. However, Airport Moving Map and Own-Ship position are considered to be an aid to
enhance crew positional and situational awareness while planning taxi routes and taxiing, this
system is not intended to replace normal taxi methods including the use of direct visual
observation of the taxi-ways, runways, airport signs and markings and other airport traffic.

The Own-Ship position must not be displayed or used in any application while in flight and is
limited only for use on ground at speeds of less than 80 knots.

14.5.12 Airplane Mode

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Prior to pushback or engine start, the iPad must be on Airplane Mode.

14.5.13.6 EFB Emergency Procedures
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
14.5.13.6.1 Overheat Prevention
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Prevention is the first and foremost concern with regards to the use of EFBs. Portable Equipment
Devices (PEDs) require adequate ventilation and cooling. Do not leave an EFB in direct sunlight or
stuffed between books or binders. Prior to turning it on, check the EFB for any obvious damage.
Avoid spilling any liquids on the EFB which may cause damage or a short circuit. Do not attempt to
use an EFB that appears damp due to condensation, remove it from the wet environment and
ensure that it is completely dry prior to applying power. In the event that the EFB or cord feels
overly warm to the touch, unplug it, and use the backup EFB until you have landed.
If you suspect that the unit is hotter than normal or producing any fumes , the unit must be
shut off and not restarted until the cause has been fully investigated. Normally, if the unit reaches
a certain temperature it will automatically shut down and give you an advisory message that the
unit should cool down before you use it. In which case the unit should be removed from any direct
contact with the sun, and placed in a cool, shaded area.
POLICIES AND GENERAL STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES

14-5-13
ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
14.5.13.6.2 Lithium Battery Fire

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
It is imperative to remove an EFB or any other PED from the flight deck as soon as overheating of
the device is detected.

If fire is confirmed the following procedures are recommended to extinguish the fire and cool the
remaining cells:

Extinguish the Fire: Use a Water extinguisher, if not available use Halon 1211 extinguisher
followed by available water source.

Cool the Remaining Cells after Extinguishing the Fire: Douse the device continuously with
stream of water or any other non-alcoholic liquid to cool the device and prevent additional battery
cells from reaching thermal runaway.

WARNING Do not cover or use ice to cool the device. Ice or other materials insulate the device,
increasing the likelihood that additional battery cells will reach thermal runaway.
Once the fire appears to have been extinguished, attempt to move the device to an
area without flammable material, such as the galley oven (courier area oven). The
device must not be moved if it is still on fire, is smoking or if it is too hot to be moved
safely.

Installations Instructions:

Hold the device with one hand. The leading edge of the device should be slightly aft of the
chart spring clip and in line with the top edge of the window shroud;
Lower the device onto the window shroud and rotate it slightly forward toward the chart
spring clip;
Keep lowering until the bottom of the inboard edge of the device snaps into place in the
gap between the window shroud and the sidewall;
Lift the chart spring clip and push the unit forward until the raised tab on the device is
captured by the chart spring clip;
Release the chart spring clip. The installation is complete.
Removal Instructions:

Lift the chart spring clip and pull inward on the lower lip of the device;
Slide the device aft until fully clear of the chart spring clip;
Lower the clip. Pull inward on the tab in the center of the device to clear the bottom of the
window shroud;
Lift upward until the device pops off the window shroud;

14.6 TASK SHARING

Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24
In order to optimize Flight Deck workload and enhance the overall safety of the flight during
normal, non-normal and emergency procedures, well defined tasks and areas of responsibilities
are allocated for each Crew Member.

Flight Deck Crew Members shall crosscheck and confirm critical actions during normal, abnormal
and emergency situations, to include:

Aircraft configuration changes (landing gear, flaps, speed brakes);
Altimeter bug and airspeed bug settings, as applicable;
Altimeter subscale settings;
Altitude (window) selections;
Transfer of control of the aircraft;
Changes to the Automated Flight System, Flight Management System and radio navigation
aids during the departure and or approach phases of flight;
Weight and balance calculations and associated FMS/EFB entries;
Performance calculations or inputs, including FMS/EFB entries.
The task sharing is divided into two areas:

Task Sharing Normal Procedures;
Task Sharing Non-Normal Procedures.
NOTE Flight Deck Crew must ensure appropriate aircraft response to inputs by cross-
checking mode control panel status, observing the results of any mode changes, and
supervising the resulting guidance and aircraft response. In addition, they shall use the
level of automation appropriate for the task, to include manual flight when aircraft
response is not appropriate or adequate.
NOTE For Cabin Crew duties during situations that require coordination, refer to OM Part F.
14.6.1 Task Sharing Normal Procedures

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
Flight Deck Crew duties are designed in accordance with an area of responsibility concept; an area
of responsibility is allocated for each Crew Member to exercise his defined tasks during normal
and non-normal operation.

The task sharing specifically defines the timely required action of each Crew Member, within his
area of responsibility, during normal, non-normal and emergency procedures. As a general rule,
EGYPTAIR crew shall perform their duties as follows.

14.6.1.1 On-ground

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
The SIC is responsible for conducting pre-flight/transit walk around and Flight Deck safety
preparation;

Each Crew Member is assigned an area where he initiates actions for the required in-flight
normal and non-normal procedures, as specified in the table below;
The SIC in-flight duties, as PF shall commence when the aircraft is lined up on the runway
centerline and the PlC has advanced the throttles to set take-off thrust;
SIC PF duties shall be terminated at the end of landing roll when the engines are out of
reverse and the aircraft speed is below 60 kts;
It is the responsibility of the PlC to take over control any time he feels that the safety of the
flight is in question, the PlC shall call aloud ( I HAVE CONTROLS ) and the task sharing shall
immediately revert to PlC/SIC.

14.6.3 Prepared Emergencies

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Prepared emergencies mean that there is "Adequate Time" available for the Flight Deck Crew
before landing, therefore Flight Deck Crew shall:

Carry out the appropriate non-normal checklist;
Gather required information (ATIS, available ground assistance after landing, etc.);
Review alternatives;
Decide next course of action;
Carry out approach preparations and approach briefing;
Brief Cabin Crew about NITES.
In order to keep passengers calm, PA announcement shall be made by the PIC, indicating that the
situation is under complete control.

14.6.4 Unprepared Emergencies

Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21
During unprepared emergencies there is "No Time" available for the crew;
Unprepared emergency is an extremely time critical maneuver that requires great precision
from the crew in the execution of their tasks;
Standard calls between Flight Deck Crew and Cabin Crew during unprepared emergencies
are extremely crucial and contains specific meanings;
The PIC call ( ATTENTION CREW AT STATIONS ) must be announced over the PA, as soon
as the aircraft comes to a complete stop, this call indicates that:
The Flight Deck Crew Members are still alive and have complete control of the situation;
The Cabin Crew Members are to expect further instructions from the Flight Deck Crew.

14.6.5.1 Rejected Take-off

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
Rejected take-off is the responsibility of the PIC. In other words, if the SIC is the PF, the task
sharing and areas of responsibility shall automatically change to PlC/SIC, when a rejected take-off
is initiated.

Rejected Take-off Philosophy

The decision to reject the take-off must be made by the PlC prior to V 1 speed.
NOTE V 1 speed is not a decision speed; it is the maximum speed at which the PIC must
take the first action, (e.g. apply brakes, reduce thrust, deploy speed brakes etc.),
to stop the aeroplane within the accelerate stop distance.
In order to stop the aircraft on the available runway length, the rejected take-off (RTO)
maneuver shall be initiated immediately and without delay;
According to the type specific OM Part B, the low speed phase of take-off is up to 80 kts for
Boeing aircraft and up to 100 kts for Airbus aircraft. After passing the applicable speed, the
aircraft is at the high speed phase of take-off.
NOTE For conditions to reject the take-off during low speed and high speed phases, refer to
the type specific OM Part B.
Rejected Take-off

If a rejected take-off maneuver is to be initiated, the Commander shall loudly call (STOP)
and simultaneously apply the rejected take-off procedures contained in the type specific
OM Part B;
When the A/C comes to a complete stop, the Commander shall announce on the PA
( ATTENTION CREW AT STATIONS) ;
If evacuation is NOT required, the Commander shall announce on the PA (CABIN CREW
AND PASSENGERS KEEP YOUR SEATS).
14.6.5.2 Evacuation

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Evacuation decision is very critical and may end up with a number of injuries; therefore, every
effort must be made to carefully assess the situation before taking the evacuation decision;
Before taking the decision to evacuate, and in case of engine, APU or cargo fire, the fire drill
and checklist must be completed;
Positive confirmation should be obtained from the ground fire fighting personnel or the
tower that the fire is still persisting, if available;
Task sharing and timely application of the evacuation drill, without unnecessary rush, shall
ensure minimum passenger and crew casualties.
When the evacuation decision is made, following procedures shall be applied:

14.6.5.8 Windshear

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
Windshear can simply be defined as a sudden change of wind speed and or direction over a
short period of time, at low altitude;
The early recognition of Windshear is very essential for the application of the required
procedures or maneuver;
If Windshear is recognized before V 1 , the take-off must be rejected;
If Windshear is recognized after V 1 , perform the type specific Windshear Escape Maneuver;
The call ( WINDSHEAR GO ), shall be announced by the PF, and acknowledged by the PM;
NOTE The call ( WINDSHEAR GO ) means: Do not change landing gear or flaps
configuration, until Windshear is no longer a factor.
The following parameters are an early indication of Windshear when flying below 1.000 ft
AGL:
15 kts indicated airspeed;
500 fpm vertical speed;
5 degrees pitch attitude;
1 dot displacement from the glide slope;
Unusual thrust lever deviations or changes for a significant period of time.
When the above parameters are exceeded, Windshear Escape Maneuver must be initiated.
For Windshear Escape Maneuver, refer to the type specific OM Part B.

14.6.5.12 Rapid Deplaning

Issue: 5-Revision: 2 - 15 JUL 22
Introduction:

A rapid deplaning is when passengers and / or crew rapidly exit the aircraft via the boarding
doors and via the jet bridge, stairs or Slides as a precautionary measure;
A rapid deplaning may be initiated by the pilots or, in their absence, the Purser/SCC;
If no bridges or stairs are attached, Slides shall be used.
Rapid deplaning can be initiated, and not limited to the following examples:

Fuel Spills leads to Fire;
Smoke in the Cabin;
Engine Fire observed by ground staff;
Ground equipment or Cart Fire;
Any other situation poses a potential hazard;
Bomb threat (target not found).

14.7 STANDARD CALLOUTS

Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20
14.7.1 General

* Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24
Standard callouts are used to convey vital information with minimum number of words that
have an exact meaning to all Crew Member. Standard callouts identify conditions, actions,
instrument settings, switch positions, visual sightings or other operational items specified by
procedures;
Standardization of crew communication is essential to increase the efficiency of crew
coordination and to increase crew situational awareness, during times of high workload;
Proper adherence to standard callouts will stimulate more meaningful and standardized crew
communication during the critical phases of flight;
The concerned Crew Member shall accomplish the appropriate callouts based on instrument
indications or observations i.e. FMA changes, pitch, bank deviations. The other Crew
Member(s) shall verify the condition from their instruments or observations according to the
type specified in the OM Part A e.g. FMA changes, thrust, pitch or bank deviation, etc. and
acknowledge it;
If the concerned Crew Member does not make the required callout, the other Crew
Member(s) should make it and should receive acknowledgement.
CAUTION A challenged Crew Member must respond (by corrective action and verbally, to the
other Crew Member's verbal challenges. If the Call-outs were not answered properly
(by corrective action and verbally) after being challenged "twice", subtle incapacity of
the Crew Member shall be suspected and the other Crew Member will assume control
of the aeroplane by announcing (I HAVE CONTROLS) and initiate the appropriate
corrective action. i.e; After the second call from the PM if the PF continuous an
unstabilized approach the PM shall assume control of the aeroplane by announcing (I
HAVE CONTROLS) and initiate a (GO-AROUND).

the push back phase until engine shutdown.

B1 Organization and Responsibilities
Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24

Advice Note

The supplementary CARGO OPS sections include the major differences which reflect the
procedures on cargo aircraft.

All concerned Flight Deck Crew Members dealing with these sections shall read them in
conjunction with the Main OM Part A for chapters and items not included hereafter.

A number of supernumeraries (see Chapter Carriage of Supernumeraries ) who may be required
for the operation of the flight may occupy the seats provided in the courier area.

Minor differences such as a wording (which has no impact on procedures) has not been included
in the CARGO OPS sections but are still referenced in the main OM Part A manual.

While reviewing the manual by a cargo operations employee the following wordings are an
indication of minor differences:

(Purser/SCC/Cabin Crew) replaced by Senior Supernumeraries (SS);
Passengers replaced by Supernumeraries;
Cabin replaced by Courier Area.
Terms and Definitions

Courier Area An area of an aeroplane designated for accommodating
supernumeraries' seats and needs, formed between the flight
compartment and the main deck cargo compartment.
It is separated from the MDCC by a 9G net and a smoke curtain.
Crushable Loads To protect the safety barrier net from damage and work as a
safety zone in the position adjacent to the safety barrier net.
Crushable cargo must meet the following requirements:
No single large rigid pieces of cargo;
The single loads shall have no sharp edges which could
cut the safety barrier net;
Single pieces of cargo shall be large enough to avoid
penetration of safety barrier net meshes. Minimum
section: approximately 0,50 m x 0,30 m.
Flight Deck Crew Member A licensed Crew Member charged with duties essential to the
operation of an aircraft during flight time (e.g. Commander,
First Officer).
APPENDIX CARGO
B1 Organization and Responsibilities
OM A
B1-2

ISSUE: 6
15 OCT 24

Main Deck Cargo
Compartment
Supernumerary
Senior Supernumeraries
The upper deck area of an all cargo A/C, designated for loading
most of the cargo, equipped with smoke detectors and cargo
loading systems and restraining devices, (a 9G net to prevent
the cargo from shifting, obscuring emergency exits and/or
interfering with A/C features concerning the safe conduct of the
flight) also equipped with a smoke curtain to prevent smoke
from entering the courier area and/or the flight deck.
A supernumerary is a person in addition to the Flight Deck Crew
that is not a Cabin Crew Member, but is on board either a cargo
or passenger aircraft during commercial or non-commercial
operations, and is not classified as a passenger by the operator
or the Authority.
Such person is typically any of the following:
An individual assigned to the flight by the operator as
necessary for the safety of operations and has certain
(operator-required) knowledge and abilities gained
through selection and mandatory training (e.g.
loadmaster, animal handler, dangerous goods handler,
cargo handler, security guard);
An inspector, auditor or observer authorized by the
operator and the State, to be on board the aircraft in the
performance of his duties (e.g. CAA flight operations
inspector, IOSA auditor, LOSA observer);
Assigned to a passenger flight by the operator to
conduct certain customer service activities (e.g. serving
beverages, conducting customer relations, selling tickets)
in the cabin; not designated to perform any safety duties;
Any other individual that has a relationship with the
operator, is not classified as a passenger by the Authority
and authorized by the operator and the State to be on
board the aircraft (e.g. courier, contract coordinator,
individual with operator required knowledge and abilities
traveling to/ from a duty assignment, company employee
or dependent in the supernumerary compartment of a
cargo aircraft). They shall be briefed, by the Commander,
not to impede Cabin crew/ Flight Deck Crew Members in
the performance of their duties.
An EGYPTAIR employee who is assigned to a flight operated by
a cargo A/C and is necessary for the operation of the flight.
He has certain operations requirements, restrictions and
knowledge according to EGYPTAIR standards to undertake tasks
in the courier area.
A cabin crew member may be assigned as a senior
supernumerary on board a cargo aircraft as he is qualified to
perform duties related to the safety of flight during operations.

**B1.8.1 Senior Supernumerary

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
An EGYPTAIR employee who is assigned to a flight operated by cargo A/C and he has certain
operations requirements, restrictions and knowledge according to EGYPTAIR standards to
undertake tasks in the courier area.

Shall introduce himself to others on board as a Senior Supernumerary.

Senior Supernumerary on aero planes fulfill important functions:

They carry out under the overall authority and responsibility of the Commander, courier area
safety normal/abnormal and emergency procedures
Form the link between the Flight Crew and the supernumeraries;
Inform the Flight Crew of all irregularities and malfunctions and, at the prescribed times,
report either courier area secure or not.
B1.8.2 Prior to Flight
Issue: 5-Revision: 0 - 1 MAR 21

They shall conduct the following by delegation from the PIC:

Supervise courier area preparation before take-off;

**B4.3.1 Chain of Command

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
The Chain of Command will be in the following order:

Commander;
Safety Pilot, (if carried);
F/O;
Third Pilot, (if carried);
SS.
NOTE Commanders (USV) have priority over F/Os, while Safety Pilots have priority over
Commanders in (IOE).
NOTE In case of augmented crew of a Commander and two First Officers, the functioning
First Officer will take the responsibility for the flight and acts as PF; the other First
Officer will take the left hand seat and the acts as PM.

main deck.

SECTION (3)

THE AFT SECTION: shows the weights, cumulative limits and index units for 09 pallets in the main
deck, 12 containers and the bulk hold in the lower deck.

SECTION (4)

The index units table according to weights and positions.

SECTION (5)

THE INDEX AND WEIGHTS CALCULATIONS TABLE: to calculate AZFW, ATOW, ALW, MAC ZFW,
MAC TOW AND MAC LW.

**B8.2.1.3 Fuelling / Defuelling with Supernumeraries on Board or Embarking /
Disembarking

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
Fuelling/defuelling with supernumeraries on board is permitted and in exceptional cases
supernumeraries may board the aeroplane during the fuelling/defuelling process provided the
following preventive measures are adhered to:

The aerodrome Operator/Authority shall be notified and when required by the aerodrome
Operator/Authority the fire brigade will be positioned at the aircraft;
One Flight Deck Crew Member remains on the Flight Deck;
Stairs and/or air jetties docked at the aircraft;
Doors attended by senior supernumeraries;
Evacuation paths to useable emergency exits clear of obstacles (see OM Part B Type Specific
Parts);
Supernumeraries have to be advised to open their seat belts and remain seated;
Senior supernumeraries shall be informed about the start and end of the fuelling/defuelling
procedure (through interphone);
Courier area and MDCC maximum lighting must be switched ON;
If fuel vapors in the courier area and/ or MDCC or other dangerous situation are observed,
Flight Deck Crew and fuelling staff must be informed immediately and the fuelling/defuelling
process has to be interrupted;
Fuelling/defuelling activities are restricted to one side of the aircraft;
Two way communications shall be maintained by the aircraft.s intercom system between the
flight deck and the ground crew supervising the fuelling/defuelling process of the aircraft;

SS must be on board to monitor supernumeraries' safety and execute courier area evacuation
if required.
With respect to emergency exits, following conditions have to be adhered to:

In any case - as far as Crew Members available - all doors have to be occupied in order to:

Be able to evacuate through assigned doors;
Block doors which cannot be used for an evacuation;
To secure open doors when loading vehicles are retracted;
Loosed doors remain Disarmed. (They have to be set into ARMED before opening, if an
evacuation becomes necessary).
As only one passenger stair/air jetty is used, fuelling/defuelling with

supernumeraries is allowed under following conditions:

The fire brigade or airport firefighting equipment is ready for action at the aeroplane. If in
exceptional cases the fire brigade cannot be positioned at the aircraft the emergency exits and
escape slides must not be obstructed by catering and/ or loading activities.

Fuelling/defuelling activities are restricted to one side of the aircraft and are no obstacle for the
evacuation slides.

If in the extreme case no passenger stair/air jetty is available:

The fuelling/defuelling activities are restricted to one side of the aircraft. Simultaneous catering or
loading is not permitted in order to allow the deployment of all escape slides clear of obstacles
during the fuelling/defuelling process.

NOTE When an aeroplane is re-fuelled via an over wing filler cap by means of an
unpressurised fuelling system and when this filler cap is located closer than 10 m to the
nearest exit door, then fuelling/defuelling with supernumeraries aboard shall not be
permitted.
NOTE In the event of an emergency (e.g. APU fire), during fuelling/defuelling, the operation
must be stopped and an immediate disembarkation initiated. The Flight Deck Crew will
decide whether this should be an expeditious (normal) disembarkation or an
(emergency evacuation).

B8.2.2.7 Loading and Securing of Items in the Aeroplane
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

B8.2.2.7.1 Loading
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

General
All baggage, cargo, mail to be loaded should be positioned on the ramp in sufficient time in
order to ensure an on-time departure and to reduce pressure upon staff detrimental to
safety;
The load must be protected against the elements and all sources of contamination;
All loading equipment and material shall be handled carefully to avoid damage to the aero-
plane or the load;
Only the appropriate compartments shall be used for loading;
Loading in toilets, courier area, etc. is prohibited;
All aeroplane specific limitations and instructions (e.g. for loading unit load devices - ULD’s)
shall be observed (OM Part B);
The mass of cargo should not exceed the structural loading limits of the floor or seats;
In compartments with pallet positions no load shall be stowed on the floor beside the pal-
lets;
APPENDIX CARGO

B8-18

ISSUE: 6

Uncontrolled when printed or copied
The number/type of restraint devices and their attachment points should be capable of
restraining the cargo in accordance with applicable certification specifications refer to A/C
type OM Part B;
Special handling instructions (e.g. "This Side Up") shall be observed for sensitive shipments
which must be loaded carefully to prevent damage by other items;
Heavy and solidly packed pieces must be loaded at the bottom of the ULD;
The location of the cargo should be such that, in the event of an emergency evacuation, it
will not hinder egress nor impair the crew.s view;
Positions directly behind the safety barrier net may only be occupied by ULDs containing
crushable loads, this position has to be loaded with a ULD loaded to at least 80% of
maximum volume with crushable cargo. (Refer to terms and definitions for crushable loads).
The ground handling personnel shall inspect and ensure the availability, accessibility and
serviceability of the restraint systems within the lower and main deck cargo compartments
including the 9G barrier net and smoke curtain before, during and after the loading process.
Unserviceable locks shall be reported to maintenance for rectification or to be logged in the A/C
technical log book while observing any load limitations concerning this matter according to the
OM Part B weight and balance manual and its supplement if any.

Cargo shall be excluded from carriage if:

It is not properly packed;
It may damage or contaminate the aeroplane or other load;
Special handling instructions/equipment can not be observed/supplied.
NOTE Any damage to the aeroplane skin or structure, however slight, which occurs or is
noticed during loading/ unloading, must be reported immediately.
NOTE Special loading/unloading procedures have been developed and published in each
(OM Part B) which safeguard the aeroplane.s ground stability and prevent its tipping.
In principle, loading should start in the forward compartments and continue in the aft
ones, whilst offloading should start in the aft compartments and continue in the
forward ones.
B8.2.2.7.2 Unloading
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

For unloading the same safety-relevant principles are valid as for loading;
Personnel and equipment should be available at the parking position upon arrival of the
aero-plane. Mail shall be unloaded before other cargo;
After completion of unloading the cargo, compartments shall be carefully checked by a
designated staff member for damages, spilled liquids, and contamination;
In case of absence of EGYPTAIR station representative at the airport e.g.(after diversion)
make sure that the lower deck cargo compartments unloading is completed.

B8.2.2.7.3 Securing of Load in the Courier Area
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

Each item carried in the courier area must be stowed in a location that is capable of
restraining it;
Mass limitations placard on or adjacent to stowage must not be exceeded;
Under seat stowage must not be used, unless forward and sideways movements can be
prevented;
Items must not be stowed in toilets or against bulkheads that are incapable of restraining
articles against movement forwards, sideways or upwards unless the bulkheads carry a
placard specifying the greatest mass that may be placed there;
Items placed in lockers must not prevent doors from being closed securely;
Items must not be placed where it can impede access to emergency equipment and/ or
emergency exits;
The location of crew and supernumeraries luggage should be such that, in the event of an
emergency evacuation, it will not hinder egress nor impair the crew’s view;
Items carried in courier area (e.g., each item of galley equipment, each serving cart not in
use, any medical or other apparatus providing in-flight medical aid) shall be secured in such
a way as not to become a hazard by shifting under the appropriate load factors
corresponding to the ultimate inertia forces specified in the emergency landing condition of
type certification;
Take-off and landing are not permitted unless each serving cart is secured in its stowed
position.

B8.2.2.8.4 Live Animals
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

General

Carriage of live animals in the courier area is prohibited due to considerations of safety.

Carriage in cargo compartments may require pressurization, ventilation, heating, and lighting.
Particulars are, therefore, specified in each aeroplane.s (OM Part B). The following general
guidelines have been developed.

Cargo Compartments

The carriage of live animals in cargo compartments shall take the specific needs of the animals into
account.

The basic environmental requirements shall be ascertained from all sources available.

The temperature range and oxygen requirements must be matched by the heating and ventilation
capability of the cargo compartment provided.

Feeding requirements must be met; e.g., for carriage of birds on long haul flights the cargo
compartment lights shall be left switched ON to enable the birds to feed during flight.

Stowage and loading of animals shall follow the principles outlined in Chapter 8.2.2.8.6 Wet
Cargo and the following additional guidelines shall be taken into account:

Containers shall be stowed in such a manner as to guarantee sufficient air circulation;
Containers shall be accessible, without needing to be offloaded when care of the animals is
required at transit stations;
In the event of excessive delays, special care according to shippers. instructions shall be
taken of the animal(s);
Containers shall normally not be loaded directly in front of or below air ventilation outlets
or internal lighting, the ventilation apertures must not be blocked by other loads,
compartment or ULD walls;
Animals which are natural enemies shall not be loaded in close proximity of one another;
If mature male and female animals are loaded in the same hold or compartment, they
should be stowed as apart as possible segregated by other load, if possible;
On arrival at transit stops, it is advisable to open the compartment door(s) to check the
condition of the animal(s) and ventilate the compartment, in extreme weather conditions
the climatically conditions inside the compartment may be better than that outside. In such
case it is advisable to keep the doors closed and use ground equipment (air-conditioning)
to maintain the compartment temperature and humidity;
In general, live animals shall not be loaded in close proximity to any other load which might
have a negative effect on their wellbeing or health, see Chapter 9 Dangerous Goods and
Weapons for more details;
The handling staff shall, by Special Loads Notification, inform the Commander before
departure of all live animals, their requirements and their location; the Commander will brief
the crew on all animals carried, and the handling staff will inform all down line stations by
appropriate messages.
NOTE All devices used in carriage of live animals shall be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected
after unloading.

B8.2.2.8.9 Time and Temperature Sensitive Healthcare
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

Time and Temperature Sensitive Healthcare Products are those whose condition or suitability may
deteriorate if exposed to undue changes in temperature or humidity, or delay in carriage. They
shall only be accepted for carriage when it is reasonably certain that they will reach destination in
good condition.

The handling staff shall, by Special Loads Notification, inform the Commander before departure of
all Time and Temperature Sensitive Healthcare Products carried and their location. All down line
stations shall be informed by appropriate messages.

Cargo Compartment

The carriage of Time and Temperature Sensitive Healthcare Products in cargo compartments, shall
take into account their specific needs.

Temperature range must be matched by the heating and ventilation capability of the cargo
compartment provided.

Stowage and loading of Time and Temperature Sensitive Healthcare Products shall follow the
guidelines:

ULDs shall be stowed in such a manner as to guarantee sufficient air circulation;
ULDs shall be accessible without the need to be offloaded;
In the event of excessive delays, special care, according to shipper's instructions, shall be
provided;
Normally, ULDs shall not be loaded directly in front of/below air ventilation outlets or
internal lighting;
In general, Time and Temperature Sensitive Healthcare Products shall not be loaded in close
proximity to any other load that might have a negative effect on their well-being or health.

B8.2.2.13 Operation of Aeroplane Doors
Issue: 6-Revision: 0 - 30 DEC 22

Aeroplane type specific normal, abnormal and emergency procedures, concerning the operation of
the cabin doors and the MDCD, are specified in the respective (OM Part B). The following general
guidelines shall be observed:

Selection of Door Mode before Take-off

The PIC shall announce the following order via the courier communication system or verbally -to
initiate the door mode selection

(ALL DOORS IN ARM POSITION, DOUBLE CHECK AND REPORT).
The SS shall act as an operator and checker, go to R.H.S door first to arm the slide, then go to L.H.S
door to arm the slide and double check both exits before reporting.

The SS shall report to the PIC ( ALL SLIDES ARMED ), If the door mode selection of any door is not
working properly, SS shall inform the PIC immediately;

Selection of Door Mode after Landing

The PIC will switch the FASTEN SEAT BELT signs OFF as soon as the aircraft reaches the parking
position and chocks are in place, The PIC announces via the intercommunication system or verbally
the following order:

(ALL DOORS IN DISARM POSITION, DOUBLE CHECK AND REPORT).
The SS shall act as an operator and checker, go to R.H.S door first to disarm the slide, then go to
L.H.S door to disarm the slide and double check both exits before reporting.

The SS shall report to the PIC ( ALL SLIDES DISARMED ) to confirm slides disarming before door
opening.

NOTE Due to the fact that the all cargo A/C is operated with only one SS, the following must
be observed:
Operator : SS is responsible to select the door mode for one exit;
Checker : SS is responsible for the opposite exit;
Double Check : SS is responsible to select the door mode for two exits by himself and
check before reporting to the PIC.
Preventive Measures While Opening Cabin Doors

The SS shall open the A/C doors after receiving permission from the PIC, and clearance from
ground staff.

Main Deck Cargo Door (MDCD)

Open/close the MDCD after receiving permission from the PIC; normally MDCD operation is
achieved via the MDCD control panel, , and to be carried out by loading staff.

The maximum wind for main deck cargo door operation is 40 kts;
The main deck cargo door must be closed before the wind speed exceeds 60 kts.
Opening/ closing of MDCD shall be made after coordination with the loading staff concerning the
loading equipments to prevent damage caused to the aeroplane.

NOTE When, in exceptional cases, one engine must be kept running (e.g., when no APU
available) doors may only be opened at the aeroplanes side where all engines has
been shut down.
The Commander and the ground staff shall, beforehand, have agreed on the course of
action to be followed, see also the Chapter 8.2.2.12 Positioning of Ground
Equipment.
All aeroplane entry and service, doors shall normally be opened and closed by members of the
operating crew only , i.e., from inside, or, in exceptional cases, by trained handling staff from
outside.

When opening such a door from outside, the respective staff member shall ascertain by knocking
at the door that nobody is standing in the danger area on the inside.

Whenever steps/ jet ways (Chapter 8.2.2.12 Positioning of Ground Equipment ) or catering
trucks are used the design of which does not permit opening or closing the doors when the
equipment is in position, the respective doors shall only be opened immediately prior to the
positioning of the equipment and closed immediately after the equipment has been removed,
cargo and lower compartment doors shall normally be operated by the handling staff.

Manually Operated Doors

Their operation does not require special training, but shall have been demonstrated to the staff

Electrically, Pneumatically or Hydraulically Operated Doors

No person shall operate such doors without having received prior theoretical/practical training by
properly qualified staff, for such training, the company via the respective (OM Part B) shall provide
detailed descriptions of such doors and their operation.

NOTE For the operation of 1L/1R doors and lower deck cargo doors in strong winds refer to
the (OM Part B) FCOM, also refer to FCOM supplements if any and/ or (OM Part F Part
II) for operation of the Main Deck Cargo Door (MDCD) and/ or (OM Part B).
They specify maximum permissible wind speeds and other particulars to be observed.
If difficulties occur when attempting to close doors in strong winds, the aero-plane
shall be moved in order to position the doors concerned on the down-wind side.

**B8.3.13.1 Flight Deck Door Principles

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
Before each flight, the Commander shall brief the SS about the flight deck door emergency access
code.

The Commander should ensure that the code is not written down on any paperwork by the SS
to guard against the code falling into the wrong hands;
The Emergency Access Code must only be used if Flight Deck Crew incapacitation is
suspected.
General Rules

Access to the Flight deck should be limited;
Prior leaving the Flight Deck, Crew Members must ensure, through the video surveillance
system, viewing lens or by communicating with the SS through the interphone system, that
the area around the Flight Deck door is clear and that SS are positioned to prevent access to
the flight deck while the door is open for flight deck crew exit or entry;
Prior permitting access to the flight deck, Flight Deck Crew must positively identify the fact
that the area around the Flight Deck door is clear and that the person requesting entry is
authorized to enter the Flight Deck;
SS should be vigilant and observe the surroundings carefully before entering the Flight Deck;

**B8.3.13.2 Carriage of Supernumeraries

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
NOTE Supernumeraries to be carried on board the aircraft in the (courier area)/
supernumeraries compartment must be limited to the maximum allowed number by
that relevant aircraft (to FCOM and its supplements, if any).
The following persons, but no others may be carried on board:
(refer to ECAR 121.583 for more details)
a. A Crew Member;
b. A company employee;
c. A ECAA inspector, who is performing official duties; and
d. A person necessary for:
i. The safety of the flight;
ii. The handling of animals;
iii. The safe handling of hazardous materials;
iv. The security of valuable or confidential cargo;
v. The preservation of fragile or perishable cargo;
vi. The Experiments on, or testing of, cargo containers or cargo handling devices;
vii. The operation of special equipment for loading or unloading cargo; and
viii. The loading or unloading of outside cargo.
e. A person described in paragraph (1)(d) of this section, when travelling to or from his
assignment;
f. A person performing duty as an honor guard accompanying a shipment made by or
under the Authority of the Arab Republic of Egypt;
g. A military courier, military route supervisor, military cargo contract coordinator, or a
Flight Deck Crew Member of another military cargo contract air carrier or commercial
operator, carried by a military cargo contract, if that carriage is specifically authorized by
the appropriate armed forces; and
h. A dependent of an employee of the certificate holder when travelling with the employee
on company business to or from outlying stations not served by adequate regular
passenger flights.
All seats in the courier area of all cargo aircraft are considered emergency exit row
seats.
Those persons as specified above in paragraph (1) shall be in compliance with exit seating
criteria.
The following are extracted from ECAR 121.585; refer to the ECAR for more details.
No person may sit in an exit seat if it is determined that it is likely that person would be
unable to perform one or more of the applicable functions listed below in this paragraph
because:
a. A person lacks sufficient mobility, strength or dexterity in both arms and hand, and both
legs:

Communication between the Flight Crew and supernumeraries:
Maintaining a two way communication between the Flight Deck and the courier area is a
vital tool in maintaining coordination that asses relevant safety issues;
The Senior Supernumeraries shall form the link between the Flight Deck Crew in the
Flight Deck and the supernumeraries in the courier area;
The communication will be established between the Flight Deck Crew in the Flight Deck
and the Senior Supernumeraries either verbally or via the intercommunication system
according to the situation and time of that announcement also via the illumination of
corresponding signs;
In addressing the importance of communication between the Flight Deck and the courier
area, the following shall be observed:
a. A call from the Flight Deck Crew (SS TO COCKPIT) , means that an abnormal or
emergency situation (including Flight Crew incapacitation - Medical situations) has
arisen and the Senior Supernumerary is required to proceed to the Flight Deck
immediately to assist for the in-Flight Crew incapacitation or to receive a briefing
from the PIC in case of an emergency or abnormality, that briefing shall include
(N.I.T.E.S) :
i. N ature of the emergency;
ii. I ntention whether ditching or crash landing;
iii. T ime available until impact/landing;
iv. Any known factors affecting E scape routes;
v. The agreed “brace S ignal”.
The SS will acknowledge the Captain’s briefing by repeating back the full instructions given,
and must ask for clarification on anything not understood.
The SS will then return to the courier area to brief the supernumeraries and prepare the
courier area as follows:
Stowing and securing all loose items and baggage, ensuring that the path to
all emergency exits are clear;
Instructing supernumeraries on the use of safety equipment and bracing
position;
Location of emergency exits, escape routes and what to do when the aircraft
stops.
b. In case a loss of cabin pressure occurred during flight while all occupants are

anymore a call from the Flight Deck Crew

Check outside conditions:

Open door in ARMED configuration to activate the slide;

Command courier evacuation and assist courier;
Follow a safe path on ground away from the aeroplane.

Block the exit and direct the courier to the nearest usable exit;
Assist courier on ground.
