B8.3.15.3 Recognition of an Incapacity
Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24

(Applicable only when no SS carried on board)

In case of a flight crew member leaving his duty station outside the flight deck for a prolonged
time than expected for the function he left the flight deck for (i.e., Physiological needs, Food
preparation, etc.) the remaining crew member shall make a PA announcement asking the other
crew member to return back to the flight deck. If there is no response after 10 minutes the crew
member shall make another announcement (that he will declare an emergency and consider him
incapacitated).

Afterward incapacitation of the other flight deck crew member shall be suspected and the related
procedures shall be carried out.

B8.3.15.4 Actions
Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24

(Applicable only when no SS carried on board)

Actions to be taken when an incapacity is recognized:

Take over control of the aeroplane by announcing ( I HAVE CONTROLS );
Engage autopilot;
Declare emergency;
The incapacitated crew member seat should be moved back to the maximum possible
extent to prevent obstruction of flight controls, switches, levers, etc. (if applicable) by using
pilot seat horizontal adjustment control;
After landing, medical assistance should be arranged for the incapacitated Crew Member;

B8.3.16 Courier Area Safety and Security Requirements
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

B8.3.16.1 General
Issue: 4-Revision: 0 - 20 JAN 20

Legal provisions require all Crew Members not to perform any activities during critical phases of
the flight other than those required for the safe operation of the aeroplane.

This means that the PIC ensures (through SS) that the courier area is secured before engine start,
take-off and before descending through 10.000 feet AGL for approach and landing.

**B8.3.16.2 Courier Area Preparation

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
Emergency Equipment/system check & Forms
The courier area emergency equipment check has to be performed by one of the active Flight
Deck Crew or by delegation from the Commander (the SS shall perform that check.).

The check has to be performed whenever the crew takes over the aircraft at the beginning of a
day's flight or series of flights, the check shall be performed whenever crew change over takes
place or if the A/C is left unattended for any reason (for outside stations, if no company
representative on board) a pre-flight check shall be performed (Flight deck & courier area).

An emergency equipment checklist / discrepancy form shall be provided with the flight documents
while dispatching from base, if there is a night stop the crew shall keep additional forms to
perform the check.

This form shall be attached to the flight documents.

Courier area emergency equipment diagram is provided on board the A/C with a detailed location
of the emergency equipment and number for each, the check has to be performed in accordance
with that diagram; (equipment found at a wrong place has to be stored at the assigned location
and state that situation into the discrepancy form).

MEL “No-Go” deficiencies must be rectified before flight.

Any discrepancy concerning the emergency equipment before the flight shall be reported
immediately to the Flight Deck Crew who in turn will inform maintenance personnel and make an
entry in the A/C technical logbook for corrective action to be taken, any discrepancy during the
flight must be logged by the Flight Deck Crew in the A/C technical logbook.

The check of the flight deck emergency equipment shall be performed according to the Aircraft
Operations Manual (AOM) by the First Officer (F/O) during the pre-flight check.

Service Trolleys
All service trolleys shall have a functioning brakes mechanism otherwise they are not acceptable
on board, braking devices on service carts should be checked prior the first flight of the day, at all
times to prevent injury from unanticipated turbulence, service trolleys shall be stowed inside the
galleys:

During take-off, landing, or any emergency situation;
Prior or during turbulence (according to the turbulence severity).
For safety concerns the trolleys shall not be stowed in the courier area during flight.

Carry-On Baggage
Carry-on baggage must be stowed in a manner to prevent them from forward and side
movements, they may be stowed in the galley stowage (area/floor) if a space is available while
observing load capacity as indicated on the placards and secured using the provided net to
prevent obstruction to the Flight Deck entrance and escape routes, they must not block the way to
reach any emergency equipment.

For A/C equipped with Flight Crew Rest Compartment - FCRC, The flexible use of the upper bunk,
either for crew rest needs or as a stowage compartment, requires the removal of the oxygen bottle
if the upper bunk is used as a stowage compartment to avoid hazardous conditions in case of fire.
If the volume is used as a bunk, the oxygen system must remain installed.

It is not allowed to attach luggage to the 9G net by any means as this may lead to a serious injury
to occupants in the courier area when an abnormal and/or emergency situation arises such as
(rejected take-off or emergency descend).

Observation of the Courier Area
To avoid or detect in time dangerous situations, Flight Deck and courier area have to be
permanently observed on ground and in flight. This includes following general duties and rules:

In case an announcement is made by the PIC at any time of the flight, the announcement
should be acknowledged by the Senior Supernumeraries;
If the announcement is not clear or not understood, the Senior Supernumerary (SS) shall
proceed to the flight deck to verify the announcement conclusion;
For the interest of safety and to break the monotonous nature of the long range operation
especially during night flight, the Senior Supernumerary (SS) is encouraged to pay a visit to
the Flight Deck every 30 minutes;
Plastic bags, magazines and other papers should not lie on the floor;
Lavatories must be checked with respect to development of smoke.
Irregularities During Flight
Events, which may affect the safety of the operation, as well as cases of illness or the use of
emergency equipment, have to be reported immediately to the Flight Deck Crew. This applies also
to unusual perceptions (e.g. noise, odours, and observations).

**B14.3.21 Flight Deck Door

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
Flight deck door must be closed and locked during all phases of flight;
During SS briefing, the Captain shall agree with the SS on a signal for their identification;
Positive identification and forward area check should be established before opening the Flight
deck door (e.g. through the eyehole or identification cameras);
Flight deck door must be closed and locked when any member of the Flight Deck Crew is
outside the flight deck, at least one flight deck crew member and one SS shall be in the Flight
deck.
NOTE For more details, see Chapter Flight Deck Door Principles.
NOTE Door area from either pilot’s seats should be monitored at all times.
If the video surveillance system on both pilot’s seats is U/S, the presence in the flight
deck of an additional crew member/SS during all phases of the flight is mandatory.

**B14.3.29 Leaving Flight Deck during Flight

Issue: 6-Revision: 2 - 15 OCT 24**
Flight Deck Crew Members are only permitted to leave their duty stations in the performance of
duties in connection with the operation or to meet physiological needs.

The Flight Deck Crew Member leaving his duty station must ensure that:

The other flight deck crew member and one SS are in the Flight Deck;
If no supernumeraries are carried on board, the Flight deck door shall be opened, unlocked
and is not obstructed by any means.
The remaining active Flight Deck Crew Member:

Has unobstructed access to the flight controls;
Is aware of the flight situation and fuel status; and
Is alert and ready to take-over controls.
The remaining Flight Deck Crew Member must remain in his assigned duty station with his:

Seat Belt and shoulder harness fastened; and
Headset on.
When the absent Flight Deck Crew Member returns to his duty station, he shall be briefed about
the current flight status.

An active Flight Deck Crew Member who intentionally stays outside the Flight Deck for prolonged
periods of time is committing a serious safety violation.

Flight Deck Crew Members deviating from the above rules shall be subjected to disciplinary action.

CAUTION No person other than the active Flight Deck Crew Members shall occupy designated
pilots seats.

B14.6.1.1 On-ground
Issue: 6-Revision: 1 - 25 MAR 24

(Applicable only when no SS carried on board)

The PIC shall always perform PF duties on ground, conducting pre-flight, Flight Deck and
FMS preparation;
The PIC is also responsible for handling engine fuel valves/switches;
On ground the PIC will call for all checklists;
The SIC is responsible for pre-flight/transit walkaround, courier preparation, security checks,
lavatory and galley serviceability check, courier area securing and door operations;
With the exception of Beacon/Anti-collision light, Taxi light and SEAT BELT sign, the SIC is
responsible for actions in the overhead panel excluding Flight Deck preparation.
